On draft at the icelandic beer festival. Aroma of some coffee and oatmeal. Lacked more character and the body was too light.
Catching up on some old ratings from Untappd -- First rated on 30 May 2011.

Pours a dark brown with a nice foamy off-white head. The aroma is a combination of oats and dark chocolate, which comes off less appealing than it sounds, unfortunately. Otherwise the beer is fantastic. Has a nice mix of sweet malts, oatmeal, chocolate, and even a touch of bitterness in the taste. Goes down smooth and has an excellent full body feel.
Good balance of everything. The smoke is rounded out by the oats and the chocolate. Very enjoyable and expert stout.

Pours dark black-brown with a creamy espresso mocha head that fades to a nice uneven coating that leaves wet legs. Aroma is oatmeal, toasted malts and chocolate with a sense of dry hops. Taste is a bit tangy - oatmeal again, with chocolate roasted malty goodness and some hop/burnt coffee bitterness that lingers. Quite carbonated and active on the palate - crisp for a stout. A classic oatmeal stout, but a bit shallow and perhaps a bit too bitter.

Bottle from Beer Central, Sheffield. Clear, very dark brown. Light brown, thin head. Cocoa. Roasted nuts. Some tinned prune. Taste is ash dry. Smooth, milky palate. Dryness and bitterness on the finish.

Aroma: coffee, alcohol, cough drop, unpleasant esters
Appearance: black, clear, minimal brown head
Taste: medium sweet, medium bitter
Palate: full body, texture thick, average carbonation, bitter finish

Overall: to much alcohol, bitterness to high as for oatmeal stout. Some unpleasant esters in aroma. Rather not a session beer.

22oz - pours deep brown , tan head . Smokey , some vanilla notes , smooth palate , not bad .

Maybe it¬ís just because I just recently had a Sam Smith Oatmeal Stout, but I can care less about what awards this beer has won: it lacks everything a good oatmeal stout should have. I remember my first oatmeal stout: an Ipswich back in 1995; now, that was good. And full disclosure: I¬ím a big Rogue fan. I have a big box from Rogue ready to be opened in my dining room. (Dead Guy - XS Dead Guy especially - both are great beers.) But this beer: the inappropriate hops, the uncreamy bitterness, the overall blandness: this just isn¬ít what you want in an oatmeal stout. 

In an extremely rare act, I have dumped out my glass. I did this because, beckoning me from my fridge, was a beautiful bottle of Speedway Stout. I wanted to (a) clear my palate, and (b) reaffirm my belief in the Stout. I poured a glass... and belief is restored. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

650 ml bottle bought at YATA in Grand Century Place, Mong Kok.
Looks: Clear, deep Cola blackish brown colour with lots of chocolate-like yeast sediments. 

Pours: without yeast, it¬ís half finger head and dark beige foam which last for 30 seconds (the final yeast pour comes with an explosive 3-finger head which lasted for 3 minutes). Very good sticky lacing and small bubbly carbonation.

Aroma: Very fragrant and nicely sweet roasted malt, with light black coffee, rich chocolate, nice vanilla, cream, dark fruits, sugar, caramel and light grass.

Body: Mid to light, with pretty slick and creamy palate.

Taste: close to medium sweet dark roast malt, with distinctive sour notes, then comes with a quick fire combination of strong nuts, fresh, black coffee, rich dark chocolate, burnt toffee, and sharp grassy hops. Then all of a sudden they are wrapped up into a lightning fast very sharp and bitter blitz of sharp liquorice comes with very herbal and salty after taste. Crazy!

Mouth Feel: Initially it feels like a decent, if unspectacular chocolate stout, the sudden bitter attack by roasted oat and hops took me by surprise: nicely bitter and highly astringent, it dominate 2nd half of the taste, overbearing yet likeable. Sourness is sharp and nice throughout. Coffee, chocolate and burnt taste are all there albeit ended abruptly. Some brew!

Hoppiness: light grass nose, sharp liquorices and very herbal grass in taste. Strong bitterness, astringency and saltiness to finish the rollercoaster experience.

After Taste: Fairly dry, smooth, tart and bitter to mouth.	

Comments: This one is full-on roasted oat attack, with its smooth mouth feel and out of this world bitterness almost stole the whole show, but its own nice maltyness and chocolate stout taste still stand up well to the challenge. Tailor make for boisterous sessioning with friends in the evening, a big beer to savor. Cheers!
750ml bottle. Pitch black color. No head. Sweet, chocolate, roast, mild coffee in aroma. Roasted malts, grainy, coffee, minerals in taste. Nice roasted bitter finish. Crisp mouthfeel.

A great recommendation from ratebeer! A great rival to Sam Smith's Oatmeal. Will be recommending this to friends! Beautiful pour and well balanced head with common aromas of oatmeal stouts! Very smooth tasting with subtle hints of oatmeal and chocolate.

Chocolate, coffee, and some dark fruit in the aroma. Flavor is bittersweet, with cocoa and coffee. Roast coffee bitterness in the finish. A fine choice for a cool winter evening.

Another great stout from Rogue. Pours a dark brown with a tan head. Minor lacing, nothing too fantastic. Aroma is cocoa and roasted coffee malts. A little bit of bitterness from hops, but mostly malts. Great stout!

Pours very dark brown with brown head. Aroma is nutty and smoky mocha milk chocolate. Incredibly smooth with some tartness underlying the rich dark malt character. Aroma: notes of chocolate, mocha and oatesTaste:hopiness right off the bat but paired with roasty malts and oat tastes. Pretty bitter finish Appearance: dark body with lace head and good retention

Sample from 650ml. Pours a dark brown/black with a thin, mocha head. Aroma has notes of roasted malts, chocolate, coffee, and. Taste is a balanced bitter with bit roasted malts, dark chocolate, and an espresso bitter on the finish. Medium body and carbonation. Overall super tasty.

A delicious brew that combines a full complex taste while managing to keep the alcohol content in check. All the better to enjoy another.

355 ml bottle, labelled as Brown Bear Beer and brewed for Ezo Beer in Sapporo. No label as such, all information printed straight on the bottle. Pours dark brown, close to black. Small brownish head that fades soon. Aroma is very promising - full of malty roastiness, some sweet dark fruits and chocolate. Taste is not sweet and body a bit lighter than I expected from the aroma. First comes the carbonation together with some sweet fruity notes and coffee. Bottle to glass. Dark black or with a thick khaki head. Nose is all roasted malt and chocolate. Taste is similar. smooth body with an oat body with roasted malt and coffee.
dark coffee colour, huge brown head; aroma of chocolate, roasted malt and coffee and some earthyness; taste is less complex - roastedness, some coffee and earthy notes; dry mouthfeel
The name says it all, it¬ís a dark roasted stout beer with the grainy taste of oat. Nice, but not very special.

22 ounce bottle into signature pint glass, no bottle dating. Pours fairly pitch black color with a 1-2 finger dense tan head with good retention, that reduces to a nice cap that lingers. Spotty soapy lacing clings down the glass. Aromas of big dark chocolate, cocoa, roasted malt, light coffee, light char, oats, toast, caramel, dark bread, floral, and roasted earthiness. Fantastic aromas with great complexity and balance of dark/roasted malt and oat notes; with great strength. Taste of big dark chocolate, cocoa, roasted malt, coffee, toast, caramel, light char, oats, dark bread, floral, and roasted earthiness. Light earthy/roasted bitterness on the finish; with lingering notes of dark chocolate, cocoa, roasted malt, coffee, toast, caramel, light char, oats, dark bread, floral, and roasted earthiness on the finish for a good bit. Damn nice complexity and balance of dark/roasted malt and oat flavors; with great robustness and zero cloying flavors after the finish. Medium carbonation and body; with a very creamy, smooth, and lightly chalky mouthfeel that is nice. Alcohol is very well hidden with minimal warming present after the finish. Overall this is a highly excellent oatmeal stout! All around great complexity, robustness, and balance of dark/roasted malt and oat flavors; and very smooth to drink. A highly enjoyable offering.

Bomber in the basement. Pours shimmering dark with a burnt sienna head. Nose of dark chocolate and light wispy pine. Body is full and smooth. An brief tone of acrid bite appears and then fades. Fast and enjoyable.
Poured deep dark brown with a frothy beige head. Aroma of roast malt and bitter coffee, dark chocolate. Medium body, flavour is a bit weak compared to the aroma, bitter sweet end.

Awesome brewery, philosophy, and many great beers: especially the Rogue Shakespeare Oatmeal Stout. Sorry, I don¬ít get into the descriptive categories. I just care about the taste of a beer and this one tasted great.

It¬ís strange now to see that a beer doesn¬ít list its alcohol by volume on its bottle now, but what¬ís stranger: not only for a stout not to list its alcohol by volume, but the fact that it does list its bitterness units. Stouts almost never list their bitterness... and for this to only list its bitterness and not its alcohol content. Just... strange. Fortunately, nothing else about this beer is strange.


The head on Rogue Shakespeare Oatmeal Stout
The beer is solid black in color with a full, frothy, medium-brown head that rests a centimeter above the edge of the glass. Waves of lacing are left straight down the edge the glass. The aroma is sweet and malty, with only a hint of roasted malts and chocolate. It¬ís very smooth and very easy on the nose. It¬ís super silky in the mouth, full-bodied, with a delicious, sweet hop and malt aroma making its way through the nose as the beer enters the mouth. A sharpness surfaces through the softness of the body, ending in a slightly bitter flavor - and you can¬ít really tell if it¬ís bitterness from the hops or from the roasted grains. I¬ím guessing it¬ís a little of both. 

It¬ís incredibly well-balanced in the middle, with flavor mellow enough to let the smoothness shine unobstructed, but sharp enough for its hay-like, rustic oat deliciousness surface. Well done. Most stouts are either too roasted or too overdone on chocolate. This focuses on neither, and allows you to really enjoy a palatable, yet still rich, stout.
Pours a dark black brown with a thick dark tan head with light lacing. Flavors of chocolate, coffee, and even a slight oatmeal flavor. Easy to drink a vwry good beer from Rougue.
Dark brown pour, thick tan head. No distinct smell. Taste of chocolate and maybe tobacco. Real smooth, little bite. Worth the try

Dark chocolate head. The color is black. The pallet is heavy and n alcohol laden. Full-bodied with a bitter aftertaste.

Pours pure black with off white head. Creamy texture. Taste of chocolate bread malts. Medium carbonation. Nice beer
Poured from 22oz bottle at home. Dark brown/black with tan bubbly head. Roasty aroma. Smooth and creamy oatmeal, earthy and slightly malty taste. Well balanced and a top notch stout overall
This is probably my favorite Rogue beer. Very well balanced and an esy drinker. Not quite world class (despite the awards) in my humble opinion, but very good.

Poured from 22oz bottle to shaker glass. Pours intensely dark brown with a thick, tan head. Great stout smell. Traces of malt and oat with hint of chocolate. Tastes just like it smells, also earthy with small amount of coffee back to it. Finishes great, awesome beer.
Bottle from Cotteridge Wines;  dark black pour with tan head,  big malt aroma, oaty malt taste bread vanilla,a bit of leather earth, delight.
(bottle 25/06-2013) medium lasting brown head, black color, roasted aroma, dry roasted taste.

Not what I would expect from a traditional oatmeal stout, but certainly what I had in mind waiting for a well-crafted Ameriacn OS. This is much more dry and bitter than for example the english OS, but it is also perfect. Sweet grapes juice and black currants on the chocolate nose, and a lovely dark, bitter chocolate on the flavour. Deliciously balanced with the hops for a bitter finish. Medium bodied... Ag! This is perfect.

On tap (nitro) @ Chuck¬ís 85th. Pours opaque inky black with thick super creamy nitro head. Aroma is nitro heavy, but dry charred malt stands out. Incredibly creamy, rich mouthfeel. Deeply roasted malt balanced by slight hop bitterness and dark chocolate on the finish. Impressive richness for this low an ABV. Balanced as well. For a non-imperial stout, this is the gold standard.

Pours a brownish black with a beige, coffee head. Tastes of oats, coffee, nuts, fruit, roasted malts. Perfectly smooth on the palette and melts in your mouth. Becomes thicker and tastier as u swish. Worth buying just because of the mouth feel. The taste however could be better. Still a decent beer.

Nitro tap at Dexters.  Opaque brown-black body with a  massive, steady, thick and creamy beige head.  Rich chocolate, some nice hop bitterness too.  Watery nitro body makes it intensely refreshing and sessionable.  Well done, true to style, quite a nice cask feel.  Hopped chocolate milk aftertaste.  Nice.
Bottle. Pours dark brown/black color with medium beige head. Smell of chocolate, coffee. Taste of coffee, roasted malt, hints of sourness. Medium body.

Deep dark brown beer with a creamy beige head that sticks to the glass in a thick film. Nose is rich with hints of chocolate, licorice, and luscious brown sugar. Taste is semi-sweet upfront with flavors of burnt sugar, mocha, and dark molasses which then develops into a medium bitterness with undertones of toasted malt. The roasted flavors and pleasant bitterness linger forever. Absolutely delicious beer and everything you could hope for in a stout.

Draught at Bierhaus. Pours a deep black with a thin tan head and very nice lacing. Aroma is a gorgeous blend of oats, coffee chocolate and hay. Medium boozy and oaty sweetness followed with a light roasted barley bitterness. Dry, sweet, and smooth finish. Absolutely gorgeous stout.

Deep black brown, mocha coffee coloured head, medium lasting. Lovely rich intense nose - coffee, chocolate, roasted notes, soy and oats, really good. Flavour follows the nose, more lush coffee, roast, almost burnt malt, followed by a big hop bite. Slightly lively carbonation, long, long finish - chocolate sweetness, liquorice, offset by heavy hop bitterness which parches the tongue. Really impressive this.
Roasted character (coffee/cocoa), with some sweetness. some bread flavor, too--plus Cascade citrus (not as much in the aroma). Sweetish at first, with a dry, roasty finish.

Split a 22 ounce bomber with Ed at the Bayou. This is a great beer, but I really enjoy the bitter chocolate and coffee finish. There is a strong caramel character in the middle of the taste that detracts from the flavors I enjoy. Overall a solid stout.
Pours dark brown with a dense beige head. Aroma is roasted malt, chocolate, coffee and light liquorish. Flavour is roasted malt, chocolate, light malt acidic, coffee and liquorish.

My first Oatmeal stout, and what a ripper! Do all oatmeal stouts taste this good? Appearance is stout with the added bonus that this beer has some of the most beautiful, intricate lacing I¬íve seen. Beautiful plumage! And the taste! Honestly, I can¬ít pick out the oatmeal, but all the flavours of this beer just seem to get sucked into my tastebuds like there has been a drought or something. Very nice.

On tap at Pete's. A black pour with a frothy, retentive light brown head. Good lacing. Aromas of sugary malt and coffee. Taste is oatmeal, espresso, and a semisweet chocolate finish. A well balanced, albeit bitter stout.
Better than most. Black with tan head. Aroma is smokey snd sweet caramel. Taste is same but malty with chocolate and coffee.

Pours black with a lively, thick, tan head with some lacing after a sip. Syrupy sweet, roasty nose. Creamy and smooth entry with a malty mouthfeel followed by a dark chocolate, roasted nut, somewhat bitter dark roast coffee finish. Where is the vanilla ice cream when I need it?

Draft at Yardhouse in Boca Raton. Poured into an American pint glass. Jet black, opaque with a thick two-finger off-white head. Almost looked like it was on nitro but it wasn¬ít. Aroma of chocolate, coffee and roasted malts. The taste wasn¬ít as complex as I expected but very good overall. The notes of chocolate, roasted malts, slight coffee and bread came through nicely. The mouth was smooth and the after was slightly bitter and dry. Very good job though.

Bouteille 650ml. De couleur noire et opaque. Nez de chocolat noir, de malt r√¥ti, l√©ger de caf√© avec des notes de chocolat au lait (notes lactiques), de fum√©e de bois, de houblon herbeux  ainsi que quelques traces de m√©lasse sucr√©e. Very deep almost black ruby with medium brown head. Lasting & lacing.
Aroma.. roasted malts, coffee, chocolate, cocoa, bit hops, kinda vanilla
Sweet dominates. But definitely not oversweetened.
Standard, but very decent and well balanced brew.

650ml bottle. Pours an opaque black, with a large tan head, which lasts well and leaves very good lacing. Milk chocolate, Irish coffee, port and cream make for an alluring aroma. Herbal and floral hops up front interplay nicely with roasty malt. Smooth milk chocolate and Vienna coffee create a rich, silky body, with the coffee strengthening to a more bitter espresso flavour leading into the finish, where it blends with a mild resurgence of herbal hops. This is a very nicely balanced stout: rich and flavoursome, with just enough hops to stop it from getting bogged down. A thoroughly enjoyable beer.

Pours an opaque very dark brown with an Irish coffee froth colored head. Aromas of chocolate and coffee bean. Mouthfeel is a little thin for the style. Not unappealing, just not complimentary of the flavor. Nothing like a good, creamy, viscous fluid to deliver flavors of chocolate and coffee so nicely. A lot of chocolate flavor is noted with some underlying coffee. Coffee bitterness lingers long after the beer is gone. I¬íd been really excited about trying this one, but I¬ím disappointed.

Color negro opaco, espuma beige. Aroma ligero aunque complejo: caf√©, bizcocho dulce, ligeramente alcoh√≥lico. Su sabor es de un amargor equilibrado y agradable (sobre todo acafetado) que se une a esas notas terrosas propias de la avena. No obstante, es poco persistente en boca tras la degustaci√≥n. Tiene una textura media y est√° bien carbonatada, sin excesos. Es una buena stout, quiz√° se echa de menos algo m√°s de intensidad.

UPDATED: AUG 31, 2015 Nov 2012 - 100ml sample.  Coffee, very rich, v big mouth feel - like expanding foam.  Liked a lot.  (3.9)  
 Nov 2012 - Full bottle.  Slight coffee, big mouthfeel, mild flavour.  Not much to the flavour really.  I like the mouthfeel, but the flavour could be bigger.  (3.8)
Aug 2015 - Cask at GBBF.  Black, small foamy brown head.  Aroma is ash, yeast, smoke.  Body is medium, smooth, low carbonation.  Taste is ash, thin malts, smoke, soft bitterness.  The bottled version is better. (3.6)
bottle. Black with one finger head. Roast malt with light chocolate. Dry and smooth. Solid stout.

Opaque brown-black with a tan head, no lace.  Taste is burnt malt with mild bittering that grows through the palate.  The finish adds cazrbonation and a light oil texture.  Overall, a decent brew, not as appealing as the ratings indicate.
Ar√¥me de  chocolat au lait. Mousse qui s¬í√©vapore rapidement. Go√ªt de malt torr√©fi√©, chocolat, finale s√®che. Bonne amertume. Manque de rondeur.

(bottle) pours a hazy darkest brown colour with a frothy light brown head. aroma of treebark, roasted malts and light black pepper, candied hazelnuts and vanilla. flavour is mostly roasted malts and light herbal hops, also quite smoky, with big notes of ash and smoked ham. slightly watery body with average carbonation.
The head is brown, the body black. It smells coffee, chocolate, aromatic. The taste is coffee-bitter, tasty and intensive, roasty-chocolate. Good! 12/13/13/12/12/13
Excellent stout across the board.definitely well hopped for a stout, no problem with me. The nitrogen tap version is excellent as well, as long as its fresh.

UPDATED: NOV 18, 2015 Draught at the Rogue Ales Public House. Notes from tasting session.
Softer mouthfeel and flavor than the porter. Good roast grainy flavor. Smooth finish. Also goes toward a roasted coffee at the end. Very creamy (oats). Kind of strange fishy aftertaste. Still, very good.

Bottled. Pours deep brown and nearly black with a large tan head, that leaves a good lacing. Nose of slightly roasted malt, chocolate, caramel and citrus notes. Sweet flavor that ends up more dry and slightly bitter. Medium bodied, oily texture and soft CO2. An enjoyable stout. ‚òÖ‚òÖ‚òÖ‚òÖ
On draft at the Iota Club in Arlington. Pours almost bkack with a tan head.  Roasted malt aroma.  Hints of Chocolate and coffee.  Burnt coffee finish.

65cl bottle @Cimmeria, Oviedo. Sweet chocolate and coffee aromas, some nuts and toffe ones. Pours very dark, a bit cloudy, with frothy tan head, creamy, some persistent, good lacing. Medium body, soft carbonation, oily texture. Taste is a bit watery, lacks some more body, chocolate notes present, nuts, some caramel, well balanced. Enjoyable anyway, but more body would be nice.

Pours black with a mocha head that disappears quickly. Smell a of baking cocoa, a bit of coffee and roasted malts. Taste is rich chocolate with a little hop bitterness. Dry finish with a good medium body. Just as good as the first time I had it.

The color of this beer is opaque black with a minimal brown head, and the aroma is a blend of roasted malts, chocolate, and oats without being overpowering. This beer is slightly bitter and mildly sweet, and the medium-thick body, flat carbonation, thick texture, and bitter finish combine to make this beer very nice on the mouth.

Black and foamy on the pour. Coffee head an inch or more.
Hah! I¬ím a poet!
Aroma is toasted malt with a touch of dark chocolate and coffee.
Taste is slightly bitter; pleasantly so.
Soft carbonation, medium body, Slightly sticky mouthfeel.
Fairly standard, solid Oatmeal Stout. Frankly I think my seasoned variations of this recipe are improvements, but I certainly wouldn¬ít turn one down.
Nice malt, chocolate, coffee scent. Creamy with medium carbonation. Drinks very smoothly while still imparting a lot of flavor. Slightly bitter aftertaste. Very nice.

650ml bottle- pours out an opaque engine oil black with a massive cola colored head that lasted the entire glass with plenty of lacing.  Aroma was black coffee.  Taste was bitter coffee and unsweetened chocolate with a bite of a finish.  That finishing bite is not exactly a welcome addition, dropping the score somewhat.  Palate was thin for a stout.  Not bad, but not as good as I had expected, either.

Pours black, with a fleeting light brown head.  Strong aroma of roasted malt and caramel, a bit floral too.  Taste begins really bitter, quick to burnt sweetness, sour notes coming through.  A bit of umami there.  The finish is short and bitter.  Good solid stout.  One to have with dinner or a good chunk of old cheddar.
Very good stout.  Good aroma.  Nice taste and full body.  Pallet is a nice mouthful.  Very good flavor, but finish is a bit harsh as you get with some imperial stouts.

Pours a fairly solid dark brown/black color with a smallish khaki head that persists quite well. Smells of caramel and roast with hints of cream vanilla and earth. Light bits of dark fruit aroma as well as hints of light sugar round out the nose quite well. The flavor is roasty chocolate vanilla with a hint of chalk and earthy hops. Medium body with a creamy velvety smooth mouthfeel and a light level of carbonation. This is a really nice stout, approachable yet flavorful and creamy as hell.

The reason this does not come close to Samuel Smiths Oatmeal Stout is balance. Balance is everything, and this does not have it. For one thing, the malt tastes like it has been burnt to a fare-thee-well. For another, this is too hoppy for the style. A proper Oatmeal Stout should be "smooth as monumental alabaster" not rough as the winds that "shake the darling buds of May".
UPDATED: NOV 29, 2014 Tap, black pour, white head, nose is coffee, taste is coffee, chocolate, bitter, vanilla
Deep, dark pour with thinner head. Palate is flat, simple, and smooth. Thick mouthfeel. Roasted coffee flavors and a dry finish. Balanced. Very good.

Draft at craft ale house. Pours pitch black with a small tan head. The aroma has dark chocolate, light coffee, mild toast. The taste is dark chocolate, roasted malt, a little hoppy finish. A slightly more flavorful dry stout.

Bitchin dark hops have obliterated my dark lonley cavern of IPA sovereignty. My little Island has been invaded y the Republic of Cascadia. Dark is the lonely future of the missing traveler, may we rush, release and cascade through the hoppy places of our soul.

Roasty, hopsy taste with dark chocolate throughout.  Medium bitter that is smooth and not overwhelming.  

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Pours black with a sizeable creamy tan head and excellent lacing.  Gentle notes of caramel and grain.  Smooth flavor with a gentle finish and decent carbonation.
Smell of tar and chocolate. Black colour with brown head. Too much essence chocolate overall. Aroma of tar, mocca and licorice. Some coffee in finish. Flat carbon.
Roasted chocolate aroma, black beer light brown head. Taste is roasted light bitter,milky roasted finish. Excellent light stout. Finish could be longer, creamy.

UPDATED: JUL 4, 2013 Black pour with brown head and nice roasted aroma.  Incredibly deep roasted full flavor stout that leaves your taste buds ingulfed in roasted malts long after the last sip, everything about this is impressive and lacks nothing.  Best beer ive had to date, I prefer this one to rogues chocolate stout and thats saying something, I never get tired of this brew I salute rogue for this incredible beer!

UPDATED: JAN 7, 2013 Dark color and good smell. Leaves a dark chocolate/coffe after taste in your mouth. Its kinda borderline almost ashtray taste. Overall its better then the average and I will leave it on my list as a potential buys for a stout craving

Nice oatmeal stout but not as good as Samuel Smith¬ís. I did not taste a lot of oats in this stout and it was a little more hoppy then I was expecting. Overall a good stout but I will not drink again.
Black. Small tan head. Milk chocolate aroma, some hops; ditto for the flavor. Creamy, some alcohol warmth, medium body. Some dry bitterness in finish.
hints of cholocate, coffee, slight hop.  Pours a dark chocolate brown, with a well pronounced head.  Sweet chocolate taste.  delicious and very smooth
Aroma of dark chocolate, cocoa and very sweet coffee.  Pours black with a big tan fluffy head.  Taste is nice and roasty with coffee and slight sweet chocolate.  Great stout!

22 oz bottle, Andersons Columbus.  Black; massive brown head dissipates into a very thin ring.  Aroma is sweet and shows lots of chocolate with plenty of coffee to boot; light ash, very light caramel.  Flavor is surprisingly tart; green apples, chocolate, roast; a little acidic.  Mouthfeel medium-thin; fizzy carbonation.  This is drinkable but I seriously don¬ít see the big deal, and for this to be 100th percentile in the stout category and 99th overall is utterly laughable.

Dark brown, tan head, slightly cheesy roast barley aroma. Medium carbonation, sweet, meaty, watermelon, light smoke, sharp sweet spike, milk chocolate, long toasty finish.

Expected much more. Best part was the appearance which was dark with brown sugar head which lasted only a minute. Aroma was mostly cocoa chocolate with very little coffee at the end. Taste was grainy with mild chocolate and a hint of coffee on the finish. Not much going on. Mouthfeel was dry and thin for a stout. So many better stouts.
Bottle and Draught.  This is a stout that highlights the combination of grassy west coast hops and the smooth mouth feel of oats in the grain bill.

650 ml bottle. Pours black with medium head. Aromas of dark chocolate and burnt malt. Dry for an oatmeal stout. Flavors of black coffee, light ash, a bit of vanilla, and roasted malts. Light bitter finish.

(From notes 16.11.12) Bottle. Beige, small foam. Aroma malty, some smoke, chocolate. Flavor bitter coffee. Smooth mouthfeel. Excellent, complex stout, despite a lacking description. Served much too cold, which is a shame (but understandable).

Soapy bubbaly brown cola head,black beer with a tad redish brown at bottom. Smell is light chocolate & oat. Taste is more chocolate then oat but still noticable good amount of oat & some hop bitterness. Not the best stout I¬íve had but it¬ís still fine,just the hop bitterness is my less liked part. Cheer¬ís. Long aftertaste. What¬ís the % because it¬ís listed 6% on ratebeer,some bottles some ppl have show a 6.5% sticker on it but it¬ís 15 plato witch I think is 7% because there pumpkin ale is 14 plato and is 6% I had that one with a sticker on it so yeah cheers

Draught at BrewDog Manchester. Dark black with brown head and lacing. Ashy and roasted aroma with some bitter dark chocolate tones. More of those elements in the taste with some added liquorice and blackcurrant hints peeping through. A fair amount of carbonation. Hits many of the right notes but the end product isn¬ít too exciting.

Dark black pour thick brown head.  Chocolate aromas. Thick body. Chocolate roast is most noticeable. Well balanced with malt sweetness.  

---Rated via iPhone

Bottle 650ml, a dark beer with huge brown head. Nose is very roasted and dark malt like. Aroma is on creamy dark chocolate with coffee cream too, medium sweet to low, very pure on malt flavors, light leather and vanilla notes, bit acrid at the finish, good but not exceptional. Peppery hops and long coffee aftertaste.

Nice. Can taste the oats. Malts are mellow. And the underlying hops add some character. Bit of chocolate, too, after resting. Not a thick stout, but complex and enjoyable. Session stout perhaps?

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
disappointed. hoppier than i expected. / toast, astringent, woody, rocky, sparkling, medium, citrus, vanilla, hay, cough drop, amber

On tap at Tap House Grill. Pours very dark brown with a chocolate milk head. Aroma has roasted malts, caramel and chocolate. Taste is of choco-coffee, roasted and burnt malts, caramel and some smoothness from the oats. Quite smooth with roasted bitterness. Finishes bittersweet with malts. Nice stout.
Really smooth stout flavor with a hint of smoke on the back end. Sweeter than you would expect without being sweet at all (if that makes sense).
Pours black..thin brown head. .sweet aroma,  taste is very smooth coffe milky nutty,  with smoke on the back end,  bad ass stout!

On tap at WJ Kavanaghs in Dublin. Appearance: Pitch black, tiny brown head. Aroma: Chocolate & milk, a little leather, a little coffee. Flavour: lovely coffee and chocolate up front, the oatmeal gives it a lovely oiliness, sharp espresso finish. Just a great stout.

Pours a velvety brown-black with a minimal tan head.  Smells of chocolate, floral, toast, hint of coffee.  Taste is bitter and sweet, cocoa, rich roast malt, moderate hops, a touch of acidity giving a little bite on the palate.

Aroma is sweet, chocolate, vanilla, a slight boozy smell. Appearance is jet black, light brown head, half finger head. The taste is sweet to start, a little bland but it picks up by the middle with a strong coffee presence. Not much on the sweet flavors, but the coffee presence is nice. The mouthfeel is smooth, perfectly carbonated and lovely. Overall, the beer is pretty good, I was expecting a little more but I¬ím not disappointed.

From tap: Poured dark brown with a small creamy head that lingered till the bottom. Aroma was roasted coffee and chocolate. Taste was similar with a nice hop bitter to it. Vanilla and small alcohol warmth afterwards.

Half pint on draught at Pivni in York.  Black with a good but short-lived head.  Chocolate and vanilla taste, sweet with a hint of roast.  Lovely chocolate/vanilla aroma.  Hint of spice in the taste.  Very nice stout, if a little ¬íartificial¬í.  Leaves good lace on the glass.

Pint at the rogue tap house in Portland. Despite the name of the brewery, there¬ís nothing unusual here: chocolate, oats, roasted maltiness, a touch of coffee. It was a little lighter bodied than I expected. Black color and brown headed. Medium bodied, but lighter than you¬íd expect. Aroma is subtle chocolate. Overall it¬ís a good, traditional soothing stout, and a decent choice if you want to showcase the style to the uninitiated.

Nitro tapped! Aroma is dark and creamy. Hint of oats in the smell. Appearance is cute. The taste starts of dark malt and stays a dry dark the whole time. You can taste the oats, with some carbon through out the whole taste. A good burnt taste is left in your mouth, almost popcorn flavored. The palate is a mellow burnt flavor. OverAll, good beer done well. I wonder if the bottle is the same?

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
A bit bitter but overall good. Will put hair on your chest, (ladies).
Bottled. A brown beer with a creamy beige head. Aroma is roasted malt, coffee, chocolate and hops. Taste is malty, roasted, coffee, chocolate, licorice. Nice creamy texture

First appearance it lacked the head retention I¬íd usually like to see but that could have been my fault... the aroma was nice and malty although it was light. The flavor was dark and had a nice heavy oatmeal mouth feel, especially at warmer temperatures. Hop flavor was medium low but extremely well balanced. Overall an excellent beer to enjoy by the fire on a cold winters night.

Aroma:  Unimpressive, almost no smell, I¬ím used to a much more powerful aroma from a stout.  Appearance:  Not impressive either, dark black, but a small (less than a finger) head that fades quickly and leaves no lacing.  Taste:  Gets a boost here, coffee, little wood from the barrell, oatmeal is a non factor, and chocolate.  Something else that I can¬ít quite put my finger on.  Palate:  Beautiful palate, one of the best actually, strong carbonation in the front, smooth flavor as you drink, and no fade as it finishes.  Best part of the beer.  Overall:  It¬ís good, maybe not something I would drink regularly, but its definitely worth a buy.  I usually don¬ít like Rogue but they pleasantly surprised me on this one.
Dark brown color like chocolate with brown head. One of the smoothest stouts I have had. I smell coffee and malt. I taste coffee, dark chocolate, and dark bread. Very good...
Tap at Three Fires. Chocolate, earthy peat, roasty coffee malt aroma. Black with a small brown head, moderate lacing. Very earthy coffee malt flavor. Medium to full body.

Pours thick black with a fluffy white head. Aroma of some coffee and mostly roasted barley and other grains. Thinner than expected on the palate, but still pretty hearty. Flavors of toasted coffee, dirt, bitter chocolate. Very nice beer.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Poured from a 22 oz. bottle. Nice chocolate brown color with caramel colored head.  Very smooth with a good balance of chocolate and bitterness with a pleasant amount of hoppiness. Not the best oatmeal stout I've had but very drinkable.  

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
A very nice brew.  A nice thick creamy body.  Has a nice roast chocolate aroma and taste is a bit of chocolate roast blended with barley.

On tap at Brewdog Camden. It pours a dark brown colour, almost black, with a small tanned head. Foam is creamy but dissipates fairly quickly. Aroma is oat flakes, espresso and coffee. Taste is bitter and coffee forward. Loads of espresso and some burnt woody notes. Mouthfeel is medium to full with good carbonation. Overall, what a stout is all about.

Good.  The nose is full of roast malt and coffee.  Deep black with a cream colored head. Bitter from both roast characteristics and hop profile.  Medium bodied with that distinct oatmeal smoothness. Dry with a snap finish.

Dark brown, almost black colour with a tan head. Coffee, chocolate, licorice and roasted malts in aroma. Roasted coffee and roasted malts in flavour. Also some dark fruits and chocolate in aftertaste. Quite smooth.

Review #1

Poured from 22 oz. bottle into snifter glass.

A: Pours a dark black with a one finger dark khaki/caramel head. Light cannot pass through this wonderfully looking stout. Great lacing.

S: Instant chocolate hits your nose for a brief second followed by a slightly bitter coffee. The hops come through to enhance the bitterness and tone down the sweetness of the chocolate

T: Bitter coffee upfront with a sweet oat taste through the middle followed by an even sweeter chocolate that hits the back end and stays on the pallet. 

M: For a stout it is light but slightly chewy at the beginning. Smooth finish. Goes down VERY easy

O: Great Stout that paired very well with the meat I was having at the time. Take the time to enjoy a few sips before the meal though as this changes the taste slightly and is less bitter up front during the meal.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 05-02-2011 00:39:30

Thx. to Vincent for sharing this one / bomber sampled @ RBBSG 2012. I have no idea as to why people say that Rogue sucks except for this beer - this one is not that good and their others are not that bad - the labels sucks terribly as usual. Dark brown with a BIG mocha head. Light oatmeal, ok mocha, choc powder, bit weakened, dusty. Mellow bitter roast, sweet mocha, caramel, sweeter malts, nuts, coffee, oatmeal, okay but too thin, too light in flavour and body. Seems bit over the hill as well.
Thick dark foamy pour. Musty chocolate aroma. Light carbonation creamy texture and flavor.

Location: 22 oz bottle from Buy Rite, 9/27/12


Aroma: The nose is roasted malts, coffee, un-sweet chocolate, and a little smoke

Appearance: It pours a dark brown color with a small medium brown head

Flavor: It tastes dry, roasty, and smokey, without much sweetness, and with a bitter finish

Palate: The body leans full, it has a slightly creamy feel, a soft carbonation, and a heavy dry finish

Overall Impression: 
I¬íve had this beer before, as it has been a staple for quite sometime, but it has been a while since I had one.  This is a good beer, that is fairly one-dimensional on the dry roasted malt flavors, but works well enough.  It¬ís basically what I remembered, nice job here by Rogue.

Dark brown almost black with big mocha head. Bitter  hop smell with a little dark chocolate. And that's pretty much the taste as well with some roasted malt. Not a bad stout, probably wouldn't get it again. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle. Pours black with tan head that doesnt stick around very long. Heavy roast aroma, almost smokey, burnt toast, some licorice and dark fruits. Tasteis very rich, ashy, dark chocolate. Smooth and creamy with a lingering dark chocolate finish. Very nice

Had it at flying saucer on tap, by far the thickest beer I¬íve ever had.  My friend was looking at me weird comparing it to motor oil, but it was fantastic.  Everything you would expect with a delicious chocolate aftertaste.  Definitely would try again

Poured from a 22oz bottle into a pint glass.

Appearance: pours thick, black as night with a light brown finger and a half head.

Smell: roasted malts and coffee! Not a very strong smell, though.

Taste: strong coffee and roasted malts. Very good taste. Alcohol taste lingers at the end.

Mouthfeel: thick in the mouth with a lot of carbonation

Overall: the more I drink the lower the score gets, unfortunately. The carbonation is off-putting to me. Still a great beer, though. I wouldn¬ít hesitate to get it again.

N√§stan svart √∂l med ett ljusbrunt skum. Doft av choklad, lakrits, vanilj och med rostade toner. Kaffe och choklad framtr√§der tydligare i smaken. En v√§lbalanserad stout. Rakt igenom god, men hade kunnat ha lite mer av allt f√∂r en kraftigare k√§nsla.

650!ml bottle from giant eagle. Good sweet smoky nose and good thick pour. Full body and great balance. Oats come first and little chocolate finish. Could be a bit thicker and more full to make an unstoppable beast but still wouldn't pour out for my homies.

650 ml bottle from Premier Wine and Spirits (Halifax).  Pours an opaque near black dark brown with moderate-sized tan head.  Aroma is chocolate, coffee and caramel.  Flavour is fairly roasty with a little sweetness, notes of chocolate/vanilla, caramel, coffee and a little earthy hoppiness.  Smooth, slightly creamy mouthfeel.  Quite pleasant.

I couldn¬ít really detect a scent. (But then, I may have allergies acting up.) 
But the pour was great! Deep, rick, thick black. Opaque. 
The head is a full finger thick, and is indeed thick. Dark, dark brown and rich. Slow to dissipate, but does dissipate completely. 

I started it cold. It tasted both sweet and bitter at the same time. At first all I could get was a slight coffee taste. Hoppy. And, a little flat aftertaste like the end of a Bud. That part wasn¬ít pleasant. But I don¬ít know if it was because I got used to it, or getting warmer improved it, but that flat, bitter, sour aftertaste didn¬ít last through the first glass, and not at all in the last two glasses. 

Did I mention the bottle is large enough to fill too smallish pilsner glasses? 

After it warmed up a bit, I started tasting a cocoa flavor. Not chocolate, but cocoa. Almost like a cafe mocha... but with hopps. 

Creamy mouthfeel. And not a sticky creamy that causes that back of the pallate linger. But just a rich consistancy. 

Kind of heavy--I felt full after the whole bottle. I don¬ít even want to think of how many calories this liquid bread has! *grin*

Black colour, beige head. Aroma of chocolate, roasted malts, oatmeal, light smoke. Light sweet flavour, light roasted malts bitterness. Quite dry. Finish bitter chocolate and oats.

Clear dark brown beer, aery brown beer, unstable, non adhesive. Aroma: some mocha, caramel, some grains, bit dusty. MF: ok carbon, medium to full body, little creamy in texture. Taste: mocha, coffee, lots of hoppy bitterness. Aftertaste: coffee, hops, very bitter ending. Did not like.

Bottle @ Oliver Twist. Pours pretty much black with a small creamy mocha head that slowly dissipates while leaving some trace on the glass. Smell is slightly sweet and malty with roasted malts, sweet liquorice candy, roasted oatmeal flakes, caramel, bitter chocolate, dark bread, smoked chili and hints of charred wood. Taste is tiny sweet, bitter, tiny sour and malty with heavily roasted malts, roasted almost burnt oatmeal flakes, salty liquorice candy, burnt caramel, bitter chocolate, dark roast coffee, charred wood, dark bread and hints of ash, vanilla and resin. Mouthfeel is very smooth, round, very tiny tart and medium bodied. Finish is tiny sweet, bitter and malty with roasted malts, salty liquorice, dark roast coffee, bitter chocolate and charred wood. Very nice and smooth...

22 oz. bottle poured into a tumbler pint glass.

A: Pours a borderline pitch black color. The head is a huge four finger light mocha color with frustratingly high retention, a wonderfully creamy texture, and huge clumps of lacing on the glass.

S: Light oats, mild chocolate, and some solid roastiness. Nice, but a little weaker than I like.

T: At first, it¬ís vaguely sweet, likely from the oats. There¬ís little opening flavor here, it¬ís mostly concentrated after the midtaste and finish, which is not only strong with roast (slightly acrid and excessively strong at times), it also tastes overhopped, to an extent. It¬ís not a well melded hop profile as with Storm King, it¬ís a ¬íclashing with the stout base¬í profile. At least the hops don¬ít completely overpower the palate with grapefruit and pine; still, it¬ís hardly a paragon of balance. Finally, enough sips will cause a slight lactic acid ¬ítwang¬í to accumulate. I expected a lot more from this, but it¬ís decent enough.

M: Creamy at first, before becoming prickly dry with a little lingering stickiness and low carbonation. Little to complain about here, Rogue got this part of the beer right. On the other hand, it¬ís not as drinkable as it should be, but that¬ís due to the unbalanced flavor profile more than anything.

O: I¬ím wondering if I served this too warm - but then I realized I had Samuel Smith¬ís oatmeal stout at a similar temperature, and was far superior to this in just about every manner. I¬íd definitely try it again, just to confirm whether or not my fears are true. All in all, it¬ís far from bad, just disappointing.

at RBBSG my bottle 
Colour: dark brown, black

Taste: kinda like the aroma, overall nice beer but a bit thin and that¬ís a shame ...

Charcoal, beige head, creamy froth that diminishes to a ring and a spot of warm-light brown.  Aroma: Light cocoa, refreshing sap hops, hint of smoke and bbq.  Body is medium thick, but smooth, with creamy carbonation, and a fairly light flavor profile, light sweetness, giving it the illusion of medium-light; certainly not fatiguing to drink.  Flavor has a burnt wood, almost smoky character, herbal, sappy hops, a little burnt dark cocoa, some tantalizing floral hop character that affects the sides of the palate.  Roast is neutral; no coffee. It¬ís good, but needs more flavor to deserve the score it has.

Awesome milk chocolate scents and taste is similar with a little roasty backbone. Super creamy smooth mouth feel, great oatmeal stout.

Super-duper stout. The stout standard bearer. The burnt malt and bitter hops flavors are great and what I look for in a stout. Dark brown/black color; Medium to heavy slightly creamy body; Aroma of toasted malt, chocolate, & coffee; Flavor of roasted malt, rich chocolate, coffee, and some hops; Finish is slightly bitter; Nicely balanced; Pretty good overall - solid brew from Rogue.

Originally reviewed: 3/9/11. Had a coupon for $1-off any bomber at Total Wine. Decided to grab something that I continually pass over. This one jumped out at me this time around. And it¬ís a "Top-100" Popular beer to boot!

Poured into a pint glass. Pours an absolute black. No light-penetrance at all. A small half-finger tan head sits atop. Retains well enough for its size. Minor bits of lace cling around. The nose is sweet with sugar cookie, oatmeal, brown sugar, and coffee. Very nice. 

This beer starts out more on the bubbly side, which I wasn¬ít expecting given that this is an Oatmeal Stout. As it warms, this mellows out to become quite a smooth drink. 650 ml bottle. Pours a nice reddish black with a thin white head. Tastes mostly of ash, dark chocolate and oatmeal. Slight coffee-ish, ash bitterness in the finish. Body is average. Personally, I liked it, but I think it is slightly overrated...
Pours black as night with a good brown head. Smell is nutty, bitter and malty. The taste is surprisingly smooth. Chocolate and coffee in a perfect blend.

From notes.  Poured from a 22 oz. bottle into a pint glass.

This pours nearly black, with nearly no other color highlights -- just a hint of ruby in the very corners of the glass. A nice creamy brown head forms, then fades to a ring with some thin film on toop. The head reaffirms itself with every swirl of the glass. Some foamy lace.

The aroma is mostly roasted malt without much sweetness attached, some chocolate malt, chocolate, brewed coffee, and a bit of earthy hops as well.

The flavor starts with a huge dose of unsweetened roasted malt character. Some unsweetened chocolate and chocolate malt step in, with a rising touch of bitter coffee, and earthy hops to finish. The combination of coffee malts and a strong hop presence just give me too much bitterness here, and I am a hophead.

Mostly creamy, full bodied. Some bubbly carbonation. Chewy, resiny, lightly acidic, and a bit dry.

The flavor gets more bitter with each sip without giving me enough complex flavor to make it truly enjoyable.

Pours black with a tanned head. Aroma of dark coffee and hints of chocolate.
Didn¬ít note anything else. Very good.

Pours totally black with a tall frothy brown head. Aroma is sweet, coffee, chocolate. Taste is also sweet with some roastiness, chocolate, coffee and oats. Really great and solid stout but short of incredible.

Black pour with a hidden red hue.Tan creamy head.
Slight yeast aroma and dark roast  faintly with chocolate mild floral citrus,strange petroleum aroma also like oil.
 Medium body with a slight slickness fairly smooth with a heavy piney hop flavor and bittering, and a crapload of harsh dark malt bitter,seems like a pretty robust stout pretty drying in the finish, with the oats i guess i wasnt expecting the dry bitterness to overpower any oat significance. I think it would be better with a toned down bittering of dark malt/hops.Very dry darkmalt bitter finish.I think some sweetness would balance this better.But its a dry bitter robust stout if thats your thing.
On draft at iron abbey. Pours dark, tastes of oats/chocolate.  Nice creamy full mouthfeel. Very good. Rogue doesn¬ít disappoint.

Tasted from 1pt 6oz bottle into tulip, thanks gregwilsonstl! Poured an almost opaque, dark reddish-brown, almost black color with creamy tan foam which faded to a persistent layer of bubbles and lace. Aromas of roasted barley, husky cereal grains, fruity ale yeast esters, more zesty American hops than typical stouts. Rich malty and roasty flavors, bready, caramelly, somehow simultaneously tart and smooth, surprisingly dry, notes of burnt toast, coffee, chocolate, plums. Creamy, chewy, protein-y oatmeal mouthfeel, moderate-high carbonation, lingering bittersweet aftertaste which finished bone dry. Not as dizzyingly alcoholic or complex as most Russian Imperial Stouts, which is fine with me. Accessible. Satisfying. So delicious.
Awesome chocalate oatmeal flavor.   Nice tan head.  This is a nice well rounded stout.
Jet black...light tan creamy head. Strong chocolate creamy aroma; roasty as well. Light roasty creamy taste and ultra smooth finish.

22oz bottle. Near black pour with a decent light brown head that leaves a little lace, but less than I¬íd like to see. Medium roast coffee dominates the nose with an easy chocolate note. There¬ís a faint hoppiness in there as well. The chocolate comes out in a big way on the palate and then moves into that medium roast coffee across the mid-palate. Finishes with a light bitterness that adds a little hop presence.

Had this in a bottle and on nitro tap; this review is for the nitro tap version.

This was already one of my favorite beers via the bomber. Then I tried this on tap and, WOW, it was only ridiculously better. The big downfalls from the bottle version (effervescence and somewhat thin body) were improved upon and what was already good was only better.

A: Nice, creamy dark brown body with a nice, brown head.

S: A rich, semi-sweet, and somewhat bitter aroma.

T: A beautiful combination of chocolate, sweet oatiness/maltiness, roasted malts, and bitter coffeeness

P: Beautifully creamy and medium bodied.

O: What was one of my favorite oatmeal stouts became my favorite oatmeal stout having now tried this on tap. Honestly, the perfect beer via nitro tap imho.

Aroma is heavy on malt with the roasted coffee notes at the front. Appearance is black with a minimal tan head... I always struggle to credit a stout for its appearance. They¬íre black? Taste has a medium sweetness with strong bitter tastes from the coffee aroma. On the palate it¬ís creamy with a full body and soft on the carbonation. It¬ís a great beer with great flavor.

Solid offering from Rogue, aged 1 years plus, I was much anticipating trying, strong burnt flavor coming through, a little too much for my taste, coffee flavor, strong aftertaste as well, not as smooth as I imagined.  Just not really what I expected, still decent, worth trying, but not my fav.
Jet black colour with tan head. frothy and laced. big chocolate aromas, roasted coffee bean, and has a bread note. big brew with some hoppy note, bitter charcoal. great finish. tasty brew!

Excelente Outmeal Stout. Delicioso aroma aun que no tan persistente. Muy Buen color y densidad. Un sabor completo e integral. En resumen una excelente y cremosa Stout de Avena. Lo unico que creo se deber√≠a mejorar es que su espuma y cabeza no es perdurable.

Draft (nitro) - Pours a dark black with thick tan head and cake-like lacing.  Smell is sweet malts with nice coffee and chocolate.  Taste is big semi-sweet chocolate malts with some toffee and coffee.  Creamy texture.  Great stout.

Bottle; black with moderate brown head; aroma-coffee, chocolate, roasty, oak; taste-light sweetness, lightly bitter, medium sourness, medium body, slightly creamy, soft carbonation, long finish. I wish it was creamier and sweeter
Bomber.  Deep dark brown, tan head, light chocolate aroma.  Full body and creamy, coffee and roasted malt released in the mouth, smooth aftertaste.  Nice stout.
650ml pours deep dark brown with a creamy tan head.  Smells chocolatey and a little floral from the hops.  Tastes of chocolate a little coffee and a dry bitter hoppiness.

Nitro keg @ Rogue, San Francisco, CA

Pours pitch black with a smooth creamy head. Aroma of licorice, roasted malts, hops and ash. Taste is quite smooth with some roasted notes, licorice, leather and oatmeal. Finish is slightly bitter and roasty.

Bomber. The aroma was filled with cereal and a slight malt/coffee tinge at the finish. The pour was a dark black with a decent head for a stout, tan as expected, that stuck around for a bit before dissolving to a film, and once settled, I found the appearance to be a pitch black, even when tilting toward the light, this sucker didn¬ít give on the edges, still pitch black. 

The palate was a heavy, thick body with a creamy texture that sat on the tongue with a pleasing frothiness. It gave me a little tingle as it finished. The taste was a med-heavy malty cereal at first that faded to a light bitter on the tongue with a medium bitter creeping up the nasal passage, a tasty bitter coffee/oaty aftertaste. 

Overall, if I hit the lottery - thus, having extra cash as well as being able to retire early - I¬íd drink this sucker for breakfast every morning.

Finalmente se pueden conseguir las cervezas de rogue en M√©xico aunque a un precio muy alto, sin embargo, algunas valen la pena y esta es sin duda alguna una de ellas. Esta rankeada como sexta de mejor stout del mundo en ratebeer.com.


Cerveza color negro con cabeza cafe de tama√±o mediano y regular retenci√≥n.

El aroma es de intensidad media con notas predominantes de malta altamente tostada, cafe y lupulo citrico. 

El cuerpo es de medio a alto, la carbonatacion es media, el contenido tanto de malta como de lupulo son ligeramente altos y el nivel de alcohol es medio y no se siente mucho en el sabor de la cerveza.

El sabor es excelente, comienza agridulce y termina amargo, las notas de lupulo citrico percibidas en el aroma se itensifican y dominan el final de la ceveza, esta muy bien balanceada con las notas de malta tostada y cafe que le dan un sabor intenso y cremos. Muy buena cerveza. 

Esta al igual que a la Mikkeller beer hop breakfast las consideraria como india stout, pues el contenido de lupulo es alto, lo que otorga aspectos comunes de la familia de las cervezas india

Bottle. Pours black with dark tan head. Strong cereal and dark fruit nose. Flavours have a hop character, but very good oatmeal character along with chocolate, vanilla, raisin and plum flavours. Really nice, light CO2 prickle. Very nice.

Bottle at home. Black pour, bubbly tan head. Gorgeous dry roasty nose, hint of cocoa, real oatmeal, weetabix. Slightly sweet chocolate front, lots of dry malt, lovely prickly soft mouthfeel. Slightly bitter ashy finish. Really very nice.

Appearance:  Dark pour, moderate thick, tan head. Aroma: very nice, complex, roasty, sweet...very inviting. Taste: dry, roasty, slightly burnt, minimal hop presence, bit light for my tastes, finish is of dark roasted malt, maybe a bit of bitter dark chocolate/very strongly brewed coffee. Palate: slightly chewy with big mouthfuls, surprisingly strong carbonation.  Overall: a bit too light on character for me, but among drier  stouts, it√¢¬Ä¬ôs decent. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Pours black with a large, lasting dark head.
Nose shows roasted malt, oatmeal, chocolate and soft coffee. Very appetising.
Same story with the flavours, roasted malt, faint chocolate and oats. Finishes with a roasty bitterness.
Nice soft carbonation.
Very easy drinking.

Draught at Mikkeller Bar: Very dark brown with a creamy cappucino style head and good retention. Aroma is roasted malts, with notes of coffe, grapefruit and grass. Taste is malty sweet, roasted with vague notes of coffee and chocolate. Some citrussy hops and a dry, medium bitter finish. Creamy smooth texture, soft carbonation. Not bad....
Darkest black brown, big foamy mocha head. Sweet caramel malt aroma. Bittersweet chocolate, coffee and dark roasted malt taste. Long bitter finish. NFL (Not For Lagerboys)
65cl, at 6.5%Vol, American brew, from De Bierkoning Amsterdam, complex dry Stout, roasted/malty and slightly bitter, balanced, hazy, good head, good brew, yet expensive

Phenomenal oatmeal stout. Pours black with very little mocha head. Aroma of coffee and smoke. Smoke and dark roasted coffee beans on the palate. Great thick and soft mouthfeel. Nice coffee-inspired bitter aftertaste. Awesome!!

I haven¬ít had this one in years so it¬ís nice to revisit it for the tick.  Dark with an almost tan head.  Aroma is chocolate with a thick feel and more chocolate and roasty bitterness in the flavor.  It¬ís as good as I remember it.

Silky black pour with a biscuity brown head. Chocolate, oatmeal, roasted malts, coffee and hops on the nose. Chocolate, bitter from the coffee, oatmeal and roasted malts arrive on your palate on initial sip. Chocolate is the dominant flavour.  Oatmeal notes are subtle. 

Could have a few more alright....

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Bomber split with sherm1016...pours dark dark brown with rapidily dissipating head....mild chocolate nose and taste...medium body...chewy and very tasty

22oz bottle, shared by dwm1034. Thanks! Pours a jet black color with a tan head and a little lacing. Aroma is roasty, a little bitter coffee, a little chocolate. Medium on the palate with average carbonation. Taste is sweet, with flavors of oats, coffee, nutty, with a nice bitter coffee finish.

UPDATED: FEB 28, 2012 A - pours deep brown with light tan head some lacing. 

S - chocolate toffee subtle dry fruit burned Malts mocha. 

Mf - med body, a little airy. Light on the palette. 

Tastes - smokey chocolate and burned malts on the nose. lightly creamy mocha burned malts ending. 

O - Good average stout. A little less complex and strong than I would like.

6/6+
22oz bottle with spookgolds.  Deep black pour.  Roasted malt aroma.  Thick taste, chocolate malt, burnt malts, some hop bitterness.  Overrated.

22oz bottle. Pitch-black color, nice lighter brown head, great lace. Crisp, lighter carbonation, some dryness, great body... Very pleasant mouthfeel. Definitely a nice, oaty aroma... A good oatmeal stout. Visible sediment. Good mild bittersweet taste.

650ml bottle. nPours a beautiful opaque black with a generous coffee cream head. The nose has rich, creamy chocolate and some green herb notes. The taste is of more chocolate, going into a burnt cocoa or even liquorice or charcoal. The palate medium bodied, there is a creamy texture in the middle section and a dry (unfortunately slightly astringent) finish. Overall, a good beer but lacks balance on the end.

22 oz Bomber. Pours an ebony black with nice tan head. Frothy light chocolate and coffee aroma, very pleasant on a winter evening. Taste is toffee, light chocolate with an interesting hop bitterness on the back of the tongue. An enjoyable brew!

22 oz. bottle pitch black color. Beige full, thick head. Laced the glass nicely. From the moment I opened the bottle I could smell a rich chocolate. A very nice malt, chocolate and a slight bitterness in the finish. The bitterness comes through more as it warms. A very smooth and silky mouthfeel. A very nice stout

Aroma: Nuts, caramel and chocolate with hints of hops at the edges.
Appearance: Black with thick, brown head.
Taste: Medium bitterness with hints of sweetness throughout. Not unpleasant, though.
Palate: Full body,  slick texture, fizzy carbonation, long finish.
Overall: It¬ís not mind blowing, but it¬ís certainly quite delicious. I could see stocking a few of these for the winter.
Tap at Yard House in Downtown LA.  Black pour with a creamy white head.  Roasty aroma and flavor.  Smooth palate.
En l√§tt och komplex stout. Sammetslen munk√§nk√§nsla d√§r humle och malt v√§vs samman och kompletterar varandra perfekt. Choklad, fruktigt kaffe, och jordiga mulltoner. Mums.

Bottle. Pours black with a handsome tan head. Mild chocolate coffee nose. Flavour is similarly coffee chocolate with a nice hop presence. Good degree of bitterness which continues to build. Velvety mouthfeel. A brilliant example of the style.

Dark pour, moderate thick, tan head that does really hang around long enough for me. Aroma is very nice, complex, roasty, sweet..very inviting. Taste is dry, roasty, slightly burnt, minimal hop presence. A bit light for my tastes. Slightly chewy with big mouthfuls. Finish is of dark roasted malt, maybe a bit of bitter dark chocolate. Overall a bit too light on character for me, but among drier stouts, it¬ís decent. Not a go-to beer for me.
On tap. Black with a nice head. Smells of roasted coffee. Full bodied with a mild chocolate taste. A great stout!
UPDATED: MAR 3, 2012 Bottle. Black colour with a brown creamy head. Chocolate and coffee nose. Massive roasted barley and chocolate flavour with a nice hoppiness.
Black color with brown stable head. Coffee taste and smell. Smooth mouth feel. Creamy. I like this one

Nitrogen draught. Pours opaque black with an offwhite head. Smells of roasted coffee and chocolate. Tastes a medium bitter. Texture is creamy. Body is full. Finishes semi dry. Very tasty and easy to drink.
Delicious blend of chocolate and coffee.  The oatmeal adds definition to the flavor and a pleasant thick mouthfeel.

On tap at Blue Tusk, nitro. Black with a creamy tan head. Roasted malts, bitter chocolate, grains. Very smooth (obviously the nitro) and quite thick considering, full bodied, dry and hops at the end but not overly exciting.

Great stout from Rogue. Tulip. Nose is cocoa and dark chocolate with some slight roast in the nose. Poured deep black with a dark brown head. After the beer warmed up, the flavors really came out. Solid chocolate malts were followed by a light hop bitter that made this one very well balanced and easily drinkable. Very enjoyable stout.

Pours a deep black  color with a medium brown head.  Aroma is heavily roasted coffee and caramel malt.  Roasted coffee flavor with a hint of bitterness.  Medium bodied with a nice creamy mouthfeel.  This may be my new favorite beer.

I like this a little more than the Rogue Chocolate stout.  The difference b/t the two is that I find this beer to be more roasted.  In the Chocolate stout all you taste is chocolate but in the Shakespeare stout you can taste the chocolate as well as some good sweet coffee.  I made beer braised chicken with this and it was really good.

Jag √§r personligen mer intresserad av en imperial stout √§n en stout, men ibland kan det vara upplyftande med en lite l√§ttare stout och den h√§r dracks vid ett s√•dant tillf√§lle. I vanlig ordning pr√§glades √∂len av kaffe och choklad med den hade ocks√• en sv√•rdefinierad elegans som jag uppskattade. Slutsats: l√§tt, fin och god.

Excellent beer, tried it at a local restaurant on a whim and I was pleasantly surprised. It has a deep complex taste but is remarkably drinkable. Highly recommended to try for someone who is looking for a stout.

On tap at Beer Temple. Black colour, beige head. Aroma of chocolate, hard roasted malts, some cream, coffee. Flavour is sweet, chocolate, but also dry, cocoa, bitter roasted malts, coffee, bitter finish. Medium bodied, creamy mouthfeel. Nice stout.
Bottle, pours a ncie black, good solid head, the aroma is very nice, with hints of coco, the taste is very chocolatey and it has a good body with a nice finish.

Bomber. Bought at Fred Meyer in CDA, ID. Here¬ís another beer I can¬ít believe I haven¬ít rated yet. It¬ís one of those beers that was always a part of my top ten about a decade or so ago. Pours almost completely opaque black; when I hold it up to the light, faint brown highlights appear. Has a medium dark tan soapy head that collapses after a couple of minutes, leaving a skiff of foam. Nose is full of caramel, mocha and roasted malts with some faint piney hops lurking in the background. Taste starts out sweet and finishes with a bitter dryness. Mouthfeel is nice and creamy, carbonation is average. Even though it¬ís not Top Ten-worthy anymore in my eyes, it¬ís still a great beer and one I know I can turn to any time I need a quality stout to warm the cockles of my chockles.

The pour of Rogue Shakespeare Oatmeal Stout promises a velvety texture. The smell of boozy chocolate hints at a very complex brew.

It is, indeed, smooth. Roasted malt just at the point of being charred, but not burnt.The finish is an interesting mix of bittersweet chocolate and dark fruits. Not as much as an Imperial Stout, but enough to add another layer of flavor. Hops provide some bitterness and dryness as it warms. With oatmeal in the name, I expected to get more in the flavor, but it¬ís way in the background and does more with the superior texture.

Can¬ít think of many ways to make this better!

The beer was pulled from my fridge far colder than I like it. After about half an hour the beer had warmed to my purpose. The beer was served in an Imperial Pint glass.

Ar- The expected aroma of cocoa / chocolate rise out from a cloud of darkly roasted, toasted and even chared malt. I think I am getting vaguely smoke tones and leathery notes. 

Ap- The beer is black no opaqueness to light. The head was a short lived nugget coloration. Rings of foam mark the beers passage from my glass. 

T- The expected toasted and roasted notes are in place. I am a bit annoyed at the level of over roasted and frankly burnt malts present. It reminds me of Starbucks coffee. I hate Starbucks sugary burnt coffee. Bittersweet chocolate brings a welcome break from the burnt notes.

P- The body of the beer is medium. The carbonation is on the lower side but works ok the beers character. 

O- I remember liking this beer alot more than I do now. Taste and palates change over time. This beer isnt bad and wasnt a chore to drink. I most likely will not repeat.

Aroma: Hint of buttery, carmel, nutty, chocolate, very odd.
Taste: Raisins, milk chocolate, dark fruits and a hint of age. Something that reminds me of Port.
Mouthfeel: Very soft, but annoying carbonation.

Heavily malted chocolate.  Smells like a candy bar you wish existed, but taste is not as potent as my benchmark (the Terrapin Wake ¬ín¬í Bake).  Has a cloudy, doo doo brown appearance, but I knew I was getting a chocolate-y stout so I was into it.  Very sweet, almost saccharine aftertaste.  Not terribly drinkable - couldn¬ít see myself buying another one of these.
A very good stout, but a bit boring. Expected more from this beer, but a very decent beer.
Almost black with a big and lasting brown head. Aroma is sweet, roasted malt and chocolate. Flavor is quite sweet and rather bitter. Dry and roasted rather bitter finish. 221011

Keg at Craft. Black coloured with tiny short lived beige head. Aroma is very strange, initially roasted spice, almost curry like, quite beefy and very oaty. Taste is less notable but still nice. Lots of oats, bit of coffee bitterness and spicy. Low carbonation, and quite slick in the mouth. Nice.

UPDATED: OCT 29, 2011 Well done. Only hit on it is that I get a touch of cola taste, touch too much carbon, touch too much hops - - - all very minor. Aroma is complex and features roasts of all sorts !!!! Appearance like I want. Black as coal, dense mocha head and nice lacing. Like I said -a bit cola- a bit of dark hops (?) very nice chocolate notes. Smooth and creamy but I not a fan of much carbonation. I will buy again from time to time; it is one of the better.

This beer pours an almost pure black color with a cappuccino head.  Lovely aroma of roasted oats, chocolates, and earthy hops from britain.  Tastes of chocolate, malts, and a slight hoppiness for balance.  More complex than the previous statement gives it credit for, lots of oats with chocolate.  Great beer which I would drink again....

UPDATED: JUN 9, 2012 A: Dark brown/black body, finger width khaki cap, good retention and lacing. 

S: Mostly roasted malts, slight chocolate finish, floral overtones

T: Very nice. Slightly roasted. Slightly toasted. Slightly chocolate-d. Its a very subtly beer, not as in your face as a lot of american stouts these days.

M: Smooth and creamy. Clean finish. Soft carbonation.

O: A delicate stout. 6% abv is a nice treat. This is what i¬íd call a great pub stout. You want a nice beverage, but you don¬ít want to be overwhelmed with something that beats you in the face.

Appearance:  did they just pour me a Guinness?  Looks like it came out of a nitro can.   Aroma: 	light roasty malts, brown bread and chocolate; pine sap, and a hint of wood.   Taste: as the aroma indicated, but lighter.   Finish: resinous piney hops lingering over a whisper of chocolate.   Notes:  Draught at Kloby¬ís Smokehouse in Laurel, Maryland.    While it looked like a Guinness, the taste was that of a less roasty Guinness with a piney finish.  Palate was picture perfect, but overall just a very average stout.

22 oz. bottle from Total Wine in Norfolk, VA.  Dark brown, cola-like pour with a khaki head.  Aroma of chocolate, toasted malts, and very faint hops.  Smoky malts are the initial taste with a dark chocolate finish.  Chocolate, light espresso, and very faint hops linger on the palate.  Hard to find fault with this one; a very well done stout.
I¬íve waited a long while to try this Stout, and I finally did today. I chose to include it on a sampler tray at the Rogue in downtown Eugene, OR. Strangely empty, but still very very good.

I¬íve never been impressed by this beer. It seems to me a good marriage between an English stout and an american one. a lot of chocolate, coffee, and other characters, but they are weak and not so pleasant.

This brew poured up a near jet-black colored body with a frothy tan-colored head with moderate retention and lacing effects on the glass.  Aromas of burnt sugars, hot caramel, and loads of sweet roasted malts.  This is a very smooth and creamy medium-bodied brew with a slightly hoppy finish with lingering coffee notes.  There are light spice notes throughout with all flavors being very well balanced.

Botella de 1pt servida en vaso de Pinta.Saboreada en may¬¥11.Brota con color Ambar oscuro intenso.Espuma persistente de color marr√≥n claro,t√∫pida y cremosa, con burbuja peque√±a.Capa amplia con bastante buena retenci√≥n.Anillos de encaje fugaces.Aromas de malta torrefacta,avena y s√∫til chocolate.Sensaci√≥n en boca extremadamente seca;el sabor de chocolate es desplazado por los matices de fruto seco.Retrogusto de l√∫pulo seco camufla notas de chocolate.Cuerpo intenso y viscosidad alta para una cerveza de s√≥lo 6,1 ABV.¬°Puede masticarse!Asimilaci√≥n buena.1pt bottle served into a Pint glass.Enjoyed on may¬¥11.Pours deep dark amber in color.Light brown foam.Close & creamy,small bubbled.Thick layer with fairly good retention.Brief lacing rings.Toasted malt,oat & subtle chocolate aromas.Extremely dry palate.Chocolate flavor is backed by dry nuts.Dry hoppy aftertaste hids choco notes.Full body & high viscosity for a just 6,1% ABV beer.May be chewed it up!.Drinkability is ok.

Bottle @ Bishops Arms Sk√∂vde. Pours pitch black with a small brown head. Aroma is sweet, roasted,caramel, raisins and fruity. ¬†Flavor is roasted, malty, fruity, pears and bitter. Has medium body. Finishes with a nice balanced bitter and roasted malty aftertaste.

From the 22 ouncer.  The pour is dark cherry brown to black with a gently lacing tan forming a medium long lasting creamy head with even a bit of haze on the final drops.  Aromas of chocolate, oatmeal, and Northwestern hops.  The body was bit lighter than I had expected. The bitterness in the taste was mellow and it came with a friendly aftertaste.
Bouteille. Noire tr√®s opaque avec un collet tr√®s persistant. √áa donne soif. Odeur de cacao quelque peu sucr√©. Go√ªt chocolat noir avec un finale houblonn√© juste √† point. Tr√®s bien.
Nothing too special here. Just a standard, nice, straight-forward Oatmeal Stout. Nice slight sweetness with a great bitterness on the back end. Black malt and some hoppiness.

On tap.  Thick, dark pour under a medium tan head, with a nice medium lace.  Thick, smoky sweet flavor, with a ncie little bitter on the finish.  Stands up nicely as an oatmeal stout, and nicely drinkable in any case.

Bottle at GBBF 2010. From Notes. Pours very dark brown, thin brown head. Nose is syrupy milk chocolate, dark chocolate, coffee, slight citrous zing. Taste is lovely deep chocolatey, coffee, roasted notes. Bit of silky creaminess and quite alcoholic. Mouthful is fairly thin. More like a porter texture.
Poured pitch black with little head. Smelled of dark chocolate. Tastes smoky and a little chocolatey. The black malt was definitely the star of the show.

65 cl bottle
Rather light aroma has hops and some milk chocolate. Flavour has milk chocolate, roasted malt and hints of cold coffee. Bitter aftertaste. Slightly watery and too hoppy for a stout.

65 cl bottle.
Pours pitch black with a large foamy head. Aroma is dry ashy chocolate, dark malts, some grassy hops and notes of peat. Dry chocolate is strong in the flavour, some fruits and peated malts also. A bit too watery palate and too thin.
4324

650 ml bottle.
Pours a black colour with a thick beige head. Aroma of chocolate malts and some hops. Flavour of strong hops, chocolate, roasted malts, raisins and some toffee as well. Smooth bodied with a roasted, malty, somewhat sweet finish. A bit too thin but tasty.

650 ml bomber from "A Tutta Birra". Served into an english pint glass. Pours an ebony red, dark brown and almost black in the glass, with a big moka colour very consistent head. Good lacing retention on the glass. Full aroma of roasted malts, chocolate, coffe, vanilla and fresh hops. Malty taste, with a dark chocolate and burnt caramel aftertaste. Medium body, watery texture soft carbonation, dry and bitter finish. Delicious!

Poured a nice deep brown, almost completely black, and with a huge brown head. Smelled very much like chocolate, oats and hops that were a little zesty on the nose. Flavors upfront were sharp of hops followed by dark chocolate. Finished nutty and bitter, a little dry to with a sweet lingering aftertaste. Rogue has done it again, this beer is truly fantastic.

Bottle from myBreweryTap.com
Appearance Black with ruby edges. Rich tan head.
Aroma Roasted malt, coffee, bitter hops, earthy.
Taste Initially strong bitter hops, then a rich complex taste, chocolate and coffee, bit of alcohol burn.
Palate Silky mouthfeel, lingering roast bitter finish.
Overall A good oatmeal stout, but a wee bit rough.

Pours pitch black with a big, foamy, light brown head. Aroma of chocolate, roast, and oatmeal with slight coffee and hop notes. The flavor is very roasty, with the bitter and sweet characteristics of dark chocolate. Medium bodied, dry, and a little creamy with above average carbonation for a stout, but it fits just fine. Lovely stuff.
pitch dark, large smooth brown head. Aroma is roasted sruff, chocolate, dark caramel. Flavor is coffee roasted stuff, hops, very well balanced, but also a rad boring.
Nose is vanilla, wood, cream, weak smoke, sweet malt, feel is mediumlight, carb is medium, taste is licorice, sour leaves, smoke, artichoke, smooth bitter hops finish

UPDATED: JUL 6, 2011 Bottle @ Chad¬ís house. Deep brown appearance with a dark brown head. Toasty, milk chocolatey, light espresso, sweet, dark malty nose. Roasty, dark chocolate malty, fairly bitter, slightly milky flavor. Milky, light mouth feel. Pretty good.

0.65l bottle. Pours a really good lock¬ín - near black body with a gigantic chocolate creamy head. Aroma is mildly chocolate, roasted malts, notes of leather and licorice, thin coffee and some thin woody notes. Average to soft carbonation, oily mouthfeeling and medium-bodied. Tastes nicely roasted malts with notes of chocolate milk and it also has good notes of a mild roasted caramel with some lightly dry molasses in the finish. Not bad at all. Considering that I like the genre as much as I do, I¬ím surprised over my self that it took me this long to rate this highly available little thing. /me really like

Black color with very little head. Aromas of soft roasted chocolate with wine and flat tones of smoke. The flavor was roasted and a little watering. A little unbalanced with a relatively mild aftertaste.

Bottle @ Mogwai. Black as night with a fading dark brown foam. Rich aromas of chocolate, roasted malt and coffee. There is also a vinous tartness in the nose which was unexpected but still nice. The body is medium to light and it somehow feels almost to light after the impressive aroma. The taste is filled with more chocolate, cacao and coffee that lingers for long after your last swallow. A good stout.

On NITRO at the brewpub: Super sweet and smoky nose. Thick and puffy with a rustic bonfire flavor distilled into a delicate puff of smoke. Smooth and slippery. Long and airy in the finish.  4 8 8 5 16

Pour dark brown almost black, brown tan head decent lace. Aroma bakers, chocolate, bitter hops, roasty, vanilla, brown sugar oatmeal. Taste bitter, dark chocolate, rolled oats, cereal, cocoa, bittering hops, quite roasty. MF medium rich smooth body light on carb. Overall solid brew easy to drink rich bold and decently complex.
Bottle. From notes. Dark brown to black with a light brown head. Roasted malt, chocolate, coffee, some fruit. Smooth mouthfeel. Will get this again if I see it.
Bottle from FOneFan. Almost black with small light brown head. Flavour is roasted malts, chocolate, coffee, bitter, hops, notes of liquorice and a little sweet.

On tap at Maxs. Pours a very dark brown, tan head that lasted forever and nice lacing. Aroma of coffee, chocolate roasted malt. Tasted the oats and the coffee. Hints of chocolate. Medium bodied, thick texture, Bitter chocloate finish.

Bottle 650ml @ home
Pours black with a tan head. Aroma has notes of roasted malt, chocolate, oatmeal and a little licorice. Taste is medium sweet and light bitter with a roasted light bitter finish. Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is soft.

22oz bomber thanks to weihenweizen, pours a very dark brown with a nice tan head and lacing through out the glass, aroma has nice notes of chocolate, coffee and a hop presence, the flavor has a nice backing of chocolate that had a nice full finish, good brew.
