Pours not-quite-black with average sized tan head. Looks enticing, not overly heavy - medium bodied. Aroma is roasty, chocolat,e a little vanilla and a bit nutty. Flavor is oats and chocolate, a touch of coffee and a slight bitter hop finish. Pretty deece; drink and repeat.
On tap at champs. Dark brown with quarter inch tan head. Aroma is oat. Flavor is chocolate and oat. Delicious.
From a bottle poured a dark brown/black color with a small amount of head.  Nice sweet toasted malty flavor with a quick finish.

An incredibly dark brown that doesn¬ít quite hit black. Gorgeous and thick brown head that stays for a while and eventually leaves rich lacing down the glass. Very pretty.

A wonderful aroma of coffee and chocolate. Little hop presence. Smells rich and lovely.

An incredible amount of flavor. There¬ís tons of coffee, and chocolate, and even some significant hop presence. Bitter yet sweet, nearly perfect. Very good.

Rich mouthfeel, ample carbonation, very nice.

An exceptionally good oatmeal stout. It does everything right.

22oz bottle in a shaker.  Pours black with a thick, lacy, tan head.  Aroma of roasted malts, light chocolate, and floral hops. Flavor about the same, with a little coffee and chocolate on the finish. If this were thicker, it¬íd be an incredible beer. It¬ís still a really good stout.

22 oz. bottle pitch black color. Beige full, thick head. Laced the glass nicely.  From the moment I opened the bottle I could smell a rich chocolate. A very nice malt, chocolate and a slight bitterness in the finish.  The bitterness comes through more as it warms. A very smooth and silky mouthfeel.  A very nice stout. I would buy again.

Had this from the handpump into a mug.

3.5 A: Black with a creamy brown cask head. Average retention and no lacing.

3.5 S: Some chocolate, oats, and yeast. Overall, rather dry and unassuming.

3.0 T: Pretty boring. Oats, somewhat chalky dryness, and woody yeast. Light roastiness.

3.5 M: Medium body. Good carbonation for cask. However, it not ridiculously creamy like a lot of beers from cask. Otherwise, okay.

3.0 D: Not bad, but probably the worst cask beer I¬íve ever had. Just not enough flavor going on.

Serving type: cask

Reviewed on: 03-26-2011 17:03:30

Pours Nearly black,more like Cola.Frothy/big tan head reduces to a thin layer on top,like mentioned-lasts to the bottom.Nice coffee notes,Nice roast not burnt like some, mixed with an earthy,I wanna say grassy smell to it,prolly the oatmeal. Nice creamy texture,smooth with a slight bitterness near the end.balanced-not too sweet. Mellow Coffee flavor with hints of choco,milk choco more so than bitter sweet choco. Tobacco,roast after taste,nice..... A very nice, mellow smooth drinkable stout. Will definitely be revisited in future

Bottle with Nick. Dark brown pour, tan head. Roasty malt nose, rich mocha. Light sweet flavor, great roasted malts, chocolate, dry coffee, light burnt wood. Medium bodied, chewy, with average carbonation. Roasty finish, mild brown sugar, tobacco and scorched malts. Earthy bitterness in the throat Extremely solid. Can¬ít really fault this.

22oz bottle into a De Struise glass...Dark brown pout, light tan head, ok retention, not mcuh lacing...Aroma is way to light, a little chocolate comes through, light grass, and a little alcohol...Taste brings about more flavor, a good feeling to the beer, but the taste is not as sweet as I would expect for an oatmeal stout. The more it warms it becomes very bitter, way to bitter for a drinkable stout, alcohol comes through too much.

A disappointing stout, not a worthy of an a- let alone being ranked as a top 100 beer based on these nutty rankings.

One of the best stouts out there. A nice thick black pour with a thick tan head. Aroma of chocolate, malt, coffee, and oats. Flavor is chocolately, a little bitter, malty, and smooth. Fantastic stuff!

22 oz. bottle from iTap-Soulard. Pours a deep, dark cola brown with a thin but resilient tan head that settles into a creamy little ring that lasts all the way down. Aroma of roasted malts, earthy hops, milk chocolate, toast, and mild coffee. Flavor of mild coffee roast, chocolate, roasted malts, brown sugar, toast, earth, and wood. Medium-bodied, with moderate carbonation and a roasty, earthy mouthfeel. Dry finish. One of the most frequently rated beers I hadn¬ít tried yet, it was about time I tried this. Not bad.

Pours a very dark brown with a creamy, light brown head that lasts.  Dark chocolate aroma with notes of dark toast and earthy hops.  Toasty bittersweet chocolate flavor up front that develops into a dark espresso with some earthy hops then a long bitter coffee finish.  Smooth, medium body with fine carbonation.  Overall, a very nice stout.
Roasty flavor, with coffee and chocolate notes. Very dark brown with a medium head. Bitter, but not overwhelmingly so.
Black of color with a small brown head. An aroma of roasted coffee, smoke, bisquit and weak citrus hops. Flavour of black coffee, dark chocolate, grass and roasted.
Sample.  On nitro.  Creamy stout, looks gorgeous.  Taste is a great blend of coffee, roasty malts, and slight chocolate.  Lactic mouthfeel.

Pours with a dark chocolate color and a small head from the tap. There is a subtle hop aroma with a strong charcoal kick. Initially, there is a heavy BBQ flavor that flows into a light hop bitterness on the finish.

This beer looks almost straight black to me.  Most have ruby highlights, but this one had light brown highlights.  This is quite possibly the darkest beer I¬íve ever seen.  Smooth and creamy head, but not overly large.  Good retention and worth while lacing.  Some dark roasted malt.  Hints of a cocoa powder type chocolate.  Some coffee notes, but not enormous.  Rather subdued really.  Some sweetness breaks through from the chocolate.  The taste brought forth the roasted malt.  Almost smokey in flavor.  The coffee is more pronounced in the taste and the chocolate is there and balanced in admirably.  I actually almost get a dry walnut type of flavor.  A small bit of bitterness also.  Not as creamy as I was expecting.  Medium to medium/full mouthfeel.  Very dry and mostly smooth.  A little bit of sharpness from the coffee.  Cloaks the palate fantastically.  This beer is most definitely worth one¬ís time and effort.  Good all aorund.  More than solid.  Easily drinkable.  It could almost be a session brew, that¬ís how easy it went down.  Perfect for a chilly evening or afternoon.  Would even be good as a night cap.
A very tasty oatmeal stout. Pours nice and black with a thin black head. The flavor is nice and roasty, just a touch of burnt. Not too bitter, very easy to drink.

650ml bottle. Pours a rich, very dark brown with a reddish-tan head. Aroma and taste had a strong coffee flavour to it, with a bitter bite in the end. A tad thin in mouthfeel. Finish is lingering and enjoyable. Decent.

The beer has got a very dark, opaque brown body, with a rich brown head. Wonderful lacing and impressive head retention. A truly beautiful stout!

A pronounced earthy hoppiness really fights for the main role in the aroma. However, the strong roasted malt profile is still the dominant. Dark chocolate and coffee, with some toasted bread notes.

The taste is kind of coarse at first, with a very pronounced bitterness and coffee notes. However, after a few moments, it becomes much smooth and a bit more complex. It has a very rich roasted malt profile, with almost tobacco-like notes. Dark chocolate, espresso, a bit of licorice, and oatmeal. The finish is bitter and malty. As the beer warms up, you may get some nice sweetness and a smoother finish. Tasty, yet very roasty, so not necessarily a beer for all.

Medium-bodied. Some carbonation can be felt at first. No real feel of alcohol. Not the most pleasant mouthfeel, yet it is quite alright.
For such a hoppy and bitter stout, this goes down very well. I would not call this a session stout, but this is certainly very drinkable nonetheless.

Pours almost black with tan head.  Nice lacing.  Aroma is chocolate, roasted malts, and a hint of smoke.  Taste is briefly sweet with chocolate bitterness and coffee dominating afterward.  A very nice stout.

A: Pours essentially black with a dense, creamy tan head. Nice sticky lacing to go with it.

S: Tons of roasted malts on the nose with a strong earthy hop aroma. Plenty of bitter dark chocolate and cocoa powder as well. Not much sweetness, maybe some burnt sugar.

T: A moderate level of bitterness with lots of earthy hop flavor to go with it. Cocoa powder and bitter, baker¬ís chocolate are definitely there. Quite a lot of roasted malt flavor as well.

M: Medium in body with a moderate level of carbonation. Was expecting a bit more silky mouthfeel, though.

D: Like a lot of Rogue beers, this is good, but not amazing and not really worth the price they charge.

UPDATED: OCT 29, 2011 Bottle from Mane Liquor. Pours a very dark brown with a two finger tan head. The head mellows down pretty quickly, leaves some good lacing. Aromas of liquorice, chocolate, roast coffee. Taste begins with a slight hoppiness that smoothes out into a bitter chocolate, roasty finish. Good stuff

This is a great beer. One of my favorites from Rogue. Which is alot with such a big offering from them. Just delicious stout not overwhelming on the oatmeal part but there with chocolate and malts. Very tasty, almost like dessert. One, two, or three that is the question.

On tap at pour 24 in Las Vegas¬ís NY NY. Pours a black with a medium thick brown head. Smells of smoked malts and finishing hops. Has a very slight hoppy start with a deep smoked malt and coffee finish. Has hints of Chocolate and oats. Pretty darn good stout!
UPDATED: MAR 14, 2011 Smell of roast, coffee, and cigarette ashes. Taste is not far off, with a bit of acidity.

Bottle. Black with a thin tanned head. Smells of chocolate, liquorice and coffee. Taste is much same as aroma. Sweet body with a bitter finish of burned malts. An oily feel in mouth. Finish is intense and bitter of cascade hops. Interesting with both hop and malt bitterness together.
(bottle) very dark brown, small brown head; aroma of longan, plum; dry, rich flavour, long medium bitter finish, excellent
Very, very smooth, not too sweet, malty, a great stout, among the best in America.

Pours black with a thick brown head that leaves impressive lacing. The aroma consists of roasty, coffee, chocolate, smoke, vanilla, and a little spiciness of clove or ginger. Tastes slightly sweet and moderately sour with a dry and bitter finish.

Pours a super thick, slow liquid.  Black with a coffee colored, one finger head with good lacing.  

Smells mega heavy.  Deep, dark, and thick roasted malt aroma.  Oats and chocolate and a big dose of coffee.

Big roast bill on the taste.  Thick and chewy.  Dry oat flavor, pumpernickel and chocolate sweetness, and then huge coffee.  

A big, thick, slow-drinking beer.  Drinks like an imperial stout.  No alcohol flavor but the heaviness seems more like a 10% abv than 6%.  An impressive stout.

Chocolate and coffee malt, earthy aroma. Maybe a bit of licorice. Black of color, tan, frothy head. medium sweetness and bitter. Full body, creamy texture, soft carbonation. Long finish. Overall a very good stout.

Bottle. Poured black with a very large light brown rocky head that was mostly diminishing and had good lacing. The aroma was of burnt cereal malts, mild resin hops and an earthy doughy yeast with strong notes of coffee and dark chocolate. It tasted mildly sweet with a hint of coffee at first then went to a slightly bitter-sweet coffee flavor that had a nice hint of chocolate and  was mildly hoppy at the finish with the flavor lingering for an average amount of time. Mouthfeel was full in body and creamy in texture with a flat carbonation. Overall a nice stout, great on a cold winters night.
Pours a dark black with a medium tan head. Aroma is sweet coffee and oat. Taste is dark fruits, oatmeal and coffee. Palate has a light mouthfeel but goes down smooth. Overall a pretty decent brew.
One of my favorite stouts. The chocolate notes are very present but not overpowering. Very well balanced brew.
22 ounce bottle.  Pours almost black with a nice tan head.  Aroma of roasted malt and chocolate.  Taste is an excellent balance of hops, chocolate and coffee.  Very well done.  Excellent.
Bottle. Almost all black color, light tanned head. Aroma of coffeeand lots of burnt malt. Finished off by a sweet chocolate and hops. Nice touch!

Pours a thin black, with a decent amount of head. Smells of bits of coffee, and generally of pleasant dirt, a little bit of pine in there too. Tastes very earthy, with chocolate and oatmeal sourness in there a bit. Thin texture was pleasing in this case, this was an easily likable beer.

Drinking during what I hope will be an Oregon National Championship victory. Nose is slightly roasty, maybe some earthy coffee, bordering on unpleasant but passable. Taste is an improvement, earthy and piney hop characteristics with a slight dark malt sweetness. Finish is dry and clean. Not as good as I remember.

Bottle. Pour is dark brown near black with a dark kahki head that dissapears to a ring. Aroma is sweet and toasty malt and some faint bitter scent. Taste is dry and chaulky with some burnt coco and malt flavor that is bitter. Palate has a fizzy chaulky feel that finishes chaulky and dry.

It pours a black color with a little brown hue¬ís on the bottom edges. It has 1 finger tan head and a bunch of carbonation, small amounts of lacing.

On the nose I am getting a good dose of oatmeal,chocolate notes. Nothing really that overpowering.

The flavor is similar to the aroma. I am getting some good doses roasted malt, oatmeal, chocolate. No element is more overpowering than the other. It¬ís nice a well balanced beer with a great creamy feel.

It finishes with a lingering bitterness. As far as oatmeal stouts go this is one of better ones I have had. Rogue never fails to disappoint and a another great offering.

(null)
Malt: caramel, nuts, molasses, roasty
Hops: resin
Yeast/Bacteria: dough, earthy
Color: black
Liquid: cloudy
Head: frothy, white
Initial: light bitterness
Finish: light bitterness, light sweetness
Finish Duration: long
Body: medium
Texture: creamy
Carbonation: soft
Finish: long
22oz bottle...Pours very dark basically black with a brown head. Smells and tastes chocolaty. Also has some nice toasted notes.

(22 ounce bomber - tumbler glass)  Apperance is black with beige head. Aroma is of chocolate malt with a quiet hoppieness.  Tastes of chocolate and oatmeal.  Velvety texture,  Flat carbonation and smooth bitter dry chocolatey finish.

UPDATED: DEC 25, 2010 Pours black with a small beige head. Sweet oatmeal aroma. Roasted malt and oatmeal flavour with a faint chocolate note. Nice thick palate and texture. I appreciate that this is a well made and complex beer, I can see why others like this, but I can¬ít get into the flavour of oatmeal.
Poured a great dark brown / black color. Light brown head. Little bitter from the choclate but not overpowering.

Pours very dark brown with a small tan head. Aroma is of oats, very hard to detect if it wasn¬ít for the name. Teste is that of a traditional stout with a slight tinge of oat flavor. It¬ís ok for a stout, would like to see some more complexity in the taste but overall not a bad beer.

Pours dark brown almost black hue with a light brown frothy head. Aroma is a little smoky and diffcult to pinpoint for me. Taste is a nice smooth bitterness bite then a over the top smoke finish. Nice body. Decent stout , not one of my tops.
This is a very delicious stout. Has a dark appearance with a brown head. This stout is heavy but not to bad has a satisfying taste and a very pleasant bang.

Delicious.  (see some of our other reviews for more witty expos¬íe)

~3 of 13

A: Pours a near black with a nice brown head.

S: Plenty of coffee and chocolate alongside some roasted malt characteristics and a little bit of earthy bitterness.

T: Roasted malts is definitely the dominatnt flavor melding together with chocolate and coffee. All this is a bit balanced out by some earthy, citrus hops.

M: Medium bodied and fairly chewy.

D: Everything here was good, but for some reason it just really wasn¬ít drawing me back for more.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 05-07-2010

A smooth dark pour with a light tan head. Definite notes of coffee and motor oil come through in the first sniff. Smooth, full body with a well balanced malt and hop character. Slightly dry on the finish. Overall a great oatmeal stout!

Almost pitch-black with a mocca coloured foam
Aroma; Coffeebeans, chocolate, toasted malt, a hint of sweet lemonzest
Flavour; Rich and creamy mouthfeel, same flavours as on the nose. Good aftertaste, but alittle hollow in the mid-palate
Summary; This was bottled in 08, have had it in the cellar for 1 1/2 years. I really good beer, but alittle unbalanced.

Aroma of hops, roasted malt, coffee and chocolate. Taste of roasted malt with a vaguely burnt tone, crisp hops bitterness and chocolate tones. I can not, however, find the soft tone of oatmeal, which should have been clearer. A fine beer, but it is somewhat thin to be an Oatmeal Stout!

Refrigerated bottle poured into a shaker.  Pours opaque black with dark brown highlights with medium brown head.  Medium lacing and medium carbonation.  Taste is malt (mostly chocolate) and finish is bitter hops.  Aroma is chocolate and hops and medium body.  Based on the rating this beer is dissapointing, get a samuel smith oatmeal stout.

Clear but very dark brown pour, dark brown head with scattering of large bubbles.  Good toasted malty aroma.  Good amount of bitter with the taste, gives structure to the toasted maltiness, and while there¬ís a twist of sweet at the finish, the toasted malt and good level of bitter drown it out.  I like it, and not as overpowering as some of the bigger stouts I¬íve tried.

Pours black with a large creamy brown head. Aroma of hops and roasty malt. Taste has more citrus than expected. It still has lots of dark chocolate bitterness even though the hops are more prevalent than most Stouts. Thick texture, full carbonation.
Whiskey bar, Seattle. Super dark, with a creamy head. Slightly more bitter than I expected, almost tasting burnt.

UPDATED: SEP 27, 2011 Bottle at Hashigo Zake

Pours clear, dark brown with orange highlights with dark brown head and good lacing; medium amount of carbonation, almost creamy, big body, lightly astringent finish. Dark chocolate, dark roots and coffee aromas, bitter and no discernible sweetness; Very enjoyable.


Noteworthy

#1500Bomber, shared with Tonycaviar on a tasting session organised by American Hop Growers at Brau-Beviale-Nuremberg.
Deeep brown near black one with a fantastic, compact and foamy, creamy beige-brown head. Dark chocolate, cocoa, deep roasted malts with some wood and coffee in the aroma. Medium bodied with a dry vinous character, dark chocolate and coffee, dried dark fruits like plum. Dry, burnt wood and roasted aftertaste.

Pours a nice dark brown/black with a thick 1/4 inch head.  Aroma is nice, but there¬ís not much there some malt and coffee.  Taste is medium to full bodied, nice with coffee and roasted malt, molasses.  Decent, but not stellar.

Bottle. Superdark, nice tan head. This was the beer that started it all for me - named a top beer in some obscure beer guide I picked up in the mid-90¬ís, and one I unexpectedly found in the local liquor store not long after. Aroma chocolate, roasty, coffee, but nothing like I remember from that first time. Has it changed, or have I? Still, it will always have a sentimental spot in my heart.

Roasty licorice scent, fairly mild. Appearance is black with medium small brown head. Taste is roasty forward, nutty, chocolate, burnt, coffee, mild sweetness. Palate is medium+. Burnt flavor lingers. Overall not bad. Not smooth or rich enough for my preference in an oatmeal stout.
Doft och smak av kaffe och mj√∂lk (tydligen havren som ger den lite mj√∂lkaktiga smaken). Smaken √§r ganska br√§nd och har tydliga referenser till stark kaffe.

slightly dissapointing; no aroma; great dark cola color with beige head.
Solid taste - roastedness and smooth flavor like oatmeal do...

disspaointment was the palate - this was watery/thin compared to all other oat stouts...

Sampled at the Top of the Hops Beer Festival, Charlottesville, VA, 9/11/10. Pours a dark brown color with a medium head. Nutty aroma with roasted malts and caramel. the taste is bitter citrus hops, bitter roasted malts and faint smoke. Medium bodied.
Dark, sweet, light on the palate.  Deep chocolate and coffee undertones.  Bottomless dark color with a minimal white head.  Could stand for more flavor.

Poured black with a smaller tan head.  Aroma is mostly chocolate with coffee and cherries.  Not as much oatmeal as I expected.  Taste is quite bitter and chocolaty.  Body is a little thin, but still flavorful.  Some dark fruit upfront, and then it transitions into a coffee/oatmeal finish.  A little one dimensional, but still quite tasty.  I would have liked a little bit more sweetness and oatmeal.

22oz bomber.  Poured a near black body with a bubbly tan head that was creamy and left lots of lacing. Aromas of heavily roasted malt, cocoa, alcohol, fresh coffee and some red wine sourness.  Flavor of fresh coffee, cream, bittersweet chocolate and a medium bitter finish.  Fine, soft carbonation and a thin to medium mouthfeel.  More body puts this one into the 4.0 range.

(Sample Date: 10/20/2010   Source:Other)   Resiny hops over moderate caramel with some chocolate and roast notes. Clear almost black with medium tan head. Flavor follows aroma with resiny floral hops in the front. Some roast and chocolate. Medium body and mouth feel. Finish is hops with a touch of roast and a light astringency and moderately bitter.

Poured into a pint glass. Black body with a tan head that lingers atop the beer through it¬ís entirety. Aroma is of hops and dark chocolate. Taste is of dark chocolate, oatmeal, and an unexpected hoppy finish. All around a good beer but not necessarily great. Definitely a beer to have again though.
Sample at Beer Geeks in Highland, IN.  Two finger head.  Smells chocolate, vanilla, sweet.  Hoppier than a guinness.  Dark brew with tan head.  Sweet stout.  Good brew..

Tap at SBWF, cons 2010-10-08, Nacka
AR: strawberries, roasted malt, coffee
AP: black body, wee white head
F: thin smoke, chocolate/coffe, great bitterness

Poured from a 22 ounce bomber into a Samuel Adams Perfect Pint glass. 

Appearance: Pours a motor oil black with a 2 finger creamy chocolate brown head. Excellent lacing. Looks pretty much perfect for a stout.

Smell: Toasted malt, coffee, burnt toast and chocolate with a hint of hops in the background.

Taste: A hint of sweet chocolate up front followed by coffee, toasted malt and dark chocolate in the middle then ending burnt toast. Aftertaste is bitter hops. Flavor really comes out as it warms up.

Mouthfeel: Full-bodied with a good amount of carbonation. Nice and creamy.

Drinkability: High drinkability. You could knock back a few glasses of this on a chilly evening.

Overall: Excellent beer overall. I would recommend trying it if you¬íve never had it.

Pours with heavy, full, brown head. Good amount of head right out of the bottle, sticks around quite a while. Smell is of bitter chocolate, malts, caramel and some light notes of oatmeal. Not much oatmeal in the nose, however more comes out as it warms and brew is swirled. First taste is dark chocolate and malt. Nice smooth taste, with some oatmeal but very feint. Oatmeal becomes more apparent as the beer warms and swirled, similar to nose. Overall a wonderful dark stout with great flavor and depth, nice body, smell and appearance. Would highly recommend for anyone a fan or Rogue, stouts, or craft beer in general!

Pours dark brown/black with off white head, aroma is chocolate, coffee, oat, touch of pine.  Taste is some nice hops up front, leading into a bit of watery roast, chocolate, coffee, and a oat finish.  Pretty good, a bit thin but overall good.

Bottle from Vinmonopolet (Sandaker), Oslo. Two-inch, dense beige head, reducing slowly, leaving coarse lacework. Black colour. Nice, complex, surprisingly fruity and hoppy aroma including smoked wood and some Belgian-style sweetness. Taste has a distinct oatiness, well balanced. Mouthfeel is a bit light and watery, quite fizzy carbonation. Dry, bitter finish with licorice and coffee.

UPDATED: DEC 18, 2010 Bottle.

A - Dark black with deep walnut hues on the edge. A fairly large, sticky, cloudy, frothy cafe colored head. A bit above average retention that settles into a thin layer of lace and then later just a ring of lace.

S - Very nice smelling with plenty of coffee aroma and a fair amount of hops as well with citrus being strongest but some others. Some chocolate/cocoa and some other roasted aromas. Good amount of earthy aroma.

T - Taste is similar to the nose, but it isn¬ít as enjoyable or as good as I had hoped for in comparison to the nose. Coffee and roasted barley and oats provide a lot of the flavor. Pretty well hopped as well with some citrus and earthy flavors being the strongest. Some sweet chocolate and a touch of caramel.

M - Medium body with a good amount of carbonation. Smooth and fairly creamy and chewy feel. Pretty good but not the best feel in regards to other oatmeal stouts.

D - Pretty easy to drink beer and tasty. Although with the onslaught of roasted flavors and hops make it a bit more difficult to keep drinking it all night.

Notes: A nice beer with a lot of roasted and hop flavors. Lots of coffee flavors as well. I thought this was a good beer and it was tasty, but it wasn¬ít top notch.
In bottle; aroma of brown sugar. Taste starts with a chocolate note, finishing with a hint of oatmeal and espresso acidic/bitterness. Overall a good beer.

A-pours a near opaque black liquid with a bubbly khaki colored head.

S-the nose brings some roasted malt, a little chalky, hints of ash, a light chocolate malt with notes of burnt coffee, a fair citric hop presence in the back.

T-the taste has a huge roasted malt presence, light chocolate malt, a nice citric hop presence with plenty of coffee bitterness in the finish.

M-smooth and creamy on the palate with a medium body, very inviting and easy to drink, well carbonated crisp rough finish.

D-great representation of the style, creamy texture, good flavors, well balanced hop profile, really a tasty drink.
Very nice dark brown color.  Nice espresso head.  Good amount of chocolate notes.  Smooth with a hint of alcohol.  Lovely dessert beer.  Oatmeal adds a light touch.

22 oz Bottle: Pours a Dark Brown, with a mild tan head. Smells of chocolate, like the chocolate stout; flavors are chocolate as well, but the bite comes off of the oatmeal this time, with some coffee and malt once again. Like the chocolate stout, i was surprised at how watery/thin this brew was. I enjoyed it overall

22oz bottle: Pours a dark black with a chocolate head. Aroma is of chocolate malt and coffee. Taste is a nice balance of deep chocolate, cream and American hops. Beer is just a little thin for my preference, but very good overall.
Bottle from Bierkoning. Dark black body with tan top. Nose quite rough, some hops. Taste of chocolate, plenty of hops. Really yummy. Bit watery in the consistency. Nice one.

Bottle at Olympen in Oslo, July 2010.

Dark with a good looking head. Sweat with aroma and taste of milk, coffee, chocolate. Easy to drink and not bad at all, although not heavy in any way.
Tr√®s bonne IS, bon go√ªt de malt et de houblon. Dommage qu¬íelle ne soit pas disponible encore au Qu√©bec!

Good-looking pour with a foamy head.  Aroma was mostly yeast with some esters.  Shakespeare is a pretty dry and earthy, with a noticeable yeasty flavor.  It reminds me a little of Arrogant Bastard - there must be some similar Rogue touches in the brewing.  A nice medium weight stout.

In a word, nice.  Dark pour from bottle with little head.  Nose and taste  is bitter chocolate and burnt wood.  Creamy mouthfeel, with a warm, not overpowering finish.  At 6% abv, it is a lighter choice to reach for when you are not in the mood for a bigger stout.
Draught at Pour 24, LV. Rich, bitter and hugely dark chocolate tasting. Burnt malt dominates and the finsh almost borders on the acidic, but in a good way! A big, big beer......
Bottled sample at Freakin Frog in Las Vegas. Shared it with some great guys and we all loved it

I had this on tap while staying at the Rogue Bed & Beer in Newport, OR.  What stuck out in this for me was the appearance.  Holy creaminess, it¬ís pure black with a rich creamy head.  Aroma was light with tones of alcohol and malt with small chocolate notes.  Taste was fantastic, very creamy, I was getting coffee, chocolate, and lactose into the mixture, like an oatmeal stout should be.  Very very good stuff and would definitely have again.
Pours a dark smooth black body with a smooth tan head.  Aroma is light malt.  Taste is bitter chocolate, oats, malt and a little to much hops.

Velvety in texture, hearty in complexion, and decadent in taste, this Rogue concoction is dessert bliss. A richly-whipped caramel head gets sudsy up top, while the rest of the beer gets black as coffee grinds. The taste is perfectly reminiscent of Rogue¬ís Chocolate Stout, as they share the same bakery-like flavors. The chocolate has no problem flushing over the tongue; it¬ís almost like a cocoa levee breaking on your taste buds. Feverishly tasty, this guy goes down nice and easy.

22 oz. bottle- Pours pitch black with a nice frothy tan head, aroma is chocolate malt. The flavor is a robust stout with subtle creamy oatmeal flavors and a hint of chocolate malt, a superior stout, but I was hoping to be blown away, and I just wasn¬ít, still a damn good beer.

Surpirsed I haven¬ít rated this yet.  This was one of the first Rogue beers I tried and it has since been a goto.  Pours stout like with a fine head that dissipated given time.  Aroma is full of roasted malts and a hint of hops.  It drinks smooth with a nice creamy mouthfeel, light to medium carbonation.  The oats in this one help it achieve greatness.  A great stout without all the bells and whistles of other popular stouts.  A wonderful example of the style, top notch offering from Rogue.

On tap at the Happy Gnome, Saint Paul, MN. Dark chocolate brown and very opaque; tight tan head. Smells of dark, bitter chocolate but has a commanding presence of earthy/citrus hops. Earthy chocolate on the tongue, definitely creamy; there¬ís a mellow bitterness, too. Good balance but the hops are a bit too showy here for me.
Bottle 50 cl. Black with a nice lightbrown head. Aroma; sweet malty with some hoppy sences and dark fruits. Taste; sweet, dark fruits, plumb, nice. TEsed apr 2010.
Head is very dark (so is the beer). Mildy bitter stout flavor and aroma. Still not my favorite style, but good for what it is.

black with large, long lasting brownish head. aroma strong chocolate. taste has little sweetness up front, big chocolate bitterness on finish, lingering chocolate flavor. heavy body, creamy, just a bit sticky.
Bottle. Black pour with a small brown head. Scent of roasted coffee, smoke, and hops. Taste of coffee. Outstanding with a pizza!

65cl bottle from Vinmonopolet. It poured a pitch black colour. Big light-brown creamy head. Carbonated. Aroma is dark roasted coffee, oatmeal, some liqorice and dark chocolate. Flavour is slightly bitter, dark roasted coffee, dark chocolate, and liqorice. A bit thin and watery. Medium long aftertaste.
Best stout I have ever had.  Deep and grainy with lots and lots of character.  Chocolate at the end.  Very good.
The aroma is pleasantly sour.  The foam is creamy and the beer dark.  The flavor is creamy and smooth.

650ml bottle. Pours black with a thick brown head that leaves impressive lacing in its wake. The aroma consists of roasty, coffee, chocolate, smoke, vanilla, and a little spiciness of clove or ginger. Tastes slightly sweet and moderately sour with a dry and bitter finish.

Chocolate and roasted malts on the nose with hints of coffee.  Pours black with a thin tan head that dissipates.  Bitter and hoppy upfront with dark bitter chocolate notes hints of tobacco with creamy vanilla.  Not bad.
A modest sort of beer that isn¬ít overpowering. Good combination of chocolate and roast flavors with a mild to moderate bitterness on the backend. Nice.

24.05.2010, 0,65l Bottle. Dark brown, almost black in colour with thick firm tan head. This beer is bitter, very bitter. Aroma is dark malty, and it is roasted and bitter. Its also dry, like bitter dry dark chokolate. This is a very nice stout.

Black pour tan creamy head .... lots of lacing .... aroma of roasted and chocolate malts ..... very smooth and silky taste of roasted malts and chocolate a good balance of the two so its not too sweet but not too roasted and a light bitter finish .... very well done great stout
Black with dark brown head - aroma of roasted malt - same roasted malt body with a nice and smooth ending - very nice

Bomber poured into imperial pint.  Color of darkest brown and tan foam head.   Coffee, chocolate and roasted malts.  Hops at the end and a lasting carmel/coffee aftertaste.   Must have for any fan of stouts.
By far my new favorite!, I am a huge fan of Oatmeal stouts and this one takes the top, full body, thick feel, soft carbonation, coffee, nuts, vanilla, black, brown foam,

Pours dark brown out of the bottle and is near-black in the glass. Small light brown head. Nose is typical dark chocolate/ roasted oat for a stout with a hint of hops. Flavor is similar and fairly strong...seems to be higher on the IBUs than most other stouts I¬íve had. Medium finish with a little extra chocolaty sweetness to it. Heavy and solid but honestly nothing all that different from other quality stouts I¬íve had beyond the hops (which really doesn¬ít add that much to it).
Great beer. Pours a jet black in the glass. Nose and taste of roasted nuts, oats, chocolate malts. Rated 11/3/2000

How haven¬ít I rated this before?  Bottle, Goodbar beer club.    Black body, tan head.  Nose is roasty malt, sweet caramel, milky with a little smoke & some nice green hop.  Flavor follows aroma - roasty, a tiny but burnt, toffee & caramel.  A bit of that hop character comes out in the finish.

Pours a jet black body with a thin white head. My nose gets toasted malts with hints of sweet, fruity hops. Taste is surprisingly light, the oat is not heavily present but appears to a certain extent in the backdrop. Very drinkable, but not as much flavor as the imperials. Strong notes of cascade hops that I don¬ít really like in certain combinations (Anchor Christmas Brew being the prime example) pulls down my rating a bit, although this is an ok brew by most standards. I still think the rating here is vastly exaggerated.

On tap at Monk¬ís in Sioux Falls-Black with small tan head.  Nose of malt chocolate.  Taste is similar but with noticeable coffee notes.  Nice and thick like a stout should be with minimal carbonation.  This made a good finish to the night.

Black body.
Aroma: Chocolate, coffe, tar. Robust and complex.
Flavor: chocolate, coffe, burnt malt, milk, hops.
This one is medium bodied.

650ml bottle, 6.5% ABV, from Vinmonopolet Troms√∏ Sentrum. Attractive appearance with a beige- brown, frothy, steady head. Great lacework, too. Devil-black body. Sweet aroma of chocolate malts with a touch of anise. Well blended taste of coffee and dark chocolate malts and a bite of roasted grain. Fine dark bitter fruits to the ending. Not more than medium bodied and easy to drink. Satisfying stout enjoyed for almost two hours during Valborgaften 2010.
Chocolate and roasted nose.   Deep black with dark tan head.  Nice thick roasty, chocolatey  flavor with an earthy finish that lasts.  Excellent!

Bottle.  Pours a very dark brown with a nice brown head that dissipates fairly quickly leaving plenty of nice lacing.  Dry.  Very chocolaty, roasted malts, burnt coffee.  Taste is also dry, full-bodied and dark with no surprises based on the nose.  Overall a very well done stout.

Pours a thick, opaque nutty brown with light frothy tan head. Aroma is brown sugar, chocolate and grains. Flavor is rather hoppy, a mix of citrus/pine with bready note and bitter finish. Body is light with medium carbonation.

650 ml bottle from Volo. Nice stout! Pours black with small amount of tan head. Nose of roasty coffee, malt, and a bit of chocolate. Taste of roasted coffee and malt up front followed by a hint of hop bitterness. Smooth finish.

Pous deep chocolate brown with quick thinning brown head. Great bottle! Smells chocolatey, with roastey notes. Really good smell. Taste is chocolate, malt and coffee, but not too bitter. A really, really tastey beer IMHO.

A- deep brown almost black body with thick dark brown head. Leaves behind plenty of lacing. It almost looks ominous in the glass.

S- Coffee, malt, and hints of chocolate emerge in the smell.

T- Roasted coffee and malt up front followed by a hint of hop bitterness. The finish is of coffee and a hint of dark chocolate.

P- medium carbonation and a nice thick body. Pretty smooth.

O- This was good. Very drinkable. It still a sipper since it is a stout; but it is a very interesting and complex beer. Recommended.

Serving type: on-tap

Reviewed on: 05-24-2007 04:00:23

Thanks Nordcore!
Appearance: Very dark brown, almost black. Some tan head.
Aroma: Dark malt, smoke. Roasted.
Taste: Very dark malt. Burnt. Dark fruit. Quite bitter.
Info: 650ml bottle, 2/4-2010, 208/300

5.99USD from strip liquor in Las Vegas (north of Wynns/Encore casino). 22oz Bomber. 6%ABV. This unfortunately was not savoured in a glass (strip walk beverage) and subsequently not enjoyed to it¬ís full potential. From the small opening i was able to admire the aromas to a lesser extent; some citrus from the cascade, however mostly chocolate and roasted malts. As my experience continued with this beer, the head remained an inch thick until the lesser part of the bottle, carbonation was medium-low. Medium mouthfeel showcasing chocolate, roasted and sweet malt flavours with cascade hop flavour quite predominant in the initial stages. The oats present allow a very smooth creamy finish, ensuring your willingness for the next taste. Not all that complex, but that¬ís a job for the Russian Imperials. This is an excellent beer which i look forward to savouring again.. this time in a glass.

UPDATED: SEP 30, 2012 One of the ways I measure my enjoyment of a beer is by how much I would like to drink more of it. In the case of Rogue Shakespeare Stout, simply drinking a 22oz bomber was not NEARLY enough. This is exactly what I look for in a beer: a strong flavor that caters to the discriminating beer drinker while also being easy to drink and surprisingly light in weight. I know lightweights won¬ít like it, which in turn makes me enjoy it even more.POUR, COLOR AND AROMAThe beer poured a little rough and formed a nearly pitch-black opaque body with a thick, creamy head which lasted for quite a while and left quite a lot of lacing on the glass. It scent was odd for a stout with a deep roasted quality detectable in the nose as well as a significant hoppy component. So many stouts tend to be weak and flat in scent, but Shakespeare Stout is quite vocal.TASTEThere¬ís only one word that comes to mind when it comes to describing the taste of this beer: roasty. I often associate stouts with having a dry, bitter flavor with some roasty quality. But in the case of Shakespeare Stout the opposite seems to be true. This is a beer whose roasty flavor is quite pronounced, balanced with a creamy core which mixes coffee and chocolate flavors to give it a subtle, smooth, sweet finish. Its rare I come across this beer that is so intense in taste and still makes proper usage of its hoppy side. Usually, I associate an India Pale Ale with the high IBU rating of 69 this beer has, That a stout can be this bitter and this tasty without coming off as bland and dry is quite an accomplishment.FINISHFor a highly-hopped beer, Shakespeare Stout is surprisingly smooth and easy to drink. It does have a noticeable creaminess to its taste, which probably accounts for its smooth finish.BODYStouts are often thought of as being ¬ìheavy¬î beers which is not necessarily true (Guinness has only 15 more calories than Bud Light). At 6% ABV, Shakespeare Stout is only slightly more potent than your average beer. I¬ím not sure how many calories it has, but for such a dark beer it is surprisingly light on your system. That¬ís another sign of quality, though ¬ñ not overwhelming the drinker.FINAL THOUGHTSRogue Shakespeare Stout is what I would consider a beer for serious drinkers only. The flavor is quite complex and intense that it¬ís better for sipping, not chugging. I drank mine as slowly as possibly trying to savor the craftsmanship that was put into making this such a great beer.NOTE: watch the video version of this review at:http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=fF2S1pk_YAQ

Pours almost pitch black with a persistent thick tan head.  Aromas of caramel, chocolate, plums, and burnt sugar.  Taste is coffee, caramel,  nuttiness, and fruit, finishing with medium herbal bitterness.  Light to medium body with soft carbonation.  Different from what I was expecting, but nice.

An oatmeal variant of their famous - and highly rated - Shakespeare Stout, which is one of my faves. It pours a beautiful opaque near-midnight black with a thick, fine-bubbled, persistent dark tan head. Strong aroma is richly of fine coffee and quality chocolate, very tempting. Flavor is like a fine mocha, quality roast coffee and good chocolate, not too sweet, hints of molasses. Texture is smooth, tingly and fizzy, leaving a slightly sweet and very pleasing finish. A must for stouties!Earlier Rating: 2/5/2008 Total Score: 5Absolutely fabulous! A rich sable, almost pitch black, with a nice thick and persistent head. Aroma is heavenly - strong, smoky, overtones of roast coffee and more than a hint of chocolate. Taste is like a fine mocha, with strong coffee and chocolate flavors and pleasant smoky/burnt hints. Texture is velvety smooth and most pleasing. It would be tough to improve this one!

UPDATED: DEC 17, 2010 Rogue Ales--Oregon Brewing Company--Warrior Ale--Dedicated to Richard Marcincko--2008 22 oz. Bottle Release. 6.25% ABV--69 IBU¬ís.	4.5 / 5.0 Stout--Dense lacy rich espresso head.  Opaque ebony color with bronze red edges.  Huge dense dark pellicle.  Rich floral Cascade hop roasted chocolate espresso front.  Tangy dry crusty earthy mild sweet roasted chocolate espresso rich Oat Stout body.  Dry hoppy spice end.  Sampled 12/9/2009.  2 @ $6.00 Each.Earlier Rating: 12/9/2009 Total Score: 4.2Brown Bear Stout--1997 12 oz. Bottle.  6.25% ABV.

Warrior Ale 2008 Release.  Tasty tangy hoppy espresso cocoa oat Stout.  Crusty rich body. Floral chocolate Cascade hop front.Clean balanced hop spice lingering chocolate end.  Dense lacy espresso head. Thick tight dense dark pellicle.Clear ebony black bronze red edge color.  Dry sweet.  Hoppy Stout.

Rogue Ales--Shakespeare Oatmeal Stout--2010 22 oz. Bottle.  5.78% ABV? Calculated from 15 Plato 77% AA Specification.  69 IBU¬ís.  (3.75 / 5.0)  Big dense lacy espresso head.  Tight thick sediment.  Opaque jet black color.  No edge.  Dry rich burnt espresso hop front.  Sediment adds creaminess to crusty burnt rich roasted no fruit dry Stout body.  Missing Oatmeal silk.  Too dry crisp hot hop clean Stout end.  Sampled 12/17/2010.  Purchase for $4.99 @ Fred Meyer--Ballard, Seattle on 12/16/2010.
22oz bottle. Deep dark brown pour with a cocco brown head. Roasted barley coffee rich flavor with a nice longlasting pallet.

22 oz bottle.  Pours opaque black in color, cocoa head.  The aroma is a little smokey, toasty like roasted coffee.  The flavor has a nice bitter character.  A medium body and a rich creamy mouthfeel make this well rounded.
Dark black in colour with toffee coloured head. Sligght diactyl on nose. Thin body. Dryer finish than chocolate stout. As warms up big hop bitterness comes through.
A decent stout, very very bitter. Looks very good and dark right out of the bottle with a thick head of foam you could rest your chin on.

Tasty beer, almost black in color with a tan head. Served in pint glass, strong coffee aroma emanating from the glass. Tasted like chocolate/coffee, the coffee taste was very dominant. A little herbal aftertaste too, not bad at all. Might want to tone down the bitter a bit though.

Had this awhile ago but wanted to try again so i could rate. awesome overall I would say. A deep foreboding black color with a tan head that fades into a thin top that laces down the sides. The aroma was a bit salty like olives but also a musky dusty leather like a pair of boots. The flavor was roasted malt with some grass and pine hop. palate was kind of watery for the style but light carbonation.
Pours black tan head, rummy sherry woody nose. Fluffy mouthfeel, dark chocolate brown sugar and coffee taste.

650 mL bottle served in a snifter. Pours black with a tall creamy brown head. Head fades quickly, leaving fair lace. Aroma is primarily burnt malts with a hint of pine hops. Notes of molasses, chocolate, coffee, earth, smoke and charcoal also present. Flavour is very dry throughout, with some chalk. Finish is long and dry, with some charred notes. Medium in body with a dry texture and lively carbonation. Overall, a fine brew but a bit dry; I feel like it would come together better with sweeter malts. Enjoyed this one @ TB¬ís, watching our men¬ís hockey team win Olympic gold. 2010-02-28

Tap at Clark St.  Pours a black hole of a beer with a finger of tight bubbles that don¬ít dissipate at all.  Malt, vanilla, and chocolate make up the bouquet.  Generally smooth and full-bodied but relatively unassuming.

22 oz bottle.  Dark brown with a pocked tan head.  Nose is chocolate, molasses and coffee with hints of dark fruit.  Medium body but feeling thinner with spritzy carb.  Taste is coffee, plum and burnt sugar with a grassy finish.

UPDATED: MAY 8, 2010 This was okay. The aroma was really good and it made me expect the beer to be as good. However, it was just your average stout (Meaning it¬ís good when compared to all beers but not so good when compared to other stouts). Flavors were leathery, smokey and  bitter. I don¬ít know where the "Oatmeal" part comes in. It didn¬ít have a creamy texture and it didn¬ít taste much like oats at all. It wasn¬ít that bad I just had higher expectations for it. Oh well. I didn¬ít hate drinking it but it could have been better.

22oz in bordeaux glass.  Deep black with medium brown head.  Very prominent roast, almost to the point of astringency, with a vague note of herbiage.  I¬íve had bottles of RSS previously which I remember having much more hop character than this, even to the point of being able to pick it up as Cascade.  Back to the sample at hand, flavor can be broadly described as a refreshing espresso.  Palate clears very rapidly for such a quantity of flavor-active congeners!  Faint praise follows: this is by far my favorite Rogue product so far.

Dark black body with a caramel-coffee colored head.  Strong toasty and roasted aroma with some bitter chocolate.  Rather carbonated initial mouth feel with a nice bitter body.  Bitter coffee flavor with some bitter toasty notes.  Nice bodied stout with a comfortable bitterness.

Big bottle, bought at Vinmonopolet.  Huge coffee head, slowly scrinking to a finger of foam.  Body is black with ruby highlights , limited clarity. Initial aroma of plummy fruitiness, an intense and extratced fruitiness, followed by a scent of  coffee, cocoa and roasted dark malts.  A fairly dry, cocoa-ish malt body with coffee and dry chocolate notes and a fine, dusty and straw-like hop bitterness.  Chalky mouthfeel.  Healthy body. Nice, semi-dry cocoa-malty ending. Very likable.
22 oz. bottle, pours deep black with a tan head. Aroma is espresso malts and chocolate. Flavour is smooth chocolate and rich espresso, with pretty much no bitterness. Great stout.

Bomber pours black with a fluffy brown head into a pint glass.  Great looking beer.  Malty aroma with a good bit of roastiness, coffee, and a touch of dark cocoa.  Smells good but seems thin.  This is a very, very coffee-like stout.  Dark roast dominates the taste; hearty base.  Only a slight addition of pure coca in the finish.  Medium bodied with a frothy mouthfeel and a low-medium level of carbonation.  Pretty tasty, but it¬ís so roasted that one pint is enough.
1pt 6oz bottle. pours a deep black colour with a nice rocky head.Taste is deep chocolate and mocha notes with a long, hoppy finish. Over all a complex and delicious stout.

Bottle. Solid black. Medium tan head that stays. Lots of chocolate aromas. Some coffee, roasted oats and more sweet chocolate. Long burnt and bitter taste. Notes of chocolate and malts. Roasted coffee, maybe espresso flavors as well. Medium to full bodied, well balanced through and through. Very solid brew.

Big brown lasting head. Black body goes dark brown at edges. Roasty chocolatey aroma with milky toffee notes. Dry roasty earthy chocolatey taste with rye notes. Fullish body. Mild, smoothish mouthfeel. Dry roasty earthy rye aftertaste with wood and resin notes. Malty rye crisp bread flavours linger. Interesting, but quite harsh and unforgiving. (0.65l bottle, wine monopoly.)

22oz. bottle.  pours jet black with an attractive off white head.  Aroma is filled with semi sweet chocolate, but not over bearing.  Roasted chocolate and slit bitterness round out this beer.  Carbonation is higher then normal with this stout.

I can¬ít imagine this beer looking better it¬ís a very dark chocolate color with a large creamy tight brown head that leaves plenty of lace. The aroma is coco powder some cream and lots of roasty notes. The flavor is nicely hoppy with a good chocolate character and some bitter burnt toast flavor; there is also a mild tone of smoky coffee. This is really not a very complex beer but it is fantastically put together.

650ml bottle, 15C. Pours very dark brown with a large tan head. Nose has sweet and roasted malts with vanilla, oats and cocoa. Burnt flavours briefly gives way to gentle sweetness, which yields to a bitter finish with cocoa and coffee notes. There is slightly more bitterness than the beer can handle, but it¬ís very good nonetheless.

Pours black with a thick tan head.  Excellent roasted malt and molasses aroma.  Feels like you¬íre about to be in for a big treat, but unfortunately the flavor is quite a letdown.  It weighs in at about  zero on the complexity scale, which is too bad, since it has great mouthfeel and bitterness is just right.

So, i¬ím not a bit stout fan.  This stout, however, is pretty tasty.  It wasn¬ít too bitter, as I have found to be an unappealing factor in many stout¬ís I¬íve tasted.  It had a great aroma, lots of nice sweet chocolaty notes.  It had a great mouth feel - not too carbonated, just the right density.  It was nice that the flavor wasn¬ít tinged with something.  So many stouts have these real flavors of chocolate or coffee, but this was kind of stand alone.. Very nice.
This beats Guinness any day.

Brown bottle, 650 ml, savoured on January 31 2010; eye: black, opaque, tiny sheet of cappuccino head, light lacing; nose: grain, dark chocolate, roasting, roasted malt, light burnt malt, lactic, coffee; mouth: grain, dark chocolate, roasting, roasted malt, light burnt malt, lactic, coffee, finale in roasted malt with presence of coffee, full body, mildly bitter, lightly lactic, light enjoyable acridness, slightly oily texture, average carbonation; overall: quite good

FRAN√áAIS

Bouteille brune, 650 ml, savour√©e le 31 janvier 2010; ¬úil : noire, opaque, petite couverture de mousse cappuccino, l√©g√®re dentelle; nez : grain, chocolat noir, torr√©faction, malt r√¥ti, l√©ger malt br√ªl√©, lactique, caf√©; bouche : grain, chocolat noir, torr√©faction, malt r√¥ti, l√©ger malt br√ªl√©, lactique, caf√©, finale en malt torr√©fi√© avec pr√©sence de caf√©, cors√©e, moyennement am√®re, l√©g√®rement lactique, l√©g√®re √¢cret√© agr√©able, texture l√©g√®rement huileuse, carbonatation moyenne; en r√©sum√© : bien bon

Black with a nice thick brown head that lasts for a little bit before fading into nothing. The smell is of chocolate, dark malts, roasted barley, and oats. The taste is very bitter but with a smooth malty and roasted finish. The taste is strong but the smoothness is outstanding.

Not as smooth as a nitrogenated stout, but this one is pretty smooth. Felt flat early on, and the khaki foam faded quickly.
 Chocolate, oatmeal, grain notes... all pretty strong.

Bottle. Pours black, with a small brown head. Aroma of earthy hops, burnt malts, sweet, dark fruits and bitter chocolate. Nice. Sweet on the tongue before a big, bitter burnt finish. At first I thought this was a good thing, as it made it more refreshing and drinkable, yet as I neared the bottom of the glass it became a bit too harsh, and I felt it should have more sweetness to balance that finish. Carbonation is fairly lively, could have been toned down a little. Good, but it has got room for improvement.

22 oz bottle. Pours out quite lively. Big puffy tan head, solid black body. Lovely aroma of cream, milk and dark chocolate and some coffee, with a faint hop fruitiness in the background. Flavour is spot on, lots of earth and bitter coffee, it¬ís surprisingly bitter in fact, which I like. Nice fully roasted malts almost burnt, some bready flavours, also some good wet stone and liquorice . Body is maybe slightly lighter than I would have liked, but in some ways I like the mid bodied feel as it makes the beer very drinkable and almost refreshing! Finish is quite lengthy with loads of bitterness and earth and some hop sharpness. Good stout, not too chalenging but very enjoyable. A bit like Beer Geek Breakfast but slightly lighter.

0,65l bottle. Black with Short lasting brown head. Aroma of chocolate and roasted grain. Taste is roasted, sweet, alcoholic. There is a light acidity and bitterness in the roasted finish. It drinks smooth with an almost oily texture. Medium body. Very nice!

Shared this bomber with MereLikesBeer. This stout was pretty crazy. The aroma was huge, with lots of chocolate/caramel/coffee goodness, much like an imperial, but the taste, while less intense than the aroma, was balanced, and smooth, with a superb mouthfeel. A very well crafted stout indeed!
Cheers!

Bottle. Black with a big, lacing beige head. Earthy and milky oats, dry chocolate aroma. Sweet maltiness featuring milk and hints of chocolate, quite moderate roast. Very good, lots of flavours, a bit too much on the sweet side, but not excessively so. Could pass for a (heavy) milk stout.

Flaske 0,65l kj√∏pt p√• Vinmonopolet i Troms√∏. Svart p√• farge med litt r√∏dskj√¶r ved sterk gjennomlysning. Kraftig kremaktig lysebrunt skum som varer ganske lenge. Skummet lager nydelige m√∏nster p√• glasset. Behagelig aroma med kaffe & sjokolade. Smaken er avdempet og avrundet. Starter litt forsiktig men √•pner s√• opp med litt t√∏rr frukt. S√• kommer kaffesmaken som raskt g√•r over i en kraftig t√∏rr bitter ettersmak som varer lenge. Et godt √∏l med karakter. KI=9

660 ml bottle. Very dark, almost black, with mahogany hues. Medium-sized fine-laced light beige head that clings to the glass. Crisp floral hops. Sharp roasted black malts in the nose. Dry papery malt flavours with a dry bitter aftertaste. Piney and chocolatey with hints of licorice. Flavourful. Quite smooth, but the sharper roasted malts and the hop bitterness cut through all the malts leaving the beer somewhat bitter. An excellent stout.
Staples.  They hurt if you leave them in too long.  Kind of like Rogue and their prices as of late.

"Ebony in color with a rich creamy head, an earthy flavor that comes from oats, and a mellow chocolate aftertaste."

Highest rated beer (4.8) in the Rating Guide.

Purchased at Lowe¬ís Foods, Greenville, NC

HUGE head!  Thick and black pour was awesome.  Definitely bitter but good taste and texture (heavy).  Looks jet black and sleek with full glass - I can¬ít imagine a beer looking any better than that.  Great overall - I love the thickness and color.

Pours a black color with a brown head.Got the aroma of chocolate, and roasted coffee.Flavor is of roasted coffee and malts.Got a bitter and mellow chocolate finnsh.The mouthfeel is real smooth.Overall another great brew from Rogue.

Pours dark brown to black with a tan head. There is a ton of sediment suspended in the beer even though I poured carefully. There was also a lot of yeast left on the bottom of the bottle. The aroma is chocolate and roasted/burnt malts. The flavor is roasted malts and chocolate, with quite a bit of hop bitterness and bitter dark chocolate. Very creamy mouthfeel and low carbonation.

While I have never tried this side-by-side. this beer reminds me quite a bit of Stone 12th Anniversary Bitter Chocolate Oatmeal Stout.

Tantalizing aroma of chocolate, roasted malt and some hop notes. Black appearance with a great head. Tastes awesome, mellow chocolate and roasted malts along with a wonderful hop presence and bitterness. Smooth and creamy! Very drinkable. Bottle was finished before I knew it!

UPDATED: NOV 29, 2011 I¬ím not a big stout guy at all but this is a hell of a stout!! Big roasted chocolate malts and a very present hop backround, full bodied, rich creamy flavor and mouthfeel.. Very much enjoyed this one..Great job ROGUE...

Bottle.Pours black with a dense beige head.Aroma of roasted malts , chocolate, coffee, nuts and floral hops.Medium bitterness, medium sweetness, lightly sour and salty.Full body, oily feel, soft carbonation, long finish.Very nice imperial stout.
24th October 2008. Smooth stout slightly tangy, like a thick porter. A light coffee mid and a semi dry finish. Easy drinking stout.
Pours jet black with a soft brown foam head. The aroma is dark with hints of chocolate, barley, and oats. Smooth and well balanced.

Splendid aroma of roasted coffee. Definitely smoked wood in my nostrils. The appearance is jet black with a beautiful brown froth. The taste is perfectly balanced chocolate, coffee and hops. One of the finest beers I¬íve had the pleasure of drinking.

Bomber. Pours an opaque dark brown with a medium sized milk chocolate colored head. Aroma has generous amounts of chocolate malt, medium coffee. Straighforward aroma, but good. Flavor is surprisingly hoppy, along with the expected chocolate malt and coffee again. There¬ís something tainting the flavor that I can¬ít quite put my finger on... Thick mouthfeel, medium carbonation, neutral finish for its weight. Likeable overall despite some flaws. Overall, good to very good.

UPDATED: JAN 16, 2010 BIg chocolate aroma mixed with floral hops. Pours pure black with a thick, rocky brown head. Loses some points because the head dissipates a little too quickly for a stout. Tastes of bitter hops with chocolate and roasted malts. A bit thin on the palate but the carbonation is pleasant. Lingering chocolate and bitter finish. This is a pretty damn good stout but it leaves a bit of room for improvement.

Bottled at Cardinal, Stavanger.Pour thick and pitch black with a large fluffy tan head that looks great. Great body with a robust deep chocolate and coffee aroma that tantalises the nose. Tastes as good as it looks with a nice burnt flavour and long aftertaste.

Aroma: Rasins, chocolate, coffee. Appearance: almost black with a nice head that fades too quickly but does leave a nice lacing. Taste: Dark fruits, chocolate, coffee, and a touch of hops. Palate: Medium, creamy, soft carbonation, short finish. Overall: It¬ís a good beer that is very drinkable but it¬ís not "great" in any way.

22 oz bottle served in a clear pint glass.  Pour was opaque with three fingers of muddy tan head; there was excellent lacing with the brew as well.  Nose is chocolate, earth, roasted malt, and just a touch of hops.  Taste was very much the same, only the earth and hops were a bit more pronounced.  While not my favorite in any regard, this is a very strong offering from rogue, and one I could enjoy again.
Black pour with a thick brown head. Aroma-rich, roasted malt, coffee, oats, pine. Taste- strong coffee, chocolate, piney hops. finishes bitter. Very nice.

UPDATED: SEP 11, 2010 (br-btl wh/bu-pnt-lbl, 650ml, 6%)

opq-bk, sudsy-tan-head, wavy-lace, ^co2, full-body.

aroma:  sweet-malt pine-hop ¬ßalchl.

flavor:  sweet-malt co2 ¬ßbready T1, chclt-malt balancing-hop-bitterness ¬ßcitrus-fruit-cascade-hop astringent-burnt-malt ¬ßsmokey T2, hop-bitterness ¬ßburnt-citrus-seed T3.

^attractive ^drinkable session stout.
i love this beer after a vigorous pour to release some of the co2, and a little time to warm up too. the burnt-citrus-seed character of the cascades seems to fade out and a brighter fruitiness emerges as it warms. links up nicely with the cocoa flavors in chocolate cake.

No doubt this is a great stout and one of my favorites.  But, after some recent revelatory experiences, I have to say it¬ís a fairly simple stout, just done well.  There isn¬ít anything that pops out but it¬ís very well rounded and drinkable.

Opaque oil black with 1.5" of dimpled tan head.  Aroma is roasty with coffee, cocoa, and a bit of graham cracker.  Taste is firmly bittered with prominent hop notes in addition to the chocolate and coffee from the aroma.  $6/22oz

22 oz bottle. The pour is black with a medium tan head. The nose is roasted dark malt, chocolate, coffee, and small amounts of hops. The taste is similar to the smell with a good hop bite on the back end and a small amount of smoke. Nice drinkable stout.

Bottle. 25.4oz. Pours deep, dark brown, nearly black with an extremely creamy, lacy beige head. Aroma of chocolate, cinnamon, clove, barley, roasted malts, and nutmeg. Smoothy, silky body with a very moderate, yet delicately spicy mouthfeel. Slow, bittersweet finish. Great stout from Rogue.

22 oz. bottle.  Pours dark black with creamy frothy brown head.  Smells of roasted dark malts, slight chocolate / coffee aroma.  Hops also noticeable in aroma.  Taste is of rich, roasty malt, balanced with slight hoppiness on finish.  As advertised pretty mellow stout, very drinkable, nice, nothing too exciting here though.

On tap at a Rogue bar in Portland.  Deep black with a cream top.  Nuts, chocolate, cream and a bit of fruit.  Good balance of aroma and body, both of which is not overpowering.  Bitterness and coffee at the end but finish is shorter than expected.  This is pretty impressive.

This brew is a very dark brown, almost black in color.  Aroma is of sweeter malts, chocolate, and some slight hops.  Taste is full of malts, with chocolate, roasty, and some hops in the end.  Has a chocolaty and hop aftertaste.  Impressive.

A: Pours black as night with a three finger khaki colored head which settles down to a beautiful ring just covering the top of the brew. 

S: Nice and malty with hints of underlying chocolate. 

T: Malt, oats, and caramel are the first thing to hit me. Then a nice warmth of chocolate comes thru with just a hint of charcoal in the finish. 

M: I love the way this beer feels in the mouth. It¬ís really smooth, crisp and clean. Very nice.

Poured dark, dark brown with a luscious and thick caramel head.  Aroma¬ís of mocha and chocolate malts, but was somewhat lacking compared to the taste.  The beer was smooth going down with rich chocolaty malts and definite coffee/mocha notes and a dry, bitter finish.  Smooth beer with great taste.  Sipped on a 40 degree night... definitely enjoyed.

Pours a deep black with a head the color of chocolate milk.  Aroma of chocolate, toffee and molasses.  Bitter initial taste, very much like a very dark chocolate.  Finish is smooth, well balanced and chocolate.  Quite a nice stout

Bomber from the local. Pours a deep black, no light getting through this guy. Big foamy coffee colored head eventually recedes leaving gobs of thick lacing. Chocolate, coffee, and roasted malts attack my olfactory system as I wait for this guy to settle. Bold bitter chocolate flavor backed up by an earthyness and roasted malts. A slight bitter tang and notes of coffee at the finish. Quite tasty, not too in your face intense...nice mild mannered stout.

Bottle. Poured a deep black with a nice beige head. Aroma was full of roasted malts with undertones of chocolate and coffee. Flavor had aggressive roasted flavors, a bit too much for me, but there was an undertone of coffee.
very smokey, roasty. too much for my tastebuds at the time when i drank it. i drank it right after an imperial, but even so, this thing did not do it for me.

Honolulu, 22 bottle. Pours big with a charcoal head. Lots of chocolate and nuts. Great balance with an o¬í so nice bitter finish. The carbonation is fine and a little up. I love this beer and I love Rogue.

Pours black with a thin, tan, disappearing head and some frivolous lacing. The aroma is pleasant but not terribly strong and consists of warm sugars, toffee and malt. Tastes of burnt coffee and sweet malt with some hops surfacing later on. Small amount of bitter chocolate at the very end. Overall a very nice stout, but not my favorite.
UPDATED: MAR 5, 2010 Dark, rich, potent stout from Rogue.  I enjoyed this one and would definitely recommend it to fans of the stout style.  Nice aromas of roasted malt and chocolate.

22 oz bottle. Pours pitch black, with a small, lasting head. "Wow" is the only word that sums up this stout. Prevalent bitter chocolate taste, but very smooth. Wow, this stout is delicious. In fact, I¬ím going to drink another one.

Brewed in the USA... Pours a very dark brown almost black in color with a small foamy beige head. Aroma of malts, chocolate and dark fruit. Taste of rich  malts, chocolate, dark coffee and hops. Mouthfeel is thin for a stout, yet smooth with some prickly carbonation and hoppy bite at the finish. Overall, very pleasant and easy to drink !!!
Nice cola color with a beige head that lasts till the end. Easy drinking. A little thinner than I would like. light hops and malts without many accentuates. Decent.

22 oz bottle. Pours black with a big foamy tan head that leaves some lacing. Aroma of dark roasted grains, fruity hops, chocolate and coffee. The flavor is bitter hops and chocolate with a sweet malty base. Full body that is cut with active carbonation and a long roasty finish. This is a very easy drinking stout, one that I¬íve had many times before and will have many times in the future.

A solid black stout with a small brown head that never suprise nor let you down. Aroma and flavour of typical light roasted stout components such as dark chocolate, dark fruit and light cocoa powder. Clean slick mouthfeel which resaults in a very drinkable brew.

Bomber. This one pours a nice clean black with a big tan head. Roasted coffee-like malt and some deep hops. Strong hop presence in the flavor, accompanied throughout by very chocolaty malt and a little soy sauce-like flavor - not one that detracts from the flavor, though. Moderate body. Pleasant, fairly sweet, very tasty.

If I could call a beer lovely then this would be it.  Nice full and thick mouthfeel, the head becomes a dense creamy froth that lingers on and on and on.  The alcohol and body are perfectly balanced with the roasty chocolateness accompanied with a pleasantly smooth bittersweet flavor.  Precious few stouts can even come close to this one.

On tap.  Pour is dark brown with a ruby hue and thick brown head.  Aroma is coffee, chocolate, roasted malts, black malts and floral hops.  Flavor is bitter and not very sweet which is nice.  Palate is incredibly creamy, smooth, thick, rich, lush.  Overall its a solid stout...

Bottle. Pours nearly jet black with a creamy tan head that lasts well. Nose is quite hoppy and also has aromas of caramel, chocolate, liquorice, coffee and a hint of saltiness. Flavour is pretty similar but with hints of vanilla, oatmeal and roasted malt. Full bodied and with an exceptionally smooth and creamy mouthfeel, this is an excellent stout, one of the hoppiest I have tried but one that can carry it. I will be getting more of this.
Difficult to figure out aroma. Hint of chocolate and maybe soy sauce(?). Typical black appearance with a rich, thick white head. Medium body. Definite chocolate in flavor.
Drank it with the Casta¬ís during the Mexico-El Salvador game.  Heavy bodied, thick mouth feel, great taste of dark chocolate, some rum like characteristics.
que rica cerveza.  gracias ramenend adonde raulc viendo la selecta.  esta cervezasi es una verdadera stout, con un buen nivel de hops y malta para darse gusto.  definitivamente mi tipo

Has a mellow chocolate/coffee aroma.  Pours thick with a creamy head that stays around.  The mellow chocolate/coffee aroma transfers right into the taste. Bitterness balances well with the malt.  Body could be slightly fuller.  Went great with the steak I had.  Overall a quality stout.
Bomber. Pours dark with lasting head. Aroma of chocolate and coffee. Not as much bitterness as I was expecting but a nice cross of malt and coffee. Good stuff!

Big oily stout on tap. This stout is quite slick and oily on the palate, I was probably expecting more roast harshness but was pleasantly surprised. There is a lot of hop bitterness in this beer around 60ish IBU¬ís I believe but the generous malt bill balances it out very well.

On tap at brewery.  Pours a near black with a thick cappuccino head and lots of lace.  Aromas of mocha, caramel and oatmeal.  Tastes a little smoky with a lot of chocolate.  Bitters come through at the end but the smokiness definitely lingers.

On tap at Portland Intl airport with nitro. 
Appearance: Pitch black
Aroma: roasted chocolate and coffee
Flavor: dry, bitter chocolate, burnt coffee with intense hop bittering. Finishes with burnt coffee and more hop bitterness.
Comments: A fantastic palate--starts creamy and turns toward a sharp bitterness on the front/mid- part of the tongue (not in the back of the mouth as one might expect from bittering hops). Great balance of malt and intense hops. This blows standard draft Guinness out of the water.
Near black pour.  Aroma is chocolate, coffee and maybe a little woody.  Big chocolate taste mixed with malts and oats.  Dry finish.

Draught at Rogue Ales and Public House, Portland.
Beautiful head-tan, silky, fine, with black beer. Aroma: chocolate, hops, roasted malt, coffee, big all around. Flavor: wood, coffee, chocolate, burnt malt and hop finish, harsh, yet deeply rich and flavorful. Not my favorite style of beer, but it is great.

22oz. Bottle.   Pretty much black with a lasting tan head.   The aroma has some sweeter malt with a more acrid, almost chalky roasted character and light hops.   
Medium-dry flavor with some caramel fighting to get out over the burnt roast flavor.   Minerally with a metallic bitter finish.   A little sharp in the mouth.   Robust for a regular stout but not really close to their imperial.

Poured from 22 oz.  Dark brown with large tan head. Nose of coffee, milk chocolate.. The taste was bitter, coffee mostly with a bit of malt.  A bit on the thin side for a stout, but good tasting.  Nice, dry finish, not on the sweet side.

Pours motor oil black with a thin, brown head. There is no subtlety to the hops when drank young, they seem to dominate the aroma.  The taste is quite bitter, mostly chocolate and oats. If left to age i could see this beer becoming decidedly better, but never brilliant.
Rogue¬ís Shakespeare Stout is the first "real" stout that changed my perspective on this style of beer forever.  I have since moved onto bolder, but seldom better stouts.

650ml bottle at Oliver Twist.

Nice chocolate and hop aroma, Unfourtunately the very sharp carbonation destroys the potential.
Bottle. Boring, boring stout. Tastes old coffee and sausage. Way too carbonated.

Bomber from Mission Valley Bevmo ($5.89).  Pours an almost pitch black with only a little light shining through around the edges.  The finger and a half of mocha colored head soon subsides to only a thin layer.  Moderate aroma of roasted malts, wood, and some chocolate/coffee accents.  Flavor of mildly roasted malt, wood, earthiness (as in dirt), and some coffee.  Some very dark chocolate emerges late, contributing (along with noticeable hops) to a bitter finish.  A bit light for my tastes, but still quite good.

bomber from scrizzz. pour black with a tan head. aroma of chocolate, roasted malt and hops. the flavour is milk chocolate with a hoppy bitter finish. the oat adds to the silky mouthfeel. like st ambroise only hoppier. thx scrizzz!

Black!!!
Aroma of spices, coffee, alcohol, wood and chocolate. A bit acidic.
A flavour of fudge, hops and coffee.
Bitter and a bit thin.

Pours black with thin mahogany highlights and a 3 finger creamy caramel tan head that has good retention and fades to a really thick skim after a couple minutes. Aroma is roast, chocolate, coffee, wholesome cereal grain, dark caramel, and a little char. Flavor is lots of roast, bittersweet chocolate, smoke, some dried nuts, coffee, some char, a few woody and dark fruit notes come out as it warms. Palate is medium bodied, somewhat slick, creamy and has a dry finish with a light, but active carbonation. This is a really nice stout, one of the better stouts I have had actually.

Intriguing. This is a really solid stout with obvious coffees and deep chocolates, but it is strangely missing that sweet and sour taste you often get with American breweries. It¬ís really good and a nice change.

Pours a motor oil with a thin shortly lived brown head. The aroma is good, but leaves something to be desired, standard notes of roastiness, coffee, and chocolate, with a little vanilla bean in there too. The flavour is again, pretty standard, but with a strange sort of fruit/vegetable flavour in the beginning, which quickly fades to chocolate, espresso, vanilla, ends on a hop/chocolate bitter note. All and all a decent stout, just nothing special here that sets it apart.

Bottle (650 ml).  Pours black with a great thick tan head.  Aromas have roasted nuts, some leather and some coffee.  The flavor is similar, with great bitterness.  There is a lot of chocolate on the flavor as well, and an almost peaty finish.

Bottle (650ml). Poured extremely dark brown (virtually black) with a dense, tanned, frothy head which lasted well. Aroma was of tropical hops with pineapple rings, ripe apricots, roasted hazelnuts, new leather and hints of carob chocolate. Flavor was somewhat similar to aroma with a moderate tropical hop bitterness with nectarines, caramel malts, toast, black coffee and a dry earthy finish with some light hop resins. Medium bodied with medium carbonation, a dry hoppy mouthfeel, slick texture and a great length finish.

a very nice drinkable stout, creamy mouthfeel and pleasant chocolatey bitter finish. aroma is weird - cascade in a stout I something I will never really be into - but at least here it¬ís a lighter session stout, which means it¬ís not used to excess like in the rogue imperial, and you can almost pretend it¬ís an apa once your mouth gets used to the roast. fairly tame roast flavours make this easy to do. still, a stout that tastes like a pnw stout should. grapefruit and chocolate.

22oz bottle.  Big fluffy head pours very dark.  DEcent coffee taste with some bitterness on the finish.  Pretty decent stout to drink while watching a crappy movie on a saturday afternoon, which is what i¬ím doing.
22 Oz bottle. Pours black with a thick light black head.  Aroma is black cherry and chocolate.  Taste is espresso with great carbonation and a crisp finish for a stout.  Really super.

had all the elements in a classic stout, Esppresso notes coffee and roasted malts. A great beer for a session. Not the most Complex stout but overall enjoyable. I imagine it would be another thing altogether on tap!
Smells like a coffee stout. Flavour builds, crests and then mellows nicely, a bit of alcohal taste but the next sip brings the flavour all back.
I was a bit disappointed with this, actually. it tasted like charcoal 3/4 thru the bottle. poor carbonation. burnt espresso without much complexity.

22oz. bottle.  Black pour, fluffy tan head.  Dark roast coffee with medium-vanilla on the nose.  Smokey flavor, with a good malt body.  Not a rauch bier, but reminds me of bacon without the sweetness.   A very, very good stout.

650ml bottle. Pour thick and pitch black with a large fluffy tan head that looks great. Great body with a robust deep chocolate and coffee aroma thta tantalises the nose. Tastes as good as it looks with a nice burnt flavour and long aftertaste. Feels good in the mouth.

Pours black with a tan head. Very light aroma, but a touch of chocolate. Flavors of coffee, chocolate, and roasted malt. Flavor is nice and rich with a great mouth feel. This is definitely one of my favorites!

22oz. bottle. Pours a mocha colored head of  good retention, with attractive lacing, over a clear dark brown body (SRM 30-35) .........nose of coffee, chocolate, molasses......taste is similar with heavy coffee, chocolate, then bitter lingering hop toward the finish.....mouth feel is thick and creamy (oats coming through). A very nice stout which is a bit on the heavy end of the spectrum.
On Tap at Kingsport Grocery Company. Pours black as midnight with a beautiful tan head.  Very smooth. One of my favorite stouts.

Dark brown, almost black pout, pretty decent tan head for a while. The aroma is nutty with lots of roast and dark malty sweetness in there too. Nutty, roasty, dark malts, hints of sweetness with some earth in the finish. Smooth creamy body with light carbonation and some lingering dry roasty notes.

UPDATED: FEB 1, 2011 Dark appearance. Heavy malt aroma, slightly musty. VERY smooth. Slides over the tongue nicely. Slight roast flavor, with a touch of hops but subtle and subdued. 3.6
RE-RATE 2/1/11 Bottle from World Market.  This beer pours a very dark brown color to almost pitch black with a tall brown foamy head.  After holding it up to the light, I am convinced that no light is coming through.  Awesome.

The aroma here is very nice.  It has a big, dusty chocolate aroma, with some roasted malty notes and sweet spice.  Very nice aroma indeed.

The flavor is very roasty, with toasted notes and burnt nuts.  Heavily malted and bitter Baker¬ís cocoa.  There is a sharp flavor also that tingles on the palate.  Near the finish is when the oatmeal flavors come into play.  They balance out the toasted bitterness and ease on into oblivion.
Pours dark brown with an off white head.  Smells of roasted malt, some spicy hints, some dark fruit.  Tastes roasty and spicy with some bitterness on the finish.
Pours black with a tall beige head. strong aroma of roasted malt and barley.Very smooth drinking, flavours of chocolate, and roasted barley. Dry and strong very oily, with a long lingering flavour.

Bottle. Pours an inky-black with a tan head. Head disappears quickly but the lacing is still quite good. Nose is big and roasty, coffee, chocolate, licorice, ash. Palate is very nice, with surprisingly bright acidity, good bitterness, a miont-choclate character in the finish, with more ashiness as the beer warms. Very nice!
