Pours out black with lots of creamy head.Taste is roasty and bitter. Flavors of toasted malt, cocoa and hops. Nice dry finish. Full bodied brew, great everyday drinking stout. Goes down smooth. I¬íve been drinking this beer for years and its still good.

Black pour with a big, long lasting tan head. Oats and coffee malt aroma. Good initial flavor of the coffee and chocolate malt, has a good deal of hops on the finish as well. Well balanced, smooth and creamy body, nice lacing, overall an excellent stout.

appears pitch black with a red tinge towards the light, big bubbled fluffy brown head, very inviting. aromas of coffee and choc. big malty flavor with roasted bitterness and a some sweetness. very well balnces bitterness, with a hint of US citrus hoppiness. tasty for sure!

Enjoyed via one pint six ounce bottle in a pub glass.  Pours a jet black with a tan head.  Initial aromas give hints of milk chocolate, which gradually give way to more "stout-like" notes of fresh roasted black malt and a touch of west coast hops.  On the palate, the beer initially gives some indication of the advertised specialty malts, followed by an espresso-like roasted character, and a citrusy American hop note, respectively.  Overall, this is not a style that appeals to all beer drinkers.  However, I think this is one of the best examples of the "American Stout" style available.

Bottle, Mondial 2009. Black with small head, short retention. Aroma is oily dark chocolate with hints of hops. Palate is oily at first but becomes really dry on the finish. Taste is black chocolate, roasted malt and hops.

22 oz. bottle.  Pours almost pitch black with a tall, creamy, brown head.  Hops, coffee, chocolate, a touch of alcohol, roasted malt, pepper, and a bit of smoke in the nose.  Medium carbonation with a medium mouthfeel.  Lots to experience on the palate with notes of roasted malt, earth, ash, pine, and coffee.  Medium-long, bitter finish.  Great lacing left behind.  Overall a very nice, bitter stout.

This stout pours black and has a big bubble tan head that started to vanish quickly leaving only a skiff of bubbles floating on top after two minuets. WHY HOPS!!!!! The sent is fairly week in this stout but the aroma that can be picked up is mostly hops, with maybe a hint of chocolate, I don¬ít understand why allot of the beers coming out of the states lately are adding tons of hops to every thing. Thankfully the hops don¬ít show up as much in the flavor. This isn¬ít a bad tasting stout, coffee, chocolate, and a bitter taste and after taste, I think I can even taste a touch of vinilla in the finish. This was a ok tasting stout, and I¬ív diffenatly had worse it just didn¬ít live up to its awesome reputation, and I guarantee I would have enjoyed it a lot more if they used less hops and concentrated more a rich tasting malts.

I smell everything! Breate deep every time you are thinking about how this smells. Chocolate aroma is the biggest, but not by much. This is very complex. It¬ís fresh, warmer smelling than any beer I¬íve tried - humid actually, has a dark roasted nuttiness, flavoured malts and slightly dusty. You can notice the faintest hint of alcohol...but I¬íve been smelling this for 15+ minuites...it just keep changing. But none of this comes even close to being overpowering at all. A perfect pour produced a HUGE dark tan head that occupied 1/3 of my glass. Now that I¬ím done the aroma part of the review it¬ís finally gone. Very very dark, but still has a noticable reddish hue. The intensity of the differnet flavours waver throughout the tasting, but once again never overpower the beer. More sweet than bitter chocolate goodness, soft roasted malts and a slight candy?? not sure there...I¬íll have to add more on the next bottle cause by time I got this far, I¬íve only got about 2 sips left - too busy enjoying it. Mouthfeel is freaking awsome. Man, can I feel the bitterness of the chocolate and the roasted flavour on my tongue. Good bitterness and a slight sweet bitter aftertaste. Very smooth. This beer has made me very happy. Now that I can actually appreciate a beer like this, it will be on constant supply at my house.

UPDATED: SEP 12, 2009 Pours a deep brown with a nice tan head.  Aroma is chocolate and roasted malts.  Taste is near off the charts, sweet but well balanced with the mild bitterness, hints of milk chocolate and roasted malts.  Body is light to medium and tastes of sweet chocolate linger on tongue.  Definately one of my favorite stouts, Shakespeare Stout is easy to drink and tastes phenominal.

Bottle. The Rover. Gothenburg. Black colour with a small tan head. Aroma: Roast, chocolate, sweetness and hops. Taste: Smooth, light roastiness, sweet malt, caramel, chocolate, light bitterness. Almost a bit light bodied for a 6% ABV stout.
Pours dark brown with foamy tan head.  Great roasted malty aromas, chocolate, toffee, with flavors of chocolate, chewy oats, and noticeable hops for a nice dry finish.  Excellent!

Bouteille de 22 oz obtenue via Importations Priv√©es Bi√®ropholie. Ar√¥me: Odeur de caf√© avce une pointe chocolat√©e. Apparence: La couleur est noire opaque. Pr√©sence d¬íune fine dentelle sur le verre. Saveur: Go√ªt de caf√© avec une pointe de chocolat mi-amer. Dur√©e moyenne de l¬íarri√®re go√ªt. Palette: Le corps est moyen avec une texture l√©g√®rement cr√©meuse. Moyenne effervescence en bouche. L√©g√®re pr√©sence de torr√©faction en arri√®re go√ªt. (Rating #2434)

22 oz bottle.  Overall, I was shocked to find I was not at all pleased with this one.  The appearance is decent, but the flavor was terrible; watery, unfittingly bitter, thin, without any pleasant chocolate or coffee undertones.  I enjoy stouts, but I wouldn¬ít try this one again unless it was free.

22 oz. Pours black with a creamy tan head. Aroma is dark roast, chocolate, coffee. Taste is dark roast cofee. some chocolate. Medium mouth feel. smooth with just the right amount of bitterness. well done.
UPDATED: JUN 13, 2009 A great stout, people always talk about rogue¬ís s chocolate stout which is good but i believe this is the better stout.
Sweet and bitter, thick, but not too strong. A pleasurable slow drink that hits you slowly and smoothly. Smoky and Roasty.

The style of this Stout is moderately rich with smooth silky cocoa-chocolate flavors with a bright coffee/hop finish. Comparing this A:B with Stone RIS is a good illustration of contrast between a regular and Impy modern USA Stout, with the Stone showing a greater density and liqueur-like presentation, and near double the alcohol.Shakespeare at 6% is not all that light in the body, however - I find it one of Rogue¬ís finer brews. Sticky dark coffee pour with brown highlights and good size espresso crema head. I find the crisp hop bite refreshing in contrast to the roasty sweet malt. Beautiful lingering treacly cocoa aromas. I see why Greg C said he liked this, and is also a fan of St. Amby Oatmeal... Excellent... Bomber from Premier!!

Opaque dark brown with tan head, fragile lacing.  Weak aroma of roasted malt and carbon.  Hint of coffe if you really look for it.   Very full ad nicely carbonated palate.  Roast omes out first on the flavor, then develops into bitter chocolate, finshes with a dark rasted cofee and sharp hot bite.   Very nice flavor, nice lasting aftertaste, but somewhat simple.

Aroma of alcohol, black licorice and roasted malts. Pours like dark coffee. Rich and creamy tan head. Leaves massive lace. Flavors of coffee, strong roasted characteristics, Bitter and harsh finish. Medium mouth feel, slightly coats. Lingers for a while. Pretty good stout. A bit weak in aroma, but enjoyable. Perhaps a little 1 dimensional in flavor profile.
TAP: nice black pour, decent head. Nose of roasted coffee, dark chocolate. Some hop profile, pretty heavy mouthfeel.

Jet black, brilliant crema head that laces a good length down the side of the glass. I wasn¬ít sure what to expect, a bit of a nervous schoolboy fumbling the lid off. Nice mellow aroma that smelt like my grandads robe. A bit musty, aged and kinda just old-man ish. The flavours waft beautifully around your mouth a mix of dark malts, dark chocolate, coffee beans and then this wonderful burnt ashtray type finish with a flick of almost green hop to it. This was a treasure.

Bomber.  Nice black coffee/chocolate pour, with a thick, foamy, brown sugar head at least 3 fingers and of decent duration.  Caramel, chocolate, coffee, and anise are well blended in the aroma. Suprisingly sparkly and light mouthfeel, as well as a starkly light, almost watery taste.  Have to remember this is a stout, not an imperial stout.  It is a dry tasting beer, but thick in texture, a touch short on flavor.  Not bad.

Bottle this was one of my go to stouts for a long time and a frequent recommendation amongst new craft beer drinkers.  A black body with a tan head.  Chocolate and sweet caramel, subtle and dry with a creamy body and roasted coffee beans.  Ill keep my original rating for this one.

Bottle. Poured a jet black with a two finger creamy head. Aroma was roasted flavors, and coffee. Flavor was roasted malts, coffee, and some bitters. Great beer. Great roasted flavor. Very well balanced beer. One of the better stouts.

Poured almost black with a perfect 2 fingers of a dark tan head.
Lacing just like you¬íd want to see.
Smelled like toasted oats and mocha.
The alcohol is not hidden, not a lot of alcohol, but its nice, kind of kicks your tastebuds into overdrive.
Perfectly balanced. Not too many flavors, but all are well represented, with the coffee and chocolate backing up the oats in a gang fight of awesomeness.

Pours near black with light tan head.

Nose is hop dominated with espresso and maybe dark roasted coffee beans.

On the palate this ale is big and roasty, full flavored, with ample hops to stand up to the roasty flavors. Finishes bitter, but bitter in a good way.

First impression was of coffee and a little chocolate on finish .  As beer warmed, it gave off this unpleasant, dirty bitterness that ended up being too pervasive for the beer to be enjoyable.  The apperance was spot on with a deep brown color and a lasting, though perhaps light, head.  Palate was full and creamy with good carbonation (maybe a little much).  Overall, enjoyed it at a colder temperature, but just had too much of muddy taste when it warmed up.
Very tasty, smoky and bitter. The aroma was a little off, but the flavor more than made up for any inconsistencies.

Very dark brown opaque pour with a thick fluffy tan head.  Malty aroma with chocolate and coffee.  Some milky lactic notes.  Bitter roasted malt flavor.  A little acidic and sour.  Touch of sweetness and smoke.  Bitter hop finish.  Chocolate notes throughout.  Very good.
Simply a brilliant combination of cascade flavour and aroma, chocolate, and roast. And much more easy drinking than I was expecting.
Bottle, local liquor store, Boston. Dark brown colour, tan head. Aroma of roasted malts and chocolate. Flavour has roasted malts, chocolate, a bit of coffee cream. Nice one.

Bottle from bevmo.. Pours black with a light brown head.. Smells like chocolate and beef jerky...Flavor is chocolate smoke and kinda salty.. A little over carbonated for me but it was still pretty good.

Pours an opaque black with a dark tan head. Strong roasted aroma with solid malt backing. Nice hop aroma. Hopped with Cascades, although this isn¬ít readily apparent. Some yeast in the nose although quite subdued. Strong roast flavor with underlying dark chocolate notes. Full hop bitterness and moderate flavor. Silky mouthfeel. Full body. Very creamy. One of my favorite stouts.
Had this beauty on tap. Very smooth and tasty hints of coffee perhaps taffy. the small cream head goes quickly but this dark blend finishes even better then the start. Partial to this style of beer.

This stout pours black in color with a nice tan great fluffy head. Roasted malt, dark chocolate, and coffee on the nose. Full bodied,smoky,and rich. I imagine this would be great with a rich chocolate dessert, or even with a scoop of old fashioned vanilla ice cream in it.
Black pour with a small tan head. Aroma is roasted, coffee, and chocolate. Flavor is sweet with a slightly sour finish. Mostly caramel and chocolate flavor, not too much coffee.

On tap at Rogue Ales Public House in SF.  Black color with a creamy tan head.  Aroma is roasted malt, coffee, chocolate, and hops.  Flavor is roasted malt, coffee, toast, and a little chocolate although not nearly as assertive as in their chocolate stout.  Nice oatmeal smoothness on the palate.  Fairly full body.

As the label says, ebony with a creamy tan head. Very nice aroma of bread, coffee, bitter chocolate. Flavor is similar with a dry finish. Very smooth and easy drinking for a stout. Canal¬ís in Williamstown has these and other Rogue choices in their reduced bin. Great buy at under $5.00. I shouldn¬ít be mentioning this though. Less for me.
bomber bottle...dark black pour.... small dark head with some legs... aromas of coffee, hazelnut, and light chocolate... flavors much of the same.... very impressive.

Thanks to my living-in-the-US brother.  6,99$ at the Perfect Pour, Maryland.  Very dark, quite hoppy for a stout, which makes coffee and chocolate flavors more subtle.  Maybe a little watery texture will affect the rating downward but it is a very balanced and enjoyable beer.  The hop bitterness makes it better than most stouts I¬íve had.  Better than Qu√©bec¬ís Aphrodisiaque or St. Ambroise Oatmeal Stout to me.  But I think we have some better stouts than these 2 highly rated beers (D√©esse Nocturne and Saint-Barnab√©)...

Very dark pour with a lingering mahogany head. Aroma has notes of roasted coffee, oats and dark chocolate. The flavor is not as strong as many other stouts. Definitly roasted coffee, but nothing else was very present. Body is smooth from the oats. Mouthfeel is pretty watery, which I do not enjoy in a stout. Overall, a good stout but not something I would come back to.

22oz bottle from greater Seattle area.  Medium body, medium bitterness at first with harsh bitterness later.  Had definite chocolate and coffee overtones.   Head was medium thick and beer was nearly opaque when help up to a light.  would have scored higher but aftertast was not as pleasant as, say, the rogue chocolate stout...had 2 other stouts to compare directly with during this tasting.

UPDATED: OCT 19, 2009 bottle shared by pampdogg.  aroma of stale coffee, light roasted malts.  pours a deep brown with a big foamy crater head with nice lace.  decent aroma, a little coffee heavy, nice roasty coffee chocolate flavor good.

Bottle.  Poured black with a thin brown head.  Sweet aroma of roasted malt and some coffee.  Medium body maybe a bit too much carbonation.  Flavor is of roasted/burnt malt with some coffee. Dry finish.  Good overall.

Black with a thick tan head. Nose is roasted malt and light hops, kind of weak though. Flavor is kind of basic roasted malt and chocolate. Slight hoppy bitter aftertaste along with the roasted coffee finish. Overall, kind of disappointing.

One of the first Rogues I have ever had so it was good to find a bottle to rate it. The pour was a dark black with a rich brown head. The aroma came out as I was pouring it- hints of chocolate, roasted malt, coffee, and sweetness, almost fruity. Taste was great- started with the roasted malt, sweetness, coffee, some bitterness, and hints of chocolate. Just as good or maybe better than I remembered it.
Bottle. Poured a black-brown color with a thick brown head. Very tasty stout. Hints of chocolate and coffee with a slight bitter finish. I really like this one.
Amazing.  Had it out of bottle and once it warmed up a little it was excellent.  Hints of choc and coffee, slightly sweet.  Great bold texture on the palate.  Would recommend to anyone.

bottle poured a chestnut brown color with a nice frothy light brown head but no retention. Aroma has roasted malt, coffee, chocolate, and some nuts. flavor has a nice roast, chocolate malt, coffee, and some low bitterness. a touch of hops pokes through and after reading the ingredients I can see the oats in there. nice hearty session level that is easy to put down.

Nicely packaged stout. The bottle gets you in a good mood, the pour adds with the releasing of a thick coffe head and strong chocolate and roasted malt notes. Flavor is spot on for a stout. Easy t drink, stronger than I thought with above average malt character. Some hops linger for a great all around drinking experience.

Bottle as shown. Pours a very dark brown with a small frothy tan head that diminishes quickly. The aroma is roasted malt with chocolate and coffee. Decent spotty lacing on the glass. The taste is a sweet malt with chocholate and coffee. Easy to drink a good stout from Rogue.

650 ml bottle....from my wonderful beer  director.  Pours black in color with a light tan head that has pretty decent retention. Aroma is full of dark roast coffee and somke hints of dark choloate. Flavors of espresso beans, chocolate malt and a light nuttiness. Very dry and bittering on the palate. Light hoppiness. Overall, its a good simple stout, I¬íd drink it again... just not one of my favorites.
Poured nice and dark with a thick brown head. Subtle coffee flavors were present throughout. Very good stout.
bottle. Pours black with brown head. Aroma:  coffee and some sweet chocolate. Flavor: rich coffee and chocolate

650 mL bottle.  Dark chestnut brown with a small brown head.  Lovely and strong aroma of sweet chocolate and roast.  The flavour is not quite as full as the aroma, with chocolate, coffee and roast.  There is significant bitterness throughout and especially at the end, but somehow it is not overly intrusive.  A nice stout.

Pours a nice dark black with frothy tan head.  Aroma is bready, with some coffee based bitter smell in the background.  Taste is similar to smell, malty coffee and light chocolate notes.  Thin-medium bodied and medium carbonated.  A nice "regular" stout and very easy to drink.  Not as flavorful as I would like but nice no less.

22oz. bomber.  Pours a dark black with a tan frothy head, leaving a nice bit of lacing.  Aroma is earthy with coffee and chocolate.  Taste is the same...also noted caramel and hops with some smokey malt as well.  Medium mouthfeel with a nice bit of coffee and hops in the finish.  Not my favorite, but a nice stout just the same.

black pour with 3 finger tan head, frothy and aromatic.  roasted malt aroma, some chocolate and slight coffee. taste is smooth, good creamy mouth feel, chocolate and some coffee bean.  rich yet drinkable. wonderful offering

Pitch Black appearance with brown semi- thick top. Sharp smells of smokey malts, choco, nuts, raisons, and coffee. Tastes of DARK COFFEE, choco and truffles. Bitter conclusion. Long lasting and smooth. Not as creamy as Old Rasputin. Watered down texture but not on taste.

Pours a deep black with a nice thick tan head
Taste and smells of chocolate malts with a hint of coffee
Really a stellar stout

bomber bottle

I am a big fan of Rogue beers and this, being the first of their beers that I ever tasted, explains why. Deep black pour, with a heavy nose of coffee and caramel. Extremely creamy mouthfeel and a well balanced taste that inches a little more to the sweet side. This is an excellent example of what a stout should be.
Malt and light alcohol aroma. Dark brown color with a small brown head. Moderate sweet beginning with a mild bitter finish.

Bottle. Pours black with a one finger tan head that leaves good lacing. Aroma of roasted malt, coffee, chocolate, and caramel. Taste is the same as aroma. Medium full mouthfeel with a mild to moderate amount of bitterness. Very good.

22oz - Aroma of dank roasted malts, peat, chocolate and some hops.  Pours black with a big brown head and good lacing.  Flavor is very roasty with a strong cacao finish and some bitter hops.  Palate is dry and tart.  A very tasty classic stout.
Bought it on a visit to Miami, shared it with my wife.  Delicious!   Buy it if you can find it.

Bomber! A very easy drinking stout. Pours a rich ebony with a creamy medium tan head that seems to fade a little too quickly. Smells flowery and the hops are prominent. Extremely hoppy...I wish it had a bit more maltiness to balance it out. Ends with a bitter aftertaste, but a good one.

This is another example of the fine beers put out by Rogue Ales. This Shakespeare Stout is a beer that I think William Shakespeare himself would be proud to drink. It pours a nice, dark color with a fairly big tan head. The aroma and taste are of coffee and caramel with some molasses. For all the great flavors in there, it‚Äôs not overly sweet, This one, if I remember correctly, was a bit more fizzy than usual. Overall, an excellent beer that I highly recommend everyone to have at least once.
650ml bottle.  dark thick pour.  smells of chocolate infusion and burned hazelnuts.  taste is harsh and overly bitter; i prefer smoother beers.  overall a disappointment.

22 oz. bomber. Pours a thick, black/brown color with a foamy, tan head, and nice lacing. The aroma offers dark, bakers chocolate, a touch of coffee, roasted, sweet malt, and a bit of molasses notes. Some smoke, and a  hint of vanilla follow these into the flavor. Full bodied, with a nice, creamy texture and hop bitterness throughout, but particularly in the finish. I like!
Excellent stout.  Chocolate with some coffee notes.  Dark, rich and thick without a hint of stickiness.  Good hop bite at the end.  One of the best normal stouts I have ever tasted.
Large bottle at the Mesquito cafe in Doylestown PA. Good, thick, choclate-and-coffee taste. Fat white head, dark brownish black body. Sweet.

Pours a deep coffee brown with a caramel colored head.  Nose full of cedar, hops, char, malt, and smoke.  Full to the brim with charred, smokey character and hoppy balance.  Notes of coffee and dark chocolate.  Great beer!

On tap at the Sanctuary.  Light and airy aroma, with roasted coffee bean cream, and minor presence of hops which is nice in a stout.  It came with a about a half inch of dark cream, pretty nice lacing, and dark cocoa color. Flavor has a lot of roasted malts, toast and coffee, and a very pleasant grassy bitter in that makes the finish quite nice.  A good, solid stout with a little extra that help make it stand out just a bit more than others.
22oz bottle, black, lingering tan head, nice lacing. Nice aroma, but a bit dry for my taste.

Bottle. Pours black with a thick light tan head that just keeps coming. Aroma of roasted malt. Flavor of sweet roasted malt. Body is somewhat light for a stout but it is decent. An alright stout. Not much going on flavor wise.

Bottle. Aroma of roasted malt, light, playful coffee. Flavor has some chocolate along with the roasted malt and a sweet milkiness, presumably from the oatmeal. Slightly astringent, but noticing that was more of an afterthought to enjoying the tasty beer.

Large tan head on a deep black body. Good head retention and rings of lacing. Milky coffee on the nose though I did get hops in there as well. Some liquorice in the taste also chocolate, coffee, oats, and toasted notes. Excellent!

22oz bottle sampled at the Rogue tasting at Blacklick Wine & Spirits.  Pours darkest brown/black with a minimal tan head.  Aroma is very roasty with some tanginess.  Flavor is robust and roasty with a strong coffee character and lingering hop presence.  Great stout.

Pours black as midnight with a thick and creamy tan head. Nice licorice and coffee smell with a hint of backing chocolate and some oat. Very roasty flavor with chocolate, oatmeal, coffee, licorice and a bit of a bitter finish to it all. One of my favorite beers in my younger days, I had a bottle last week that didn‚Äôt quite live up to my memories but was still better than 90% of the beers I‚Äôve ever had.

Large tan frothy head on a darkest stout with good carbonation.Aroma chocolate,maltiness,molasses,liccorice,brown sugar,coffee.Flavour chocolate mild lovely taste,malt,decent hop backing,liccoprice touch,easy drinking stout,bitter smooth finish.

Bottle.  Pours black with tan head. Aroma of malt, chocolate, coffee, oatmeal. Flavor is dark and roasted with chocolate and coffee notes.  Finishes with slight hop bitterness and leaves a chocolate aftertaste.

Pours a very deep black with a nice creamy pillowy tan head. Aroma is very roasted malt with a little bit of nuttiness almost to a point of being smoked nuts. Chocolate dominates though. Flavor starts heavy on the milk chocolate. Just at the right time the cocoa bitterness rushes in and provides a great balance that holds through the finish. Medium body that is very easily drinkable. Great stout that doesn‚Äôt try to do too much. Just stays true to the style.

On tap at the flying saucer in KC. I¬íve been waiting to rate this one for quite some time. Pours a straight black body with a creamy tan head that remains lacy. Aroma of roasted malts, chocolate, oatmeal, and lots of bitter earthy hops. Taste is very similar. Roasty and bitter, but extremely well balanced. Creamy and full bodied. Overall, another great Rogue brew. They balance the sweet chocolate malts very well with the abundance of hops. One of my all time favorite stouts.

Pours a silky black with a nice tan head. Little aroma, but I do smell roasted nuts and coffee. Taste is coffee, roasted malts, dark chocolate, earthy bitterness. Creamy mouthfeel with just a bit more carbonation than I‚Äôd like in a stout, but I‚Äôm splitting hairs now. Damn good.
Deeeliciousss...I¬ím not normally a straight stout guy but this was great. Nice, full bodies stout that you could drink all night...makes guiness seem like a bad dream

black color, thin tan head, nice lacing.  aroma of chocolate, coffee, roasted malt, dry fruit... a touch of sweetness.  flavor is roasted malt, dry, sour fruit, perhaps a touch of alcohol.  also cofee and a touch of chocolate.  full bodied, a raosty, bitter finish.  one of rogue‚Äôs better offerings, i think.  the sweetness of the chocolate malts is definitely offset by the coffee bitterness. a nice complex brew.

Pours out of the bottle opaque espresso-black with a coarse and short lived taupe head. Classic stout aromas of coffee and dark, bitter chocolate topped with faintly floral notes and a hint of earthiness. 

Roasty, malty sweetness gives way to a lingering, bitter finish

Palate is surprisingly light and there is carbination. 

Good Stout... Didn‚Äôt blow me away.

A long anticipated brew, and rightfully so.  As soon as the beer is poured, it‚Äôs poetic beauty is captured in the pitch black, opaque ebony body and thick, frothy, root-beer-float head, which itself is the color of a rich chocolate shake.  As the head dissipates, it leaves thick brown lacing on the glass and maintains a small pleasant ring atop the body.  (I have found that even the darkest stouts still have a ruby hue when held to the light.  This one does not.  It is black as night, and as unforgiving as a black hole...)  Roasted malt, rich chocolate and marshmallows drift languidly from the glass, followed quickly by aromas of flaky, grainy rolled oats, brown sugar and maple, and sticky sweet raspberry liqueur(Chambord).  The taste is lusciously bittersweet, with baking cocoa, espresso, vanilla bean, and toffee-like, caramel-malt.  There is a particular earthy quality, likely from the oats, and again, dark fruits and ripe black raspberries.  The sensuous dark liquid rolls like silk across the tongue, and caresses the throat with a smooth, oily, velvet-like body.  A terrific mouthfeel, soft and sweet, make this beer very easy to enjoy, and it‚Äôs modest alcohol content allows for more of the rich, sweet chocolatey flavor to come through before the gentle, drying hop finish.  Excellent pairing with rich desserts.  (In my case, a homemade batch of oreo/brownie pizza with marshmallows and walnuts.)  Delicioso!

I‚Äôd hardly classify myself as a big stout lover but you don‚Äôt have to be one to enjoy this beer and I‚Äôm not sure why I waited this long to try it.  Pours a black color with just an ever so slight trace of amber sneaking through with a thick tan head.  The aroma is great, rich espresso, chocolate, and some toffee or caramel as well.  Lots of coffee in the flavor with milk and dark chocolate, roasted malts, and slightly bitter hops in the finish.  Very well rounded, smooth, and creamy.  The aftertaste is a combo of coffee and chocolate.  I‚Äôve always thought Rogue was a bit over-rated but this one is very good.

Getting my notebook online. Bottle. Pours a rich black with a good creamy head. Good coffee and chocolate on the nose. Taste is sweet with great coffee, chocolate, and oat flavors. Mouthfeel a bit thin, really drinkable. Tasty stout!

Bomber from BOTW (Rochester), served at cellar temperature in a tulip glass.
App.:  Very deep brown with a large mocha head.
  
Aroma:  Lots of black coffee, some dark and milk chocolates, green, peppery hops, black strap molasses, a bit of black licorice, a little wood.
  
Palate:  Medium+ body with fairly full but round carbonation.
  
Flav.:  Still lots of black coffee, a touch of grapes, ashen, some milk and dark chocolates, less of the hop notes, only a little molasses/licorice; dry with fairly good bitterness and a bit of mineral and black coffee left over.

A well-executed stout.

Sampled at the 12th Annual Knoxville Brewer‚Äôs Jam.  Pitch black pour with a nice tan head that settles to a nice ring and leaves a coating of lacing on the sides.  Chocolately aroma and dark malts offer a slight bitterness.  Smooth body and more chocolate, coffee, bitter roasted malts and an even hop finish.

UPDATED: JUN 1, 2010 22 oz. bottle. Pours a motor oil black with an enormous tan head. Aroma is not too intense but there is some coffee, unsweetened dark chocolate, and roasted malt. Taste is at first a little disappointing after hearing so much about this. Very watery but also very hoppy for a stout. The espresso and chocolate is still there but now there is a heavy crystal malt, roasted flavor. Alcohol is completely masked by the malt and hops. This is very drinkable, smooth, and not too filling. I am though sad that it is so watery. Of the darker Rogues, I prefer the Mocha Porter over this.

UPDATED: JAN 26, 2009 Tasted 05/10/2008. 22oz bottle fron a good friend. Pours black with an airy dark tan head. Grassy dry hops and strong plunger coffee on the nose at first, followed by a faint whiff of citrus fruit and pine-like resin. Smells dry and hoppy, and it is. Dark coffee-like roast barley dominates the flavour, with a good dose of west coast hop flavour through the middle, and an off-dry supporting base malt. Resinous hops and charred toast finish things off nicely. Really nice, and would be superb with a touch more sweetness - I reckon it would have that if it were a little fresher.

22 oz. bottle.  Pours a jet balck, foamy head, that dissipates in a few minute.  Roasty, coffee aroma.  Flavors of roasted malt, coffee, and some molassas sweetness as it warms up.  Mighty fine stout.

bomber.  dark brown pour with a big brown head that dissipates quick like.  aroma of smoke, dark chocolate and coffee.  first impression is that it‚Äôs really hoppy for a stout.  burnt malt, caramel and chocolate in the taste.  nice long tinny bitter finish.  just a tad bit watery-er than I like for the style.  but it‚Äôs a pleasure overall and as drinkable as it gets.  K8.5

This dark brown ale poured with a decent beige head and a delicate chocolate malt aroma. There is a smooth roasted malt flavor with a sour tinge and a dry chalky finish. This is a nice hearty stout that is tasty but not overbearing.

Pours a murky black from the bomber with a firm brown head that leaves plenty of lacing.  Loaded with cocoa and malts on the nose with notes of milk cocoa, hops, barley, and oatmeal in the flavor.  Flavorful, but not particularly balanced or ambitious.

Bottle (in NZ) courtesy of yalnikim, pours black with a foamy brown head. A floral hop aroma with a hint of molasses in the malt. The roasted malt palate is a bit grainy, with some coffee flavour. The finish is, dare I say it, a little thin and metallic. Still good, but I don‚Äôt quite see it as high as the ratings here indicate.

on tap at hopvine
V - pours thick black with creamy tan head
A - little aroma as the body is too thick to exude much
T - mild with subtle chocolate notes
P - excessive creaminess, very nice

(Bottle, Stockholm Beer Festival, 20 Sep 2008) Black colour with firm, brown head. Malty, roasted nose with lots of dark chocolate and notes of dark rye bread. Malty, roasted taste with dark chocolate, coffee, dark rye bread and a dry cocoa bitterness in the finish. Medium to full body. Smooth, mellow mouthfeel. Lovely balance. Great beer!

Pours opaque black with thick creamy tan head. Aromas of malt, chocolate and coffee. Tastes of chocolate malt, coffee,oats with a chocolate and flowery hops finish . Thick, full mouthfeel. This is one of the very best stouts.
Crushed with Jakebra.  Solid nose.  A little watery, but some awesome coffee and maybe, possibly, unprobably some dark chocolate and finishes very nice.

what an amazing roasty aroma!!! So much roasted malt, roasted coffee, semi burnt chocolate, and some roasted grain. FLavour is sharp and bitter, this reminds me of a full bodied oatmeal stout. Loads of roasted malt, and roasted grain with a great hop bite, and nuance. Wow, incredible stout!
Pours very dark with a medium head. Roast, coffee, chocolate with a tad bit of hops. A good stout. Would like to rate again when I have more time!
Almost black, roasted malts, coffee, dark chocolate, oats, little hops, dry finish.

Bottle.  Poured an opaque dark brown with a thin light tan head.  Aroma is sweet and chocolatey.  Roast and charred malt on the tongue with hints of richer smoke.  The cascade is evident, particularly in the finish where it washes over the more prounounced burnt toast character of the toasted malts.  Medium bodied, well carbonated with a dry lingering aftertaste.
Tan head that settles quickly.  Smells of roasted coffee and sweet malt.  Taste is bitter but sweet with coffee/dark chocolate but not overdone.  Aftertaste is pleasant hops.  This is a nice beer.
Dark tan head, chocolatly hazel aroma. Dark brown, noticebly more carbonated than other dark beers.

The nose is of caramelized malt with toasted coffee and sweet dove chocolate. The appearance is a dark black with a thin tan head and some streaks along the sides of the glass. Initially it has a bitter sweet flavor and you can really taste the dark malts used and the toasted oats. The hops leave a nice impression on the palate and there is also a coating of roasted coffee left on the sides of the mouth. Overall it has a nice texture and a good amount of carbonation.
Kind of has an earthy hint to the taste.  Chocolaty, but not too much.  Not too bitter either.  I like it

Pours black with a really nice tan head. There is nothing wrong with the way this beer looks in a glass. The aroma is pretty dissappointing; Notes of smokey malts gives way to bitter chocolate the more it warms up. The taste is diluted dark chocolate. Dissapointing, watery mouthfeel.

Bomber.  Pours a dark brown with a large, tan head.  Aromas are chocolate, maybe oats and grain dust and a touch of pine hops.  Flavor is similar to nose, but it isn‚Äôt a very full palate, which makes it fairly disappointing.
user_location: The Wet Side of a Dry Town, Pennsylvania, USA

text: UPDATED: DEC 22, 2008 Pours jet black with choc orange coloured head. Aromas dominated by coffee and chocolate with hinting dark fruit. Palate is maltier than previously sampled Choc Stout. Displays some liquered fruit and finishes with dry coffee roast and very slight sour tang from oats.
Quite classical. Chocolate and roast flavours drive the palate quite convincingly. Good balance and well made.
Dark Amber, modest tan Head, looked just like Mocha porter but with more smoke, less vanilla,  and less overall flavor.  Too much alike so quite dissappointing for a Brewer of such reputation

pours a 1\4 inch tan head, and is a beautiful dark non translucent color. aroma contains hints of mocha and toasted malts with metallic undertones.  tastes great surprisingly the metallic taste is great with the roasty barly mocha flavors. very smooth on the palate .

I think this is a great beer, both on tap and out of the bottle.  Pours a dark black with a huge tan head.  Oatmeal and bitter chocolate dominate the nose, with a slight hint of coffee.  Flavor is chocoffee with a bitter finish.  A little light for a stout, but the flavor is excellent.  If this were a little heartier, it would rank 4.6-4.8.
Absolutley love it! This beer is the one that steeredme away from the american lager. amazing bold taste with a cream aftertaste. one of my favorites

Bomber.  An aggressive pours results dark mahogany black with a 3 finer tan head.  Decent lacing.  Nose is oatmeal, milk chocolate and light roasted coffee.  Taste is roasted malt, light chocolate and black coffee with a hoppy finish that lingers.  Lighter mouth feel than I expected.  Would be really good with more body.
Three Cellars Tasting Milwaukee. Looks like Root Beer. Slightly watery taaste but over all a good stout.

22 oz bottle. Pours deep brown with a full creamy tan head and large bead. Aroma is carmelled malts and very solid and robust sweetness. Flavour is smooth and sweet, full bodied: like creamy, sweet coffee. Had an excessively carbonated mouth feel. Hopping is light.

Bomber. Pours a blackish red with a huge tan head. Chocolate and coffee dominate the aroma, but I also caught little hints of citrus hops in there, too. Chocolate malt, coffee, bitter hop in the taste. Slightly thin body which makes this an easy drinking stout. Hints of chocolate and coffee in the aftertaste.

On tap @ Rogue pub, Portland Airport. I have had this in a bottle a few times in the past, but this pint on tap was surely the tops. A malty, smooth, chocolaty creamy experience. Hints of nutmeg and coffee. Extremely drinker friendly.

22 oz bottle. From the bottle a marshmellow and dark chocolate aroma steams out as a fizzy, tall but thin root beer float brown head cradles the black body. The strong carbonation forms the wet palate. The taste sensation wans like a wave drying sand. Dry dark chocolate aftertaste. Would like a bit more smoothness that the carbonation takes away, I bet it‚Äôs much better on draft.

Pours an opaque black.  Thin tan head with decent retention and lacing.  Aroma is coffee malt.  Flavor has a bit more sweetness with some chocolate notes.  A smooth, slightly bitter finish with a coffee aftertaste.  Good, but a pretty standard stout.
bottle, dark brown color with brown head, good nose of malts and coffee, flavor is a subdued coffee with some chocolate powder, finish is nice

UPDATED: AUG 18, 2008 Note: Fooled again by Rogue; this was for a bottle of Rogue Warrior Ale: It¬ís back. Bottle from Sondra. The blue band is red, and the rising sun is gone. The blue trim on the vest is now red - so it¬ís a two color label - three if you count white. Opaque brown color with a decent tan head. Smells of citrus hop, darker malt, and coffee? Medium plus body with chewy carbonation. Flavor is smooth toasted malt, deal of coffee, and arguably a bit of hop. Putting this in as an APA seems to have been ok in the beginning, but It¬ís a stout now. So I¬ím putting it in two places, and the admins can delete whichever rating they choose.Earlier Rating: 7/19/2007 Total Score: 3.8Bomber. Something of a mocha aroma. A nearly opaque brown color with a persevering tan head. Full bodied, moderately carbonated, nearly creamy.  Starts with coffee, moves to near burnt malt. Sort of causes twinges in the mouth. There¬ís not a great deal of bitter, and the smooth finish is mostly toasted malt. It¬ís very good stout.
Maybe it was just the bottle or atmosphere in which I had it, but I tasted nothing more than a bigger better Black Butte. Still good though.

I decided to conclude my meal at the Gramercy Tavern in NYC with a stout instead of dessert.......the beer was black in colour and the head had almost fully vanished by the time that it arrived at my table.....like all the Rogue‚Äôs I‚Äôve had so far, this one clearly contained superior ingredients.....the chocolate overtones were balanced by the bitterness of coffee and hop flavourings......lacing was also evident as I sipped down my delicious pint.....the complex flavourings had me wishing that I had ordered the German Chocolate Cake AND a stout for dessert.

fades into a rocky layer of film atop the beer, and leaves a thick coating of foam on the sides of the glass. A faint glimpse of dark redddish brown highlight is visible around the edge of the beer as you take a sip. The aroma is very nice, with roasted chocolate smells mingled with some hop spiciness. Malt sweetness is also evident in the aroma. The taste is very strong on the hops, and the citrusy notes of the Cascade hops is prominent. Strong roasted bitterness is also prevalent, with some chocolate notes to back it up. A faint hint of sweetness also creeps in on the finish

(Bottle).  Roasty chocolate aroma.  Color is black, with a creamy tan head that dissipates rather quickly.  Bitter chocolate flavor, cushioned by roasted malts.  Insanely long finish.  Really fine stout.
Bottle:  Pours very, very dark with a thick white head.  Rich and dry roasted chocolate malts, coffee with a nice rounding out bitterness.  Never a disappointment.
user_location: I F&ckin¬í hate those guys from, Ohio, USA

text: Draft...  black beer, frothy tan head...didn‚Äôt stick around long.  Aroma is of a variety of roasted grains with a hint of hops.  More than you get from most of the malt bomb stouts.  Flavors of coffee, dark chocolate, earthiness...  the hops add an interesting note to this one.  Great stout.

This was a solid, high quality stout. Dark off white head, small. Pours a pure black with just a hint of brown. A review won¬ít do the mix of flavors justice. Starts with a strong coffee with a touch of something, maybe licorise? Hints of chocolate and earth. I liked this one, and it is a thumbs up if you like a good stout beer.

NITRO @ Bittercreek - Poured dk black with a small tan head, incredibly smooth and creamy courtesy of the nitro tap...aroma is burnt grain, hops, dark malts...flavour followed, terrific balance of burnt bitters and brown sugar malts...i dug this on nitro, will need to retry in a bottle...

Pours very dark with light brown/white head.  Taste of chocolate and malt.  Not really overwellming oats flavor.  Good smell, but again not overwellming.  Smooth palate and an overall great stout from Rogue.

A pretty nice stout but it has the same problem as all other Rogue beers. To me the aftertaste is needlessly bitter. Yeah it‚Äôs full flavored, but when the strong flavor it bitter you wish is wasn‚Äôt so full flavored

Really dark brown colored, no light goes through. Creamy beige head. Aromas of chocolate, coffee and some vanilla. Tastes like dark chocolate, burnt malts. Pretty close to full-bodied. Strong espresso finish. Great dry stout.

Poured a nice black color with a tan colored head leaving pretty good lacing. Smell was roasty, chocolate-y, and hoppy as well. Taste was full of chocolate upfront, followed by a roasty and hoppy finish. Mouthfeel was a little less than full bodied, with medium carbonation. Certainly a good beer worth a visit once in a while, I just don‚Äôt seem to pick it up that often. Pretty much a must try, and should be widely available enough, that this is no problem.

A dark brown pour, quick building tan head.  Smells like a fine iced coffee.  The coffee notes trump the chocolate and chicory.  Some maltiness more hop character.  Very good, probably my 2nd favorite Rogue after the chocolate stout.
user_location: from Michigan now in Charlotte, North Carolina, USA

text: Pours a very dark brown with a tan head. Aroma is roasty with chocolate and coffee notes. Smooth chocolate malt taste with a hoppy finish. The balance is absolutely perfect. Mouthfeel is smooth and creamy, body is a tad thin and there is a lot of carb. Overall, awesome stout.

Very nice stout. Nice dark, dark brown to black pour with a thick, tan head. Very roasty smell, with a hint of some coffee. Very smooth and malty taste, with hint of chocolate, and a semi-hop filled finish. Honestly though, I¬íd just prefer a Guinness for it¬ís price point.

I have a new favorite stout. 

 Dark off white head, small. Pours a pure black with just a hint of brown.

 A review won¬ít do the mix of flavors justice. Starts with a strong coffee with a smokey malt. Hints of chocolate and earth mix mid way through. The finish is smooth and rather short. Thinner than some stoudts, but that doesn¬ít take anything away from this quintessential stoudt.

Pours a nice black color with a thin tan head. aroma is some coffee, hops and hint of sweet chocolate. Flavor melds the aromas together into one great bitter taste. This is probably the best plain stout i¬íve had.

pours very dark with a light brown head.  the head lasts for a while. scent is of hops with some roast as well.  taste is of hops, roast, and chocolate.  Like I have said before, I would probably purchase this again if Rogue beers were not so over priced.
UPDATED: JUN 12, 2012 Pours black with thick long lasting tan head. Sweet malt, chocolate and coffee in the nose, all of the same in taste with a wonderful bittering hop finish. Amazing stout!

Pours a dark brown with large brown head that dissipates rapidly. Roasty almost smokey malt aroma. Flavor of chocolate and dark malt.  Body is medium thin and high carbonation.  Pretty good, but not great.

Clear dark black pour with a small tan head.  Nice aroma of roasted malt and coffee, and bittersweet chocolate.  Flavor is sweet and malty at first sip, giving away to dark roastiness.  Just a touch of detectable hoppiness.   Long bitter finish.  A good stout.

Beautiful black beer with a chocolate colored head.  Strong aroma of chocolate and perhaps a bit of molasses. Flavor is dominated by coffee bitterness which isn¬ít entirely balanced out by the chocolatey sweetness also present.   Long lingering bitterness at the end. Very solid stout.
black, opaque beer, with a small tan head; aroma is dark chocolate, molasses, coffee; flavor is coffee with slight sweetness and a touch of bitterness; finish is coffee and roasted malt.

The aroma: chocolate, coffee, resin?, earthy, alcohol, soy sauce. The appearance: black. The flavor: light sweetness, medium bitterness, lightly sour, slightly salty. The palate is lacking, but with a light body, thin feel, soft carbonation, and a flat, lingering finish. On the whole, this beer was pretty disappointing due to the 98 rating. It is not even as good as some other Rogue ales in my opinion. Probably tastes better colder, but then again, if it has to be colder, does it really taste better, or is it just that you can¬ít taste it?

Robust stout with great character and style points in my book.  Had this on draft at the Yard House in Las Vegas, Nevada.  Burnt malt and chocolate in the initial taste.  Mouthfeel is heavy...like thick espresso.  Finishes smooth and mellow.
(D√©gust√© avec french tickler) Biere noire avec un tres mince collet non-collant. Odeur d¬íhumidit√©, de sel, chocolat, un peu de vanille et un peu d¬íalcohol. Gout cr√©meux et chocolat√©.

Deep black body with minimal brown head.  Medium, rich creamy roasted malt body - little dark chocolate, maybe a bit of burnt espresso bean. very little hop presence. Slight grass note on the finish, almost like mint.

UPDATED: SEP 24, 2008 Bottle pours black with thin brown head. Aroma is chocolate. Taste is chocolate but not overpowering. Really balanced and even a little hops bite but finish is chocolate. I really enjoyed this stout.

Poured a dark brown almost black having a tan brown head that dissipates quickly. Nice aroma of hops and chocolate. The flavor here is pronounced having an upfront flavor of hops then dominants with chocolate malt and a little hint of oats and barley, ending with a roasted easy going aftertaste, that is slightly bitter. I really dig this one, but a little pricey.

Pours a deep dark brown with an Italian coffee style head. Aroma is medium swee dark chocolate, coffee beans and some peat smokiness. Flavor is a wonderful combination of dark malts and cascage hops. Full bodied, thick texture. Finishes somewhat short with a slightly bitter roasted malt flavor.

Bomber into sniffer.  It doesn¬ít have the darkest oiliest pour (which I love in a stout) but it looks nice and black with a rich chocolate brown head when settled in the glass.  The aroma is almost all hops, which surprised me - the most hops I have ever smelled in a stout.  Not much going on in the flavor department though; everything (bitter chocolate, coffee, and hops) are very faint and a bit watery.  It is smooth on the palate with little carbonation; medium bodied.  Overall: after the great aroma and appearance, the flavor disappointed me.
Pitch black with large beige creamy head.Aroma of chocolate and mild rosted aswell.Soft mouthfeels and burnt malty finish.well done beer.
pours dark brown with fizzy off white head.  chocolate and small amount of coffee are there in the flavor.  great flavor, but a little thin and fizzy in the mouthfeel.

Opaque black color with a brown head that¬ís full and fluffy when you first pour the beer but does not persist all that long.  Nose of coffee.  Mocha flavor with some subtle wood notes.  A nice hoppy finish.

The darkest black colour you can imagine is poured with a chocolate coloured head. Nice retention in the head. Many different aromas can be picked out of this beer, oak, chocolate, coffee, caramel, moca. It is not overwhelmingly sweet or even too rich, just a nice balance of malts and hops.

Bottle @ le Mondial 

App.: 
Pitch black, thin light brown head

Aromas: 
Chocolate, toast, mineral, lactose


Palate:
Slight lack of carbonation, strong long lasting bitterness, medium body, creamy


Flavors: 
Exactly the same as the aromas...


Notes: None

22 fl oz bottle. Pours perfectly dark brown to black with a dense chocolate brown head. Aroma is of caramel, chocolate and mild roasted malt, all in a nice blend with a slight wet woody hops note. Flavour is medium sweet with a solid liqourice note all the way through, mixed with a light coffee note. Shows a light spiced/ashtray like note to a smooth chocolate malt and roasted malt base. Slowly building bitterness and mild fruity hops note into the finish.

22 oz bomber poured opaque black with a tall frothy tan head. Aromas of chocolate, roasted malts, caramel, and a touch of hops. Outstanding taste including the chocolate and caramel, toasted - almost burnt - malts, well balanced with a touch of hops bitterness and a coffee aftertaste. Really a very complex beer, has a creamy malty mouthfeel and nice carbonation. A terrific beer - seems like it would go particularly well with a fine cigar.

bottle thanks to swalden_28.  pours dark color with tan head.  aroma was chocolate with hints of malt.  flavor has strong alcohol with hints of hops at the end.  not a big fan of this one, but that can contribute to the terrapin oatmeal stout i had before hand.

Bottle, Kegs & Barrels, McKInney, TX.
Pours black with tan head, ok retention. Aroma of dark roasted malts. Flavor of semi-sweet dark roast with slight bitter at the end....Palate is medium carbonation, medium-full body.....not bad at all...

Served on the nitro tap at the rogue public house in portland. The stout resembled Guinness in appearance only. Taste blew the irish imbiber out of the water literially. taste is of chocolate, coffee, and malty goodness. i get a hint of maltballs when drinking this beer. i have had it in the bottled form and prefer it that way. The nitrogen takes away some of the complexity of this one.

Rogue Shakespeare Stout
ABV: 6%
IBU: 69
Volume: 1 pt. 6 fl. oz.
Glass: tapered pint 12 oz.
Purchased at: circle
Consumed on: 2.5.2007

first impression: Rich deep dark chocolate color with an inch thick head. A true stout. Depth is impenetrable. A darkness in flavor too, though not rough or rocky - very smooth and quite appealing. Dull and has feel of clay slip. Definite chocolate undertones, with hints of licorice and allspice. It¬ís delectable.

Visuals -- Color, depth, Belgian lace, legs: The color is absolutely thick with a deep brown. Only at the very edges does any caramel color emerge. It¬ís mysterious. Head is thick even after retreating. It is a solid stout, and fairly still, like a moat. Lace is intricate and leggy. Crystalline structures are well supported and the lace sparkles.

Olfactory -- Aroma: Aroma is like a sealed box of fudge. You can¬ít keep the flavor from scenting the air.

Taste -- Hoppiness, bite, maltiness, flavor: The taste is full, deep, and entirely satisfying. It reminds of a chocolate whole wheat bread.

Tactile -- weight, mouthfeel: This is a warming, hearth of a beer. It¬ís quite dense to look at and to lift and is absolutely full of heft.

second impression: This is the first stout I¬íve ever actually enjoyed, as others seem watery, or too heavy, or without character and I fear others will pale comparatively. This is an absolutely fantastic beer.
Bottle.  Good stout.  Black and vanilla head...chocolate, coffee flavors with a smoky roasted finish.  Quite enjoyable
UPDATED: JUN 2, 2009 Bottle. Really black and creamy apperance. Taste is vanilla,chocolate and with a smooth finish.
Opaque black with mocha head. Choc., espresso, malt and oats. thick and meaty for 6% abv. Hops finishes strong,dry and smooth.
Pours deep black with dark brown head.  Full aroma of those dark roasted grains.  Tastes very smooth and a hint of chocolate aftertaste.

Pours straight black with a nice full tan head that doesn¬ít last as long as I wish.  Tastes of roasted coffee and very little chocolate.  Has a bit of sweet finish.  A decent stout, but not my favorite.  Their Chocolate Stout is a much better brew, I think.

1/7/08 notes:  from tap at Yard House.  Pours deep black with small brown head. Smooth and medium palate.  First sip was a sharp dark chocolate, licorice, molasses, prune complex flavor. Highly recommended.  I¬íll have to try this in a bottle soon.

Bomber poured an opaque black with a lasting brown head. Aromas of bitter chocolate, coffee, roasted malt and vanilla. Palate was medium bodied and smooth. Flavors of milk chocolate, vanilla, light roastiness and light coffee with a smooth chocolatey finish.

Tap @ Blind Tiger.  Pours jet-black with a medium-sized tan-to-brown head.  Aroma is roasted malt and chocolate.  Taste is the same, with a mile chocolate and coffee finish at the end.  The flavors are very strong, but I found the finish a tad watery, which didn¬ít do justice to the enticing beginning of the beer.  It¬ís still a solid beer, but it could be phenomenal with a stronger palate.

Pours black with tan head. Aromas of burnt malts and a hint of chocolate. Slightly sweet with flavors similar to aromas, burnt malts and a mild chocolate finish. Full body with  inimal carbonation. A pretty good stout.
Black with tan head and white tips.  Strong coffee with a little sour added in.  Kind of watery. Slight malt aftertaste.  Pretty drinkable but not my favorite, or really close.
A nice enough beer but one that does not seem to match up well with my tastes.  A little too much coffee for me and i find the malts a little overly roasted.

Aroma: Smells predominantly of sweet roasted and burnt malts, like baking chocolate and a bit of coffee. There¬ís also a subdued but sharp, kind of fruity and tart hop characer as well.

Appearance: A rich coffee black. Completely opaque, except along the extreme edges, which shine with a bright cherry-red glow. The head is creamy, dense, and raspberry latte-colored with thick lacing all the way down.

Flavor: Tastes like an imperial stout! No-holds-barred burnt dark chocolate and coffee grounds are the main flavors, plus a flowery bitterness provided by the cascade hops. There¬ís also a hint of dark rum, which complicates the flavor beautifully. I think this would go well with any dessert en flamb√©: bananas foster, cherries jubilee... cr√©me brul√©e would be good, too. Nice dry finish.

Palate: Sticky, medium-bodied with creamy bubbles. It is a bit watery-feeling and kind of sloshes around your mouth, but it¬ís good overall.

Overall: This beer is slightly syrupy and kind of dense, but also quite delicious! Highly drinkable. I would definitely recommend this beer, and it was pretty cheap, too.
Bomber. Dark Brown/Black, very little light passes through. Nice mix of hops and roasted malts, with a touch of coffee and chocolate.  Very good.

On tap.  Pours an opaque black with dark mahogany hints around the edges.  Served with a dense one-finger tan head that showed very good retention and lacing.  This one looked quite nice.  Smell is dominated by sweet roasted chocolate malts with strong coffee aromas.  There was also a noticeable hop aroma in the background.  I was actually pleasantly surprised by the strong bitter hop presence up front in this one which quickly gave way to the big malty chocolate and coffee taste.  Hint of dark fruits gave way to the slightly bitter hop finish.  Mouthfeel is really nice on this - very creamy for such a medium bodied stout and a small amount of carbonation.  This was an excellent stout for me and it surpassed my expectations honestly.  I don¬ít know if I could drink more than one in an evening, but that one was damn good.

Bottle. Pours out a very dark brown/black color. Has a small tan head that disappears quick. Aroma of espresso and oaks with a hint of chocolate. Palate reviews malts espresso and hops. Finishes smooth. Clings lightly to the glass. Very good taste and presentation.

22oz bomber. Pours a deep brown with a tan head. moderate lacing. Nose is coffee, chocolate and toffee. First sip brings a roiling mixture of malt, coffee, malt and a nice undercurrent of hops.  Mouthfeel is smooth and silky. Chocolate aftertaste. This one¬ís a keeper.
Charred oak and coffee aroma. Dark brown color with a thick firm brown head. Tastes of bark, mild currants, and parsley. Coffee finish. Very good all around.
Nice stout.  Deep roasted aroma and flavor.  Smooth finish with a nice balance of malt, coffee roast, and hop.  Well done.
I am a big fan of porters and stouts and this one is a winner.  Dark beer with a nice brown head.  Roasted chocolate and caramel taste.  I have been thoroughly impressed with Rogue brews.

Black pour with brown head; aroma has caramel, roasted malt, and a little bit of hops. Tastes of roasted malt and coffee with bitter chocolate finish, nothing very sweet here. Very close to having a bit of licorice in flavor. Medium palate with creamy mouthfeel and good carbonation; very drinkable.

I have overlooked this beer for too long. Finally i tried it and it was a great beer. Pours dark with little head. Tastes strongly of roasted malt with an aftertaste of sweetness, almost chocolate. Does not end abruptly like lighter "stouts." This was truly a stout and kept the taste on your palate after the drink. Overall a great beer.

Flaske. Kulsort √∏l. Meget frugtrig duft med en snert af amerikansk humle. Fantastisk smag. M√•tte gerne have v√¶ret lidt mere br√¶ndt men ellers perfekt. Virkelig positivt overrasket over denne fantastiske stout.
65 cl bottle, at my ¬´Hopheads¬ª tasting. Black color, brown head. Aroma is hoppy with roasted malt. Flavor is coffee, chocolate and some bitterness. Very nice!
Tart and bubbly, plenty of chocolate and coffee notes. Less full than some of my favorites (of the more imperial variety) but tasty.

Bomber.  Pours a very dark brown with a nice tan head that subsides rather quickly.  The aroma is a lot of coffee and chocolate with a little bit of toffee.  Heavy roasted malt taste gives way to coffee with a touch of chocolate.  Pretty good, but a little too roasted in the taste, almost burned, and lingers nicely.

The head on this one is everlasting, if only it were creamier. The aroma is a little stinky from the cascade hops but understandable, The more it breathes the more malt that comes out. Its not Rogues best but it is compelling like the early English author.
Black color with a really nice tan head.  Smells of coffee, roastiness, chocolate.  Taste has all of the above with some sweetness.  Smooth fell of the beer.  Too easy to drink.

UPDATED: APR 14, 2011 Oily black pour with a foamy mocha head. Love the sweet roasted malt aroma... very sweet and fresh with notes of milk chocolate.  Clean flavor, very light roast, but the perfect amount of sweetness carries it well.   Some coffee in the finish.   I really dig this one.  Palate is slightly on the thin side but the carbonation is enough to fill it out and give it some crispness.  More of a chocolate stout than their chocolate stout is...   light and very easy drinking for a stout . . . . . . .[had this again 4.13.11... awesome beer! maybe not a 4 but it¬ís really a near perfect stout]
Thx for another great tasting, Kim (Beljohansen) !!! black beer, Cafe au lait head, chokolatte, coffee and malte notes, great balance between sweetness and bitterness
Very dark beer, not a lot of head.  Aroma a mix of chocolate and coffee.  Taste of burnt chocolate and coffee as well.  Malt-dominated aftertaste, not as sweet as expected.

I have found this in a local liqour store and will have to buy again. I had it back in Ill. Its s super dark beer. Plenty of taste, just enough chocolate so that you realize it is there without it being overwhelming to the taste buds. Good after taste, pleasing appearance and aroma. I found it a good evening beer, after a days work when you just want to settle down with something satisfying to the palate. I would recommend this to any beer lover.
Pours  a dark black color with a creamy tan head.  Aroma of malts, barley and chocolate.  Taste of chocolate, coffee, burnt malts and a sweet aftertaste.  Enjoyable beer.

Rogue Shakespeare Stout is a very clean stout. Deep black in color with an attractive hazelnut colored head. The aroma is deep and sweet, full of chocolate and coffee. The finish is malty but a bit dry.

Black oil poured out fo the bottle with some lacing.  This Rogue meets the challange of a true classic stout that is comparable to a Brooklyn Chocalate stout.  Burnt sour malt meets the high acohol to create a decent beer.
UPDATED: MAY 9, 2008 Really like this beer.  My favorite during a tasting involving several stouts.    Typical burnt malt flavors

Pours dark with a dark brown head. Pours thin.  mild roasted aroma. Nice up front flavor...tiny bit of coffee, burned malt.  Taste is gone instantly when you swallow with minimal after taste.  A surprisingly easy drinking stout.  I have a hard time considering a top tier stout but at the same time I have a hard time rating it average.  It¬ís a very enjoyable beer.

bottle. pours nearly black with a thick foamy brown head. smells of roasted coffee beans and a bit of the citrus character everyone else on here seems to smell. lovely deep roasted/burnt malt flavor profile. body is surprisingly light and smooth. the finish is long and bitter/burnt and has a slight metallic character to it. I used to consider this the best stout out there but now that I have a bunch more under my belt I can say that it isn¬ít the best, but it is a very good one.

Pours a very dark brown with a light tan head for a stout. Very roasted coffee aroma, maybe a little chocolate. Little thin on the body until rather warm. Strong roasted malt flavors. A little earthy chocolate poking through. Smooth transitions and a lasting coffee finish, but nothing amazing going on.
Pours black with tan head. Roasted coffee aroma. Sweet malty start moves to roasted coffee finish. The flavors are good but a bit too gentle. A little bit more muscle could make this exceptional.

650ml bottle suitcased by Ma Jenner in NYC, at some considerable personal expense. Glugging pitch pour capped with dirty beige. Succulent juicy hop aroma (sprinkled with ash) I now recognise as CASCADE. And lots of it. Blindfolded, would swear this was not a stout, but a Warwickshire/American Pale Ale from up the road at Tunnel. Slight body, but it suits. Merciless prickling dry stout lingering with cigar smokiness, charred malt and chocolate. Bitter, bitter high cocoa chocolate shot through with lemon oil and citrussy hop tang. Forceful but not overpowering, and a lip-smacking savoury balance of flavours. When I spilt some on the carpet, I nearly cried.

Poured into my Rogue pint glass. Light-sucking black with a monumental 2.5 finger head of a nice deep tan. Great retention and lacing. Can¬ít ask for a better appearance than this. Great aroma of chocolate-covered coffee beans with a clear hoppiness in the background. The citrus is unconventional (well unless you¬íre on the west coast where no amount of hops is too much) and interesting, but it may be a little strong. Flavor is an epic coffee-forward barrage of roastiness with less hops than the aroma would lead you to believe. This ends up being pretty perfect as far as balance goes. Really tasty stout. Finish is long and dry.

On tap at the Acadia Cafe.  Pours a black body with creamy brown head.  Aroma of cocoa, malts, and floral hops.  Medium-bodied with a creamy mouthfeel.  Flavor is initially cocoa and coffee, then turns to more earthy and wood tastes, and finishes with a bitter coffee and hops flavors.  Slight grapefruit aftertaste.
Black with large brown head. Sweet aroma with notes of roasted malt, chocolate and coffee. Sweet flavor with roasted malt, coffee, hops and bitter chocolate. Ends slightly bitter.

UPDATED: APR 20, 2008 22 oz bomber. Deep, black oily apperance and a creamy brown head. Just the right creaminess on the palate. Roasty with a bit of hop character and hints of chocolate and coffee. Nice warming finish. Much more complex and satisfying than your average guiness.

poured a very dark rich color of brown with a billowy cavernous tan head that leaves some pillow like lacing on the glass. huge chocolate and malt aromas with piney hops hints in the back... very interesting. there¬ís a lot going on in the flavor... chocolate, light molasses, caramel, coffee, nuts,  light pine hoppy bitterness and near ashy maltiness. nice dry finish leads to and astringent coffee like aftertaste. medium body is rather watery when cold. as it warms, the texture turns creamy and soft...
Bottle. Black with tan heavily laced head. Strong nut malt aroma with hops following up. Nicely roast taste with a hint of licorice. Nice body. Nice stout.
Black with a huge brown head. Aroma and flavours of caramel, roasted malts and coffee, finishing of with a very dry bitterness. The palate is fat and oily. Delicious!

this beer pours black with a large tan head leaving a little lacing down the sides.  The aroma is roasted chocolate and malt.  the flavors are pretty much the same.  Not a lot of carbonation which I like in a stout.  This beer pours robust, smooth and very good tasting.  Rogue did a good job on this one!  Cheers!
Another good beer from rogue. A good begineers stout. Decent amount of flavor. Quite tasty

Bottle. Pours almost black with a lasting tan head. Sweet aroma with roasted malt and coffee notes. Medium body, very smooth. Flavor is sweet and roasted malt, coffee and light chocolate notes, with noticeable hops underneath it all. Very well balanced. I like that this isn¬ít completely over the top like some I¬íve had recently, just a very well made stout.
Pours VERY dark with a cream colored head.  Chocolate flavors abound.  Hops flavor is present, but only on the finish and not overpowering.  Nice beer.

UPDATED: JUN 11, 2009 Bottle. Pours black with a nice and foamy lightbrown head. Aroma of chocolate, roasted malt and some coffee. Lovely creamy palate. Flavours of liquorice, oatmeal, chocolate and some bitter hops. Well brewed i must say..
Black with an average sized tan head. Aromas present are roasted malts, rich chocolate and oats. Tastes of coffee, caramel, oatmeal, and chocolate. Smooth and creamy. Medium to thick body.
Bottle. Black with tiny brown head. Good roasted malts, chocolate and oatmeal. Coffee and hops on the finish. Ok
Brown color with a little light brown head.  Raosted coffee and oatmeal on the nose.  Roasted malts with faint chocolate.

Sampled ye at Cellar¬ís weekly tasting in St Paul, Minnesota via 22-oz bomber. Pours a dark cola brown brew with a light beige head that has some good retention and spotty lacing. Aroma of roasted coffee, dark pitted fruits, some toasted oatmeal and flowery hops. Taste is full bodied, light carbonation with flavors of more toasted dark malt than detected in the aroma with some coffee, chocolate and molasses. Finish is slightly bitter with aftertaste flavors of toasted dark malt and coffee.
chocolate musty wood aroma. rich creamy mouth feel. bitter coffee with a sweet finish. tasty goodness.
Simply the best stout I have ever had. 22 oz bottle and on tap at Rougue Portland. Worth every penny a truly spectacular example of balance and boldness.

650 ml bottle. Beautiful dark, dark reddish body, close to black. Small, dense beige head. Aroma is roasted malt with coffee and a hint of dry fruit. Flavor is fruity, roasted malt  with coffee and mocha. Nice balanced, not to sweet and perfect dry bitter finish.
this stout abounds.  pours beautifully black with a big ole tan head, even out of the bottle.  notes of oats, roasted coffee, malt, bitter chocolate,vanilla, star anise.  nice, i like.

I am sampling this beer while i am waiting for the wort to boil on my very first homebrew.  A 1 pt 6 oz bottle purchased at Westside Discount Licquor, St. Cloud, MN.    Poors black with a lovely tan head1.25 fingers hig that is just staying there.  Definately smelling malt and roasted mocha.  First sip.  You lip passes through the head with just a lite tickel, and then, Strong chocolate malt, coffee, more chocolate and then a slightly bitter finish that leaves your mouth just dry enough to beg for the next sip.  Simply exquisite!

Half pint at Rogue Ale House, San Francisco. Utterly black with a tan head. Good aroma of dark malts sets up a great taste of roasted malt and smokiness. There¬ís a hint of oatmeal in the smooth, dry finish. A good dark stout with a great roasted flavour.

Draft.  Pours pitch black with a fluffy tan head, this pours exactly like what one expects from a stout.  Espresso, caramel and a touch of chocolate on the nose.  Body is surprisingly light with an awesome mouthfeel and more coffee, walnut, chocolate and the slightest notion of sour cherry.  Splendid.
a pretty decent and robust oatmeal stout. Cascades are distinct, though the chocolate malt makes it a bit astringent. Overall, though, a very tasty and exceptional stout.

Pours a liquidy black.  Nice head, good lacing.  Head is a brown with a tint of purple.  Color is completely black.  Smell is strong roasted.  The taste is not thick like one would think but finishes cleaner and has a good hop/malt balance.   Cool that they put the exact ingredients on the side.  Unique flavor that most stouts don¬ít have.
ebony, creamy head, very chocolatey, an intense roasted flavor, chunks at the bottom of the bottle but who cares, this is my new favorite beer!

22 oz. bottle...Pours a dark brownish black with a creamy tan head. Not much on the nose...a little coffee, some roasted malts. Slight coffee, some bitter chocolate, and some hops. Good texture, not too thick. Nice bitter aftertaste that lingers a bit...Nice stout.

Pours black with thick tan head and a little spotty lacing.  Aroma was somewhat lacking with hints chocolate and roast.  Medium bodied with lots of malts and roast.  Chocolate covered hops on the finish!  Very nice beer

Pours black with a nice brown head  Nice aroma, although not too strong.  Good body, great malt flavor with some hops in the aftertaste.  Maybe it¬ís me, but as another reviewer mentioned, this tastes better than I remember.  A fantastic beer,

Bottled. A pitch black beer with a medium sized, creamy brown head. The aroma has notes of roasted malt, chocolate and hops. Quite weak and ordinary. The flavour is better, roasted, with chocolate, light coffee and some hops in the finish. Medium bodied, lively carbonated, medium/long finish with medium bitterness. I expected more from this beer, from the ordinary nose to the too thin body, Still decent and enough tasty.

Kind of surprised at just how much sediment this had. Unsettling really. After taste is kind of more charred than I prefer but it is still good. Right now Im liking this alot more than I remember the 1st time I had it. Although I wasnt familiar with too much back then. This is a great stout and beer in general. Rogue really is a great American brewery.

UPDATED: MAR 15, 2008 Super awesome stout! There I have said it, from the first moment I tasted this I knew it was just the stand-out beer that all the other beer lovers gushed about for so long. 

The definition of the stout style.  Cascade hops and chocolate malt blend together into something so tasty I brings beer to level it should be - an artform.  Solid and stouty - a gem.

Pours a pitch black, with a smallish, unsettled light brown head.  Smells of toasted malts, light roast, chocolate, and subtle hops.  Nice smelling stout.  The flavor is mostly roasty, with a good dose of dark chocolate, mild hops, and some charcoal bitterness.  Pretty good body to it, nice oilyness on the palate.  Finishes with a light hop bitterness and profound roastiness.  Pretty solid for just a regular stout.

Bottle, 650ml purchased from Kazansky¬ís in Squirrel Hill, Pittsburgh. 

Pours tar, thin tan head. Aroma is molasses, caramel, pine, anise. Favor is coffee, chocolate, anise, pine, bitter hops. Somewhat of an oily mouth feel.
Pours a dark brown with burgundy highlights.  The head is tan and sudsy.  Definite taste of roasted barley.  It is a delicious beer that I will drink again.  Is that really Shakespeare on the bottle?
Pouredblack with a deep brown head. Aroma - roast malt and coffee. The taste was dominated by roast malt and cocoa with hints of mocha. Some hop bitterness as it warms.
Poured a dark black with with a tan colored head. The taste of chocolate and roasted malts dominated the beer. Another excellent beer from Rogue.

Poured a dark brown/black with limited head.  This brew was excellently smooth for the genre and included slight tastes of espresso and chocolate.  Overall, it was rich and thick, but it¬ís not at the top of my list for stouts.

It poured a wonderful opaque black with a pleasant tan head that left a little lacing.  It of course smelled of roasted malts and chocolate.  The flavor was a bit oaky with a bittersweet chocolate with some coffee thrown into the mix.  The mouthfeel was quite thin though, and that was where this beer fell off.  Otherwise, it was a very strong, but not too bold, stout.

I thought this was a pretty solid stout.  Light aroma, but well balanced flavor.  Nice taste of bittersweet chocolate, and a little bit of roasted malt.  I doesn¬ít have the boldness and knock you out flavor of some of the higher rated stouts, but this is a stout you can just sit down and drink.  Well done.

Disappointed by this one. Aroma is heavy chocolate and cocoa with a bit of hops, yeast, and oak. Pour yields a large creamy brown head with excellent lacing and an extremely dark brown body. Taste is of strong coffee, but it is quite watery. Mouthfeel is watery too.

This is a stout that is an every day type of beer.  Although this doesn¬ít possess the boldness of other stouts (Speedway Stout, Bell¬ís Batch 7000, Yeti Imperial Stout), it holds up well in terms of balance and quality.  Visually appealing, amazing bouquet, and extremely smooth...keep this one available for a rainy day.
22 oz bottle pours an opaque black with a thick beige head.  Aroma of sweet malts and chocolate.  Taste is of bittersweet chocolate and roasted malt.  Very smooth and easy to drink for a stout.
Pours out a thick black liquid with with a brown head.  Aroma is of chocolate malt.  Nicely balanced roasted chocolate flavor.  Very good overall.

Draught at the Brixx in Chapel Hill.  Dark, with ruby edges, medium tan head, with lacing.  Aroma of chocolate and coffee.  Flavor is similar, little cream, very roasty, light palate, slight roasty bitterness.  Delightful beer.

From bottle : Pours a very dark brown/black, with a thin light brown head, the dissapates fairly quick, to a foamy ring.  Nose is roasted and malty, some hops and a little alcohol.  Taste is really good.  Roasted malts, and some alcohol on the way down with a very coffee flavored aftertaste.  Medium to thick in body, but has very good drinkability for a stout.  Palate is creamy, very nice stout.
Poures like the color of oil with a dark frothy head that was apparent till the last sip... Chocolate and coffee with a little nip at the end, had a great chocolaty aftertaste.

bottle: pours black witha thick creamy esspresso foam brown head. aroma is a bitter cocoa powder, sweet milk chcolateand not much else. flavour is a milky chocolate and a bitter cocoa esspresso. a dry powdery finish with a small amount of bitter aftertaste. very creamy palate.
Bottle/Tap.  Very dark brownish black brew with a tan head.  Aroma is sweet with notes of coffee and chocolate.  Flavor is quite sweet with nice coffee undertones.  Nice roasted dry finish.

(Tap) Pours a black color with a good amount of brown head. Aroma of roasted malts and some chocolate. Taste includes bitter chocolate, hazelnut, and some hops. Good palate, and slightly below average mouthfeel.

Dark black with super dark head. taste chocolaty, a little bitter and a little sour. I don¬ít know if this was bad but it was much more sour than I would expect... I guess I will have to try it again. the palate was nothing special, much thiner than I thought it would be. Overall it was refreshing.
this beer is like the chocolate stout, but it is dark chocolate instead of sweet chocolate.  nice bitterness with some nuts in the mix. I love this beer

deep roasted bitterness.  Coffee and bittersweet chocolate.  Nutty and roasty.  Finish is floral hops and slight balancing bitterness.  Nice malty character, but overwhelmingly dry.  Perfect balance of roasty malt and floral American hops.  Simple, but tasty. Just a nice hoppy American stout.
Medium bodied, but not as strong or as full flavored as I had expected. Roasty, nutty, sweet flavor. Light finish. Very smooth and drinkable though. Light carbonation.

UPDATED: MAR 10, 2011 750 mL bottle. Body is sooo black, with brown head. The aroma is slight roast. Mouthfeel is ultra creamy and smooth with notes of light roast, chocolate, nuts, malt, and milk.. . ::::draft at RnH over 3 years later:::: Much better than my original opinion of the beer.

Dark brown with tan head.  Aroma of roasted chocolate, coffee, licorice, and grapefruit.  The citrus hops come on even stronger upon taste.  Slight berry/licorice flavor works well.  Hoppier than a normal stout.  Perhaps this can be called an "American Stout."

About as nice a basic stout as I have ever had, its nice to have something that isnt loaded with coffee or chocolate or God knows what else.  Dark and creamy, and not too grainy.  This doesnt even have to be a relaxation beer, I could go all night drinking this.
