right out of the bottle it is smokey and tastes of ash. in a few minutes it morphed into something -completely- different. it was an amber type heavily hopped brew with little or no hint of smoke. i found this metamorphosis disturbing. but one cannot help but enjoy the velvety palate which still underscores but does not completely hide the carbonaton. one of the strangest brews indeed. chocolate taste is in there but surely far too recessed.

On tap at Brixx Pizza, Chappel Hill, NC. Pours black and, by the time it reached me from the bar, it had little or no head. Slight aroma of roasted hops and chocolate. Again, flavours of roasted chocolate malts. Finishes with a strong hoppy bitterness. A reasonable brew, but I had better.

Pours very dark brown, almost black, with a nice, dense tan head.  Intensely roasted-malty aroma with lots of salty licorice, and some espresso notes. Very roasted-malty, slightly ashy-burned, very licorice  flavor with at least reasonably bitter hops.  Coffee, roast, caramel, and licorice on the initial taste; A very nice roasted bitterness with some dark chocolate and malt sweetness on the aftertaste.
user_location: The Crystal Coast, North Carolina, USA

text: Bottle (65 cl) shared with another dude at the Rover, G√∂teborg, Sweden. Opaque black with a small and shortlived head. Chocolate accentuated roasted aroma with some faint cascade hops. Medium bodied and smooth. Initially very good but halfway through the glass the chocolate aroma becomes a bit cloying.

YESSSSSS! I love this beer. Rogue, what a nice job. Bottle pours dark black, yo can¬ít even see through it when you hold it up to the light. A head a couple inches high, nice tightly packed bubble sin the head. Smells and tastes of coffee and chocolate. Very smooth, very smooth. Very easy drinking, I see why this one won awards! I will definetly get this one again. AWESOME!

Dark Black oily color with a beutiful disappearing brown head. Sweet smelling, coffe, chocolate, all the normal stout smells.  Sweet tasting,  roasted coffee, bitter chocolate, and malty flavor. Very easy to drink for a stout, almost to easy. Dry, satisfing finish, roasty stout taste lingers on the tip of the tongue. A nop notich stout.

Pours dark, dark black with a thick dark brown head. Probably one of the best pours I have seen to date. Head, sadly, vanishes rather quickly. Aroma is rather sweet and caramel with a hint of yeast. Flavor is pleasantly chocolate through the whole experience with a hint of hops at the finish to close it off a little. Flavor sticks in your mouth for quite a while.

Got this at Winooski Beverage- 650ml. As soon as my friend took a sip of this he uttered "This may be my favorite beer of all time." While I may not go quite that far, I agree that this stout is absolutely delicious. Perfect hop content and malt character define the essence of this beer. Not complex, but wonderful for what it is.
On tap in Winona, Nitro head that lasted throughout the entire beer. Very good would buy again on tap.
user_location: The World of Beer, Texas, USA

text: First had on tap with Nitrogen.  Creamy smooth head that lasted throughout the time I consumed the drink.  Hints of chocolate, light coffee, and spice.  Good overall beer.  Might buy again but it wasn¬ít my favorite stout.  Could use more bite in my opinion.

Sampler at San Francisco Rogue Public House. Ohhh....this is gooood! Jet black body, with a quick receding off-white head. Classic stout aromas in the nose, accented with a fruity sweetness. Lots of chocolate in the flavour, along with coffee and hops. Satisfyingly thick on the palate.

[761-20071015] 650mL. Boozy caramel cake aroma has a hint of chocolate and rum raisin. Black body with a long-lasting creamy tan head. Plummy raisin alcohol flavour has roasted malt mocha and a dark fruit finish. Medium-full body. Great stout.
Frothy with collapsing head.  Creamy mouthfeal but not to heavy.  Taste is nutty and chocolate.  Very dry hoppy finish.

Pours out a thicker dark brown color.  Has a nice deep brown head.  aroma is very malty and chocolaty with a touch of sweetness.  flavor is the same, but seemed a bit dry when it was colder.  As it warmed, the flavor became much for enjoyable.  Overall, this was a nice beer indeed.

UPDATED: DEC 28, 2007 Wowee zow bang pop whizzzzz! This beer¬ís got Chocolate! Thick and hearty, you could eat this for breakfast! Makes a GREAT chocolate stout float, far Superior to Young¬ís Double.

Jet black body with a good mocha colored head. Great chocolaty roasty aroma with tons of coffee. The aroma is very strong and delicious. The flavor has TONS of roast malt with coffee and chocolate in the background. Bitterness is pretty high for a stout, but Rogue is as Rogue does. I can¬ít get any hop flavor off this one. Good heavy body but not thick. It doesn¬ít make much sense to say, but it makes sense in my mind. All the body is right up front and it slims down almost immediately. A great stout all around.

10-6-07 bottle.  

Pours a thick beautiful black with a brown head and very nice lacing.  Smells like smores - chocolate and marshmallows - yum - but a bit subtle.  I can taste the alcohol - strange for a 6% - but it became even more present as it warmed.  Strong bitter taste.  Overall, nothing fantastic - but fairly good.

Pours out a very dark brown, almost black with a big chocolate milk head that dies slow to a ring. Smells of mild cocoa, mild coffee and a slight hop twinge. Taste as it smells with coffee and roasty notes coming forth bigger and bigger as it warms. A nice bitter hop bite on the finish. Medium in the mouth and very smooth. Nicely drinkable. An american classic stout.

22 oz bomber. Poured a nice pitch black with a small brown fizzy head. Rather good aroma with lots of roastiness, some burnt coffee notes and some dark chocolate. The body was where this beer could use some improvement as I found the carbonation to be rather fizzy and to forward. Flavor of burnt coffee, tobacco and lots of roasted malts. Not sure if Shakespeare actually drank this but he should have.

UPDATED: DEC 21, 2008 12/23/07. On tap. Aroma: Oats, creamier than I remember. Taste is also creamier than I remember, not that dark. Finishes with pretty strong dark bitter malts (tasty). Very soft, smooth mouthfeel. Body is a little thin though. Finish is slightly acidic. 8/4/8/4/16-4.0

Bomber 12/20/08. Diddo. Body feels much thicker. 8/4/8/4/15-3.9

I was pleasantly surprised with this stout from Rogue.  I usually don¬ít like a lot of their offerings but this was right on.

Pitch black, nice head.

Smells very dark and rich, lots of coffee and chocolate.

Man, this is really smooth.  Very drinkable stout especially with the low alcohol.

Very good.
Pretty damn good. Pours coal black with generous dark tan head. The aroma is of oats and chocolate, very nice. Great flavor, and very smooth.
Roast malt and mild hop aroma notes.  Black with lasting Brown head.  Balanced malt roast, chocolate, and hop flavours.  Yummy, refreshing hop finish.

Pours black as night with a sturdy, cream-shaded head. Aroma is potent with a bouquet of rich roasted barley and malts. Flavor is complex. A combination of flavorful, and bitter hops and sweet, deep, rich malt toastiness. Notes of coffee and maybe a bit of chocolate. Nice smooth mouthfeel . Good stout.

Poured a deep rich black-brown body with a healthy tan head. Thick and roasty with a nose of hardy malts and piny hops.  Toffee, coffee, roasted malt flavor.  Well crafted and superb!  One of Rogue¬ís best beers.

Draft at 2 Amy¬ís in DC.  Pours a black color, tiny dark brown head.  The taste was coffee, and roasted malt, but very smooth and subtle.  The taste was much more understated than most stouts.  This is an excellent brew.
750 ml bottle. Pours a dark black with a light brown head. The taste is really smooth and earthy. Some hops, a dry roasted malt, chocolate, coffee, and some yeast. A good drink for anytime.

Bottle poured into pint glass.  Opaque brown colour with a medium brown head, slight carbonation and lacing.  Aroma is mostly unsweet chocolate and a touch hops.  Flavour is a great blend of more chocolate, bitter hops and a smooth smokey finish.  Very pleasant.
From bottle. Sweet liquorice aroma. Jet black in colour with an off white brown bread head. Pours thick and smooth. Little thin in texture, charcoal, coffee, roasted malts. Decent stout.

UPDATED: DEC 11, 2007 Bottle. One of my favorite stouts, with a nice brown head and a unique flavor. Malty, roasted and bitter when it needs to be, with dark chocolate notes and a delicious (sweeter) aftertaste. It has that underlying Rogue flavor that is hard to put your finger on (the Pacman yeast? the water?), and you can tell that this is a high-quality , well-balanced product.

Bottle at Toms Ultimate Glasgow Tasting: Poured a dark brown with a thin light brown head. Light dark chocolate malt with some nice hops. Nice sweet smokey roastedness taste that has chocolate smooth finish.
Poured Black but could see through it. Smells of malts and coffee and taste the same. Very well balanced but did not have the robust flavors I was expecting.

Shared with a mate at European Street Jax Fl San Marco.  At first, was a bit like raw leather and tasted like ass.  Mellowed out a bit, and the leather was more defined, italian wools, kind of "jerkeyed meats" and chocolate and coffee notes. Above average hoppy bite that didn¬ít really hold its own. After about half way, and the bottle warming up, it was surprisingly pleasant. The hops broke out of their shell and the chocolate became more defined.

Gorgeous pour, thick and black with sublime head. Deserves a 5 for looks but I¬ím feeling conservative. Aroma of cream soda, hops, coffee. Medium body, but enough to chew on. Rich roasted malt and lingering bitterness. Filled with dark chocolate.
A friend gave me a few of these a while back when he didn¬ít want the hassle to fly with them.  Lovely dark roast aromas mixed with subdued citrusy hops.  Great balanced dark roast taste.
pours black with a big dark creamy head...light aroma of dark chocolate and sweet coffee...thick mouthfeel with a creamy light bitter taste...I¬ím diggin it

Truly exceptional stout. For a single stout, this stout has a truly black character. I actually liked this stout better stone cold. Extremely smooth drinking and very full bodied. Not too bitter, but very dark and roasted and malty. Smooth and rich. Lots of woody tastes in this one.

22 oz. bottle shared by highibus - Pours a dark brown color with a thick light tan head.  Light lacing.  Aroma is light roasted malt and faint chocolate.  Flavor is roasted malt and chocolate.  Palate is bitter sweet and slightly dry.  Medium body.  A pretty good beer.  Thanks Tom.

Bottle; have been hanging on to this bottle for a while.  Poured dark with a medium sized light brown head.  Aroma was really nice with a lot of chocolate and roasted malt.  Smooth and light on the palate; slightly chalky.  Flavor of dark chocolate, bittersweet chocolate, coffee/roasted malt.  Just a hint of hops.  Very good for the style; a nice beer to give those who may be turned off by "dark" beers.

Others can explain the pour.  The wonderful flavor is what¬ís gettin me.  Roasted malts, very warm and inviting.  Nice mocha tone that is very sweet.  The further down I go the more the bitterness becomes noticeable.  It coats the tongue,  though it¬ís not oppressive on the palate.  Lively carbonation if you swish around a mouthful.  Also some great new dusty flavors when you do this.  Overall it is a darn good beer that I¬íd crack open when in the mood for some roasted bitter engine oil.

Draft. As dark a pour as you can get with a light tan head. Large, soapy bubbles that doesn¬ít last long...flat on top for most of the beer. Not overpowering nose, but pleasant. Chocolate and coffee. The flavor¬ís much more involved than the aroma...dark chocolate, bitter grains, and yeast. Not the most complex stout, but a really great example of the style.

Extremely dark pour on this beer!  No light at all peeking through the glass, even on the sides.  Brown/tan head.  Thin and somewhat boring nose, not really up to par with the rest of the brew. Creamy, full, but a bit thin on the tongue, at least of a stout like this.  Flavors are kinda smooshed together in the mouth, but come apart in the aftertaste, yeilding to burnt chocolate and coffee, with an milky sweetness.  An excellent, solid stout.

22 oz. bottle pours a used diesel motor oil black with a brown head. Smells of dark roasted malts and burnt chocolate. Has a nice n¬í thick, chewy mouthfeel. The taste is of toasted, almost burnt malts with a chocolatey undertone. Finishes with a slightly burnt grain bitterness on the tongue. Jan 2004
user_location: Same Trailer, Different Park, Louisiana, USA

text: Bottle. Very dark with a small and brief brown head. Somewhat light mouth feel but the taste is still there. Nice chocolate aftertaste that actually lingers a bit. Very good stout.
great stout. very dark with a wonderful dark brown head. smells of coffee and chocolate. very smooth and sweet with a slight bitter after taste.

Bottle... Poured black with a huge brown head, kept a nice steady head throughout the pint.  definitely some barley-malt on the nose, very toasty and nutty.  Not as silky as I would like for a stout, but still enjoyable feeling in the mouth.  You kind of get everything all at once with this one, and than you can start to dissect the flavors after you swallow.  It was well hopped, but you get chocolate, oats, roasted barley and malt, and smokiness that¬ís amazing.  A nice juxtapose of sweet and bitter.

Pours very dark with large brown head.  Aroma is hops, chocolate, and smooth oats.  Flavor unfortunately was not very strong.  The body was smooth and the rolled oats were present, which I enjoyed.  But much of the beer consisted of a weak-watery sweetness.  Chocolate flavor is mellow and not overdone, also nice.  Bitterness is low, but overall just to watery to score high in my book.

UPDATED: AUG 24, 2008 Draft. Nearly opaque with a nice head that lasts fairly well. Aroma is chocolate and spice. Flavor is blandish: some chocolate and maybe some smoke. Palate is medium bodied and watery.

To beer or not to beer that is the question. A brew worthy of carrying the Bards name. Sweet poetry for your palate. Creamy head that retains throughout consumption. Pure black in color, thick consistency. Sweet to the touch with a medium bitter finish. A stout you will appreciate more with each passing sip until alas, it is gone. Parting is such sweet sorrow.

Bottle from ¬íonlyfinebeers¬í Pours jet black with a lovely bubbling brown head that rises then swiftly fades to leave you looking at a dense pool of blackness like walking across the moors and looking into a ¬íGrimping Mire¬í. The nose is assaulted by a bombardment of coffee aromas and the first mouthful has coffee, burnt, and chocolate flavours all rolled into one. This was a quite wonderful stout just getting better with every mouthfull, a lovely dryness was another great characteristic of this beer but the chocolate and coffee along with nice oatiness kept flooding back through, great beer really glad it was a 660ml bottle.

Bottle. Boy, what a disappointment. Aroma is very dry. Charred malt, some sweet, creamy oat as well. Pours pitch black. Big, brown head. Good lacing. Flavor is dry,  bitter and simple. Lots of charred  dark malt with just a tiny hint of oaty sweetness. Medium bodied. Very dry and not too complex.

On draught at Barrel House in Knoxville, TN on 10/12/07.  Pours black with a medium-sized tan head.  Nose is chocolate with some soy sauce and molasses. Flavor is sweet and chocolatey with a little bit of salt.  I used to love this beer, but now it seems a little less complex. Still think this is very good, but not quite elite status.

Black with big light brown creamy head. Lots of roasted malt and salty licorice in the aroma. Tastes of smoke, licorice, chocolate. Bitter finish. Smooth, thick and well balanced. Shakespeare would be proud.
Pours pretty dark, a very faint chocolatey taste to it, thicker than I expected. A good session beer definately.
dark chocolate bitterness, backed with a slight caramel richness.  Color is Jet black with a tight cream head.    initial taste is very bold tailing into a mildly complex malty essence.

Pours a rich, dark black color with nice tan head.  Great lacing and great head retention for that matter.  Aromas are wonderful with roasted nut, espresso, and a slight citrus/fruit element.  It is full bodied with nice mouthfeel...thick and viscous, but smooth and satisfying.  The full flavors of roasted malt, barley are nice but the "oaty" flavors are predominate which was nice.  The hop notes are significant enough to balance out the insane sweetness of the malt backbone.  Very well balanced.
Tap at Ginger Man.  Black pour, no head.  Barely any aroma.  Flavor is chocolate and roasted malt, a bit simple.

Poured on draft at The Sanctuary (Iowa City, IA) in a conical pint. Color is practically black with possibly some ruby undertones. It¬ís hard to tell in the light. Respectable head that resembles cocoa. Smell of malt and coffee dominates with some milder chocolate undertones. Sharp pleasing taste on initial. Roasted malts for sure. Coffee definately and a slight chocolate. Smooth but fierce. Head disappears but clings to the glass. Hop profile evident but extremely well balanced. An extremely well done stout.

UPDATED: DEC 15, 2007 Pours very dark and opaque... mocha... nearly black with maybe the darkest head I¬ív ever seen... a legitimate full, actually brown, head.  Aroma is a little hoppier than most stouts... fruity and chocolatey.  A bit of a flowery character in the taste... hoppy and chocolatey with a little coffee taste, too.

1 pt. 6 oz. bottle/on tap.
Blackest stout I¬íve ever seen.  Head was charcoal colored. The aroma was a mild molasses.  Tastes like burnt chocolate and tobacco.  Dry and ultra-heavy malts.  A little too intense for my liking.

Bomber.  Poured jet black with a nice tan head.  Aroma full of malts, coffee, chocolate.  Flavor was rich and deep, filled with chocolate, espresso, malts, and a nice finish of hops to round it all out.  I waited a long time to try this one, and it didn¬ít disappoint.

rich dark brew with a nice thick tan head. Malty roasted aroma with some hops evedent in the boquet. Big full roast flavor, complex, hops definatly in there, well balanced, medium mouth feel. Chocolte covered cherries adn a touch of citruis. ONe of my all time favorite stouts.

650 ml. bottle.  Pours as black as used motor oil with a very dark brown head.  Delicious aroma of malt and dark fruit.  It feels silky smooth in the mouth.  Lots of roasted malt in the flavor as well as chocolate and plum.  Was wood used in aging?  Flavor hints that it was.  This beer is thick, rich, creamy, and delicious.

Pours dark brown, almost black into the English Pint.  A quick inch of tan head reduced to a half inch and hung around.  The scent was of coffee beans, malt, chocolate, hops and some caramel.  A quick bitter rush on the palate, turns mildly creamy in the finish.  Hints of coffee, malt, barley and oats swirl around.  An excellent stout.
Drank this from a large 2 litre Mug.  poured a black with a dark tan  head.  chocolate and coffee flavors strong but not overwhelming.  For any fan of stouts.

1pt 6oz bottle.  Aroma is sweet chocolate, molases, coffee, and cream.  Average sized tan head that mostly diminished and left some lacing.  Abyssal black, I am quite shocked at how no light can penetrate.  Sweet with chocolate, coffee, malts and bitter on the finish.  Palate is medium-full bodied with a long finish.  Great looking beer but I was really put off by the aroma and flavor.  Too sweet and a weird aftertaste.  Surprised it¬ís rated so high.

Black thick pour with a slightly oil look to it.  Nice big foamy brown lasting head.  Smell is fairly heavily hopped, with a rich roastiness in the background and a bit of dry cocoa.  Taste is roasty, with medium to high carbonation, and was well hopped.  Slightly overcarbonated, a bit dry, and bland, although the body was full and rich.  Okay, but far from one of my favorite stouts.  Just boring overall, and needed some sweetness to make the flavors pop a bit more.

On tap in Issaquah.  Roasted malt aroma with a Guinness like appearance, because they introduce nitrogen when it is on tap.  This is a outstanding beer.   It is very creamy and the different flavor components of this beer are subtle but they are all there in balance.

UPDATED: DEC 20, 2008 Earthy aroma slightly bitter. Pours black with a tan finish. Medium bitterness, notes of dark chocolate, coffee, and roasted malt.  Medium body and very slight carbonation. The finish is slightly bitter and dry.  Overall a very nice stout but very pricey.
(Stockholm Beer Festival 2007) Black color, no head. Coffee aroma, rostaed, malty and with bitter chocolate. Chocolate and coffee flavor, smotth, roasted and with some tar.

650ml bottle from Bevmo. Pours a opaque motor oil black with a big brown head that fades very slowly. Aroma is spicy with anise, pepper, smoke, burnt toast and coffee. The flavor mirrors the aroma with less emphasis on the spice and more on the smoke and coffee. The mouthfeel is full,  smooth and creamy. The finish is long with lots of roasted notes. Overall this is one great beer. Recommended.
Bottle.  Very light soapy brown head.  Aroma is dark and sweet with notes of chocolate and coffee.  Taste is deep coffee and chocolate with notes oak and tobacco.  A nice stout but pricey.
nice black color with a caramel head.  smells like sweet chocolate and malts.  thick but not extremely thick with a distinct chocolate taste.

This is a good one to go back to and relive the old days in GA.  The old days with barely any good beer.  But, we did get rogue, so we made it through the drought.  This is a nice coffee and tobacco flavored stout.
The rogue reputation wears thin when you taste what else is out there. I still feel tempted to revisit Rogues, though. Could I be so wrong? Then I do. And I don¬ít feel differently.
The usual suspects.  Roasted malt, coffee, dark chocolate.  A dry finish with some hops that equals an extremely satisfying beer.  I hate their prices but Rogue has some really good stuff.

22 oz bottle - Poured ink black with a brown head with very little lacing. Smelled like roasted nuts and sweet chocolate. Tasted like chocolate with a medium mouthfeel and a bitter taste on the palate. Not my favorite stout but is alright. Rogue has done better.

Nice aroma, has a bit of oatmeal and chocolate.  Appearance is a deep black with a dark tan head.  Has a nice chocolate flavor that ends well.  Overall, very good.  Would like a bit more body, but one of the better stouts.

22 ounce bottle in pint glass.  Black with tall brown head and lace.  Aroma of roasted dark chocolate and earth and something slightly acidic, hops, I guess.  Very earthy, oaty flavor, smooth and roasted with a moderate lingering bitterness.  Hard to describe, but awesome.

Tap. The malt¬ís coffee and chocolate notes dominated the aroma in this beer. Hops smelled lightly of herbs, yeast smelled of musty, wet leaves, and there is a licorice note in the background. Head is creamy, brown which mostly diminished but left excellent lacing. Color is pitch black (for lack of good lighting). Flavor starts moderately sweet and lightly acidic then the long finish was lighty acidic and heavily bitter. Palate was creamy and medium/full with a soft carbonation. It finished moderately astringent and very dry. A good palate cleanser and after dinner espresso all in one.

Pours jet black with a creamy, pitted, tan head. Dark roasted malt, molasses and dark chocolate on the nose. Medium to full-bodied, slick and creamy with a lightly dry and bitter finish. The flavor is dark roasted malt, chocolate and coffee with a dry, roasted finish. The hops used in this beer are very well integrated as its 69 IBUs are well hidden behind the malt front. A nice stout.

On draught at the Issaquah brewhouse.  Aroma is roast malt forward, slightly sour, bready, with light dried fruit and no sweetness.  Appearance is dark brown with a well retained tan head.  Flavor is plain, bready with low sweetness and roast.  Mouthfeel is medium/high bodied, creamy, with almost no carb feel.  Overall, not easy drinking, kind of boring, with no reason to have another or even to completely finish what you have.
50 cl bottle, Fargo. Deep black with a light brown head. Heavy roasted malt aroma, strong concentrated flavor, nice sharp very long finish. Very nice.

Pours a onyx black with lingering microfoamy tan head giving off chocolate malt balls aroma and oatsy smokiness.  Rich on the palate, thick and smooth, dark malts balanced with slightly citrusy Cascade hops, solid bitterness unexpected from a regular stout.  Not too sweet, not too strong.  Wonder what the Bard would think.

UPDATED: JAN 8, 2008 A Sim rate (draught at Flying Saucer Memphis): Delightful chocolate, coffee and caramel aroma. Creamy; like half-n-half with slight fruitiness. Maybe it¬ís grape? Bizarrely has a fried sort of smell to it. Dark opaque colour with a chocolate head. Not much lace though. There¬ís not too much in the flavour until it gets to the amazing dark chocolate bittersweet finish. Very impressive stout!

650ml Bottle: Pours deep black, thick tan head that settled to a thin but ever-present 1/4-inch.  Aroma is heavy with roasted malts, sweet with molasses, odd traces of jelly beans of all things.  Taste is thick with roasted malt, quite bitter, but pleasingly so.  Very thick mouthfeel, slightly oily but glides down effortlessly.  Nice sweet aftertaste with that lingering bitterness, very well done stout.
3/10/05 Bomber. Black with large brown head. Chocolate aroma. With chocolate and coffee body.

Pours dark and very little light can get through (though a wee bit does). Nose is almost a gummy cocoa. You get that roasted coffee and chocolate that you come to expect from some of the great stouts. But the flavor. Oh baby, the flavor. Rich and full with strong coffee tones and it just stays constant with a slight change throughout the life of it on your mouth. Feel is smooth and it is very drinkable. Even more so than the Imperial Stout for the obvious reasons of course.

great black pour with red highlights. dark beige head, not too big, not too small.  smells of roasted malt, even  a fresh roast coffee.  smooth and velvety.  good body without being too heavy.  in fact  it was a bit lighter than i expected.  Great roasted flavor.  all the flavors are present- coffee, deep roasted malt, chocolate with an ample hop presence lingering in the backround.  Great stout with a good balance of flavors.

Bottle. Pours nearly black with small tan head. Aromas of light coffee with cascade hops fairly evident. Flavor is very coffee like, with a fairly high bitterness, lots of cascade hoppiness, and a hint of chocolate. Feels kind of powdery in the mouth. Finish is dry. Pretty good.
Pours deep black with a tan, creamy head. Aroma is chocolate and malt. Flavor is roasty with a very creamy mouth feel. Very smooth stout.

Poured from a bomber.  Poured a deep brown (basically black) color with a thick, creamy tan head.  Aroma of roasted malts with some chocolate, and a bit of hops peaking through.  Initial taste is roasted malt with some chocolate and coffee that leads into a slight hop bitterness.  Some smokiness is apparent.  Left a nice lacing in the glass, and felt nice on the palate.

UPDATED: MAY 9, 2010

dark, smokey, rich, tasty, bitter finish

smokey and choclate aroma dark, smokey, rich, tasty, bitter finish, simular but smokier than shakesphere

Appearance: black, rich tan head and lots of lace
Flavor: strong roasted malt aroma and flavor, lingering bitter finish

very pronounced roasted flavor and lingering bitter finish

hidden roasted, slightly grassy, nice hop nose, a black pale ale, hint of roasted bitter finish

Name: Shakespeare Stout

Appearance: black, fine beige head, scattered lace
Aroma: roasted malt aroma, citrus hops, rich dark chocolate, touch of sweetness
Flavor: rich roasted malt flavor, very hoppy, rich dark chocolate, long roasted bitter finish

Name: Shakespeare Stout
Date: April 26, 2010
Mode: cask
Words: tmac woodstock
Aroma: rich chocolate aroma with lots of dry roasted character
Flavor: rich chocolate and roast flavor, dark chocolate bitterness, touch of espresso, long bitter finish

Aroma: 7/10; Appearance: 8/10; Flavor: 7/10; Palate: 6/10; Overall: 15/20
Rating: 3.6/5.0Drinkability: 7/10
Score: *** /4
Mmmmmmmmmmm.  Great beer.  Pours blacker than most.  Great chocolate and coffee aroma and taste.  Very good.  I am glad I had a 22 oz.

Poured deep and dark black charcoal with a thin pocky head. The aroma was mostly yeasty with a few floral notes in the back. Not what I was expecting. The taste was an improvement over the aroma, containing cocoa notes, a smooth and low key coffee roastiness and a distinct hoppy finish. I havn¬ít had many stouts where the hops were so pronounced. This is a nice, drinkable stout but it doesn¬ít make me crave another.

served cold from bottle. i really enjoy this stout and revel in any opportunities i get to consume this (or the chocolate stout, or the mocha porter, or any of another half-dozen rogue beers). it¬ís not the best stout, but its in my top twenty for sure. it pours almost black with a creamy off-white head. the aroma is malts, chocolate and coffee. the taste starts with more of a coffee flavor but the finish is chocolate. very good.

this is a very nice and smooth stout with bittersweet chocolate overtones... however, there are so many other great US stouts like 8 Ball, Blackhawk and the robust Steelhead Extra. go for one of those others instead

650mL bottle.  Pours very close to black with a creamy tan head.  Aroma is sweet malt, chocolate, coffee, vanilla.  Starts off with coffee and maltin the mouth and finishes with a smooth chocolate flavor.  Some roasty and biscuity flavors as well

Pours almost black with coffe and chocolate aroma. Very coffee forward in the taste, smokey middle with a subtle chocolate finish. A little too subtle. A good stout, but there are better easily available for my taste.

Pours deep brown with a medium and quickly fading chocolate colored head.  Aroma is chocolate, malt, and hops.  Very bitter, hoppy flavor with a finish that is somehow even more bitter. Not very complex, but overall it¬ís not all that bad a stout.  Much better as it warms up.

650ML bottle from Bayville Package Store, Selbyville, DE...pours black with minimal caramel colored head, quickly dissipated (sounded like Rice, or should I say Coco Krispies!)...rich toasty aroma of coffee, sweet chocolate...taste is much of the same, roasty, dry, slightly bitter aftertaste...just a little bit too carbonated for my liking...big bottle, big taste, very good.

Caramel head..very dark brown in color, smells quite hoppy with some mocha showing through the hoppiness....smooth body,Palate: not as much bitterness as Rogue usually portrays in their products....hopped stout, good stuff

Black with foamy brown head / Nose of roast coffee and vanilla / Full body with spritzy carbonation and long finish / Flavors of roast coffee, bittersweet chocolate, black pepper, and vanilla / Elegant, balanced stout.
Bottle. Nice big head brown head with good duration. Color is black. Aroma and taste are roast malt and coffee. Also some chocolate.

UPDATED: AUG 18, 2007 Bottiglia da 65cl al Pub del Duca; colore nero come il carbone, schiuma marrone molto cremosa. Aroma cioccolato, liquirizia, caff√©; in bocca piena e rotonda. Favolosa stout della Rogue, questi ragazzi hanno talento da vendere.

UPDATED: AUG 28, 2008 Black, even when held to the light this beer is DARK.  What‚Äôs more is the espresso frothy creamy head looks like it was poured from a nitrogen tap and I can‚Äôt help but to dip my finger in like it‚Äôs a dessert.  Strong roasted aroma, fully pegged.  Dry and dusty, the complete grain quality really comes forth in the first sip and becomes more creamy as I finish the glass and the oily burnt french roast coffee notes come out.

On tap. Black with tan mousse head. Palate is very think and smooth. Flavor of toasted chocolate malt and lots of bitterness and hops.  The palate was incredible as was that big tan head. However, I think it is too bitter.

pours a jet black with a nice brown head, sweet smells, tastes of coffee, chocolate.. now im not going to rate a beer down because i didn¬ít like it, but after the 5th or so sip i just can¬ít drink anymore, stouts just don¬ít do it for me.
Very nice beer. It is really a mix of a slightly sweet, rich chocolate coffee. It has the alcohol buried, in the flavor.

UPDATED: DEC 23, 2007 Bottle.  Outstanding.  Aromas of chocolate, coffee and roasted malts.  Wonderful palate, light carbonation and full body with a pleasant chocolate/coffee aftertaste.  Huge 1" head from the pour - which diminished to a 1/4" head which lasted throughout the entire glass.  Extremely black - looks mighty good when you pour it.  Excellent offering from Rogue...

UPDATED: SEP 16, 2007 April 2005 - The beer poured with a HUGE head...which is odd for a stout like this.  Way too hoppy for the style, imo.  Do the Rogue people think this is a pale ale??  I don¬ít get the super high rating. I think too many people on here are just impressed by a big hoppy taste.

Sept 2007 rerate - I find it funny to come back to these beers from my "beer youth" and see how much my palate has changed.  Black as night pour with nice head and lacing.  Sweet aroma of chocolate and fruits, but a full rich flavor of roast and some bittering hops along with the trademark Rogue yeasty.  Very nice full flavored stout.  I can¬ít believe I ever thought this was too bitter.

UPDATED: APR 30, 2008 old ratings:
6/5/7/4/18 - 4.0
7/5/8/4/17 - 4.1
pours a jet black with a brown creamy head, very good lacing.
smells is of chocolate, espresso, and a little faint smell of hops, roasted nuts, some licorice>
very creamy taste, chocolate, roastiness, a little coffee, ends nicely bitter and dry.

Inky black body with barely a hint of dark brown at the edges when held to the light.  There is an ample, mottled, chocolate brown head that leaves behind some beautiful tan lacing.  The aroma is fantastic!  Various chocolates, from dark to light, strike the nose immediately.  Roasted coffee beans follow closely behind, with a faint bit of smoke and a striking herbal hoppiness.  The hops really lend a freshness to the aroma that is quite appealing.  The flavor is comprised of chocolate, fresh roasted coffee, subtle anise notes, and again that fresh herbal hop flavor that really sets this one apart.  The body is just on the full side of medium.  The finish is smooth, with a great coffee aftertaste.  I love how Rogue is able to infuse these beautiful herbal hop flavors into their dark beers!  In a world of stouts and porters dominated by simplistic chocolate and coffee roasted malts, it is a refreshing change.
This is a fantastic Stout from Rogue, a brewery with which I have only good experiences.

UPDATED: FEB 6, 2009 Re-Rate: 6 February 2009
Smells like coffee and alcohol. Tan head recedes quickly. First tastes are dark chocolate with something akin to molasses. Roasty and toasty but feels a bit watery. I feel I was a bit harsh before. I think it was originally rated next to a Great Divide Yeti (which was awesome).

Original Score: 3.2
Exceptional stout, but nothing that wowed me.  Seemed to over-power my mouth by brute force rather than seduce with finer complexities.  Familiar chocolate/coffee pairing makes for a satisfactory yet disappointing drink.
22oz bomber.  Black with beige head.  Aroma and taste of coffee with hints of chocolate.  Very good stout.

Bottled. Black appearance, small brown head. Roasted malts, dried fruit, coffee and chocolate in aroma, really nice. Initially sweet flavour, which develops to be quite bitter towards the end. I expected more complexity in flavour, but besides the bitterness not a whole lot is going on.

(bottle 22oz) Black body and dark brown head with stiff peaks that slowly collapses. Aroma is chocolate and roasted coffee. Flavor is sweeter than expected, but bitterness is long and strong in the end - still, not as bitter as I expected, in a good way. Medium bodied, very smooth.

22oz bottle.Pours inky black with a huge tan head. Sweet roasty aroma with ints of choclate. flavor is sweet and roasty with hints of choclate and coffee. very smotth a creamy mouthfeel. A very good stout.

Bottle, from Wohlenbergs Vinhandel, S√∏nderborg. Near pitch-black, with a big foamy beige head. Aroma is malty sweet with a clear roasted character as well as a little chocolate. Nice, full, oily mouthfeel. Flavour is dry, roasted and quite sweet. There is a clear smoky finish to it that is not too powerful - just well-adjusted. Nice stout, indeed.

A fantastic stout from a bottle at Wooman¬ís pours black with a tan head from a 22 ounce bottle.  Flavors of coffee chocolate and hops with perhaps some different spices in the finish and nice bitterness.

Poured from a 22oz bomber into an English pint glass.  This stout poured a deep brown/black color with a decent sized dark tan head that slowly turned into a thin layer of bubbles that lasted.  Minimal lacing.  The aroma included chocolate, coffee, and some spicy hoppiness.  The flavor was dark roasted malts, coffee, and just a bit of hops on the tail end.  There is a slight lingering aftertaste of chocolate and coffee left on the tounge.  The mouthfeel was medium-bodied and creamy with light carbonation.  An excellent sessionable stout from Rogue!

Ezo Beers Brown Bear Beer.  Pours black with brown head.  Kind of light smelling head, smells a bit like an IPA me thinks.  Ooof, quite a nice gamut of flavors, starting slightly bitter smokiness, transforming into coffee and a bit of hops bitterness.  Quite a nice beer, but I liked the Bitter Chocolate Bear better.

black with brown and small light brown head. chocolate coffee aroma with a great cascade undertone and a very light earthiness. silky creamy body with surprisingly crisp carbonation. tastes of dark chocolate with light coffee. beautiful   cascade bitterness and flavor of floral orange and pine. with a lasting roasted bitter flavor. unbelievable

Another very good beer from Rogue. The hint of chocolate and coffee in the taste bring this stout to pretty good. I think it could had a little more umph in the body of the beer. Nice Finish and very drinkable
veramente scura sapore nettamente tostato ma anche luppolato un tocco di dolce dato dall¬íavena tanti sapori ma per niente armonici

Full bodied stout from Rogue.  I was expecting a little more flavor here, but the beer had a great appearance.  Hints of smoke, coffee, and even chocolate, but not enough to really enhance the flavor.  Either way, a good stout.

UPDATED: DEC 2, 2007 Bottle at home ... deep solid black ... roast coffee malt ... high fruit hit ... some blackcurrent ... cherry andplums followed by some sweet roast malt ... tiny bitter chocolate in roast followed by toasted oats. bottle BBF 2004 Drunk 2007 ... Bottle at Toms Ultimate Glasgow Tasting ... Deep black ... with a typical imp stout nose ... lots of roast malts well balanced. 3.9
pours dark brown with creamy head. tastes of roasted malt, chocolate. lingering and pleasant coffee aftertaste. good stuff.
22oz Bomber. pours black with nice brown head. Smells and tastes of chocolate. Very tasty, drinkable. I prefer this brew over the Stone Imerpial Russian :)
UPDATED: OCT 31, 2007 Bottle.  Almost black pour with nice head.  Aroma and taste of dark roasted malt.  Very good stout that I would buy again and recommend.
As far as stouts go, this is one of the better I have had.  Roasted malt flavor with some bitterness to the finish.
xxx this is just a great great beer all around, avery good taste to it, makes me happy-
Bottle. Very dark brown, almost black color. Pretty good, off-white head. Thich, rich palate and taste of dark roasted malt. Just a hint of the flavorful hops. This is an excellant stout.

Massive tan brown head. pitch black color with aromas of sweet chocolate and roasted coffee malt. On the palate  some carbonation mildly. Flavors of roasted malt and light hops. Somewhat lasting finish. Good stout.
One of my favorite stouts!  Chocolate and a roasted flavor are present.  Pours a thick dark black.  I¬íd def get this again, I love this beer and this brewer and this brewery!!!!!!!&

16 oz. nitro pour at The Happy Gnome in St. Paul, MN. Sampled during the pub crawl at the RateBeer Summer Gathering 2007 in the Twin Cities, MN on Friday, June 22, 2007. The Happy Gnome called it "Rogue Nitro Stout," but described it as the nitro version of Shakespeare Stout. I see no "Rogue Nitro Stout" listed on RateBeer, so I¬íll enter it under Shakespeare Stout. Weak aroma of sweet chocolate with a hint of coffee. Pours a dark brown with a large amount of light beige/tan head. Looks very good, as one would expect from a nitro. The initial dominant flavor is coffee, but a carmel, malty sweetness increases with each sip. Nice, roasted coffee finish and aftertaste. Light to medium body. Smooth and creamy; classic nitro palate sensations. Satisfying, but not great. Serves its purpose adequately. I¬ím sure I¬íd like it better carbonated.

A 650 ML purchased at From the Vine for $3.99 or $4.99. I bought a number of beers and lost the receipt so I can¬ít recall which. Pours black. Nice tan head. I recently had a Yeti. It was my first experience with a really hoppy stout. I am a hop head and I like stouts but the 2 together were not really to my liking. This was hoppy but better balanced. Great lingering bitterness.

nice stout. was a bit tuned up when i consumed this so a bit hazy on the details. had at the Gnome one  night. it was on a nitrous tap. the head was so creamy it was unreal and laced like no other. coffee notes with nice choclate too. nice stout would try again sober
a nice dark color with a coffe colored head.  aroma has hints of chocolate and fruit.  more sweet than bitter with a nice chocolate roasted malt finish

22 oz. bottle.  Pour is jet black with a big, rocky khaki head.  A bunch of settling, a very pretty pour.  Aroma is slightly roasted malt, which really comes out as it warms.  There is also a nice citrus hoppiness on the nose.  A rush of flavor in the initial taste piney hops, followed by coffee roasted malt and finishing with a somewhat dry, very clean finish.  Great stuff.

Draught (nitro?) at Bar Americain, NYC.  Dark brown to black color with a frothy/creamy light brown head.  Rich aromas of chocolate cake and espresso.  Flavor was one of the most "earthy" I¬íve tasted in a stout.  Dark chocolate and robust coffee, with notes of what seemed like oil-cured black olives, with almost like a fine and minerally  "soil" character, by which I mean not "dirt," but just a rich fertile earthy goodness.  Mild roasty bitterness on the finish.  Full bodied and smooth.  Pairs very well with the smoky and peppery Bobby Flay fare.

pours black with a frothy head.  Smells roasted....malts, toffee chocolate.  HInts of chocolate as well.  Tastes smokey, a roasted concoction of malts which produces a very nice stout indeed. A strong flavored entry, Rogue never disappoints.

UPDATED: SEP 10, 2007 I had this beer at a bar named Tap in Atlanta.  The bartender offered me this drink when I asked her if she had any Bare Knuckle Stout and they didn¬ít.  I¬ím glad that I was able to try this one because it had a good taste and a very dark colour with a dark brown head.  The taste was smooth and very good. I drank this out of a shaker.

It looks like some gasoline topped off with a brown head that is quite massive and sticks around forever. I can¬ít pinpoint the smell at all, but it was different from other stouts that I smelled. It wasn¬ít as roasty to the nose, but something else. The taste was clean, smooth, and full of delicousness. Lots of malts all over the place and some chocolate to top in off. Feels like sex in the mouth. Good stuff.

Bottled as Ezo Beer¬ís Brown Bear Beer.  Black in color with a thin deep brown head.  Aroma is roasted malts, coffee, anise, molasses, and smoke.  Medium, but almost thin, body.  Smoke, roasted malts, and bittersweet cocoa are the main players here.  Finishes bittersweet with the smoke very evident.  Good, but not what I expected.
A fairly standard stout.  Nothing inspiring.  Fairly light flavor, little aroma.  Flavor didn¬ít stick around.

I expected more aroma, it was hard to pick up the different sensations.  The appearance is typical of a stout.  Dark and delicious.  The flavor was somewhat subdued but I could taste the toffee and oat hints.  Not much of a lasting flavor however I liked the slight hint of bitterness at the end.  There are better stouts out there with more pop.  This one kind of fizzled out on me.

Beautiful opaque black pour, with an initially frothy head, diminished through the session.  Chocolate, caramel, pastry, and possibly a hint of silage comes through the nose.  Well-integrated malts, chocolate, grains, roasts, smoke, nuts and burned toast (crackers) tickle the tongue.  The mouthfeel is very creamy and delicious.  A nice bitter toasted finish ends a very well-rounded brew.  Effervescence of smoky roasted grains lasts for a while.

UPDATED: JUL 20, 2008 Appearance: Pours out pitch black with a modest coffee-colored head that... Hm. Well, the head snuck away while I was watching "Sixth Sense". There wasn¬ít any lacing.

Smell: Aroma is mainly chocolate, roasted malts, and smoke.

Taste: Extreme roasted malt flavors (burnt) that follow with black licorice and chocolate. The bitterness tends to lean towards being astringent, squashing the other flavors. Oh, and this one definitely finishes dry.

Mouthfeel: Smooth, with a sharp carbonation, and just a touch watery.

Drinkability: Not my favorite of the Rogue Gallery.

22oz bomber, no date.  Black with a three finger tan head, great retention.  Aroma has lots of roasted malts, some coffee and unsweetened chocolate.  There may be a hint of oatmeal and grain.  Flavor adds some smoky char and the chocolate takes a backseat for a while.  There was just a little bit of pine in there.  Dry char finish.  Body may be a bit thinner than I would¬íve liked, moderate carbonation.
user_location: Ocean Beach, San Diego, California, USA

text: UPDATED: APR 5, 2009 This is a re-rate.  Initial impression is the aroma: chocolate, coffee, roasty aroma - VERY appealing. The color is a brown/black, with a brown head.  The beer has a medium sweetness, nice flavor of chocolate, roasted coffee and oats.  The mouthfeel is of medium thickness.  Nice long finish of chocolate, oatmeal, light hops on the back end.   Very good beer all the way around.  (I have to admit though, I am partial to stouts)

On tap at the Bocktown. Pour is black opaque and it has a thick chocolate mousse head that fades to a film after a few minutes. Roasty dark beer aroma that lets you know this is truly going to pack a flavor impact. Definitely a stout by the flavor of the first taste. Burned charcoaled meat flavor that sticks to the back of your throat. You know, like when your grilling and drinking at the same time and you forget you got meat on the grill?  Cold strong black coffee.  Low carbonation. Quite bitter and offensive to an extent. Finish is dark, bitter and lasting. This probably should be categorized as an imperial stout.  On par with Oak Barrel Dominion but cannot hold a candle to other more enjoyable stouts that do not offend such as Bells Kalamazoo Stout or Yards Love Stout.
user_location: Beaver Valley, Beaver County, Pennsylvania, USA

text: Dark deep coffee brown, with the  nut-tan creamy head. Bartender did a 2 part pour. Held a malt, coffee taste...bit of light sweet on the end. A little better as it grew slighty to room temp. Went great w/ an Ashton dark cigar.

22 oz Bottle. Pours very dark brown, almost black. Entirely opaque. Smell is malty with lots of coffee and some chocolate, some toffee/caramel notes in there too. Taste was fairly unremarkable: roasted malt with a good balance of bitterness. Mouthfeel was too flat for my liking, but was nice and creamy and really coated the mouth. This beer was a bit of a let down after the hype, but it is still a solid stout.
Very dark brown with a tan head. There is a malty taste with light chocolate. Good stout

On tap at the Saucer.  Deep dark brown with light tan head.  Aroma is slightly floral and citrusy which is unusual for a stout.  Tastes of chocolate, light coffee, and grapefruit.  Must have used American hops for this one.  Like a light version of an Imperial Stout.  Different and interesting.
UPDATED: JUN 5, 2008 Good look and aroma. Didn¬ít get a huge complexities of flavors. Felt almost lacking to me, overall.

Bomber pour.  Pitch black with diminishing tan head.  Some plum and raisin aroma along with an underlying malt presence.  Slightly tingly mouth feel that evened out to a nice creaminess.  Taste of dry, dark fruit with a heavy amount of chocolate and malt.  Very good stout from Rogue.

Bottle. 22 fl. oz. Black color with dark brown head. Pleasant aroma of roasted malt, coffee, and light chocolate.  Full bodied with a dry finish. Flavor is light sweet with a moderate bitter finish.  Good beer, but I prefer the chocolate stout from Rogue.

Dark black with a tan/brown head and slight lacing throughout.  Beer feels and finishes extremely smoothly, almost refreshingly so which is unique in my experience of drinking stouts.  Same general flavors as most stouts, but not over bearing which makes the stout very drinkable.  Very solid stout.

22oz. Bomber
$4.99
Binny¬ís Orland

Poured jet black into an imperial pint glass. If I look hard enough and hold it to the light I can faintly see a mahogany shimmer. The head is amazing after the pour. Two fingers of billowy milk chocolatey goodness that makes itself very comfortable but eventually fades to a cap. Thin micro bubbled lacing after each sip. 

Smells mainly of roasted malts. There¬ís some cocoa powder in there as well along with the smallest amount of burnt malts. I can pick up a little cascade hoppiness at first but it fades to the malts rather quickly. As this beer warms I even pick up sweet tobacco. Smells like a perfect beer to drink on this cold evening.

Tastes begins with mellow bitter coffee beans and intensifies by mid-palate. On the swallow the coffee beans turn themselves in to a creamy cappucino with a touch of milk chocolate in the aftertaste that makes a nice accompaniment. The more I drink the more the bitterness lingers in the finish. Very nicely done.

Mouthfeel is good. I would like it better if it was a little more creamy in the mouth but it¬ís still good. theres some carbonation that makes this beer feel lively and keeps it moving like it should. Finishes moderately dry and clean.

For a stout the drinkability is pretty high. Being cold like it is right now I could easily drink a couple of these bombers. If it was a warm day I don¬ít think it would be as easy to put down.

This is a really clean well made stout. I am constantly finding myself impressed with each new Rogue I pick up.

Rated 10/20/06:  Mighty fine stout. Aroma of roasted burnt malt, coffee, and hops! Jet black pour with a medium dark brown head and some lacing. Velvety smooth mouthfeel this one slowly slides down the gullet with a bitter hop finish incredibly good. Nice rich flavor aside from the roasted malts there is a strong coffee presence along with some chocolate and toffee flavors. A mild smokiness comes about which is unexpected and well received. What¬ís fantastic about this stout is the enormous hop presence, bitter biting and right in line the hops really round out this great brew. Nicely brewed.

This bottle had dust on it and the beer tasted the same. Pour was a dark brown with a ring of cherry for a head. Little aroma of roasted malt. Taste was smokey malt with some caramel and chocolate. Mouthfeel was very thin, though. If this was a little thicker it would have scored higher.
user_location: Moon Twp, suburb of Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania, USA

text: 2 oz bottle. Very black and opaque. Very good stout - very rich and very roasty.
22 oz.  Extraordinary stout, full of flavor and mild roast.  The chocolate rounds it out well & nothing is ever intrusive, smooth. Rogue in every aspect.

The aroma is awsome.  It is full of dried apricots and cherries and roasted malt of course. It pours black with a wulickly diminishing black head. The taste is also mosly of dark roasted chocolate malt and dried fruit. Its definatly a solid stout on the edge of an imperial stout. I gave this beer such a high score because the aromea is awsome, the appearence is good and I think the palate is ideal, so overall think this is awsome.

Bottle @ Copenhagen √òl Festival 2007. Average beige head with some good lacework. Pitch black. Yeast, chocolate, liquorish, coffee, dry fruit. Medium bodied with an average carbonation. Well balanced with a moderated sweet flavour. Sweet malty finish.
Bottle. Dark color, medium frothy brown head. Aroma of roasted malt, rye, licorice, some coffee, oatmeal. Lots of roasted malts, rye and oat in taste. Quite bitter taste. Good balance.
looks, feels and taste how a stout should. dark as burnt motor oil with a small tan foam.  chocolate and malt flavors mingle with the smooth creamy texure producing a exceptional stout.
Pours a nice deep dark brown color with a thick chocolate brown head. The finish is some what clean and it tastes of chocolate and malt. Pretty good beer needs more roasted malt.

650ml bottle.  Burnt motor oil color.  Pours with minimal head.  Alcohol well hidden.  Smoky, burnt chocolate flavor.  Smooth palate.  I am not a big fan of stouts so I don¬ít want to drive down the overall score.  I have had other stouts and in comparison, this is much better.

350ML bottle. Great start-- creamy tan head and strong chocolate aromas.  Fantastic flavor-- full, sweet, chocolatey and certainly more sophisticated than your run-of-the-mill stout.  Rogue really did well here.  Highest Recommendation.
Poured black with nice brown head.  Had the aroma of malts and chocolate.  Nice chocolate flavor with slight bitter palate. Nice stout
Aroma of chocolate and roasted malt.  Taste of sweet chocolate and a good strong hoppy bitterness and an alcohol and burnt coffee finish.  An enjoyable stout.
Botlle. Black colour with a light brown head. Aroma  is hop, burned, coffee. Flavour is hop, burned, coffee, chocolate. Very hoppy and burned coffe, but i like it.

Intriguing appearance
Smells of rich coffees and chocolates
Maintains a strong taste yet goes down as smooth as anything, ultimately leaving you both filled but extremely content.
Bottle.  Aroma is nice... some floral hops, roasted malt and some creamy chocolate.  Flavor is also nice... mostly roasted/chocolate/coffee with a nice amount of bitterness.

I have to admit, I¬íve never been a fan of the stout type of beer.  Too much time spent with Miller Lite and such.  When I poured it out into the glass, I thought I was pouring motor oil.  It smelled very nice, and as I tasted it, I expected something much more hoppy, with an aftertaste, but this is really good.  I¬ím very pleasantly surprised and will definately be adding this to my regular beer menu.
Another great stout from Rogue Ales.  Chocolate and Coffee aroma....wonderful ebony pour and creamy head.  Great stout for the right occassion.

Bottle. Pours very dark brown, almost black, with a nice, dense tan head. Licorice, burnt, some smoke-sourness, chocolate, coffee and mocha in the aroma. Burnt, hops, coffee, mocha and chocolate in the flavor. Full body and a long, roasted finish with hops, chocolate and mocha. I find it maybe a bit too hoppy, I like my stout more on the chocolate- and coffee-side, but a very good beer. (070413)

Deep dark brown color, medium thick head with fine lacing. Aroma of roasted coffee and a hint of mint.  Flavor is rich, texture is creamy.  Notes of coffee, caramel, a faint twinge of cherries & chocolate.  Finish is bitter and lingering.

UPDATED: APR 23, 2007 Draught at Barleys in Knoxville. Pours ultra dark black, with a wonderful brown head. Aroma is strong coffee and chocolate, with some sweetness, like melting chocolate candy. This carries through to the flavor where a nice hop presence shows up as well. After tasting the hops, I wonder how I initially missed them in the aroma. Very nice beer.
Very dark and thick. The taste is that of oaken malt and is very smooth for a stout. Nice slow-sippin¬í beer.

Again a pretty good session beer from Rogue, nothing too serious. Decent dark brown head but not much of an aroma to compliment it. Bitter flavor with smaller chocolate and toffee notes in the background, and a bit of earthy oatmeal. Finishes dry, not much warming effect with only a 6% ABV. Chocolate stout was better for sure.

An inspirational stout that seems to be bringing out the poet in all of us. I shall dabble a wee bit as well.

Super black color, thick as night, 
no light penetrates this glass, as it is poetry to write.
Head is gorgeous, super thickly creamy delight,
big bubbles and luscious lumps, I could swim in it all night.
Colour of light tannish leather, not so light as a feather,
delicate sheets of tight lace did stick together.

Aromas of roasted malts, earthy, tangy hops up front,
some notes of chocolate and coffee and a wee touch of dark-like citrus, nothing to blunt.

Full and delicious, smooth, yummy, dark tones in flavor, 
roasted and chocolate malts with a perfect blend of earthy hops in its favor.
Hop twinge in there, and a nice dryness follows,
all very pleasing, this stout, and continue to swallows.

Full body feel, smooth, then tongue tingly,
to a nice sweet tart-like drying and mingly.

To drink or not to drink, that is the question.
Answer, is to drink this stout! 
And thank Hamlet¬ís revenge it comes in a 22 oz bomber to tout!

UPDATED: JUN 16, 2007 Bottle. Re-rated. Looks delicious as it pours like thick creamy dark chocolate. A complimenting tall mocha head with good lacing tops it off. I get a fairly  weak aroma of roasted coffee and bread. Taste is much more impressive! Starts with a sweet chocolate on the front of the tongue and then deep roasted coffee and the promised smoky earth flavors in the aftertaste. Very nice but not really unique aroma was the weakest aspect.
UPDATED: APR 27, 2007 A very dry stout and not enough to it for me to really take a liking to.  Pretty bitter.  Had this one a while back, but still enjoyed the chocolate stout version a little more.
UPDATED: SEP 1, 2007 Bottle.  Has a rich, creamy, chocolatey flavor with a very smooth, oily mouthfeel.  The aftertaste is of cocoa and coffee.  Not the best stout, but very good nonetheless.

Pours black with a nice tan head that laces well.  The pleasant aroma has plenty of dark roast malt and chocolate. The roast malt flavor has the coffee and chocolate notes that a good stout often has along with ample hops that give it a moderate level of bitterness.  Full bodied and certainly enjoyable, this is a fine stout.
black with tan head. chocolate, coffee, caramelon the nose. hints of chocolate and hops with a rich sweet roastyfinish. very good

After reading several good things written about this beer I thought I would give it a try.
I¬ím all about dark, coffee/chocolate stouts, so I figured this would be right up my alley.
Upon pouring, I wasn¬ít disappointed. It looked like it should. Dark opaque, almost black, thick, no problems there.
The taste is where it didn¬ít live up in my opinion. For one, I like my stouts to be more smooth, less hoppy. There was a nice hint of chocolate mid way through each drink, which was subtle and very well done.
It¬ís easily drinkable. But a bit of a disappointment for a stout. It tasted more like a hoppy porter. Reminded me of the Great Divide St Bridgettes Porter.
Oh well, nothing lost, it was a $3.99 bomber. To each his own, just not to my liking.

Color is deep black with brown head. Aroma is a little sweat and roasted malt. Mouthfeel is very smooth and very good. Flavor is chocolate, fruit, and coffiee. It¬ís complicated and good body. Not dry.

This stout is a deep brown/black with a good-sized, frothy red/brown head with good longevity that leaves great lacing.  The aroma is a little sweet and is of roasted chocolate malt and citrusy hops.  It is medium-bodied with soft carbonation and seems perhaps more watery than I¬íd expect.  It leaves the mouth feeling a bit astringent.  The flavor is of charred wood, chocolate and grapefruit.  Pretty darn good.  This almost seems like a foreign stout to me.
Dark chocolate color with mocha head. Chocolate, coffee, and roasted malts in the nose. Chocolate and coffee in the taste. Nice one to keep warm with.

Bottle.  Almost perfect looking large, creamy, (mostly lasting) brown head.  Black body.  Good lacing.  Chocolate and caramel are present in the aroma.  Some smoke is also present.  Flavor is initially sweet and finishes moderately bitter.  Duration of finish is actually on the short side.  Medium bodied.  Dry textured.  Soft carbonation.  This is a solid stout.

Ultra-dark, viscous pour with a three finger tall, brown head.  The aroma was a bit restrained.  Mostly a smoky, roasted malt with a bit of chocolate.  The flavor was very sweet initially, almost more of a milk stout quality until it opened up a bit.  Then a decent balance of sweet malt, dry  chocolate, smoke and just enough bittering hops to give a nice finish.  Medium bodied.  Nice.

Bottle - Black with creamy head.  Good aroma of roasted malt grains, nuts, caramel, chocolate, hops.  Flavors of malty grain, chocolate, oats, bitter finish.  Good stout.  Definitely a beer to go with a thick juicy ribeye steak.  Cheers!

Still trying to classify this one in my mind.  Dry or Sweet?  I guess the crystal malt makes it more of a dry stout.   I agree, not as good as the chocolate stout, but then I am biased towards sweet stouts.  Has a rich plum, roasted malt and chocolate aroma.  Has an oily, somewhat acidic, grainy palate, with a toasted finish. Oh yeah and it looks great too, I can¬ít fault the looks, really black with a thick creamy looking tan head.   Decent product.
You can cut this with a knife.  This is one of the thickest beers I have tried to date.  Plus the roasted malt and chocolate back ground really shined through.  Excellent stout.
Good dark pour, fine aroma, an excellent stout, makes you want to write plays and read literature

Although thin bodied, this beast is intensely malty. The roasted malts really give this one a kick. There are some nice hints of espresso and licorice, too. This is really good, but still doesn¬ít match up their chocolate stout.

(Bottled, 0.65l@Hilpe√§ Hauki) Very dark brown with a small, cocoa head and some lace. Intensely roasted-malty aroma with lots of salty licorice, and some espresso notes. Very roasted-malty, slightly ashy-burned, very licoricey flavor with at least reasonably bitter hops. No signs of alcohol here. Medium-bodied, neutral and softly carbonated palate. Could be more complex, but anyway it¬ís a very nice, licoricey and hoppy stout.

Definitely malty, but not thick! I was shocked. This beer is only quasi-thick. Nothing like The Yeti. I know I compare a lot of my stouts to this, but it was my favorite stout so that will be the basis of the comparison(s). Nice coffee/chocolate aftertaste. I can say I was impressed with that part of the beer. Even when I poured the beer I noticed it wasn¬ít a thick as some of the others that I¬íve tried. The color is awesome, nice and black with practically no head. Decent beer, and should be commended.
Pours very dark with large tan head.  Arma is malt, taste is chocolate.  Very good, better than the regular rogue chocolate stout IMO.

This is a great looking and smelling beer.  Pours black with a thick light brown head that looks absolutely magnificent.  Smells malty with a hint of hops and chocolate.  Tastes nice, not quite as good I as I was expecting based off reviews i read, but still an excellent beer that I will be drinking again.
Pitch black pour with a coffee, hop, and crispy bread nose.  Flavors of chocolate, lots of malt and hops, and some coffee that¬ís been on the burner for a while.  Went down nice.  Good stout.
Bottle. Black with a nice blend coffee, chocolate, rum and hops in the aroma. Bitter (but very well-balanced), full body and  medium-high carbonat√≠on. My favorite non-imperial stout!

Pours motor-oil black with chocolate mousse-like foamy head. Lots of lacing left on glass.

Surprising whiff of hops up front. Wasn¬ít expecting that, but the aroma hops mingle nicely with the deep, earthy aromas of roasted coffee, chocolate, and tobacco.

The beer is thick and full on the palate. Moderately bitter with some suggestion of chocolate. Not sweet at all. In fact the stout is very dry. The finish is long and dry with flavors of coffee and spent cigar. 

This is a very classy brew that¬ís not too good to befriend store-bought chocolate-chip cookies!
UPDATED: APR 26, 2007 Awesome black color with thin tan head.  Nice lacing with a Coffee Chocolate Malt flavor.  Sweet meets bitter in the middle.. Nice balanced Stout.

Draft. Thick black in the glass with a nice tan head that leaves some lacing. Roasted malt aroma backed with light hops. The flavor found chocolate and roast yet a slight hoppy bitterness. Medium body.
Black color! Lots of burnt malt and hops in flavor---without the sweetness or thickness of some stouts.

Pours pitch black, with a huge chocolate brown head.  Lots of hops and burnt flavors in the aroma.  Flavor has some nice hop bitterness, balanced by a very dry malt character.  Eminently drinkable.  Outstanding stout.
UPDATED: AUG 24, 2007 While I disliked this at first I have come to respect it.  A hoppy stout lots of roasted malts and west coast hops.  Well balanced.  A very good session beer.

This is a sight to behold-- inky black with a chocolaty head. Smells of coffee and toast, tastes of cacao and rye bread. Thick, but unfortunately fizzy mouthfeel. I do love stout, though, and this is an excellent one!
This is what a stout should be.  I have gotten spoiled by these and nice Imperials and fins the stouts that I used to drink to be dumpers.

the flavor is less on the chocolate/coffee and more on the fruity/hops side, which i liked as a change from most stouts. tempered bitter aftertaste. perhaps a little too bitter and dry for the stout-lovers.  the main complaint i had was the seeming over-carbonation. perhaps it was just my bottle, but it had the carbonation-sting of a newly opened can of coke. pours a nice head that doesn¬ít instantly disappear and the ABV is just right.

UPDATED: MAR 25, 2007 22 oz bottle.  Pours ebony in color with a good head when poured fast.  Slight floral nose.  The taste is bitter and dry with a hint of chocolate.  This is a good stout although not quite up to the standard of some of the recent offerings from around the country (or even Rogue itself; the chocolate  and imperial stouts are better).
Pours almost black with a creany tan head. Aroma of malt as soon as I openned the bottle. Tastes of malt chocolate, coffee, caramel. smooth. Very nice finish.

This tastes like a Porter to me,it pours black like tar.Nose of hops and chocolate .Too much hops,like most american brews , it overpowers the malts and makes it bitter.This brew was still very good,just not my favorite type of porter.It has a nice palate refreshing.This costs way to much where I buy it.Very small head from the excessive hops,mocha in color.It has notes of coffee and prunes.If they backed off the hops I would buy it again and give it a higher rating.

UPDATED: MAR 10, 2007 Poured from a 220z bottle, this stout is deathly black with a lingering tan head. Nose is very hoppy with some nice chocolate, coffee, roasted barley and caramel undertones. Flavor was on the bitter side, but mellowed out over time. Medium bodied, a very good beer. Slight edge to their Chocolate Stout though.
Bottle. Deep black, creamy dark cappucino head. Strong roasted and some piney hoppy notes. Dark edges - spikey coffe roast on a moderately light body. Roasted barley aftertaste.
UPDATED: MAY 15, 2008 Bomber.  Very dark, with a tan head.  Roasted malt aroma.  Roasted, malty, and chocolate flavor.  This is a wonderful stout!
Jet black with thin brown head. Chocolate and roasted malt nose with slight hop hints. Thin chocolate malt taste with mild dry finish.

Simply excellent. When you pour it out of the bottle it is a dark dark black (DARK brown) and pours with a thin head yet still frothy. Taste is amazing and the after taste is like dark chocolate. A wonderful stout.

Roasted flavors permeate this dry-ish stout.  Almost porter-like in flavor, & definitely flavorful.  Opaque, black in color; with a deep tan head that quickly diminishes to rest atop the beverage until you polish it off entirely.
Very good stout.  Similar to the chocolate stout if you tone down the chocolate flavor quite a bit.  On the plus side it gets rid of the chalky taste also in that brew.  I enjoyed it a lot.
very good stout.  the best rogue i have had so far.  chocolatey aftertaste and a good balance of malts, barley and hops
Seems like a solid middle-of-the-road stout.  Just the right amount of sweetness and bitterness.  Bears a little more punch than the Rogue¬ís Chocolate Stout, which makes it go better with food.

Bottle. As dark as a night meant to keep secrets with promises of dark chocolate and coffee flavored head. Roasty, toasty malts, cocoa, caramel, and maybe...licorice? Tantalizing tidbits of smokey, hazelnut heaven. Clouds laced with chocolate and coffee.

22oz bomber.  not-quite-black hue, khaki head.  more of a roasted creamy malt aroma than anything else.  hoppy mouthfeel.  it¬ís a good toasted/roasted multitude of flavors.  mild finish; smooth for a stout.  one of the best from rogue
17feb07 Excellent beer.  4.50 a bottle sucks though. Black stout with carmel colored head.

Extremely thick, dark tan head; layers upon layers of thick lacing; roasted and smoky malt, caramel, and chocolate taste with a hint of black licorice at the end, accompanied by some hoppy bitterness; looks beautiful in the glass:  very dark, creamy, and full-bodied (to where a little bit of sediment is left over at the bottom of the bottle); not my favorite stout (I docked some points for the aroma and possibly because I had higher expectations for it), but nonetheless very enjoyable and definitely worth a try!

Bomber from Wilburs poured into english pint at 54 degrees - Pours black with a 2 1/2 finger dark brown head that reminded me of a milkshake; Malt, licorice, caramel, and a little coffee to the nose; Coffee, roast, caramel, and licorice on the initial taste; A very nice roasted bitterness with some dark chocolate and malt sweetness on the aftertaste; A creamy full body; Good carbonation; Definitely liked the body and enjoyed the beer until the last drop!
Pours a rich dark black with a bubbly tan head. Aroma of darkly roasted malts and cocoa flavors. Taste is coffee, oak notes & smokiness. A bit thin and the flavor wasn"t  quite strong enough
Extremely dark in the glass with a small tan head forming. Roasted malty goodness at the nose. Much the same on the palate with coffee and choclate coming through as well. Finishes quickly.
Bottled. Poured dark brown, medium brown head. Nose is raisins and smoke. Flavor is smoky, chocolatey and the finish is dry and nicely bitter.

22oz bottle.  Pours black with rich creamy tan head.  Aroma mild, roasted malt and very hoppy.  Flavor is powerful!  Roasted malt, chocolate, raisins, with a touch of brown sugar, pronounced hop flavors up to the task of balancing the malt.   One amazing stout!
Black color with a nice brown head. Slight chocolate aroma of coffee. Body a bit light and the bitter aftertaste lingers on the tonge and is dry.
Bomber.  Dark brown, blackish pour with thin deep brown head.  Aroma of coffee, chocolate, hops and some faint nutty scent.  Taste of chocolate and coffee with a semi bitter finish.  Fantastic.

220z. bomber. This stuff pours out almost black but i looks thinner than I would think. Aroma is nice with nuts, roasted malt and possibly a bit of smoke. Taste is smoked bacon and nutty. Mouthfeel was very thin and slightly dissapointing. Alcohol was tame and not a factor. Bitter finish with bakers chocolate and hops.

Fresno finaly got this dude. Pours a like any other good stout, dark as teh night and forms a dark tan head. Smell is jsut good, nothing really spectacular. Taste is where it¬ís at. Very full of chocolate and slight alcohol. Very very good brew and will get again for sure.

Solid. Very nice dark oily looking stout. Forms a wonderful but ephemeral head. All is balanced and in perfect proportions for a regular stout. 

Congrats !

Nice thick looking black pour with a quickly fading dark tan head.  Nose is dominated by the roasted malt.  Mouthfeel is not quite as thick as I expected, but the carbonation is near perfect for a stout.  Flavor starts with chocolate and finishes with nice coffee bitterness.

Pitch black with a creamy, beautiful, dark nougat head. The aroma has notes of roasted malt and the smoothness from the oats is nice. The flavour is very smooth, full-bodied, harmonic with notes of chocolate, and even if it¬ís smooth and gentle, it has a nice strong hoppy bite in the finish. A truly nice stout. 1526

Pours black with a thick creamy/slightly rocky brown head. Light aroma of caramel, with notes of chocolate, light coffee, and hops. Chocolate, and lightly bitter coffee are  most notable in the flavor, along with some caramel and light earthy notes. Palate is medium/full, a bit chewy, lightly bitter coffee, but a bit more carbonation than needed. Definately the best Rogue I¬íve had so far.

Jet black with a lasting light brown head. Burned and roast aromas, some wood, brandy and a hint of cherry. Sweet and fruity flavour that finishes dry and wooden. Somewhat thin and watery for the big flavour.

22 oz. bomber.  Nice thick pour, resulting in a jet black brew with a dark tan head.  Powdered cocoa and chocolate malt aromas dominate.  Palate a bit thin, I prefer something like Kalamazoo¬ís thick chalky feel.  Roasty and chocolately to begin and smoothly transitions to a dry roasted finish.  A great beer, one of my favorite Rogues.

The color was a very nice deark black, which light could not penetrate.  The head was very thick, medium brown, and creamy.  The aroma was roasty, coffee, chocolate, and vanilla.  The flavor was nice dark roast, coffee, bitter, some hops, and nutty.  The palate was smooth and the finish was clean with a little bitterness.

I thought this was a really good stout. Ergo, I rated it well. Pours a pretty black brew, lacks the viscosity of the impy¬ís i¬íve come to know and love. The head is nice, thick, creamy, tan, lasts a good while too. Mmmmm, sweet aroma, chocolate, coffee, roasty, some toffee/caramel maybe. Flavors good too. Roasted, coffee, chocolate, however, lacks the depth of an impy (i¬ím not judging them in comparison though). The palate is full and creamy. The finish is smooth and leaves a burnt taste in my mouth. Good stout. I didn¬ít think Bell¬ís Kalamazoo was really any better.

Pours a beautiful pitch black with a dark brown head with great retention & character. Aroma of coffee, chocolate, roasted malt, dark brown sugar. Complex, rich taste - burnt malt, coffee, light hopping. Nearly no aftertaste - a bit of a disappointment. A veritably thixotropic body - I have never tasted such a thick beer! Slightly lacking in carbonation. Great brew, shame about the aftertaste, but a winner all the same.
Pours a dark color with a brown head. Aroma of chocolate and coffee. Tastes of coffee, hops, roasted malts and chocolate. Finish with light hop bitterness. Great Stout.

UPDATED: MAR 6, 2007 Pours very black with a dark brown head.  Very thick.  Smells like chocolate. Tastes of cocoa and is heavy in mouth with a bitter aftertaste.  This tastes like the Rogue chocolate stout with not as much chocolate.

Pours a deep thick black color, darker than Iago¬ís heart. This is topped by about half an inch of soft brown foam. Thick sheets of lacing. Coffee and chocolate a-plenty in the aroma.

Silky smooth texture with lots of roasted grain, bitter chocolate, and strong coffee flavors. Very full flavors. A touch of hop bitterness in the finish and aftertaste. The roasted flavors are so strong in the aftertaste that they are almost smoky.

Fairly full bodied for a stout, again I¬íll mention the smooth texture. Moderately carbonated, making it pretty creamy

22oz old bottle/recipe from 1999. Poured almost black in color with a tiny tan head. Aromas were roast then chocolate, oats, caramel and a very mild hop. The taste was big on the roast flavor with a good chocolate and oat finish. Not sure why they had to try and tweak this recipe out any further. I would give it a even higher rating if it wasn¬ít from 99¬í

Bottle. Black colored with large head. Fair lacing. Aroma of chocolate, coffee, grains and just a slight whiff of grass hops. Taste is chocolate, coffee, light hops. Creamy texture. Medium/full body. Sweet and slightly bitter aftertaste.

Dark, black color with a dark tan head. Aroma is mostly chocolate and roasted malts. Taste is the same as above while remaining smooth with a pleasant bitterness in the finish. This is a really good stout.

(bomber)poured into a pint.  pours a dark, almost black, can¬ít see thru it when you hold it to the light.  The head is dark tan and frothy to the rim.  has a smooth chocolate aroma.  very smooth on the palate front, middle, and finish.  has a light mocha chocolate taste with hints of coffee, with a real tasty aftertaste..... very good stout.

Pours a deep brown edging on black with a thin and fading light brown head.  Not too jazzed over the aroma - it is all over the place in a bad way, a bit muddled, I cannot pick out anything entirely distinct.  I think the aroma here would be what you¬íd get if you stuffed a chocolate bar into lukewarm coffee and then crumbled burnt toast all over it...not that I¬íve ever done that, or anything.  Taste is slightly redeeming, with a roasted malt presence coming through more than anything else. Slight coffee, and a pleasing and not-so-subdued hop fruitiness that fades to a significant but not overpowering bitterness in the finish.  A little lacking on the tongue compared to some.
On tap @ Coles Buffalo, NY. Very dark black body with dark khaki head. Chocolate, rosated malts & Coffee very evident. Medium to full bodied & very well balanced. What a stout should be. Wonderful

Dark black pour, well retained mocha head. Semi-sweet aroma with notes of chocolate, heavily roasted malts and coffee. Simple and refined, sharp and robust. Flavor is much the same, less chocolate and more roast. Hops provide a nicely bitter finish. Alcohol is present but not much of a factor. Mouthfeel is full and balanced, as was the flavor.
