Finishes dry and very roasty with a touch of chocolate malt lingering. This is almost a benchmark for the style. Not overly exciting but incredibly consistent for such a large batch product. Very good and always a reliable and satisfying choice.

Draught at pub.  Deep, deep brown with thick beige head.  Aroma of oat, chocolate, coffee and hops, complex but balanced.  Malty flavour with hops and oatmeal and coffee.  This reminds me of a good Cape breakfast.  Hoppy finish and chocolate.  Drink this in a pint glass at cool room temperature.
user_location: Munchen an der Willamette, Oregon, USA

text: 22 oz bomber - the beer is lighter in the pour, showing off a brown nature, compared with in the glass, where it¬ís a couple shades darker, though still showing off some lightness at the edges.  Nice foamy beige head. The Cascades are really there in the aroma, along with light chocolate malts and espresso.  Flavour very, very nice - opens with a surprising fruitiness from the hops, then immediately switches gears into a robust, dark roasted malt mouth filler.  All this segues into a long bitter hop/dry dark cocoa finish.  Excellent stuff, and much more full-flavoured than many things that call themselves stouts.  The body and flavour of this one creeps toward Imperial Stout territory, without the big boozy hit that many of those beers often have difficulty disguising.  Bravo!

Bomber.  Dark pour with a brown head.  Interesting beer.  Roasted coffee and some piney hops in the nose.  Pretty complex taste once it warmed up a bit.  Roasted malt, some chocolate, heavily hopped.  This was good, but the thought that I had was that it seemed like a subdued imperial stout.  All of the flavors that you expect from an imperial stout were there, but just not as intensely as you would get when drinking a good impy stout.  Still, a good beer and one of the best I have had from Rogue.

Good beer, but I wasn¬ít blown away.  nice taste, but weak aftertaste.  bitter, but not too bitter. Chocolate and coffee flavors are apparent, as one would expect from a Rogue stout.  A solid B/B+ beer.

Bottle 75cl. Black with a fine brown head. Roasted malts - caramel, chocolate & coffee. High bitterness from hops. Soft & creamy carbonation/mouthfeel. Body is filling, could however be thicker/fatter. Good Rogue!

Pours an absolute pitch black with a dark brown one inch head, slowly fading to a solid cap and leaving behind lots of really nice lacing. Very impessive looking.

Smell; chocolate and coffee notes really stand out up front, with roasted malts and little bit of black licorice.

Taste; chocolate coffee as the nose indicated, with bits of rasins and licorice. There¬ís also just a touch of soy sauce, but not to much so. I like the slight hop bitterness that keeps this from being overly sweet. Mouthfeel is just a touch thinner than I would have liked, but still pretty good, and this is very easy to drink.
user_location: Where the hell am I?, Nebraska, USA

text:
A: Pitch Black, Great head w/ many large bubbles. Head didn¬ít last long
S: Nutty, Chocolaty, Good esters
T: Bitter Chocolate, Spicy, Warming flavor
M: Heavy and lingering. 
D: Great flavor
A great beer for my first review. Opened this up to celebrate the birth of my daughter. I quit all alcohol while the wife was preg and this was my treat afterwards. Perfect choice.
Pours black with a long lasting brown head. Head also had some lacing to it. Tasted of coffee malts with an underlying chocolate taste. A nice amount of hops for a stout.

Pours black with brown head.  Aroma is coffee and a little minty.  Taste is roasty and oak, with coffee and chocolate flavors.  Aftertaste is very bitter and lasts a long time.  Palate is thick and meaty.  The taste is better than the aftertaste.  I¬ím getting sick of the aftertaste as I drink this.  ¬ìGood for a change of pace, but not something I would drink a lot of¬î ¬ñ Brad.

22 oz bottle from sam¬ís liquor in chicago.  Pours black with dark brown fluffy head.  Nice roasted coffee and dark chocolate aroma that mingled with the aroma of cascade hops.  The mouth feel wasn¬ít what I expected with it having oatmeal as one of the ingredients.  Nice lacing down the glass.  Had a bit of a smokey, phenolic flavor (is it infected?).  I expected more of a dark chocolate flavor.  An interesting beer.  There are other stouts I¬íd buy over this, but it was very drinkable all the same.
Expecting sweeter taste and thicker mouthfeel.  Earthy as stated with gentle smokey tones.  Not as expected but still very enjoyable.
Pours very dark with very little brown head.   Aroma is of a chocolate coffee, flavor is malty and with hints of coffee and chocolate.  One of the better stouts out there.
Pours jet black with a firm, thick head. Aroma is coffee and hops. Nice coffee, choc and malt flavour. Quite good.
Black pour with thick lasting head.  Smokey aroma and taste.  Slight chocolate presence with stronger coffee overtones.

Bottled, Poured a beautiful black with fluffy tan head. Head dissapated to a thin but still had good lacing. Roasted/coffee aroma with a hint of sweetness. Chocolate roasted flavor with smooth finish. Rogue Scores again.

Pours black with a brown head.  Bitter chocolate aroma with toasted oats overtone.  Sweetness in aroma is not evident in initial taste.  Taste pleasantly fills the mouth and leaves a smoky aftertaste.  A highly enjoyable stout that is well balanced.
nice dark stout, good choc, coffee bitterness, good amount of head, has slight smokyness. great beer

Pours a dark brown color with thick brown frothy head.  Aroma of roasted coffee, chocolate, malt, and light hops.  Nice lacing as the beer is consumed in a shaker glass.  Taste is interesting with roasted coffee, milk chocolate, sweet malt and a roasted grain taste with a splash of hops.  This is a pretty good stout but something doesn¬ít seem right in the finish.

Pours a dark brown color with a brown head.  Aroma is of roasted malts, coffee, chocolate, molasses, and a hint of hops.  Flavor is the same with a slight bitter aftertaste.  A very good, well-balanced stout.

22oz. bomber - pours black with a pretty big light brown head that settled quickly to a foamy layer on top. Really nice, big lacing left in the glass. Roasty, espresso coffee aroma, medium in intensity. Could be "bigger". The flavour however is much more pronounced, with lots of chocolate, coffee, roasted malt, and some hops. Yes, typical stout stuff, but the flavour here is so well balanced (including the bitterness) and big, it sets itself apart. Earthy, creamy, with a mild sugary character. Finishes lightly bitter and very pleasantly dry. Big roasty flavour, very good stout. Fantastic, I¬íll be picking it up regularly.
22 oz bomber.  Pours dark brown with lighter brown hues and a medium beige head.  Slightly roasty with a subtle bitter finish.  A bit watered down.
22 oz. bomber into imperial pint glass. Pitch black with a tan head. Aroma of chocolate, coffee. Creamy mouthfeel. Finish is bitter chocolate. Overall very nicely done.
Bottle. Ptch black brew. Aroma of chocolate, coffee and roasted malts. Well roasted creamy malty flavour with chocolate and coffee, some bitter hops, oat and some caramel. Good chocolate aftertaste.
Dark brown stout with a nice tan head. Finishes smooth with notes of chocolate and coffee.

Bottle into pint glass - Talon1117 gives an accurate, detailed review right below me.  I enjoyed their Mocha Porter just a liiiitle bit more than this one. The short finish is a major flaw that prevents it from receiving a 4 on my scale. All in all though... this is a solid Stout from Rogue that all Beer lovers should try.

UPDATED: MAR 1, 2011 Awesome pour; black with only faint hints of red when up to the light; head is full, creamy, pillowy, and a dark color.  The tight head lasts a significant while and leaves excellent lacing.  Simple but very pleasant nose; bittersweet dark chocolate, roasted grains, light coffee with significant hops aromas of earth and light floral.  Flavor is not nearly as appealing, burnt toast and light chalk are dominant with some dark chocolate, roast, maybe some oats.  Bitterness is moderate with earthy, almost cedar-like, hops and a good amount of acidity is also noted.  Palate is medium with a moderate carbonation, and a velvety feel.  Finishes dry with earthy cedar and bittersweet chocolate, kind of short.  Despite the fact that I didn¬ít really like the flavor, the rest of the beer is put together very well.  I have not tried this in a few years and my feelings are the same.  The chalkiness is a bit overwhelming but the cascade notes seem more prominent, which is nice but a bit clashing with the style.  And I feel like the oats do not add creaminess to the palate.  A bit overrated in my book.

Appears a black with a dark chestnut hue when held to the light. A 2 finger, tan head slowly fades out into a collar and mild cap. Streaky lacing is left around the glass.
Smell is of mocha, coffee, cocoa, creamy vanilla, brown sugar, roasted nuts, and caramel.
Taste is of the mentioned aromas all in a French Roast base that has a delicious but rich flavor.
Mouthfeel is roasty, full bodied, rich, mildly bitter, along with moderate carbonation and a semi-dryness.

What a stout! Had this on tap at Taco Mac. Poured a beautiful Guinness-black, with a finger-thick dark brown head that dissipated, but lasted thinly throughout. Great lacing. Nose is chocolates, roasted malts, oats. Flavor is the same, with even more earthiness and roast flavor, big chocolate and oatmeal. Smooth, thick, but silky mouthfeel. In my top ten stouts. Highly recommended.

Bottle.   Pours an inky black color with a small retreating tan colored head.   Aroma is burnt sugar, roasted malts, chocolate.   Flavor is chocolate, coffee, burnt sugar, oatmeal.   Palate is definitely full bodied, medium carbonation, creamy, bitter finish.   Good but something was just off for me.   I liked it better when I had it as Wild Irish Rogue, many years ago.

Pours a wonderful looking black with a dark brown fluffy head.  Crackles with what sounds like too much carbonation though, but I¬íll get back to that.  Aroma opens with dark chocolate, dirt, and a spicy herbal hop quality poking through.  Hmm, now I get a little oatmeal as well.  The beer make it¬ís dark chocolate tastes known right away, along with some mildly acidic black coffee notes.  Finishes with a real dark effervescense: chocolate again, but there¬ís a licorice taste merging with the tangy cascade hop flavor.  Lingering bitterness is pretty complex, and still makes me recal the dirt in the aroma.  I think the beer is SLIGHTLY on the thin side, but it¬ís plenty creamy and fills the mouth well enough still.  Carbonation starts too high, but can be easily let out with enough glass swirling.  For some I reason, I¬ím always catching some dirt and earth in Rogue beers, which is something I enjoy.  This beer is the definitive statement from Rogue in my opinion.

On tap at Landmark.  Dark color.  Smell of roasted coffee, vanilla,  hops, malt, chocolate cake, molasses and hints of oak.  Taste of bitter chocolate, a lot of hop flavor, sweet malt, caramel, toffee, vanilla beans and roasted coffee.  Wonderful bitterness at the end.

From 22 oz bottle. Poured VERY dark, almost opaque. Very nice aroma and hints of  musty chocolate. Great lasting flavor, but a little thinner that I would have expected from such a dark pour - thought it would be more of a mouthful. Still, a very acceptable beer from Rogue¬ís stable of fine brews.
No question about it -- this is a stout.  It¬ís black as coal with a creamy brown head.  However, it is a little more bitter than I like, like many of the Rogue beers I have tried.

JUST SO THAT YOU ALL KNOW!! WHEN RATING BEERS, EACH CATAGORY/
STYLE SHOULD INDEPENDENT OF ALL OTHERS. THERE SHOULD BE A "BEST " IN EACH CATAGORY. IT SEEMS THAT MOST PEOPLE WHEN JUDGING A BEER MAY BE THINKING OF ANOTHER THAT WAS BETTER. ( THIS SHAKESPEARE STOUT IS VERY GOOD BUT NOT AS GOOD AS THAT BELLS  EXPEDITION STOUT THAT I HAD) ??? 2 DIFFERENT STYLES OF BEER!!! THERE IS A 1 - 5 IN ALL STYLES!!  EX. ALL 25 TOP
IMPERIAL STOUTS ARE SCORED A 4 OR HIGHER BUT "STOUTS" ONLY THE FIRST 5.  EACH CATAGORY SHOULD HAVE IT¬íS HIGH 4¬íS - 5 AND IT¬íS 1¬íS. BY THE WAY AS FAR AS "STOUTS" ARE CONCERNED SHAKESPEARE IS 4.7

Bomber.  Deep opaque dark brown to pitch pour with a creamy light brown head.  Sweetish and mellow milk chocolate nose and tons of malt, with a few malted milk balls plonked into the mix.  Roast and dark chocolate, too.  Dry, bitter stout taste, light oats shining through from behind the powerful dark roast.  Medium ending sourness to complement the dry oaten bitterness that lasts for some time.  Chocolate dies off after a while, but that¬ís not a minus.  Medium-thin body.  Probably the best I¬íve had from Rogue.
Aroma¬ís of chocolate ann roasted malts.Pours dark black with a medium tan head.Good chocolate and coffee in the taste.Mouthfeel is a little thin with  bitter chocolate and hops in the finish.

Very pleasantly surprised. Beautiful head, very full taste. Rates with my favorite regular stouts (Brooklyn Chocolate & Storm King). Am at this moment sipping a Rogue Chocolate Stout, which, in comparison, is thin and less complex.

Bomber. Pours thick and has a foamy head in my chilled glass. Aroma seems slightly faint. Initial flavor is good, roasted coffee and chocalate yet with a bit of hop and I like that in a Stout. My whole mouth can taste this and that is nice. The finish is truffle like.

Black with deep brown head, which fades. The aroma is actually plesant. Chocolatey, oatey, roasted coffee and a nice hop, dry touch. This beer, as with Rogue beers in general, is thin. The flavor isn¬ít bad. Nice roasty chocolate flavors, decent malt profile; however there¬ís no chewyness. I¬íve noticed this with the Rogue beers I¬íve tries so far. It does have a nice hoppyness for a stout and finishes with a pleasant roasty espresso flavor.

22 oz bomber.  Pours a black cola like color with a thick and creamy brownish beige head.  Aroma is of baking chocolate,roasted oats,barley and malt.  Taste is of dry dark chocolate,oats,malt and smoke.  Slightly inferior to the Rogue Chocolate Stout, but very good regardless.

Bomber; pours thick black with a thick dark tan head that dissipates, minor lacing.  Aroma of dark roasted malts with coffee and molasses.  Nice full taste; smooth with a slight bitter finish.  Another good one from Rogue.

From a 22 oz. bomber bottle with no freshness date.

Poured a dark, blackish coffee brown with a foamy, bubbly topped tan head that settled into a thin lacing.

Aromas of caramel, toffee, sweet roasted malts and a light citric hop.

Good moderate carbonation and a crisp, creamy smooth full bodied mouthfeel.

Delicious tasting stout, sweet roasted malts, caramel covered chocolate, a hint of bitter coffee, a citric hoppiness towards the end and a sweet roasted coffee malt finish with a soft chocolate lingering in the palate.

Just a great stout from Rogue, highly drinkable.
Black, oil like colored. Very nice roasted malts. Dark chocolate and dark fruits. Medium sweet taste with a subtile bittterness. Nice stout.

Aroma of roasted coffee malts and chocolate. Black coloured with a thin, brown head. Taste is initially slightly sweet en becomes more bitter towards the finish. The finish is quite explosive bitter. Roasted coffee/chocolate malts in it.Definetaly strong on hops. Slick mouthfeel, perhaps a slightly thin body. Overall a nice stout, but it could use more balance.
Bottle. Damn this beer is good. Very creamy and smooth, chocolate scent. Chocolate taste. Love Rogue.
GABF-on tap-pours a tan head with black color.  Aroma is chocolate.  Taste is chocolate.  Mild carbonation.

UPDATED: NOV 5, 2006 650 mL bottle.  Pours black with a nice tan head that is less frothy than most stouts.  Aroma is of caramel and nuts, most likely oatmeal.  First sip is very roasty with a nice amount of bitterness and flavors of nut, molasses, oatmeal, yeast, with some vanilla (maybe honey?) sweetness.  Nice and bold but easy to drink.  Man I can¬ít believe how long this head is lasting!  Very strong finish highlighted by coffee and chocolate malt mixed with the cascade hops.  After-burp tastes like molasses and chocolate.  A very nice stout.  Shakespeare would be proud.

UPDATED: NOV 6, 2006 650ml - Pours an inpenetrable black with a creamy brown head, tight bubbles, decent lace.  Woody nose with some spicy notes.  caramel and coffee on the palate with an almost  dusty, earthy taste.  OK.

UPDATED: NOV 5, 2006 Thick black pour with thick tan head.  Rich chocolate and toasted malt aroma.  Nice roasted-grain and hop flavor.  Alot like dark chocolate with a bit of espresso.  Nice mouthfeel and a smooth finish.

Bomber. Pours black with a creamy, light brown head. Chocolatey notes, almost smells like smores... medium mouthfeel, smooth beer, and aftertaste if i just got done eatin a hersheys, well balanced.  Just wish it had a little more chew to it.
UPDATED: SEP 29, 2007 jet black, opaque color. Deliciously creamy. Tons of burnt flavors, and a nice sweetness to round it out.
Very dark in color with a carmal color head only 1 finger. Has the hint smell of oatmeal and carmal. Has a hint of oak taste.

Pours almost black with a a nice tan head.  The aroma has lots of roasted malt, lots of chocolate and some woody hops.  Medium / full body that is very smooth with a small amount of soft carbonation.  The taste has lots of roasted mlats with some dark chocolate.  The finish has some creamy malt along with woody hops and some spiciness.  An excellent stout I will be having again fairly soon.
22oz bottle: Pours a dark brown/blaclc color, huge head, lasting, brown/light brown color.  Very stouty aroma, coffee, not much else.  Coffe taste, rich.  Somewhat watery.

22 oz bottle.  Very nice stout - not as good as Rogue Choc. Stout - but very good.  Deep black color - fairly thick.   Smooth, taste which had a distinguishing hoppy flavor that I loved.  A different characteristic that I appreciated.  A repeat buy will happen. My full rec.

Ah...deep and black with a light creamy head. A nose of chocalated coffee and barley. Tasted primarily of earthy barley, a bit of peanut, and coffee notes. Could use a bit more carbonation, but could that have been the draft¬ís fault. Overall, a damned good porter.

Poured from 22 oz. bottle.  Jet black with light caramel head.  Aroma had hint of coffee and chocolate.  Very smooth beer, and the mild chocolate aftertaste was great.  Wasn¬ít a very sweet chocolate, but rather bitter.  Definitely a good stout.
Jet black body with a tan head, hoppy nose.  nicely carbonated for a stout, surprisingly hoppy flavor for a dark stout, unique but not as balanced as i would like

UPDATED: JUL 31, 2008 A nice beer with hints of smoke and coffee.  Well balanced, slightly bitter.  I also catch an aroma of chocolate.  The lingering taste is of a bitter cocoa, while the nose is much sweeter.  It is not my favorite stout, but it is very decent.  748316
---re-rate---
Aroma is creamy, milky with chocolate and dark malt, and maybe a little dms, but not a lot.
Taste is sweet although a slightly assertive hoppiness makes its presence felt.  And a little bit sour on the finish.  
Very solid beer.  I‚Äôll keep the rating as is.
UPDATED: SEP 23, 2007 A smoky, malty, rich beer.  Definitely balanced towards bitter.  Very little sweetness. Very dark.  Notes of coffee.  Solid.
22oz bottle from the spirit haus.  dark brown thick head. chocolate and smokey flavors are blended with the subtle hops... yummy.  This has the best creamy mouthfeel out of any stout I have tried.

pours thick dark black with a dark brown head. aroma lots of cocoa with a hint of coffee. bitter coffee cocoa slightly acidic. medium body. lively carbonation. long acidic bitter coffee finish. great stout. this is how it should be done. dark thick flavorful and you can drink it all night long.

Once again, another fine Rogue ale.  A one time undisbuted champ, this beer stick kicks a punch and is supurbly balanced.  It lacks the complexity and alcohol of the new Stouts but remains a great staple.  Rock on, Rogue!

650ml brown bottle. Black pour, rocky and frothy tan head. Hops prominent in aroma, pine and citrus with cocoa below it. Chocolate and coffee flavours mix with a lot of hop flabvour. Finish is suitably bitter and long. Medium body and carbonation. Another solid Rogue stout.
On Tap at Rogue Brewer¬ís on The Bay Newport OR. pours out a black topped with a nice tan head. A good mix of coffee, roast and chocolate. I also picked up some smoke.

Bomber. Pours near black with a medium red-tan head. Aroma is very chocolatey, with some roasted malt and coffee notes - don¬ít even have to put my nose near the glass to smell it. Flavor is much more on the coffee side, kind of smoky and bitter. Mouthfeel is creamy, a little oily, and slightly carbonated with a pretty dry finish with a fair amount of hoppiness to it. Solid.
Pours black with a creamy tan head.  Aroma is roasts and chocolate.  Taste is mostly roasts with chocolate, coffee, and smoke.  Hops are citrusy and noticeable.  Wonderful creamy mouthfeel.

Bomber. Pours an opaque blackish brown with a thick and lacy dark tan head. Aroma of chocolates and coffee with maybe a hint of oranges behind it. Creamy medium body with fine carbonation. The taste is roasty, smokey, with chocolate and coffee leading to a espresso bitter finish with some piney notes.

Pours a dark black center, brown at the edges; tannish-grey head with slight retention and fine-bubbled lacing.  Nose is immense: coffee, dark chocolate, cinnamon / spice, with a smoky, roasted quality rounding things out; even a bit of citrusy hops in there.  Medium mouthfeel, showing roasted malts, milk chocolate, smoke; lengthy finish ends in smoky, bitter chocolate.

Bottle.  Dark, dark brown/black, rocky beige head.  Aroma is metallic, coffee, roasty, burnt malts, hint of alcohol.  Flavor has lots of dark chocolate.  Burnt, smoky flavor, earthy.  Not as dry as I expected, but still dry.  Oily on the palate, and a bit under carbonated.  This is a decent beer, but nothing fantastic.  It is good, though, that it¬ís widely available.

Bottle.

Powerful look and massive aroma. Coffee and coffee in masses. Some chocolate and a great bitterness in the end.
Very dark color with athick tan head. Notes of espresso and chocolate. Medium body with a very nice bitter finish.
Nice black with thick brown head. Chocolate, coffee and creamy bitter. Dry finish with a very good balance.

[Sampled at RGESG 2006]
Almost black.
Sweet, full with flowery hopiness and chococlate.

22oz, pours oily black with moderate foam.  Great Cascade hop aroma, nice citrus and some hints of greek olive, also light coffee..  Lots more citrusy hops and pleasant roasted malts in flavour. Nice, but much hoppier than I expected for a stout.

From 22oz Bottle.  Jet black, opaque pour with a tall layer of well sustaining, toasted brown head.  Deep, dark, roasty malt aromas with a hint of black licorice and a whiff of molasses.  Very rich aromas, coated with an oily, dark belgian chocolate incense.  Medium to full bodied mouthfeel with a touch of syrupy texture, but also with a healthy dose of sparkling carbonation.  Rich, dark, malty flavors of toasted pumpernickel bread and a bit of syrupy espresso coffee.  Lovey roasted notes, but I find myself searching vainly for something else to be there.  No matter - this is a fabulously classic stout style that brings out a bit of its American heritage in the dose of herbal hoppy spice that greets me for the final smack.

This is a nice dark, strong stout. Lots of bitterness and lots of malt (slightly out of balance from the bitterness, but not bad by any means).  Nice chocolately, mocha and dark coffee on the nose, similar with taste. Very up-front... A great value stout!

UPDATED: AUG 14, 2007 Bomber.
Pours deep black without much head, the nose is mostly roasty chocolate but is not particlarly powerful even at near room temperature. Again bittersweet chocolate in the flavor, actually some almost sourness as the hops come in with a snap leaving an unsweetened cocoa finish. Mouthfeel is fine for the style and ABV, but I¬ím just not nearly as impressed as I¬íd expected to be given everything I¬íve heard and read about this one.
22 oz. bottle.  Pours a jet black with a dark tan head.  Nice aroma of coffee and chooclate.  Taste is dark and rich with a tart/sharp bitter finish.  A very nice stout.

Bomber. Pours ebony, almost black, minimal highlighting. Big dun-colored head that looks almost pumpkin colored during the pour. Not much lace, but the head really hangs around. Beautiful roasted nose. Lots of chocolate, roast, toast through the attack and mid-palate, and the finish is nearly sweet but not quite. The sugar is subdued enough that it doesn¬ít assert, but it definitely adds complexity and a little stickiness to all the other flavors. This was the first really dark beer I ever had about 15 years ago, and I still love it nearly as much even after all the hundreds of others.

[bottle] Looks great: near-black appearance with a solid tan head. Aroma of cocoa and roasted malt. Excellent smooth, dark malt flavor. Some subtle coffee and chocolate notes come out towards the end, as well as a nice smoothness (due to the oats). Nice, solid hop bitterness in the end. A very nice, smooth stout.

UPDATED: NOV 20, 2008 First rating(Bottle at RBESG 2006) Dark color, tan head. Nice sweet and hoppy scent. Spritzy mouth feel. Bitter taste and high bitterness.8/3/6/3/12=3.2Rerate(Bottle at a beer tasting in G√∂teborg on July 4, 2008)Clear dark red color, fark brown head. Sweet chocolate scent. Acidic, malty, grainy taste. Spritzy mouthfeel, low bitterness. Roasted aftertaste.7/4/6/3/13=3.3  Rerate - (bottle) Black color, brown head. Hoppy and chocolate scent. Smooth malty and hoppy taste, bitter aftertaste. Smooth to medium mouthfeel, rather high bitterness. 8/4/7/4/15=3.8

RBESG 2006 Grand Tasting. Pitch black colour, low tan head. Very nice roasty and hoppy aroma, some sweetish bakery notes in the background. Nice roasty flavour, not overdone, notes of good coffee, hints of dark chocolate. A very good stout in my book.

A black brew with a creamy tan head with bit of a red tint. Aroma is chocolatey roasted malt with a hint of dark fruit. Sweet, bitter flavor, roasted chocolate. Bitter aftertaste but very mellow for a stout.

An impressive look to this beer.  Black, with a thick brown head that lasts for some time.  Black sediment in the bottom of the bottle.  Aroma is simple but good.  Malt, coffee, and dark chocolate.  Flavor is equally simple and straightforward.  Here roasted malt is predominant, followed by abundant chocolate and only a hint of bitter coffee.  A very thick beer, but it requires a large sip to get the full flavor of the beer.  Too small of a sip and the flavor is too light.  They should do something with a little more alcohol and get into the imperial stout category.

Bottle. Poured a deep brown color with a thick beige head.  Aroma is mixture of chocolate, roasted malt, hops and is very smokey.  Flavor was very mixed and carried over from the aroma with a light touch of molasses in the background. Very well balanced and leaves the palate with a slightly sweet finish. Definately a nice brew.

UPDATED: SEP 18, 2006 Black pour with a medium sized, frothy, light-brown head.  Aroma of roasted malt, mocha, vanilla, and a little hops.  Flavors of coffee, chocolate, vanilla, a little smoke, and finishs with hops.  Not as thick as an imperial, which makes it easier to drink.  Another well done rogue.

Bottle. Black color with a small brown head. Strong aroma of roasted coffee, smoke, crackers and pungent hops. Flavour of black coffee, dark chocolate, grass. Dry finish of coffee, hops, cocoa and smoke. Very bitter.

bomber.  Aroma:  heavy roasted malt with notes of bittersweet chocolate and coffee, oats, bread dough, and some pine and floral hops.  Appearance:  Black with slight garnet highlights.  Head was dark tan, big, and rocky.  Nice lacing.  Flavor:  Again roasted malt comes up first with some bitter coffee and slight chocolate flavor.  A touch of peanut skins and vanilla, as well.  Some piney hop flavor comes in right before it finishes.  Bitterness is a little higher than I like for the style. Also getting a bit of a metallic flavor.  Palate:  Medium bodied.  Medium-high carbonation.  Some roasted malt astringency noted.  Overall:  This is a decent stout, but a little overhopped for me.  Bitterness also a little higher than I like.  Not bad, but not my favorite.

UPDATED: SEP 11, 2006 22 OZ bottle obtained locally. Pours midnight black with a massively chunky tan head. Head last for a long while. Nice aroma. I can detect oats, vanilla, toffee, mocha. Very sweet mocha flavor up front, then some vanilla kicks in followed by the roasted malt flavors in the somewhat sour creamy bitter finish. Medium bodied. Also the hops come out on top in the end, especially the aftertaste. Actually get some of the grapefruity cascade hops in the finish and aftertaste. Tone down the cascade hops or use a different hop and this would be better. Still good though, just not great. This is MUCH better at near-room temp, or 65 degrees as opposed to 45-50...the warmer temp seems to allow the malts to somewhat keep the cascade hops in check. This beer gets a 3.4 at 45 degrees and a 4 at 65 so will split the diff and call it a 3.6 as i am not normally ging to wait 30 minutes to drink once it comes out of the fridge.
Bottled. Pitch black opaque colour with brown nice head. Coffee, roast, alcohol and malts in aroma. Flavour is black coffee along with sour dark fruits and bittering hops. Wellbalanced.

UPDATED: NOV 15, 2006 On tap at the Acadia Cafe.  Opaque black with some burgundy shining through at the bottom, with a creamy hazelnut head that stays.  Coffee and chocolate predominant in the aroma, surprise.  Very well-rounded flavor of more coffee, dark nutty tones and port sweetnes.   Creamy, smooth mouthfeel.

Bomber bottle.  Pours an almost dark burgandy color with very lazy carbonation and little to no brown head.  Smells of earthy chocolate with a slight dough undertone.  The taste is somewhat sharp and bitter, with a quick and sharp pine-filled hopped up mid-taste, following with a  much more dull and earthy finish that lasts quite a while.  The mouthfeel is fairly standard for Rogue...not too fizzy and always smooth. A well-rounded ale.

22oz Bottle.Pours a very dark almost black with a nice tan head that fades fairly quick.Aromas of dark chocolate,roasted barley and hints of hops.Flavors of bitter sweet chocolate and malt followed by hops.A well balanced and smooth chocolate brew.

Almost black opaque color, small tan head. Coffee beans in the nose. Roasted, coffeeish, long roasted aftertaste. Nice balanced stout.

It¬ís been a few years since I¬íve had Shakespeare, before I joined RateBeer, so I thought it would be good to revisit an old friend. Nice to see that it has stood up well over the years. Opaque black with a big brown head that left nice lace even though it collapsed to a thin layer pretty fast.  An earthy, roasted aroma with hints of coffee and a bit of piney hops. Medium body, smooth with light carbonation. Pretty bitter throughout the flavor, typical cascade character, with some bitterness from the roasted grains as well. LIngering dry finish. A solid effort, consistently good over the years.

Bottle. Black with a small red edge. Low brown foam. Strong aroma of roasted coffee, smoke, crackers and pungent hops. Flavour of black coffee, dark chocolate, grass and ink. Dry finish of coffee, hops, cocoa and smoke. Very bitter, very nice.
This is the perfect Stout.  Dark and thick appearance.  Roasted malt aroma.  Goes down smooth and creamy.  A slight hint of chocolate with a great hop bitterness in the finish.

22 oz. Bottle: Jet black with a brown head.  It has a choco-coffee aroma with a great tangy coffee bitter taste.  You also pick up notes of rich soil and it finishes like a creamy chocolate bar - maybe milky way.  It has quite a bit of carbonation and puts a fizzy feel all through the mouth.  The large, creamy thick body is also a delight!

Wonderful.  Amazingly dark and rich, it has a nice deep tan head that disipates slowly.  Its smooth, slightly hoppy, very deep and malty, its great.  Too dark to see through, just really well crafted.

A really excellent stout.

The look, smell, mouthfeel and initial taste of this stout could keep me drinking it all night.

For me, though, there was some small thing about the hop character and flavor that didn¬ít jive with the initial sweet and oily taste.

Still, I¬íd gladly have another pint!

Pours from the big Rogue bottle to an opaque black, with thick, dark tan head that lingers and then receeds to very good lacing. Aroma was not real strong, but chocolate and roasted coffee was evident. Taste was more of the same, but not as sweet as I had expected. Finish was nice and smooth. overall, a good tasting, stout that was pleasant from start to finish.

22oz Bomber-trade w/after4ever. Pours a dark, cola like color w/a small tan foamy head. Roasted, chocolate, toffee aroma. Big beer, big flavor. Kind of takes you back & takes a few sips to get used to it. Up front hops w/roasted malt to follow. Reminds you somewhat of a smoked porter. Long bitter finish. My last beer from this trade-guess we¬íre gonna have to do another one!!

Pours black 1 inch deep tan head.  Laces decently.  Aroma citrus hops, roasted malts, and caramel.  Fizzy smooth mouth.  Flavor smooth roasty coffee toasty with some caramel sweetness.  Nice dry bitter finish.  Drinks almost like a big dry stout.  Excellent beer.
This is a sweet black brew with a  frothy, tan foam.  It contains notes of coffee, and earthy, smoky woody taste.  This full  creamy bodied ale is highly recommeded.  Consistent.
Black pour with tan head.  Heavy and rich.  Roasty and malty. Chewy.  Notes of coffee, bitter chocolate.  Bitter finish.

2005 bottle.  Pours a dark brown almost black with some ruby red when held to the light.  Creamy/bubbly brown head that sustained and left some nice creamy lacing.  Aroma of chocolate, hazelnut, some light roast, sweet maltiness, toffee and light coffee.  Flavor of dark chocolate, some coffee, roasty malts, nuts and maybe a light hop bitterness.  Left a lingering coffee grind taste in your mouth.

UPDATED: JAN 18, 2007 (Bottle at home) Pours brown to black with a big brown head. Smell of dark chocolate and minerals. Some hoppy notes. Light roasted. Notes of soil and crisp bread. The flavour has some sweetness in the beginning, then pretty dry and roasted with a sour finish. Cocoa. Medium body with a bitterness that lingers. Some soil. Some peppery feeling.

On tap. Poured a deep black with a decent tan head. Aroma is chocolate, malt, and hops. Flavor is very enjoyable. Chocolate taste with a hops bitterness in there too so it doesn¬ít end up too sweet or too bitter. One of Rogue¬ís best brews.

Bottle: Pours a deep black ale in the glass with a 3 finger frothy mocha cap. Good cap retention fair lacing... soft carbonation. 

Aromas of dark roasted cocoa, grapefruit and grass.

Thick malt spine. Creamy mouth feel... full bodied and a rich "filling"character.

Layered flavor profile: cocoa, coffee dried prunes, hints of roasted walnuts...very creamy, smooth and malty up front and in body. Finish was dry and bitter with a lingering metallic after taste mingling with a "burnt" astringency...gives a "soapy" decernment after a couple of these....this sharp asperity in the finish ruins an other wise creamy and smooth drink and IMHO keeps it from going into the 4+ scoring.

Pours pitch black with a large frothy tan head.  Aroma is smoky with hints of chocolate, coffee, and dark fruits.  Very thick bodied with a wonderfully smooth enjoyable mouth feel.  The flavor is big, with a mix of coffee, sweetness, dark chocolate, and slight bitterness.  Flavors are very skillfully balanced, with just the right amount of sweetness and bitterness.  A personal favorite of mine, check it out.
An extremely tasty stout that tends to be very malty without being overwhelming
Pours black with a dark tan head.  Aroma of chocolate, malt and coffee.  Flavor was basically the same.  Nicely balanced, just a bit thin on the pallete.
Excellent stout. Completely dark in the glass.  Highly recommend this. Mighty tasty!!
pours black with a light brown medium head.  Aroma is coffee, chocolate, roasted malts.....taste is about the same with a bitter finish.  very good stout.
A very stout stout.  Has a very sharp coffe bite at first with a mellow choccolate flavor afterwards.  Is a true experience for the palate.

The Rogue Shakespeare Stout pours a rich, very dark brown color with a great looking reddish-tan head. The mouthfeel was a little thin in my opinion, and I thought it had too much carbonation. The aroma and taste had a strong coffee flavor to it, with a bitter bite in the end. This taste reminded me of the Fuller¬ís London Porter, with a little less strength in flavor. A very good stout indeed, but not one of my absolute favorites.

dark as the night...dark brown good head...great lace...sweet coco smell...smooth as silk goin down...not thick but firm...a change from those thick stouts that try to hard...nicely balanced shiet!....enjoyable...i was hesitant?...but, this really was good, i sometimes don¬ít really like these sweet thick stouts, but REALLY this is a well made enjoyable easy going yet nice flavoured enjoyable stout, i mean, feel like a sweet stout, and go for this, u should not be surprised at what u find....
UPDATED: DEC 19, 2006 Coffee and burnt chocolate flavor are there in full force, as well as some malt notes. Pretty complex and hoppier than most stouts.

Pitch black with lively beige head. Chocoloate, licorice, slight coffee in aroma. Chocolate, coffee and roasted malts in abundance together with a nice hoppiness. "Why art Thou drinkinking beer instead of drinking Thy wine?" 
"¬íCoz of beers like this, you Shakespearean tw*t!"

UPDATED: DEC 20, 2007 Pours black with thin receding head.  Aromas were light molasses, chocolate, roasted barley.  Medium body, palate lighter than i imagined but well balanced and smooth with roasted barley, oatmeal, and a nice dark chocolate finish that stays on your tounge.

UPDATED: MAR 27, 2008 Gorgeous black body, moderate carbonation, thick chocolate head. Robust, but appealing chocolate barley malt aroma and flavor. Almost an imperial stout with the robustness of flavor. Black patent malts apparent. Good head retention. Slight burnt quality.

Pours black with tall brown head. Nice lacing. Aroma of chocolate malts and a bit of caramel sweetness. Initial taste is like BAM! Several malt flavors hit at once: chocolate, toffee, oatmeal, and caramel. I can just detect the grapefruit flavor signature of the cascade hops. Excellent rich and creamy stout.

This had a nice fairly long lasting head.Color black.Aroma was a nice malt,which wasn¬ít overbearing.It tasted Yes,it does have a chocolately aftertaste.This is a well-balanced stout,but it is a medium bodied stout.You hard core stout lovers would probably like a more robust stout ,like Stone¬ís.I enjoyed this because it was easy to drink and had complex flavors.Will buy again.

UPDATED: FEB 24, 2007 This beer pours a dark chalky black, with very little carbonation, but more than most stouts.  The color is about as black as you can get before returning to white.  This beer has a great chocolate and roasted nut character that is nicely balanced with a noticable hop profile.  The hops make for a nice long finish with the chocolate staying the longest.  This beer is pretty similiar to their Chocolate Stout, with a little more hops.  This beer is one of many reasons I will continue to drink Rogue Beers.
user_location: Farewell Minny; Hello Puyallup, Washington, USA

text: Bottle, Pours like engine oil with a medium brown head. Aromas of smoke, chocolate, anis and coffe. Flavors the same with added dark fruits and vanilla. Not so strong as it looks, very low alcohol, nice and refreshing. Finishes sweet and smooth. Would go well with cigaretts or vanilla ice cream.

Black with a tan head. Aroma is sweet and malty with a hint of grapes. Roasty, smoky, choco-coffee taste, immensely smooth, sweet and rich. You think it¬ís a porter, but the bitterness is late and lingering. Delicious.
Chocolate, roasty, black, brown foam, medium bitterness, medium body, sticky, creamy, average carbonation This is a beer you will remember. One word hamony.

I love my stouts .i got this from a friend and it was a surprise. did not even know about this and it was one of the best stouts i ever had. i high enjoyed and would buy a case if i could find in indiana. CHEERS  and try it

Pours dark black with a dark tan head, very nice and mild aroma, taste is stronger than one would expect based on aroma, hint of chocolate.and espresso undertones.  Exremely smooth and rich, taste is well balanced. This is a truly enjoyable brew.

Aroma is a little restrained, but have traces of roasted malt, marshmellows and chocolate. Tar black colour with brown head. Head last longer then average and there is only a limited amount of carbonation. Very espresso-like in the taste with some roastedness. The flavours are very powerfull but at the same time also extreemly smooth - yummy. There is a little hopbitterness in the aftertaste, which is otherwise dominated by the "espresso" and seems to lasts for hours.

(22oz bottle) After many years of trying to find the perfect stout, this is the closest it has come. Sweet aroma of coffee and sugary malts, near pitch-black in color and a dark head, flavor is of vanilla beans, espresso with a faint roastedness reminiscient of a smoked porter.

The strength of Shakespeare Stout is its ability to balance its characteristics, while still having each being completely original. Most stouts have one thing going, but not the others. This beer is very bold and kicks major ass!
Holy shizzel. This is some great beer. Dark as night, chocolaty, smooth with a great finish. The dude with shades on the label made it that much cooler to drink.

Bottle. Black color, small but firm head. Sweet and roasted aroma with strong vinous character. Salty licorice, charcoal and red wine in the aroma. Dryer flavor with salty licorice, coffee and charcoal roastedness. The flavor is also grainy with fruity-vinous bitterness. Finishes dry, roasted and bitter. A firm and satisfying stout.

One of the best beers I have ever had. It is worth the price if you value taste over intoxication. Very bold. Dark fruits, cherries, and even a slight hint of french vanilla espresso comes though in the nose. The taste is harcore stout mayhem. Roastes malts decimate your tastebuds as you beg for more. The end result? An excellent stout, I¬íll have another please!
22oz bottle from Bev Mo.  Pours a deep chocolate brown....almost black.  Head looks like a bubbly hershey bar.  Aroma of dark fruits,  chocolate,  coffee,  and roasted toffee.  A great beer.

the best rogue makes,tastes like chocolate milk........................................
....
Strong coffee aromas, brown lasting thick tight head.  Chococalte toffee flavors come through the bitterness.  Bitter finish with chocolate lingering.

Bottle. Black with brown lasting head. Hops are quite obvious and perhaps too dominating, other stout characteristics have too be searched for in the background; roasted malts and coffee beans, touch of dark and bitter chocolate. Quite firm, if not hard, mouthfeel. Medium body. A good american stout, packing a lot of flavor considering the abv. Could be a bit more balanced tough.
A Black very classic stout. But not boring at all. A good coffee smell, rich roasted almost burned malt flavour. Nice bitter hop and burned malt finish. Just as we like it !!
Very dark color with tannish head. Coffee and dark chocolate nose. Flavor was strong roasted coffee beans and chocolate.

On tap at Dieu du Ciel, dark black color, with a creamy tan-colored head, black malt nose, roasted coffee beans note, dark chocolate aroma follows through on a medium-bodied palate with a dark coffee character, roasted coffee beans, black and chocolate malt aceents, black bitter chocolate note, hint of mocha, leading towards a smooth lingering roastiness bitter finish.
Bottle. Pours a black colour with a tan head. Roasted malty aroma with some hints of coffee. Has a sweet malty flavor with coffee and chocolate. Smooth finish with some bitterness.
dark color and small head. Chocolate coffee taste.. with a nice burnt flavor.pretty smooth which is something I hope for in a beer. The high a% makes this a nice finish to a hard day.

22 oz bomber.. dark chocolate colored pour , thin beige head ,good lace . aroma of roasted chocolate coffee . flavors of chocolate and raisin with a slightly bitter and dry finish .very smooth and creamy, maybe a bit thin but all and all pretty good stuff .

Ok, my patience with Rogue and their same approach to EVERY beer has just about run out. Show a little creativity, guys!!! There¬ís more to a beer than hops, especially a stout. Outside of a pitch black pour with some sediment that went to the bottom quickly (the head wasn¬ít great either) and a nice sweet chocolate/coffee aroma, the beer just wasn¬ít all that. I¬íd take multiple other stouts over this one. Re-rate: 11/04/05 from a ceramic 26oz bomber. Hops are definitely featured in this one along with coffee and some chocolate. Not bad, not as great as it¬ís "reputation."
very thick head. aroma of coffee and chocolate. pretty nice taste overall. looks like coffee when poured into a coffee mug.... hahahaha

Draft at Frisco¬ís Rogue weekend. Creamy nitro pour ala Guinness, complete with cascading carbonation. The aroma is roasted, slight chocolate and molases. The flavor is roasted with some milk chocolate. The mouthfeel is incredibly soft, smooth and creamy. Good stuff.

Pours coffee black with a foamy, persistent head.  Smells gorgeous right out of the bottle: roasty, dark chocolate, a hint of warmness.   Medium-bodied and creamy, this is one smooth and comforting stout.  A mildly earthy aftertaste spoils the effect for me just a little bit.  All in all, the flavor is good...the visual, tactile, and olfactory aesthetics  are what makes this a  terrific beer.  I¬íd love to have this at my favorite brewpub with a few buddies.

Bottle at K√∏benhavnske √òldage 200506.
Black colour, with a thin brown foam. Aroma of sweet and  coffee beans.
Well balanced, with  coffe and chocolate and raisins. Nice bitter finish Medium body.
Very nice stout.  Dark chocolate, coffee, and cola swirl on the tongue.  Definitely could use a bit more body, but that is about the only flaw I found in it.

This has an almost expresso-like choclatey quality to it but I find it a tad bit too watery and I do appreciate its malty nuttiness which is balanced by some hoppy bitter tones. It doesn¬ít wow my taste buds though.

On tap. Nice chocolaty aroma.  The color is a dark, dark brown, with a thin beige head.  The flavor is very espresso-like.  Rich, but with a touch of bitterness  The mouthfeel is more watery than you¬íd expect, but a little grainy feeling at the same time.  The finish is a touch bitter.  Overall, I found this to be a very enjoyable beer.

Bomber, 41F Pint Glass, The aroma is wonderfully sweet, with rich dark chocolate notes, Nice warm hopes thick hop aromas, Very rich and warm nose. Very opaque dark color, like hot melted fudge, A long lasting and very thick brown head. Taste of Hops, followed, by rich mocha and finishing with warm oatmeal, with sprinkles of nutmeg and cinnamon.  A great rich robust chocolately flavor, and a wonderful finish of piney hops.  A smaller than expected mouth feel, not overly carbonated.  Overall the aroma, look, and taste are fantastic, rich, dark, and sumptous, but I feel that the mouthfeel is a bit lacking, and in my opinion is the only thing keeping this beer back.
Smooth chocolate tasting stout with good dark colouring and mild hoppiness.  As with many stouts, head is very creamy.  Aftertaste is not as lingering as other stouts I have tried.
UPDATED: SEP 24, 2006 bottle. black with big brown head. nice taste of licherish and chokolate. a little bitter and a little bit smokey.
Bottle. Pours almost black with a large brown head. Roasted malt with notes of coffee and dark fruits. Nice sweetness - a bit too mild though.

Bottle. Creamy brown and lasting head. Pitch black body. Coffee choccolate aroma. Barley malt flavor dominated by cascade hops and liqorice.  If Mikkeler was inspired by this I fully understand and appreciate it.

The 22 ounce bottle poured a nearly opaque black beverage with a small, thick, light brown, long-lasting head that left good lacing on the glass. There were the aromas of sweet chocolate, notes of fresh ground coffee and lots of dried plumb. The body was full with smooth, soft carbonation and a thick, creamy texture. The flavor starts off somewhat sweet and fruity but as it matures on the palate, the flavors of rich dark chocolate and coffee grow until they entirely replace the initial flavors. The finish is long, smooth and somewhat dry with a slight alcohol warmth.

Bottle - Pours thick black with thin dark tan head that vanishes rather quickly.  Smells of roasted malty chocolate.  Mouthfeel is thinner than I expected with some carbonation present.  Flavor is malty, but not sweet.  Slight hints of chocolate and strong black coffee on the follow-through.  Overall not a bad stout, but not one of the best I¬íve had.

UPDATED: APR 11, 2007 very confident stout, boastful and full bodied.  very flavorful, obvious hops and a bit nutty.  zero alcohol.  had this a while ago, maybe my first rogue.  no idea why i didn¬ít rate it already.  will rerate someday.  RERATE. wtf was i thinking when i wrote that? just based on grammar and making sense i mean. anyways, this wasn¬ít too good tonight. too hoppy/bitter. not as much coffee/chocolate as i¬íd like. nose was good, but the flavor was a big letdown.... rerate.  this beer sucks.  it just tastes astringent and tacky every time i have it and it never has much good going for it.

nose was dominated by coffee and hops.  pours black with a billowin tan head which always stays at a think layer on the top.  flavor was of dark malt, coffee, good bittering, and notes of oats.  I love how the hops shine through on this brough.  some pine and resin notes from the hops are there.  Nice mouthcoating feel.  This is a very nice stout.  Cheers

UPDATED: OCT 31, 2008 In short: The archetypical American stout.  No special character but it is very well put together
How: Bottle 660ml, consumed fresh a few weeks after purchase
The look: Black body topped by a small tan head
In long: Medium roastiness.  Light coffee notes.  Light black chocolate notes.  Light dark fruits notes.  Light-medium sweetness.  Light-medium hops bite.  In a way this an American stout with no personality but on the other hand this is a very well brewed most exemplary American stout.  Just a little bit of everything.  To be or not to be a Shakespeare Stout lover, that is the question.

As dark as a cup of coffee, modest tan head. Huge roast malt aroma, a little earthy, some coffee as well. Rich heavy mouthfeel, flavours of coffee, chocolate, toast, and a hint of stewed/dried fruits. Sweet but well-hopped, making it an interesting balance. Fantastic!
user_location: the land of bitumen, beef & beer, Alberta, CANADA

text: Full body with medium bitterness and light sweetness -- thick and filling.  Has a bit of hops and a strong roasted flavor.  Small hints of chocolate and coffee all the way to the bitter end.

Pours opaque brown with lush tan head.  Nice chocalte roasty aroma.  Flavor is nicely hoppy; not quite a wonderful as the 3F Black Sun, but definitely more interesting than your average stout.  More bitter than floral.  Well balanced, dry and drinkable.

The benchmark for a standard stout.
Deep black with brownish head. Nice roasted barley and chocolate flavor. 
Not as complex or big as the best Imperials, but for a regular stout, it doen¬ít get too much better.

Bottle.  Pours black with a dark tan head.  Great aroma of malt, coffee, chocolate, and a tiny hint of dried fruits.  Flavor has the same components, plus maybe oats, and a lot more hops.  Starts out malty and roasty with chocolate and a hint of sweetness, and finishes dry and bitter with the Cascade hops.  The heavily grapefruity finish isn¬ít really my thing, but it¬ís a pretty good beer on the whole.

Proud to be the 816th Ratebeerian to rate this puppy.  Bomber into Duvel tulip.  On the pour, this looks like Goose Island Bourbon County, which bodes well: red-brown fizzy foam producing thin but sticky and grainy brown lacing over a deep black beer.  Smells better than the GI Bourbon County: roast, fresh buttered bread, chocolate malt, and even some fruity bourbon (how does it do that without being aged in a barrel?).  That¬ís where the comparisons stop, however.  This is thin for a stout, like Left Hand Imperial (non-oaked version) only more watery.  The flavors are well articulated: roasty and subtly hoppy on the front, dry and medium bitter on the finish, which is long.  Chocolate is an undercurrent more than a signature feature all the way though.  As mentioned, this reminds me of Left Hand Imperial, but a roastier and drier version (both of which I like).

Tap at Brewpub in SF. Pours very dark with a medium head. Aroma of malt and chocolate. Flavors of more malt and chocolate with a slight note of roasted 
coffee beans. Not too heavy,  just right on the palate.

Purely amazing.  Rich, dark brown pour with a thick tan/brown head.  Aroma is sweet and pleasant to get things started.  Taste is abundent with coffee, chocolate, malty, and has a nice amount of hops.  The chocolate tones finish the beer with perfection.  Hats off to Rogue!

Good hoppy nose.  Great dark stout with a small head.  Taste of earthy oats bitter hops coffee and chocolate.  Enough hops to make this more enjoyable and more interesting than most stouts.  And, of course, the signature Rogue Cascade at that.

2005 Bottle.
Dark as can be stout! Now that¬ís what I like to see. Good but weak aroma, with an outstanding flavor that is not that mellow but really stands out in hoppness. Keeps a great head with a perfect body. Very drinkable and a nice companion to food, mainly beef. Highly recommend. Cheers!
Very solid stout from pour to last sip.  I look forward to drinking this beer again and again.

I poured this one from a bomber bottle.   Deep dark, black, light-absorbing body.  Thick, tight, tan head that stayed around and left some impressive lacing.  More hops than I expected but well-balanced.  After one bottle this has proven to be one of my favorite stouts!

Awesome dark color with creamy tan head. Head fades quickly, beer is full of hops which is surprising for a stout. Slight hint of roasted choclate. Better than the only other rogue I¬íve had. (Chocolate stout).

i must say that the color was magnificent.  a nice midnite black with a coffee colored head.  however, i was disappointed that the head wasn¬ít as rich and creamy as i was lead to believe.  there is a faint hint of hops in the nose with a coffee/bitter chocolate undertone.  the taste is a nice combo of these things

Bottle.  Pours a very dark black with a thick creamy dark brown head.  Aroma is a little hoppy with roasted oats and chocolate.  Taste is full, chocolate, and roasty.  Starts full and strong and ends bitter.  Some seem to think it¬ís too hoppy for a stout, but I think it wors great with this beer.

Fresh full dark malt and Cascade hop aroma with medium hop lace on the glass.  The flavor really delivers on the aroma¬ís promise, a veritable symphony of dark malts and hops.  The palate leaves the burnt malt, brewed nearly to dryness (the infamous Pac-Man yeast), and a slight resinous hop residue.  Overall this is one of the best balanced West Coast stouts, joining Pike Place XXXXX Stout, Bell¬ís Kalamazoo Stout, and Anchor Porter on my honor roll.

Pours close to black with a creamy tan head.  The aroma is very malty, but the taste is roasty with a slightly bitter chocolate finish.  I can¬ít admit to being a fan of roasty flavors, but this is a good beer for someone who is.  Rogue is quality.

Poured almost black with a creamy tan lacing. It had a soft almost fizzy carbonation. It was a smooth drink with a bitter chocolate finish that stayed with you for a while. If you forgot how much bitters it had you could roll your tongue around in your mouth and wake the hops back up from their nap. As it warmed and got closer to the bottom of the pint it had a slight wateryness but really good overall. I have no idea what it smelled like because everyone around me at the bar was smoking like chimneys. A good reason to rate beers at home.

UPDATED: AUG 18, 2006 FIRST RATING: Good beer.  Blacker and thicker than a lot of other stouts.  While chocolate is still present, it is much sweeter than most stouts I¬ím used to.  Smells great.  Tastes very good.  Well done all around.


SECOND RATING (8-18-06): Black opaque body with thick tan head, looks similar to the bar harbor.  More mild than many stouts, but still more hoppy than I like my stouts.  Roasted malt and hop permeate the scent and taste.  Its good,but I think their mocha porter might be better.

Bottle.  Lightly hoppy aroma with some chocolate coffee malt coming off too.  Ebony, but pour looks brown with even hints of garnet.  Tan, slight head.  Flavor is an excellent blend, plenty of coffee, a good dose of hops, and a hint of dark bittersweet chocolate.  Pleasant, easy to drink, but enough flavors and total amount of flavor to please.  Haven¬ít been enjoying too many beers lately, but this is restoring my faith in the wonders of beer.

From where doth thy creamy brown head arise? Tis clearly from thine inky black well of malty goodness. Thine aroma carries the cocoa bean on its winged back, and flies towards a resiny hop wall that engulfs it completely.  Thine mouthfeel doth not pretend to be as thick as thine murky blackness would tell. And your bitter ending sharply cuts through your roasted chocolate lingerings. Mayhap thine should tone down your bitter leaving, but, alas, you are unique nonetheless.

UPDATED: JUL 15, 2009 1. On Tap at the GBBF, Kensington Olympia 05/08/2005
Black slightly rich on the palate and strong in alcohol. Some bitterness and dryness in a lasting roast finish.
2. From the Bottle at Tom¬ís Ultimate Glasgow Tasting, Blackfriars 01/12/2007
Dark coloured strong in alcohol and rich on the palate with a crisp and slightly dry coffee roast finish.

I was a little disappointed in this stout from Rogue. It had a great presentation and aroma, but the flavor was a little weak. Still not a bad beer, just not what I expected. Will try again from a bottle.
A enjoyable stout beer with a delicious roasted flavor and a dark smooth look.
Bottle 650 ml. Appearance: Dark brown with a medium tan head. Aroma: dark chocolate, coffee, hop, roasted malt. Flavor: roasted malt, chocolate, coffee, hop. One of my favourites. Thank to jrob_21.

Dark brown with a medium tan head. Aroma of dark chocolate, coffee and roasted barley. Flavor is well balanced with the roasted barley and chocolate taking center stage followed up with the coffee on the finish. Body is lighter than I would have liked, but it¬ís a well crafted beer.

on draft rogue house San Francisco: deep rich brown color with a dense tan puffed to the max  head.  espresso and cocoa in the nares.  medium to full bodied palate with more of the same flavors from the nose.  not as robust as i expected or as good. finishes with a bit of a bitter twinge.   a good solid stout.
Smells of sweet chocolate and coffee beans.  Has a bitter coffee mouthfeel with very mild carbonation.  Not as creamy and sweet as the nose would suggest.

Really delicious aroma of dark chocolate and toffee.  Fizzy mouthfeel and a bit of more hoppiness than I would expect.  Complex and subtle overtones compliment the bitter chocolate and roasty coffee flavors.

deep dark beer with a creamy head. Slight chocolate aftertaste with some nice bitterness. Nice Oaty flavor. Have tried other Rogues ales before and have liked them. This one is good, but not as good as some of their others. Overall a good stout though...If i can¬ít get their Chocolate Stout...this one is a good alternative.

deep, thick chocolate mousse-like head, not much aroma.  A disappointing characteristic.  Appearance is dark and chunky.  Bittersweet taste with hints of ssmoke.  I keep tasting sausage.  strange.  Coffee like finish witha  watery end.  Good, easy drinking stout, but not my favorite.  Probably would not drink again, but worth a try.

UPDATED: FEB 25, 2006 Bottle courtesy of HogTownHarry. Unsure of vintage but at least a year old. Pours a deep black with an average size diminishing creamy light-brown head -- It looks great! The aroma is awesome! Predominently dark chocolate along with hops, roasted malt and coffee -- almost a perfect smelling Stout, it smells so good. After that aroma, the delicious flavour does not dissapoint: Sweet roasted malt, creamy chocolate and coffee with a nice hoppy bitterness at the end. Full bodied, smooth creamy mouthfeel. I¬ím amazed how easily this beer goes down, I think I could have 3 or 4 of these bombers in a row. A world-class Stout and one of my favourites.

22oz. Glass bottle

Poured pitch black with small frothy brown head with nice lacing on the edges. Aroma malty with chocolate and oats in the nose. Big chocolate flavor hits initially, than settles into malty notes with a roasted oat flavor. Slighty bitter through the middle to end of the beer. Thick coffee like mouthfeel. Very nice stout. Rogue makes some excellent beers.

From a bottle into a snifter. Beer pours an opaque dark brown color with a small, creamy, mostly and quickly diminishing, light-brown head. The aroma is a little sketchy: Moderately malty with notes of husky roasted grain and chocolate; A light hop note of herbs and pine; Topped off with light, but still way-yucky miscellaneous notes of urine and home perm. Blah. The flavor is moderately acidic and lightly bitter with a long, moderately bitter finish complete with pee and garden soil retronasals. The body is medium-to-full, the texture is watery-to-creamy and the carbonation is soft. I don¬ít know if I got a bum bottle or what¬óbut IMHO, this wasn¬ít a nice thing to do to somebody. I¬íll catch another sample again some time to double-check.

UPDATED: NOV 5, 2006 Great looking dark black stout with a brown head.  Smells of mollasses, honey, and maybe a touch of vanilla over the roasty stoutness.  Creamy and smooth, but there¬ís a little grit.  The taste is prototypical stout with sweet creaminess over robust roastiness.  A Truly drinkable beer.
Rerate: 11.05.06
I had this one early on, and liked it, so I figured I should try it again.  Turns out, I actually under rated this beer!  This beer still looks great, and smells great.  Now I detect more in the aroma (in addition to before).  Creamy roast and sweet chocolate malt are definitely apparent here now.  The palate is still fantastic, and I don¬ít really taste the grit now.  I have to say, I am tempted to boost this score most in the flavor department.  There¬ís such nice smooth roastiness in this brew, particularly well balanced against the lactic chocolate sweetness.  The hops even come out and stand out nicely within the roasty finish.  This gets an extra point on both flavor and overall.  This is a really fun beer.

UPDATED: NOV 5, 2006 Dark beer, with a nice thick brown head.  Aroma is very sweet, vanilla.  Palate: Thick and creamy but still a little sharp.  Flavour is bitter, chocolatey, not as sweet as it smells.  Overall, highly drinkable.

16.9 oz bottle, no freshness date noted.
Deep black coffee color with a tanish head. good lacing.
aroma is predominantly roasted coffee, but if you dig deep you¬íll find some dark chocolate and a trace of citrusy hops. flavor is big on roasty, black coffee, bitter chocolate and a  long dry finish.
Probably one of the worst beers that I have ever had. Not bashin it, just not my flavor.

22 oz bottle.  Very nice stout.  Brownish black body with big brown head.  Aroma of roasted grains and chocolate.  Flavor is bittersweet chocolate with a subtle vanilla-ish sweetness.  Very easy to drink.
pours black with a frothy brown head which quickly diminished.  aroma has notes of coffee and chocolate, taste follows with some roast and hops in finish.  not the best in breed but nicely done.

Thanks to gputty for this one. Poured from a bomber almost black with a tan head. Good lacing. Aroma of sweet chocolate and raisins. Flavor was very complex and hard to nail down, bitter chocolate malts finially came out with a hoppy bite at teh end.
UPDATED: DEC 21, 2006 Nice drinking stout.  black with tan head.  sugar cocoa aroma.  sour malt, coffee, chocolate.  sugar bounces on your tounge.  easy drinking and well done.

UPDATED: APR 16, 2006 Excellent beer!! Dark creamy lasting head with tiny bubbles. Super dark, dark brown color, almost black.  Nice assertive chocolate malt flavor that lingers ¬ítill the finish.  This beer is medium bodied  and easy to drink.
From bottle.  Pours black with a good coffee head and great lacing.  Nose is nutty, some chocolate, raisins and a bit vinous.  This is a bitter, bitter stout that is also dry and smooth.  Works well.
this brew makes one feel as if they are trying to write poetry and the roof is leaking.

Yet another gputty prop for this bomber! Dark, almost black pour with a medium brown head. Dense brown lacing. Nose is somewhat vinious, with milk chocolate , mocha and raisin notes. Flavor is lighter than expected, bitter chocolate and light malts. Finish is deceptively bitter, but muted; a soft but strong bitter. Very nice stout!

UPDATED: SEP 8, 2007 Pours next to black w/ a full, semi creamy froth. Superb head retention that finally reduces to a full, dusty canopy w/ a thick fluffy ring.  Aroma of mildly roasted chocolate malts. Full nectar w/ soft and creamy residual effers. It just turns to cream on the palate. Nice! Heavily roasted w/ strong flavors of roasted coffee bean, chunky cocoa, and leather. Mild nuances of nut shells and iodine. The malt barely factors in at all it¬ís so burnt.  Burnt like a thousand camp fires. The roast componenet is bracing. The finish is bittered extremely w/ citrus rind that lingers forever. This is a stout¬ís stout. Overall: High roast and low malts creates a unique specimen. Drinks better as she warms as the chocolate flavore really push forward. Highly recommended.
"Okay this one wasn¬ít bad, not as good as i have heard. Pour a dark black color. small brown head. Aroma was of coffee and chocolate. Same flavor, with hops, Not bad not top of the line. "

UPDATED: APR 18, 2006 This is some DARK beer.  Opaque, medium body and mouthfeel.  Very dry taste, chocolately and bitter, very very good.  Reminds me of Guinness Extra Stout.  Finish is bitter and lasts a long time.  Not bad, but not my favorite stout ever.
Re-rated on 4/18: Definitely a better stout than I first gave it credit for.

Bottle: Nearly black, small to moderate light brown frothy head, fades quickly, spotty lacing. ¬† Roasted malt nose, slight milk sugar as well, and maybe a hint of chocolate. ¬† Bittersweet chocolate to start, more dominant here than on the nose, lightly roasted malts, lower hop bitterness than I expected, with a somewhat moderate body and mouthfeel. ¬† After having the Imperial Stout last night perhaps I was expecting too much from this one. ¬† While certainly tasting like a stout, it seems to be a very minor one at that. ¬† Light, fairly smooth, lingering milk stout like sweetness, but overall not as robust as I would have hoped.

UPDATED: NOV 26, 2007 Bomber; Extremely dark opaque brown coloration with a medium cinnamon head. Coffee and chocolate aroma with some roastiness. Flavor is nutty chocolate with a coffee background, and some light hop bitterness for the finish..
Very thick.  Incredibly rich flavors that constantly change.  Strong chocolate flavor, oats, and even a subtle fruity taste.  Good malt flavors.

Pours an opaque black in color with a half-inch, velvety brown head. Aroma of roasted malt. Flavor is very dry: roasted oats, chocolate, coffee, pecan-shell bitterness . I liked this stout, but the taste it left in my mouth 20 minutes later was just horrible. Very good beer, but you¬íll want to rinse your mouth out soon after.

A pretty good dry stout. Not stellar by any means but I like it better than Guinness. Pours almost opaque with a whispy tan head that dissipates quickly. Roasted malt, coffee-like nose and taste. Medium body with a slightly bitter finish.

Not my favorite stout.  Had a skunky nose that mellowed on warming.  Poured brown-black with a foamy brown head.  Tangy, with some roasted oats, and chocolate.  A hint of bitterness.  Sweet finish.  Flavor is just ok - doesn¬ít offend, but it doesn¬ít really grab me either.
A very dark, pitch black stout.  Orangeish if not red head, though very minimal in terms of formation. Good roasted malts for the aromas.  Excellent molasses and coffee tastes, very smooth ending.
Dark black color with a thin brown head. Aroma of roasted malt and coffee. Sweet chocolate and coffee flavor.

Pours pitch black with a thin, fully receding light brown head. Aroma of sweet dark cocoa, roasted coffee, and spicy hops. Taste is sweet roasted malts, only slightly bitter. Notes of chocolate, french roast, licorice, and pepper. Mouthfeel is medium bodied and chalky with soft, smooth carbonation. Quite good, but not something I¬íd drink regularly.
chocolate, roasty, black, brown foam, medium bitterness, full body, thick feel, flat, bitter,

Quite excellent.  Not a sweet stout by any means, quite dry and very complex with nice roasted and smokey notes dominating.  Coffee aroma.  Excellent body that¬ís not syrupy but slightly foamy.  An excellent beer.
D√©gust√© sous le nom "Wild Irish Rogue" pour la St-Patrique. Un bon go√ªt de chocolat et de c√©r√©al roti, ass√© rich. Plus forte que la plupar des stouts.

Rogue Shakespeare Stout, is a big, hoppy, malty stout brewed by the Rogue Brewery of Newport, OR. This beer is an oatmeal stout by style, and is an excellent example. It is quite hoppy as well, and because of this, some beer geeks in the PNW have dubbed this beer, PNW Stout. This really isn¬ít a sub style of stout, and Rogue would fall into the oatmeal stout category.

Rogue has a marketing practice that I really don¬ít agree with. Rogue Shakespeare Stout is also know as Wild Irish Rogue, their St. Patrick¬ís Day tribute. That is right, Shakespeare and Wild Irish Rogue, are the same beer. So, buyer beware if you purchase a Shakespeare, and a Wild Irish sitting on the same shelf, you just bought the same beer. Rogue does this with  other beers as well, and marketed the same beer under a few different labels. 

Call this beer Shakespeare or Wild Irish, it is excellent. Since I¬ím of Irish/German heritage, I¬íll go with Wild Irish. Wild Irish pours to a deep black color, with a nice tan head, and good carbonation. The nose is very fragrant with hop aromatics. Its that classic, citric, piney hop aromas that are so inviting. There is a good bit of chocolate malt aroma in the nose as well. The palate is delicious, very firm dark malt backbone. Flavors of chocolate, a touch of roast, and coffee. The body is muscular, with a very slick and silky mouth feel. Oatmeal makes a beer very smooth and creamy tasting. This beer finishes with some nice roast bitterness, then really EXPLODES into a long, dry, citric hop bitter bite. Fresh this beer is amazingly good. Another caveat concerning Rogue beers. They are not pasteurized, and DO NOT travel well. I have had some horrible Rogue beers because they have been old and stale, Rogue beers are very fragile. So think twice if a bottle appears to be old, and don¬ít be afraid to ask if there is any fresh Rogue available. Match this beer with hearty dishes such as beef or lamb stew. It would also go well with a desert such as chocolate cake, or Boston cream pie.

WOW!!! One of the best stout¬ís I¬íve had the pleasure to indulge in. A nice medium-thick, caramel colored head, midnight black color, chocolate, coffee-espresso aroma and wonderful deep hoppy thick, oat-y chocolate flavor. Make no mistake, for stout lovers it really doesn¬ít get much better. Not the #1 out there, but easily within the top 20. Simply outstanding.

from the bottle. poured black with a medium tan head. aroma roated malts jump right out there and than along comes the chocolate, some coffee, with a touch of hops. flavor not disappointing at all good strong roasted flavors  with the chocolate taking first place a head of the malts did pick up some of the oats. good beer.

Good strong stout with pretty hard espresso and dark or bakers chocolate.  Bitter like this type of stout should be, but also fairly sweet.  Black in color with a large bubbled shallow head of light tan.  Pretty good.

The aroma was very rich - roasted barley, chocolate and a hint of coffee beans.  It pours very dark brown, almost black with a thin head.  No light passed through the snifter when I held it up.  The flavor consisted of chocolate, coffee and some bitterness.  Overall, it was very dry and didn¬ít last long in the mouth.  For a stout, I enjoyed this smoothness.  A great value at only $5.99 a bottle.

The aroma is just what you would expect from a stout. It has toasted malt, chocolate, coffee, and an earthy quality. It is super dark brown; to the point that it looks black even held up to the light. The head is small and tan. The flavor is bitter sweet like mocha coffee and brown sugar. The palate is smooth. Good stuff.

UPDATED: MAR 15, 2007 Pours dark with a decent sized creamy tan head, aroma of roast, chocolate malts, coffee. The taste starts with a roasted bitterness that subsides into a chocolatey body and is bitter on the way down, not bad.

UPDATED: AUG 25, 2006 This is probably the best rogue you can get...it¬ís way better than their imperial and anything else they overhype (2xIPA).  It has a really nice malt and chocolate balance...very smooth and tasty.  This is a perfect stout for someone who wants to start drinking more stouts.  A woman ended up ordering one for herself.  A little weak on the aroma side though.  RERATE.  wtf was i thinking when i wrote that?  just based on grammar and making sense i mean.  anyways, this wasn¬ít too good tonight.  too hoppy/bitter.  not as much coffee/chocolate as i¬íd like.  nose was good, but the flavor was a big letdown.
Pours engine oil black.  Very roasted -- almost smoked flavor.  Chocolatey.  A little light.  Nice stout -- I must say that I prefer the imperials.
Fantastic stout.  Frothy head, dark color with hints of chocolate.  Nicely bitter - drank easy, as if thin.

Bottle. Pours brown black with frothy brown head. Aroma of dark chocolate and roasted malts. Flavor is bitter, with balanced flavors of burnt coffee and bakers chocolate. Finish could use some improvement, but was bitter, earthy and  dirty. Very decent brew overall
Yum. Toasty mocha midnight murk that slips through the teeth and  " Though this be madness, yet there is method in ¬ít."

Draught at the Rogue Public House in NW Portland.  Pours rich frothy head that looks similar to espresso.  Dark ink black not allowing any light to pass through.  Smells strongly of roasted malts, nice chocolate, and sweet cream.  No hops are present in the aroma.  I know they are in there, but the roast overpowers them.  First taste is bitter, but not from hops, from roast.  Almost astringent.  Chocolate and espresso fill your mouth next, very nice, followed by a sharp almost harsh bitterness.  Again from roast not hops.  NIce full, rich, slick mouthfeel.  Oily and coating, from the oats one can presume.  I decided to sit on this for a while and let it warm up seeing as it was very cold from the tap.  At first it seemed to bring out this harshness even more, but after a few drinks, it went away.  It is so much better slightly below room temperature.  Definite balance.  A decent beer.

GABF 2005 (I poured at the station next to this one as a volunteer). Inky black , with creamy head.  Nice, hoppy pineyness and maltiness.  Hinsts of chocolate and crystal malts.  Awesome, though not very traditional because of the strong hop floral component in the nose.  I like it.

It poured rich and black with a creamy tan head which slowly faded as I admired it. As it approached my lips an earthy aroma promised a delightful experience. I was not disappointed. Hearty chocolate and coffee flavors coated my mouth long after the large, first sip was swallowed. At first I thought the high hop content (69 IPU) would put me off, but no it was neceessary to balance this fine recipe. The effect was a smooth, mellow, satisfying experience.

22 oz bottle. Poured dark, almost back wth a  beautiful, long lasting tan head. Nose of chocolate and coffee, plus malt and barley.    Just enough hops to balance everything out.  Wonderful mouthfeel that was good to the last drop.  This may be the best Stout I have found. Love it!

UPDATED: FEB 5, 2012 These is my fourth beer of my 2005 Christmas gift.  The head forthed quickly and then subsided.  The Aroma was of roasted malt and barley.  The color was deep black and opaque. Flavors of chocolate and malt are enjoyed in this excellent stout.  This is a very tasty beverage. Rogue has a very balanced stout with sweetness and chocolate aftertaste.

22 ox bottle drunk after I bottle my own Imperial IPA...what a great reward. Beautiful black body with that nice tan head.  Nose is chocolate and  roasted coffee notes...bit of cocoa. Tastes of slightly sweet chocolate and coffee....nice malt taste mixed with those wonderful Cascade hops. Great mouthy feel with a warm and wonderful finish. Ahhhhh.

a very nice offering from rogue again.  jet black w/ brown head, the aroma is a mix of roasted and chocolate barley w/ noticable cascade trace.  full bodied, sweet and chocolatey, this babe is smooth and very dangerously drinkable.  very good.

Thick creamy brown head. Pretty dark brown body. 
Nice, slightly dry chalking roasty chocolate bean. Some sweet buttery component too. 
Aromas continue into the flavor. Fairly basic, just dry chocolatey roasty flavors. But still good.
Very reminiscent of the Founders Breakfast stout. Just a bit lighter.

Has a pleasant, roasty coffee aroma.  Pitch black, with a brown head.  Has an excellent slightly bitter coffee and slightly sweet flavor.  Excellent body, with the right amount of carbonation.  This one is good.

(Bottle 65 cl) Pitch black with a small, creamy cappuchino style head. Roasted, vaguely coffeeish nose. Very malty, roasted flavours with distinct notes of coffee and perhaps a wee touch of chocolate. 031205
Bottle. Malty chocolate aroma. Black colour, high carbonation. Nice, malty flavour. Watery mouthfeel.
This is very good.  dark and rich - yet still very easy to drink beer.  Pours dark with a nice choclate colored head.  finished strong and semi- sweet.  I will definatley buy this again.
