Very dark black with a small but thick brown head.  Aroma of sweet roasted malt, chocolate and coffee.  Full bodied and smooth with flavors of dark roast coffee and bittersweet chocolate finishing with a light roasty bitterness that hangs around a good while.  Very good stout.
Very dark in color, brownish head.  Roasty smell of chocolate and coffee, nothing overpowering.  Flavor a little weak but smooth on the palate and easy to drink.  Nice dry finish.
Bottle. Black colour with a nice head. Very light aroma of coffee and hint of alcohol. Light smooth flavour of roastedness that ends up bitter and dry.

1 pint, 6 oz (650 mL) brown bottle purchased at Armanetti¬ís, Mundelein, IL.  Ruby black hued stout having a diminishing creamy tan head with good lacing.  No discernable carbonation.  Complex aromas of sweet malt, toffee, chocolate, and hops.  Full bodied with creamy texture that starts dry with complex flavors of expresso and roasty malt with light bitterness. Finishes dry with light lingering bitterness.  This is an excellent dry stout.
(on bottle at CPH Yeha05)Also an overly oxidated beer here; still one year should not be a problem. dark, pitch black. Aromas of cardboard, port and coffee. Very watery mouth and and finish.

this was a fine stout if i may say.  nice chocolate and coffee flavors.  some nice malty flavors.  There was some bitterness and just a touch of chalkiness but it was all in all a decent beer.  Not bad to have a few in a night.

This is an excellent stout. It has a chocolate/coffee taste to it. Pours very dark and impressive. A bit like the chocolate stout from Rogue but not as sweet and definitely better. So far my favorite stout.
Cask (gravity dispense), GBBF, August 2005. One of the more successful of the cask US imports. A rich, roasty stout with lots of cocoa throughout. I found a lot more chocolate than coffee. Very nice.
Bottle. Black colour with a small baige head. Light roasted, coffee aroma and taste. Medium to full body and a roasted dry finish.

UPDATED: DEC 8, 2007 Pours dark brown/black with a tanned head. Roasted dryness, light sourness.  Aroma of roast coffee and a hint of fruits. Also a hint of sweet liquirish in the dry finish. Very nice. Very good after a year+ in the fridge.
Deep brown beer with a light brown head. Roasted malty aroma with notes of coffee bitterness and a light chocolate sweetness. Sweet roasted malty flavor with chocolate notes.
An opaque brown beer with a collapsing beige head. The aroma is sweet with notes of chocolate and coffee, while the flavor primarily is sweet with coffee notes, leading to a dry roasted end.

Bottled.
Black coloured with a beige head.
Aroma of coffee and chocolate with notes of liquorice.
Flavour of coffee and liquorice with notes of chocolate.
Poured black with a thick brown head.  The tast is mainly chocolate.  This is a very well balanced beer.
Deep dark black color with a creamy brown head.  The flavor is everything the aroma promises and more, with its thick roasted malt/chocolate flavors.  Very Good

Deep black, but still shiny somehow. Lovely dense espresso-like cap of foam that settles slowly into a viscous skim. Sweet cream aroma, with milk chocolate, mild coffee and a subtle chewy oat aroma. (Like a warm bowl of steel-cut Irish oats, with a drizzle of honey.) All kinds of smooth roast flavors, but a shade darker than the aroma. Dark chocolate, espresso. Firm smooth bitterness that finishes clean, and then returns with a wash of mouth coating chocolate/roast. One of Rogue¬ís finest, and one of the nicest stouts I¬íve tasted.

Very much like the chocolate stout.  Nose of chocolate, malt, and some dark fruit.  Flavor of raisins, chocolate, and maybe figs.  A nice bitter/ dryness juxtaposed to malty sweetness.  Nicely complex and a good body.

Bouteille-Wow! TR√®s douce en bouche. M√©lange de malte et de houblon. Tr√®s cr√®meuse. Un bon comp√©titeur pour la Saint-Ambroise Stout Oatmeal--Bottle-Wow! Very sweet in mouth. Malt and hops mix. Creamy. A good competitor for the Saint-Ambroise Oatmeal Stout.
I must say this is one of my fovorite stouts.  Plenty of roasty flovors without being bitter or harsh.  One hell of a smooth stout.

All stout characteristics are in play. Nose and flavor have a distinctive hop bite (of the Cascade variety) to them that adds a nice finish to this brew. The creamy sweetness is nicely rounded off by the hops. This is a very enjoyable stout and if it is lacking in anything it is only in that is not an imperial or stronger version.
Very good.  Rich chocolate/coffee roasty aroma,  53 IBU must be about right for me.  I love all those erudite specs Rogue puts on the bottle, but it always makes me feel like I¬ím drinking nerd-beer.
Didn¬ít seem dark or roasty enough for a stout, but tasted great!  I loved the use of Cascades instead of the traditional stout hops.  Very tasty, and much fresher than that "other" stout!

Bomber.  Very deep burgundy pour, damn near black.  Tall and creamy caramel head, and some nice lacing going down.  Aroma of rich chocolate, light vanilla, Cascade hoppiness, and roasted barley.  Quite a bit of citrus hoppage up front and the chocolate carried it through the finish.  Oats and some caramelly sweetness were also present.  Medium-bodied, with bitterness and a little sourness across the palate.  Chocolate and grapefruit on the dry finish.  Quite tasty.

Wow, much better than I expected, even considering its by Rogue.  This one was fuller and smoother than most of its peers, and goes down so easy that it just begs for a follow up.  I usually consider a stout a waste of time unless its an Imperial, but this is fantastic.

From the bottle this beer pours an opaque super dark brown...almost black with a tan head. Aroma is quite malty with notes of toffee and dark cherry. Bold flavor...almost espresso with a touch of roasty dark chocolate. Finishes bitter with plenty of hoppy goodness that lingers on the tongue. Full bodied and smooth mouthfeel makes for an above average Stout.
Robe noire surmont√©e d¬íune mousse brune. Ar√¥mes d¬íalcool et de fruits rouges. Saveurs de caf√©, de chocolat et d¬íalcool.
Maybe just a tad heavy and sweet for me, but good. Well-engineered, if I must say.

Tap @ Summits.  Black with a creamy tan head and plenty of lacing.  Sweet malty aroma with a nice roast and chocolate nose.  Flavor is sweet and roasty with a hoppy middle and a bitter finish that is part roast and part hop.  Medium bodied.  This is a keeper.  How did I not rate this before?

22z bottle.  Beautiful opaque hue with a caramel colored two fingered head that lingers.  Good coffee and bitter chocolate nose.  Slight caramel and anise notes in the nose.  Still a little bit too cold and the beer needs to open up,,,Still chocolate and roast aromas.  Dry and full flavored, but with a nice bitter dry finish. Good dark roasted coffee flavors and a little chocolate, bitter chocolate.  That bitterness evolved into the finish as it meanders with the hops.  Slightly grainy and a little bit of a raisin sweetness.  Slight cola flavor and carbonation. Great flavor and perfect example.
Dark, thick, rich, heavy, and malty. Everything a stout should be. Finishes very dry for me. Still a very good beer.

Bottle. Flavor wise, this is what a stout should taste like. Chocolate, bitter coffee, yum. Bites back a little, partly from the carbonation and partly from what I assume is the hop content, which is usually better hidden in stouts. Still, that flavor makes this a bit more unique, and will probably appeal to people for that reason alone. Mouth feel is thick in a syrupy way, but not unpleasant. Back in the day this was my first stout, so all others get compared to it. Great stand by stout.

As you have no doubt read this is just a great beer.  This beer has my all time favorite head of any beer.  The color, thickness and retention is great. The beer goes down smooth and has a great chocolate aftertaste with a hint of coffee.  This was the first rogue beer that I cloned.

(BJCP Class)  Another strong Northwest Hoppy beer.  This was a dark black hopped up beer.  With a great flavor why did they have to add so many hops?  I am sure this is over kill on the hops and they made a mistake. A strong smokiness also and with a chocolate flavor.  I hope to try again with less Hops.

This stuff is awesome.  Crisp and clean, yet rich and full of flavor.  Leaves the mouth feeling great and moves througha malty and rich choclatey flavor to an awesome burnt coffee flavor after its gone.  Probably my favorite.
A very roasty beer that has a malty taste.  Smells fantastic and the head has staying power and an excellent touch.  You¬íll enjoy this.

what else am I going to say that anybody here hasn¬ít already. very roasty, chocolatey, and malty. black in color with a dark red hue. Smells and tastes great with a dark tan head that stays. very impressive.

Gorgeous head and some nice lacing. Black and inviting to the eye. Light bitter start, finishing with stronger bitter. You will not miss the dark toasted malt - on the tongue and in the nose. The palate is the biggest winner here - this beer feels great on the tongue - creamy and slippery....gulp, down the gullet. Coats all the way down ending with a nice warm tummy and a smile.

A rich stout. Rich and creamy. A good one. Scent is excellent, maybe a little chocolate involved. A light black look, ebony like the sacred black rhino of Chad. Not really bitter at all, a great flavor. Rolls of your tounge like a haiku. Best Rogue that ive had so far.
Super dark chocolate smell, black pour, crema like head. Slick on the palate, not harsh, but bitter. Perfectly blended hops  and malts, smokey finish. Masculine.

Bottle. Very dark reddish brown, with a large reddish tan head. Aroma is chocolate, dark malts, brown sugar. Taste is chocolate, smokey malts and a strong bitter finish. Full bodied. Very good stout, should be sampled by Guinness drinkers everywhere, to provide perspective.

Found this while looking for a swill in the sister in laws fridge. I ask her where she got it. She said her sister lives in Oregon and she had it arround for about at least five years and recently just put it in the fridge. Man I was granted to crack this one open after my Miller Lite. Aroma was chocolate and roasty malts. Body was black and had a tan head. Some lacing. A good choclatle roasted wood flavor and this was smooth to drink. Appently this ages well.
bottle 9/27/05. Pours a very thin brown head and a chocolate black color. Smoked malt nose and flavor with a very smooth finish. Fairly full bodied. Roast taste and smell. Excellent brew.

Bottle:  Pours dark and thick black with a creamy tan head.  Aroma is of chocolate and licorice. Up front you get a rush of malts, chocolate, coffee, nuts, even some molasses.  Then the finish has just the right amount of hoppiness to balance this extraordinary beer.  Truly one of the most enjoyable stouts I¬íve ever tried.  Rogue really hits the mark on this one.

The pretentious name on the bottle can more than back up the flavor of the beer. The initial taste of the motor-oil black stout is unlike anything I¬íve encountered; It is indescribably rapturous. The bottled version would suffer a few points for poor head and loss of flavor toward the end of the bottle. Rogue Shakespeare Stout on tap, however, is the greatest beer I¬íve experienced.
Rich in every way -- deep and dark, with a medium body, roasty aroma, and a pleasantly large amount of bitterness to hold it all together. Very nice.

UPDATED: SEP 26, 2006 Draught. Pours an opaque black with thin, but dense, tan head that leaves very nice lacing.  The aroma is very roasty with light chocolate. The flavor has a lot of roasted and chocolate malts, some coffee, and earthy hops. This remains among my favorites. Rich, robust, and tasty.

Draught:  Smelled malty and of coffee.  Nice aroma.  Poured dark brown with big tan head.  Medium lacing.  Tasted of coffee, choclate, and a little nut.  Very well balanced.  Pretty easy to drink.  Lighter in color than most stouts.  Overall, a pretty good, highly drinkable beer.

Bottle.  Malty molasses aroma.  Pours like weak oil - dark opaque brown with ample head.  Sweet molasses malt with strong bitter finish.  Slightly thick mouthfeel but not too much - well balanced.  A great beer

Bottle. Pours opaque tar black with substantial, lasting head and little lacing. Rich flavors of chocolatey sweetness and mocha bitterness, but dark burnt flavors keep it dry with an intensely long finish. Truly an impressive brew, with more depth than most imperial stouts.

Couleur noire fonc√©, apparence opaque, large quantit√© de mousse beige, cr√©meuse et persistante.  Ar√¥mes de malt r√¥ti, de caf√© et de noisettes chocolat√©es sous de faible effluve d¬íalcool.  Abondance de malt r√¥ti visit√© par des notes de noix, de vanille et de grains de caf√© frais, une certaine acidit√© √©merge de la torr√©faction des malts.  Finale s√®che et verte se terminant sur des notes de houblon amer.  Corps d¬í√©paisseur moyenne, carbonatation piquante.
Pours a deep black with an awesome head. Super creamy, rich, chocolately, well balanced. Also has a nice bitterness in the finish though retains its stout character. A very very nice brew.
Malty aroma. Opaque color.  Dark chocolate malt flavor with some charred  bitterness.
Dark. Creamy. A little bitter. Not as charred as other Stouts. A bit on the mild side. A slight taste of dark chocolate.

jet black with a quickly diminishing coffee brown head. good lacing.  Roasty aroma with some malt and a very faint alcoholic smell.  roasted coffee bean. nice and bitter. full with a nice malt with a minimal hop profile. Balanced and enjoyable.  nice and full with a moderate body and moderate carbonation. wonderfully bitter, dry aftertaste.  Very drinkable beer that I loved having after dinner.  Oh yeah this is a great example of an American Stout. Nearly flawless.

Big expectations here. Too carbonated to start with and by the smell to cold. Swirl around in my tulip while heating it with my hand it starts to get better. However i find that it doesnt taste good until its entirly flat and warm. Usual chocolate, coffee, not to dry a finish. Strong bitter flavours here, but not one id get super excited about.

This reminds me of Old Rasputin,  which should tell you that this is no ordinary stout.  Almost imperial in every catagory except ABV.   Deep roasted flavors of caramel and coffee but also a nice bitter hopping that makes for some complexity.   All in all, an excellent stout.

22 oz bottle. Poured into my Guinness (ah the days I thought that was the best stout) english pint glass at 48¬∞. Pours black, honest to God black. Not dark tan, not light black with some reddish tints. Black. With a smallish cappicino colored head that coats the glass and you rotate the glass. The aroma is dark roasted malt, coffee, some floral hops. Nice smell. The taste is a dark roasted coffee malt bomb. The hops come on midway and add a spicy bitterness. Nice, full mouthfeel. The finish is clean and crisp and makes you want to have sip after sip. This is a beer that belies it alcohol content, it has imperial stout complexity, but with an easy drinking stlye that makes me wish the served this at every college bar instead of bland, old Guinness. There is a reason why Rogue is so high priced, it¬ís because they put out high quality beers like this one. This is one worth it. I will be buying this one again.
At the GBBF 05¬í, a strong and a bit hoppy stout, rich in flavour, hoppy IPA like aroma, good strong roasted bitterness, overall a really nice stout.

On tap at the Bread Company, Urbana, IL. Shakespeare deserves to rank among the best stouts in the 5-7% ABV range. I¬íd drink this any day over Kalamazoo or Deep Shaft. Dark roasted barley notes with the accompanied chocolate and molasses flavors make for an enjoyable and lasting experience on the palate. The creaminess imparted by the tap adds another dimension to an already sensuous experience. Hop balance is well done, better than their Impy imo. Unlike their Imperial Stout (which I prefer after 1-2 years of age), this happens to be one of my favorite stouts to drink young and bold.

Bottle. Pours a solid black with a thick big creamy head. Smells of malts, sugar, chocolate, and almonds. Tastes of chocolate (bitterness), nuts, and a big ass dose of malts. Excellent on the tongue. Very creamy with not a lot of carbonation. Nice lacing on the glass.

UPDATED: JUN 30, 2007 Had this one on tap again at Barley¬ís and also at The Ship recently. To me, Rogue sets a standard for big American beers on their regular offerings then makes weird beers on the side. This is one of the quintessential American stouts. It¬ís a very black beer with a dark tan head and sticky lacing. The aroma is dead on for this style. Lots of coffee and chocolate,  a little soy sauce, then comes the hops. A nice sprucy, piny bite is in the mix. The palate is medium dense. The flavor is rich of coffee and chocolate with the finish focusing more on the sharp hop presence. A lot of people have second thoughts about  heavy use of U.S. hops in dark ales, but I think that it is delicious when done right. This is a wonderful example of how that should be done, let alone the thick, assertive, balanced more predictable stout qualities.
a rich black color, slight brown head.  spicy, chocolatey aroma and nice coffe taste.  malty and smooth finish

Pours jet black... as thick as tar.  The taste starts very earthy, roasted, with a little hops. and finishes with a slight sweetness and chocolate flavor.  not near as sweet as rogue hazel nut or chochlate stout.  A little earthy for me, but all in all a pretty good beer

Bomber:  Dark in appearance, tan head, mostly lasting.  Aromas of Dark malts, mostly coffee, hints of chocolate.  Slightly watery in flavor with chocolate and the slightest of hops.  Finsihes slightly bitter chocolate and water.

22oz Bottle. Pours nice, deep black with a brown head. Aromas of roasted malts, chocolate, and stout sourness. Nose is not as big as I expected from the appearance. Flavors of all of the above, with a slightly bitter finish. Overall a bit thin and toned-down for my tastes. A thicker body would enhance the roasted flavors and better balance the dry and sweet characteristics. A very drinkable beer, but nothing to rave about.

this is the best beer i have ever drank. if you drink one more beer for the rest of your life you must drink this, its incredible. just so you know ROGUE did not pay me stupid amounts of money to write this. but if they want me to im ready to make a deal.

I was hoping for much more from this stout, especially after smelling and seeing it. It has good flavor and aroma, but didn¬ít reach my expectations. It was a bit thin, and the flavor wasn¬ít strong enough.

Pours a deep dark brown / black with a thick chocolate milkshake head. Mild chocolate & hops aroma. Chocolate mocha taste with a bit of a hop bitter. So far, this is the best Rogue brew I¬íve tried. Nice mouthfeel, enough bubbly tingle to keep it interesting. Two thumbs up on this one.
user_location: Waco (Buckle of the Bible Belt), Texas, USA

text: Never been a huge stout fan until now.  Great black color with a rich head.  Nice chocolate aftertaste and roasted flavor.  A very enjoyable and nice sipping beer.
another impressive beer from rouge. just in plain words a good good beer or stout for you pros. and i enjoyed it.
Bomber. Pours oily black w/ foamy tan head. Nose of coffee, chocolate and malt. Malty taste w/ chocolate ad coffee. Finishes w some light hopps and chalky bitterness.
My first ever Rogue beer some 15 years ago, and still a stalwart.  A giant stout.  Wonderful roasty, malty flavor and a thick, robust body.  One of my all time favorites.
Pours black with a frothy brown head.  You can smell the chocolate.  Fills the mouth with coffee and butterscotch.  Flavor lingers a while.

Pours deep brown/mahogany with a thick frothy brown head, leaving a bit of lacing behind.  Aroma for this one is very pleasant - Coffee, caramel and a bit of hickory.  Chocolate, caramel and coffee flavours with a nice chocolate finish.  Only drawback - could be a bit creamier to the palate.

UPDATED: AUG 26, 2005 Bottle (650ml).  I¬íve had three bottles of this put away for at least 9 months now, time to rate one.  Poured a thick inky-black with an excellent fairly dark brown creamy, slightly rocky head.  Pretty much perfect looking.  Aroma of dark roasted malt, licorice, rich creamy  chocolate (I swear I smell table cream), hops, caramel, and some loamy richness.  Taste is very over-roasted malty, with enough earthy bitterness to balance, the chocolate and cream tastes come out with warming.  Very creamy and full-bodied mouthfeel, a pleasure to drink.  It finishes slightly bitter, but the full suite of flavours linger too, so that¬ís okay; hardly any alcohol aggressiveness at all.  A terrific stout, and this slightly aged bottle is a few points better than the two I had in the fall of 2004 before I started rating.

Bottle.  Darkest Dark color with a rather dark brown head.  Very creamy head that left nice lacing.  Aromas were very strong anise and molassas.  Flavors were some of that but with a great roasted malt too.  Some alcohol on the aftertaste, and a somewhat bitter finish.  Very good Stout.

Cask conditioned - gravity dispense - GBBF 2005.  A black beer with a big off-white frothy coffee coloured head.  The head was over big so I cannot give a 5 for appearance.  The aroma was roasty stouty with a bit of chocolate and a bit of lactose.  The taste had good roasted malt notes with more lactic qualities, and loads of coffee.  A really nice stout.

UPDATED: AUG 16, 2005 I find myself not knowing just what to say about this stout.  It is high quality in every way and yet it doesn¬ít stand out as particularly intruiging or interesting.  Perhaps that¬ís a good thing though.  Just a perfect straightforward stout, done very well, a little dry and bitter and not too sweet.  Excellent mouthfeel that is both crisp and creamy.

UPDATED: JAN 23, 2006 (22 oz. bottle from <A HREF=http://www.downeastbeverage.com>Downeast Beverage Co. 

 ) Deep mahogany color, opaque. Thick tan head, lacing OK but a little sloppy. Aroma of roasted grains, slightly chocolaty. Wonderful mouthfeel, wonderful smoooth finish with nice touch of bitterness. Nice and thick. Tastes great, but I wasn¬ít quite blown away.  Sort of like a brown ale taste but more toasty. Chocolate comes out a bit more after several tastes. A fine beer.

Cask at GBBF 2005
Black.  Fresh, roast malt nose with coffee dominant and some chocolate, some toffee.  Not too full in mouth but the finish is outstanding.  Long, coffee, burntness and some charcoal.
A roasted coffee aroma.  A deep black color and nice rich brown head.  A nice full bodied beer with a coffee taste and hints of chocolate.

Draft.  Dark black opaque pour.  Nose was a weak roasty aroma.  Roasty malt flavor, with some nice chocolate flavors that only come through if the beer is not served too cold.  Some coffee-ish notes too.  Maybe some hop character.  Medium thickness, on par for a 6% stout I¬íd think.

UPDATED: FEB 18, 2006 black and opaque in color.  tan head.  big roasted barley, coffee,  and hop aroma.  amazing palate.  sharp hop bitterness at first finshing with roasted dark chocolate aftertaste.

Had this on tap. Black color with brownish head. Roasted barley aroma and flavor are prominent with hops more in the background. Very coffee-like with chocolate and licorice undertones. Moderate carbonation. Slightly bitter hop finish.
this was almost perfect.  definately left me wanting more the $6 i paid for the 22oz was well worth it
Not AS GOOD as soe other stouts, but thick and rich in flavor and color. Can¬ít remember the nose, I¬íll have to try another and update this...

This is a straight ahead awesome rendition of a stout. Imagine a stout with all the aroma, flavor quality, palate, finish and overall good drinkability and you will have summoned up Rogue Shakespeare Stout.

UPDATED: DEC 20, 2005 Thanks Chuck!  Pours to a medium thickness dark brown fizzy/creamy head atop a black body.  The head laces well.  The aroma is similar to Dr. Pepper.  A bit too light, however.  I get a LIGHT milk chocolate.  The aroma is VERY WEAK.  The flavor, on the other hand, is rich and dark chocolatey with a light coffee and light grass.  The palate is pretty slick to begin with but then becomes thick and rich once you swish it around.  Overall, this isn¬ít a bad beer and makes really good bread (sampled that in the past when StewardOfGondor brought it over to my rating).
ar 5 ap 5 f 7 p 4 o 14
>>>>>>>>> rerate on 12/20/05 per JCapriotti >>>>>>>>>>>>&g beer has a huge aroma.  Grassy and cappachino and roasty malts.  The body is dry and roasty.  Great.  The palate has that dry charcoal feel I love so much.  So much better than I remember.

pours a dark color w/ a huge big tall brown head and lots of lacing.  Scent is a bit mild but hints of hops and dark malt, chocolate.  Palate is well coated lightly creamy but to thin for a stout.. it¬ís a 3 if not a stout.  Flavor is standard stout.. dark chocolate a tiny touch of coffee that dark malt flavor and a touch of light hop in the finish.  I don¬ít think this is anything special but rather just another decent stout.
Bottle-A nice, solid black color with a small tan head that dissipated.  There was a little too much carbonation for a stout, IMO.  Heavy chocolate aroma with a bitter finish.
Very dark brown to black body with a thick, lacing, tan head.  Chocolate and cola aroma.  Flavor of sour malt, light coffee and caramel.  Smooth palate and a light mouthfeel.

UPDATED: JUL 18, 2005 Thick, dark stout.  Almost as if it sucks the light of the room into it.  Very strong chocolate flavors with a bittersweet aftertaste.  Really liked this beer.  Would be perfect in the hot tub after a long day in Telluride.

Pours black, with medium brown head that is quickly diminishing and leaves no lacing on my questionably clean bar glass.  Nose is intense chocolate with some faint plum note.  The flavor is initially smoky, leading to an intense, milky chocolate flavor that segues to dark, bitter chocolate at the end, and leaves a long, long bitter aftertaste of chocolate and burnt barley and good cigars.  Mouthfeel is excellent... heavy and full without being cloying.  Wowsa.

Appearance: "The jaws of darkness do devour it up."
Aroma: "By any other name would smell as sweet."
First Taste: "So much complexion? look ye, how they change!"
Aftertaste: "Thy wit is very bitter sweeting."
Overall: "Enjoy and make much of it."

Complex aroma with leading notes of dark chocolates, vanilla extract and caramel.  Nuttiness, tobacco and some alcohol are present underneath.  The body is intense upfront, but becomes somewhat watery in the middle.  The chocolate malts are bitter and layer nicely with hints of fresh ground coffee.  The watery middle and slight ¬ítin¬í element in the finish bring this down from near perfection.

Dark black with great brown head. Perfect appearance. Slight coffee and cola sniff. Slight coffee ground taste with cola nut and extreme bitterness. Too much bitterness..too overly hopped for a stout. I admit, I¬ím a wimp; I didn¬ít enjoy this balls out stout that much as the others in the Rogue camp.

Had this one bottled.  Thick, black almost purple pour, with the darkest brown head I¬íve ever seen in a beer.  Very dense mouthfeel, almost oily.  Coffee and chocolate notes, bitter and very drinkable.  Satisfying.

UPDATED: JUL 23, 2005 This pours the thickest black that you could imagine with a beautifully lasting and fine-bubbled, brown head.  The nose is standard Rogue fare - perhaps there are traces of prunes and flowers - but the nose is also very noticeably roasted.  What is most striking about this brew is how thick it really is.  The mouthfeel is dense, but it doesn¬ít come across as syrupy. The tastes range from an initial dark fruitiness (prunes?), to a middle creamy chocolatiness, to a long-lasting but only moderately bitter trail.  The alcohol is not noticeable.  The roastiness comes out especially strong in the aftertaste which is only softly dry.  This is a very rich and interesting stout.

UPDATED: MAY 31, 2007 May 31st 2007 Re-Rate.

The arroma is black coffee, dark chocolate, burnt malt, bitter hops and dark fruits. The body is a solid black and holds a bubbly, two finger thick, mocha head. The fore is burnt, roasted malt, hops and dark chcoolate. Ever so slightly thinnish. Very west coast with a big bitter presence that is accentuated by ample hopping.

A great all around stout that balances the bitter roastiness of the malts and bitterness of the hops without getting ridiculous. Coffee and choclate flavors support the rest of the beer very well. Solid enough to go back to over and over though I could do with less hops.
Great chocolaty taste. A robust and sweet stout. Not the best I¬íve ever had but extremely drinkable, pleasant, and smooth.
C-H-O-C-O-L-A-T-E.  Starts like Mr. Goodbar, with chocolate and nuts, and ends like Hershey¬ís Dark Chocolate, with the bitterness to boot.  Leaves a happy tongue ( and some nice belches) behind.

Poured black with a good brown head.  Similar in appearance to the Imperial Stout.  Head left good lacing.  Aroma had bitter chocolate, coffee, espresso and roasted oats.  Very sweet taste, so sweet that I found it difficult to handle.  The mouthfeel was very roasty.  This was not really my kind of beer, but it was high quality and I will respect that.

UPDATED: JAN 22, 2006 Pours a completely black color, almost no head. The aroma is like many other stouts, with coffee, roast, and chocolate. However, hops are easily detectable. An enjoyable session and one of the better stouts I¬íve had. A hint of chocolate throughout dominated by hop bitternes. Have it with chocolate.
Dark black body with a brown head.  Aroma and taste of caramel and coffee.  Mouthfeel is thick and soft.  Very good.

Nice, modestly thick pour.  Black in color with a foamy, 1/2" dark tan head.  Aroma is cocoa powder and burr grinded coffee beans.  Rich flavor of dry, unsweetened cocoa.  Hints toward an unflavored iced cappuccino, but then transitions to taste like yesterday¬ís pot of cold coffee.  Disperses rather quickly across the palate.  Bitterness prevails.  Finishes like french roast coffee, as if you¬íve just finished off the sludge at the end of the pot.  The aftertaste is the best part of this one.

[big bottle]
Opaque black with a light brown, patchy head.  Aroma of roasty malt and some fruit: apple-strawberry.  Also a touch of band-aid on the nose.  Gentle, roasty toasty malt flavour with significant bitterness from the dark malt.  Burnt coffee with a touch of nondescript hops and a pleasant cereal grain flavour. Medium to full body and chewy with quite a bit of carbonation and an almost clean finish.

UPDATED: JUL 12, 2006 Looks like motor oil with a medium brown head, awesome.  Smell Roasted malts, espresso, chocolate, burned bread, and pine.  Big bitter chocolate flavor, along with coffee, and even cherries.  Has a nice hop kick to it.  Finish is very toasty and burned.  Very pleasant to drink.  Seems very well balanced.
Bottle.  I really do love american hops, especially in a deep, rich american stout.  You can¬ít beat a stout with rich, espresso character with citrus livleyness.  Truly enjoyable.

UPDATED: JUL 12, 2005 This is how I would make a stout.  Beautifully dark, completely opaque, and nice creamy head.  Chocolate intense flavor and completely chocolate aftertaste.  This beer just flat out rocks!

Very sweet, a stout with some true character in it, true toastyness of the malt, taste of dark-semi-sweet chocalte.
Enjoy!!!

UPDATED: OCT 28, 2009 Pitch black, with and orangish creamy head. Dusky pine sol aroma. Strong malted coffee, chocolate, and burnt duck background. Finish is dry. Not real impressive in my mind.
Re-rate. This isn¬ít as rough as I originally thought. It¬ís got some wonderful roast character and nice hop play. It¬ís good on the dryness level and has a decent mouthfeel.

2005 AIBA Sample. Aaah! Beautiful dark brown colour and big tan head. Huge aroma and flavourof dark chocolate. Thick with wonderful real bitterness of chocolate. This is the shouldabeen Grand Champion. Now, if it were actuallyavailable in Australia, I would live on the stuff.

Yet one more beer I forgot I hadn¬ít rated; and what a nice brew, too; it has a nice fruity-hop/espresso nose with a hint of  sweetness; it¬ís malty and roasty with a columbian coffee smoothness and building bitterness; ¬íbout time I rated this classic.

Pours black not much light gets through it.  A thick creamy tan head forms and stays for a few sips then laces the edges of the glass.  Aroma is smoke and burnt malt.  The taste is dark chocolate and coffee.  Amazingly smooth and creamy on the palate...  Not as thick as other stouts I¬íve had.  A pretty smooth drinker though and a pretty nice night cap.

Based upon this beers overall score, I¬ím wondering if I got a skunk bottle.  My beer actually smelled quite bad (although, I think aroma is the least important of these categories). The rich creamy head mentioned on the bottle never materialized.  This reminds me of their chocolate stout, just not as good in any way. suprisingly hoppy, but this is so far my least favorite rogue beer (and I¬ím a stout kind of guy).

From a 22oz bomber.

Pours black with hints of dark ruby around the edges with a thin brown head. Smell is smoky burnt malt but also lightly sweet and creamy.

Taste is chocolatey, a bitter dark chocolate. Lightly nutty or oaty undertones. Big flavors here but still very smooth. A strong bitter coffee finish. Nice! Mouthfeel is full-bodied with a strong smoky and bitter aftertaste. Some hop flavors evident in the aftertaste as well. Incredibly smooth and drinkable for a big flavor stout like this one.

A beer that definitely lives up to the hype.

A dense, dark brown/black body under a tan, root-beer-float of a head that ended too soon. Lots of happy chocolate aromas: from cocoa to milk chocolate to bitter dark chocolate. Well-roasted barley notes as well, and some flowery hops appear late. Somewhat balanced flavor starting as bitter coffee, but ending with lingering dark chocolate. Alas, a bit too fizzy to be truly enjoyable and surprisingly not as full bodied as I¬íd expected.
<font size=-4><a href=http://www.ratebeer.com/Places/ShowPlace.asp? Liquors, Oak Forest, IL<font size=-1>

Pours opaque black, fizzy tan head dissapates quickly.  Earhty, bready roast aroma.  Sweet nose, followed by roast malt and cocoa flavors.  Yeasty notes start the finish, with a residual sweetness complements the roasty aftertones.

Beautiful, think, rich brown head. Long lasting. Black as night. Man this beer has my mouth watering. It really looks great.

I¬ím not really getting anything special in the nose. Some roasty toasty ness. 

Tastes like dark roast coffee, chocolate, burnt toast. 

I think it might be a touch thin, but not watery. Maybe too much carbonation.

Not what I¬íd call and easy drinker, but I could see having 2 or 3 in a session.

All in all, another good offering from the guys at Rouge.
Bomber. Very dark, black stout. Lots of burnt malt and not a lot else - not very much to say about this not very nice beer. Not enjoyable at all - 3/4 of it went down the drain.
Draft. This is good, but this is the first time I drank a beer and was thinking of a chocolate breakfast bar. Clearly a sweet stout with a great roasted coffee, chocolate and nut flavor. Good brew.

ahh. this brought back sweet memories. This poured black, nice dark tan head. This great. Chocolate and malts roasted and coffee. I loved this the first time, and love it now. Very well balanced and drinkable for a stout. A pleasure to drink.

On tap - Flying Saucer Raliegh NC.  Rich chewy beer with a roasted coffee flavor,  Lots of malt flavor but not too sweet.  Flavors are not overwhelming or overpowering.  Fantastic.  Beatiful apperance with thick but smallish tan head.

Looks, smells and tastes just like a quality stout should. Black with a puffy tan head and aroma of roasted coffee. Slight dry and bitter palate. Given the choice, I¬íd drink Rogue¬ís chocolate over this one just b/c the palate isn¬ít as dry as Shakespeare.

On tap.

It can be an everyday beer for me.  Nice beautiful color with heavy lacing.  Slight chocolate aftertaste.  Great beer.

Bottle:  Excellent aroma of chocolate, roasted malt,  and coffee.  Pours a dark brown virtually black with a dark tan head with pretty good retention.  Quick malt and chocolate is overtaken by roasted coffee and a pretty big hop finish.  Definitely some grapefruit.  Mostly hoppy and light coffee aftertaste.  Would have like the malt up front to not die so quickly, but still a nice stout.
Strong hints of chocolate and mocha.  Black color with tan head.  Very malty and a bitter aftertaste.  Has a robust coffee taste.
this beer is awesome! i love the high ibu, and i cant wait to get my hands on a stone imperial sout(75 ibu)
user_location: Las Cruces, NM, New Mexico, USA

text: UPDATED: FEB 2, 2006 Dark brown pour with a slowly dissipating head.  Raisin, malty aroma.  Chocalty/coffee &  raisin taste with a solid but smooth finish.  Excellent palate. [$3.99/22oz]

I saw Lolita¬ís eyes, and they seemed to be more calculating than frightened. I heard her saying to a kind lady that her father was having a fit. Then for a long time I lay in a lounge chair swallowing pony upon pony of gin. And next morning I felt strong enough to drive on (which in later years no doctor believed).
dark dark brown with a good deal of a tan head. hoppy, chocolatey aroma.  taste is roasty, chocolatey, and some grapefruity hops at the end. one of the best stouts i¬íve had.

Overrated.  This is a good beer, but I had it in the bottle, and I¬ím not even sure you can get it on tap, which is the way that a beer like this needs to be experienced.  

It¬ís good. It¬ís not great.  Strong flavor like you¬íd expect -- better than guinness without a doubt.  Isn¬ít that sad?
Jet black with a big brown head.  Lots of chocolate in the nose, with some alcohol notes.  Flavor is coffee, chocolate, and a smoky flavor in the finish.

Pours dense and black with a dark brown, slowly diminishing head.  Aroma of roasted coffee beans, leather, and caramel.  Beer coats the palate leaving a real nice mouthfeel.  Flavors of toasted nuts, bittersweet chocolate, smoke, caramel, and coffee.  Hops give the beer a nice bitter edge and the flavor lasts in your mouth forever.  This beer could be a meal!!!!

I¬íve been waiting a long time for this one to make it back to my neck of the woods(Casper Wyoming)

Beautifully black appearance,and from the first sip to the last evidence of the aftertaste, this is one of the best Stouts I have ever tasted. I particularly like the big hop send off that shows up right at the end. Thank you, Rogue!
definitely better as it warmed.  lots of chocolate and coffee slavor.  a good amount of depth.  poured dark with a creamy brown head.  a great beer.

UPDATED: MAY 27, 2005 Big light brown head...good head retention.  Pitch black color...beautiful.  Aroma of coffee and some chocolate.  Flavor is dry, burnt chocolate malt...coffee bitterness.  Finish is of coffee bitterness.  Palate is creamy and soft.  Great mouthfeel! Great brew overall. For my own personal tastes, though, it could be a little less dry, but that doesn¬ít take away from the superiority of this brew.

Very well done stout. Nice mouthfeel good conditioning and very good nose of chocolate and mocha. creamy soft mouthfeel with absolutely no astringency. Very clean finish with no lingering. A great session stout.
bottle.  pours a nice looking dark brown with a tan head.  great flavors of bittersweet chocolate and hints of coffee.  smooth and very drinkable!

Bottle.  Pours very dark brown/black with a thin light brown head that lasts.  Very dark beer, can¬ít see through it.  Aroma is somewhat weak, but the taste is big,  malty, chocolate and coffee. Hop bitterness in the finish.  A good stout.
Dang...this beer is soooo dark.  Personally, I don¬ít like it.  Really complex with chocolate and malts.  But I just can¬ít get past the fact that I don¬ít like beers this dark.

Bottle - 650ml. Perfectly opaque dark brown (almost black) body topped with a lasting brown frothy head. Aroma is not as strong as I was expecting. It is malty with various hints of roasted coffee, brown sugar and chocolate. Robust oaty/hoppy taste with roasty, herbal and chocolate notes. Ends with a long bittersweet finish. That beer is to the Stouts what Shakespeare is to English litterature: a reference!
Choclatey!  Creamy, black, minimal head, oh so rich and delicious, just a hint of tang.  I had this for dessert with ice cream, it worked.

black appearance with minimal to no head...aroma is full of milk chocolate, with a faint hint of tartness...flavor is heavy in chocolate and coffee with a perfect toastiness to it...an excellent stout
Black with small brown head.  Aroma is roasty.  Flavor is choc. malt, toasted malts, some coffee, cocoa,man just a ton of flavor in a regular old "stout".
Black colour with a thin dark yellow head. Light/medium bodied. Roasted flavour. Sweet chocolate taste. Hoppy odour. Short aftertaste with low bitterness.

Poured like motor oil and exploded into a head that was like a root beer float, or hot coke poured over ice ... gorgeous.  For that daunting appearance, this turned out to be a nicely drinkable sweet dark beer ... chocolately and light.

Bottled. 
Pitch black, brown head. Nutty nose along with chocolate. Flavour is wonderfully chocolatey, has that "Roast Barley Sourness" and hoopy tang. Somewhat Imperial Stout-feel to it, though not as attenuated. Low-Medium bitter.

Damn near the darkest stout I¬íve seen with a wonderful creamy head and roasty/chocolate aroma.  Smooth taste with roast flavor, slight hops noticeable.  A wonderfully bitter aftertaste with hints of chocolate complete this fantastic stout.  I bought this on a lark after hearing some good things and was very pleased.  I was sorry to finish the 220z bomber so quickly!

Poured deep black, with a small though lasting tan head. Mild chocolate/cocoa aroma, with some roasty notes. Flavour is balanced between sweet choc and bitter choc. Nice roast aftertaste. Medium bodied. Not bad.

First impressions do count. When I pour a stout and the stream from the bottle is actually black, I get a really good feeling. This one does not disappoint. Supremely roasty aroma. With a body like J-lo, this one hits your palate with a vengence. Just enough malt and oats to sweeten out the hoppy aggression and a finish I¬íd pay four bucks for in Starbucks. This is all one could hope for in a Stout.

This is a nice change from the extremely full-bodied Impy Stouts I¬íve been drinking lately.  Pours black with not much of a head, but I was gentle.  I like the fact that it is without an overpowering roasty flavor but the mouthfeel suffers because it almost seems like there is some seltzer water in your beer creating carbonation but it is just the cascade hops giving the beer a dryness that goes from start to finish.  Still a fine stout as Rogue never dissapoints.

Used motor oil black with a milk chocolate color head. Grapefruit blossom hops, baking cocoa, coffee, a nice sniffing brew! A bittersweet front with plenty of roasted malts, a biting bitter middle and a mocha/java finish with lingering floral hoppy bitterness. Just a touch more sweetness would make this near-perfect but it¬ís still very good just the way it is.

Poured from a bottle. Has a fairly typical dark stout color with a VERY thick head. Has a good dry stout flavor that finishes with a marvelous hint of chocolate. Beer feels nice and creamy in my mouth. Thoroughly enjoyable stout.

Pitch black in color with a thick brown head. Sweet, hoppy aroma with chocolate and a bit of coffee. Thick and chewey with a long roasty and slightly bitter finish. Somewhat fruity with flavors of leather, coffee, cocoa. NIcely balanced and satisfying.

Appearance was very black with tan head.  Aroma was roasted coffee, chocolate, roasted malts.  Taste is chocolate with really bitter or dense cappichino.  This stout has a great palate and leaves a thick mouthfeel.  Can taste the hops in the finish.  A very good stout.

Great appearance with black body a dark tan head becoming slightly lighter on top.  Very foamy also.  Chocolate cigar smell.  Nice bitter-sweet taste.  Can really tast the roasted barley in it.  Nice smoke and bitter finish.  Stays on the palate well.  "Thickens my spit" Mike LeMieux.  Does have a little citrus in it too.  Great stout.

Pours nearly jet black with a syrupy tan head.  Lacing diminishes quickly.  Not much nose to speak of.  Tastes of baker¬ís chocolate, roasted/burnt coffee, cola, spices and a hint of tobacco.  Medium-bodied with a cola fizz and an increasingly bitter, salty aftertaste (in a good way).  Similar to Rogue¬ís Mocha Porter.  Wouild buy again.

UPDATED: DEC 22, 2005 Pours black with very little creamy tan head that mostly diminishes and leaves a small amount of lacing.  Smells of roasted grains and some caramel as well, hint of coffee/chocolate  to the smell, nice smell but nothing fantastic.  Flavor is a little sweet and a little bitter, as is the aftertaste.   Tastes smokey, which wasn¬ít in the smell, and tastes a lot like bittersweet chocolate.  Palate is alright nothign amazing.  A good beer but too highly rated in my opinion, I¬íd much rather have Rogue¬ís Mocha Porter.

UPDATED: FEB 23, 2005 Pours a deep black with a nicely lasting, if not too think head. Rich, roasted barely and oats. Velvety beginning gives way to a little bit of hops and bittersweet chocolate to dry it out and give a bitter finish. Weirdly salty aftertaste

22 oz. bottle.  Pour is jet black with thick brown head that leaves a good bit of lace.  Crisp aroma is of chocolate, roasty malts, nuts and some hops.  Taste is bitter and roasty with hints of cocoa and coffee.  Dry and even somewhat salty tasting.  VERY bitter finish.

Falling out of the bottle deep red and, when in glass sits perfectly opaque.  Frothy and foaming head with little lacing.  Smells of plums, banana, and alcohol.  Sharp  tastes of alcohol and peppers.  Bitter (good bitter)aftertaste present.  Mouthfeel was very light unfortunately.  Slight velvet touch saved it.  (650 ml bottle)

Big dark pour with a creamy tan ¬ífro of head: gorgeous.  I would give it a 6 if I could.  Light roast aroma. Light chocolate and nut flavor.  Smooth not-too-thick mouthfeel (actually a touch thin on the body). Mellow hop aftertaste with some light molasses in the back of the palate.  This beer is a bit shy and needs to express itself more clearly.  Not bad at all, but not incredibly impressive.

Had this at the ¬ìOn Tap¬î bar in Birmingham.  12 oz Bottle (unsure of year).  Thought the bar was dark it poured like motor oil.  Black with vague brown hints at the edges.  No head.  The aroma had a hoppyness to it and gave me some citrus hints.  Heavy roasted malts, coffee and unsweetened chocolate.  Perhaps some fruit (cherry?).  The flavor was litely hoppy and sweet, with caramel and coffee.  As with most stouts the flavor continued to improve as the beer warmed from bar fridge temp.  Body was sharp at first (moderate carbonation) but mellows out and leaves a lingering creamy then dry mouth feel.

Aroma:Chocolate,torefaction.
Appearance:Black with a big brown head.
Flavor:roasted malt and chocolate.
Good stout.

Had this beer head to head with Bear Republic Big Bear. Pours black motor oil with thin very dark brown head. This beer is perfectly opaque. Aroma is warm and malty with slight scents of chocolate, coffee, and caramel. Flavor is dry and of burnt grain but with significant bitterness. Finish starts bitter but subsides leaving a burnt grain flavor on the tongue. Very complex, very good.
Pours black with a medium lasting head.  Smells of chocolate coffee and roasted malts.  Great rich flavor with a sweet coffee flavor that goes into a bitter roasted malt flavor.  Great Stout!!
It starts with a slight light brown head. The taste is rich and malty. The mouthfeel is full. The aftertaste is chocolatey with a bit of bitterness. Great brew.

Smells sweet and malty.  Pours opaque black with a thin, dark tan head.  The flavor is very malty, with a roasty aftertaste.  The chocolate is hard to find in the flavor, but still good.  Tasty beer.  Bitter roasty finish touch of chocolate resurfaces.
Jet black.... brown head.  Looks damned yummy.  Nice roasted flavor.... little bitter... which is nice.  Really... This was a nice beer.... really nice.  Alot better then Rogue Dead Guy Ale.

Pours pitch black in color with a brown head. Wonderful sweet chocolate aroma with a little bit of a malty presence in the background. Flavor is quite roasty. Starts of a little roasty with some sweetness. Finishes 
with a huge roasted coffee flavor. Very tasty.

I forgot how AWESOME this beer was.  Kids, take notes, this is what a stout is supposed to be.  Amazing flavor.  Head and shoulders above the average stout... in fact this beer would be more comprable to some top quality imperial stouts.

Pours the consistency and color of heavily used motor oil and molasses with a thick brown head...looks like you could cut it with a knife.  Wonderful chocolatey mocha aroma...thick & chewy body with a strong bitter chocolate and coffee flavor.  This is possibly the best stout I¬íve had thus far.

Excellent aroma of malty caramel and chocolate chunks.  The taste satisfies with a smokey flavor of chocolately hops and barley.  Prunes, molasses, and chicory smoked coffee beans delight the senses.  Good Stout with a smooth finish. Worth a TRY!

Sweetness balances huge roasty aroma.  Opaque black body with large, brown, small-bubbled head that lasts throughout.  Roastiness dominates the flavour also, with a hickory-like smokiness and a salty finish.  Earthiness and sweeter malts emerge from hiding as it warms and on the whole it becomes far more expressive with herbal, minty notes.  Thick, rich mouthfeel and medium-full body are very enjoyable.  Seems more like an oatmeal stout than a sweet stout to me.  Bottle.

Good brew.  Poured a nice dark  brown that reminded me of used motor oil, with a nice lasting tan head on top.  The aroma was dominated by a malty sweetness, some dark fruit notes, and last an aromatic hoppiness.  The flavor was at first very malty, with a nutty flavor that reminded me of coffee and chocolate, almost burnt tasting.  As the brew warmed, it took on an incredibly acidic bite that was like drinking cold espresso.  The mouth felt very creamy and finished with a dry tone.  Overall I enjoyed this brew, however, there are others of the same type that I would much rather drink.
Tap.  Deep black color.  Brown to tannish head is long lived.  Good lacing.  Full bodied.  Coffee and chocolate in flavor and aroma.  Very nice.
bottle from 23rd, midnight black colro beige head.nice chocolate aroma .really nice roasted malt,coffe flavor,almost burnt. slight hopness nice creamy ness to it godd one
Pours a black oily consistency, smally lightbrown head. Aroma of malty choclate. Flavor is roasted malty sweetness. Palate is oily and flavorful. Very little carbonation. Very tasty.

draft. Amazing color! Dark dark brown. dark brown head, laced very well. Very nice sweet chocolate malt taste. Extremely well hopped, the hopps were great. The sweetest stout I¬íve had. Very nice balance. I really enjoyed this beer.
Amber color.  Creamy, caramel head, mostly lasting. Brown-black hue. Heavey hoppy taste, heavy malty taste but balanced. Sweet, brown sugary initial flavor. Smooth palate.
Bottle. Very nice.  Lacy dan head.  Balanced.  Tones of coffee and chocolate strong hop and malt presence.  Pleasant bitter finish.

This has a nice roasty malt chocolate,  coffee aroma to it that works out well.  In the flavor department there is a nice roasty malt, chocolate, and and coffee taste with a nice little hint of hops as well.  Another solid beer from Rogue.

Pours dark and coffee-like. Has a nice brown head with good lacing. Aroma is chocolate, malt, and hops, with hints of coffee. The cascade hops shine through well on this beer. Flavor is nice and the mouthfeel is full. Tastes of choco-coffee and hops dominate, with some earthy undertones. Overall pretty good.
The folks over at rogue never seem to dissapoint...thanks for a nice hoppy stout....plus I bought it on Sale!!!!  I am not cheap, I am frugal!

22oz bomber. Pours out a opaque pitch black color with a towering dark brown rocky head. The head dwindles down a bit while you drink this but it never disappears. An excellent smattering of lacing is also left about the glass. The aroma filled my nose full of wonderful scents of dark chocolate and roasted coffee. A good smell but not overpowering with hints of citric hops added into the mix as well. Dark chocolate and coffee flavors dominate most of the taste here. Mingling about is also citric hops, roasted malt flavors and a slight smokiness. Very tasty beer indeed with a lot going on in it. The wonderful taste is enhanced by the rich and creamy mouthfeel and the full body of this beauty. Excellent drinkability here with not much slowing you down from putting a few of these away. One of my favorite stouts for sure, give it a try if you haven¬ít already.
Dense cocoa pebbles in milk color head.  Strong chocolate nose.  Roasted malt and bitterness initially with a somewhat weak finish.

June, 2003: Bottle. Citrus, sherbet lemon qualities in the aroma are interesting for a stout. Wine notes up front, fairly juicy, almost like a porter. Dryness takes over and batters the mouth into submission. Little in the way of sweetness. Foreign stout in style, in the Guinness tradition. OK.

Pours BLACK with a large chocolate brown head. Aroma was nice, roasted coffee and citrusy hops. Flavor is sweet and roasted chocolate malt with a large hop kick in the middle. Dry aftertaste. Medium carbonation with good mouthfeel. Very nice beer.

UPDATED: JAN 14, 2005 Best stout I¬íve EVER HAD!!! Pours black and smooth. You can drink it warm or cold and it¬ís still good. Perfectly balanced and a nice nutty chocolate taste. The perfect stout. Your life will not be complete without this ale. John Maier exceeded the standards.

UPDATED: DEC 1, 2004 22 oz bottle.  Black pour and a nice brown head.  Aroma of malt and chocolate.  Full of flavor with malt, chocolate, and coffee.  A little hoppy and a touch of bitterness which does not distract but adds to the complexity. Creamy, smooth, and tasty!  An excellent stout.  Very easy to drink and yet so flavorful. I enjoyed this. ......
" I thank God I am as honest as any man living that is an old man and no honester than I. "......
          Wm Shakespeare,  Much Ado about Nothing.
Black with a big thick head. Tastes hoppy; like stout meets IPA. Not bad for a stout, considering I¬ím not a big fan of the style.

UPDATED: SEP 2, 2005 This poured black with a thin brown head.  Roasted malt aroma with chocolate and a bit of smoke.  Very creamy in the mouth.  Tastes like roasted malt, burnt chocolate, and a hint of coffee.  A touch of chocolate and bitterness in the finish.  A tasty brew indeed.<font size=-4><a href=http://www.ratebeer.com/Places/ShowPlace.asp? Armanetti, Willowbrook, IL<font size=-1>

22oz bottle:
Pours black with a tan thick tan head. Smells kinda malty. Tastes of chocolate and  roasted with a touch of  coffee flavor. Very thick and creamy palate. Highly Recommended

Whosoever shall drinketh this potion shall be satisfied through and through, much as the grass is content after the clouds do bring sweet nectar of life.  Yey, though for the few who riseth a bit after the sun smiles in the east and start after the cocking of the rooster, ye should avoid this much like the fox avoideth the hunter.  Oh but for those who doth smile fondly on concoctions with the strength of many oxen, prithee get ye to a purveyor of all things malt and barley on the now.
user_location: Ugly, Hot, and Humid Spring, Texas, USA

text: Hasten thee not to finish ye bottle of Sheak speare¬ís owne Stoute.  Nay, savor ye flavour and raise yon flagon  and may the spirits preserve thee

Black and brown with a thick bubbly khaki head.  A little lacing does occur.  Has a butter like smell with chocolate.  Fine smoked flavor of roasted malt and minimum amount of chocolate presence.  Bitter while still having a coffe like richness to it.  A mighty fine stout!!!

On tap. Very nice lightly tan head. Very dark, nice coloring. Sweet aromas. Slight hoppiness in the flavor as well as other flavors. Will have to have again and note the particulars. Definately one to try.

Bottled: Is pitch black with a chocolate brown huge dense head. Really got the looks. Aroma is the wellknown chocolate, molasses, malt, some light roastyness. Flavour as well is roasted, chocolatish and has a nice hoppy touch. Sweet and light bitter in the end. Nice one. Easy drinkable, but still full of character. Thanks B√ºck Dich.

UPDATED: APR 23, 2006 RE-RATE:nice black body with a light brown head.as the head sat some webbing did appear.aroma was a mix of roasted malts,milk,chocolate,and coffee.flavor was roasted malts,milk,malt-o-meal,coffee,and chocolate.mouthfeel was nice and full and the palate lingered on.
UPDATED: OCT 18, 2004 Absolutely delicious.  Pours dark dark dark brown/black.  Good flavor of sweet chocolate.  hoppy finish.  Great aroma of chocolate and hops.  Great beer.
Extremely dark, opaque in a mug with a brown head and hoppy roasted aroma.  Nice dark roasted flavours with some hops backing things up and decent bitterness at the end.
Black. A nice well-balanced stout. Quite bitter finish. Great mouthfeeling and great flavour. A nice "everyday" stout, when you exceptionally need a mild stout.
Pretty good sweet stout, wasn¬ít as sweet as an oatmeal... but it was pretty decent.  Very strong espresso, with notes of butterscotch, toffee, hops.  Nice thick body, and filling.

UPDATED: MAR 11, 2014 This was the first craft beer I ever tried  - years before I started to get into beer. In honesty I ordered it at random only because I liked the name. I barely remember the taste from back then but something stuck. I still have a nostalgic feel to this beer.  +++Sampled form a  22 oz bottle this beer poured thick, black and oily with a huge soapy brown head that lingered and left good lacing. . One is immediately hit with a strong floral hop aroma with a bitter, dry roasty presence and moderate black coffee and cocoa.  The flavor is rich with bakers chocolate, black coffee and floral hops. Long bitter, dry and roasty finish with lingering floral hops and coffee. Moderately full bodied. Very solid.

So it¬ís always odd to find a beer that you¬íre supposed to love, it¬ís a style you love, it¬ís rated highly from a respected brewery, but then, it just doesn¬ít hit you right. Expectations too high? I don¬ít know but I found this unbalanced, too bitter, too dry, too thin for a stout.

Poured onyx black with no traces of red (the darkest beer I¬íve poured thus far) with a dark brown head that dissipated to nothing, leaving no lacing.  Aroma is strong and hoppy... I smelled it immediately upon opening the bottle, and I was a good foot and a half away from it.  There is also some roasted character in the aroma as well.  There is a strong flavor of coffee upon the first taste, which soon dissolves into dark chocolate (the chocolate becomes more pronounced as the beer warms).  The finish is very bitter, which did not surprise me when I found out that it shares the same IBU¬ís as Stone IPA.  The body is thinner than I expected from the beer, which is its weakest link.  Overall very flavorful and complex, but a little too far on the bitter side for my taste.  Didn¬ít quite beat out my soft spot for Samuel Smith¬ís Oatmeal Stout.

Pours with a thick creamy, light chocolate brown head that sits atop an opaque deep brown to black beer.  The aroma is slightly acidic in its roastiness, and it has notes of chocolate, espresso, and alcohol.  It has a creamy mouthfeel up front, and a sharp acidic roast malt bite in the finish.  Espresso dominates over the chocolate, which is the opposite sense I got in the aroma.  The dark malt notes of roasted barley, and burnt malt dominates this beer.  Not much in the way of hops is noticeable above all of the roast character, but there is a nice hop bite in the finish that is a bit bracing and let you know that this beer is in fact 69 IBUs.  A very nice stout that I have always had a soft spot for.

NOW this is a stout. Its at think as chunky soup and blacker than a moonless midnight sky. Its taste provided the inspiration for such literary classics as Romeo and Juiliet, A MIdsummer Nights DReam, and Coriolanus. 
IF this Stout can Light Shakespeare¬ís fire, it can surely light this cowboy¬ís Blaze

Poured damn near black with a thick light tan head. The head was dense and creamy but died to a thin layer and then to nothing. Very little lace left on the glass and a large amount of sediment on the bottom of the glass. 

Not a lot to the aroma. Perhaps my nostils were fried after inhaling the fine aroma of the Gulden Draak. It sorta smelled like flowers with some light oat notes, subtle toffee and loads of chocolate. 

Smooth and silky! Which is something I definately did like. Some maple notes, bitter chocolate, then coffee then spins and goes straight into hop bitterness. Heavy in the mouth but left a lingering after taste like I just took a huge bong hit. Odd.
Hmm, interesting stout.  Pours dark black with a thin brown head.  Aroma is coffee and hops, flavor is much the same.  Tasty if a bit one dimensional.  Quality, as far as light stouts go!

UPDATED: OCT 24, 2004 (Draft) This is one of the best regullar stouts out there. Beautifull dark color nice head (nitro) Deep rich flavor hits of chocolate with some nice roasty flavors rounded out with a tang of hops at the end. a slight bit sweet but Highly drinkable

UPDATED: MAY 21, 2005 The frothy head, like pearly foam upon a nighttime-blackened sea, deceives the mind. As light as frost, unfrozen and undone, the bubbles speak no truth of what¬ís behind. It¬ís only when the foam is on the lips the mask is lost; the beer is thick as blood is red, the bubbles are but roving ships¬óand strongest seas can burst the choicest wood. The coffee flavor sinks in first, and then one tastes the mocha, rich and sweet as gold. And, next: molasses, raisins, then the end, a woe so ill its gloom cannot be told. But wait! and fret you not, my thirsty brother! From whence this came, there comes another!

Bottle:  Pours to a dark black color with a tan head.  Chocolate, roasted malt, and some hops in the aroma.  Tastes creamy, smooth, with hints of chocolate, citrus, nutty, barley, earthy.  Not bad, but just not great either.
Dark bottle. Pours nice and has a darkish brown tint. Taste is a mixture of choclate and roasted peanuts. Very nice combonation. Bittery taste as well.

Bottle. Blackish with just a very little hint of ruby and a brownish head. Chocolate/raosty aroma. Creamy, roasted, chocolate flavor. At least it doesn¬ít have an overpowering oat flavor. Well balanced and an easy to drink stout. Nice earthy hops and a bit of a fruitiness - cascade hops, but it¬ís not just citrus - there¬ís a bit of summer fruit as well.

Bottle - Pours a dark brown/black with a quite dark tan head that hangs on for a while and provides decent lacing.  A fruity, hoppy, raosted malt aroma.  Flavor is stongly of roasted and dark malt with a dry hop bitterness.  Finish is fairly long, bitter and dry.  No hop or bitter bite ... very smooth.  Excellent!

Smells hoppy with hints of chocolate and grass.  Pours black with nice long lasting dark to chocolate brown head.  Tastes nutty, earthy, and is more bitter than I would have thought for a stout.  Long hoppy finish with bitter aftertaste.  Is nice and smooth though, but the bitterness through me off, I almost thought I was drinking a pale ale.
Dry malty flavor, bitter finish.  Great aroma, and was relatively smooth.  Fantastic beer.

After having had the Chocolate Stout, I thought I was fully prepared for the Shakespeare.  Wrong!  Just as black but drier, less carbonated mouthfeel, BITTER and more mocha on the chocolate.  Delicious!

Dark black body, with some ruby tints. A big thick dark tan head, just beautiful! Sweet dark fruits and roasted malts dominates the aroma, has some winey undertones. Roasty flavor, with some nuttyness and chocolate. Nice bitter ending. Very smooth stout and very drinkable. And probably one of the most beutiful beers ive ever seen.

At first, I thought this smelled nicely of wine, so I was expecting it to taste slightly wine-ish, too. But alas, although some red seedless grapes helped me swallow this horrendous excuse for a stout (and goddamned offense to Shakespeare¬ís good name), it tasted absolutely horrible. However, for those who are fans of the belching, this came up surprisingly mild and inoffensive. Sad to say, the only non-disgusting thing about this beer was what I burped back up.

Well everyone had ranted and raved and I felt disappointed. They must have used Merchant of Venice as their inspiration because this not on par with Othello or Hamlet. It looks great, it¬ís interesting on the palate, but it smells prunish... maybe it just wasn¬ít what I was expecting.

Had this on tap at ¬íBlack Bear¬í in Morgantown, WV while on a little vacation with the best quesedilla I¬íve ever eaten. Sat down at the bar and ponied up $3.50 for a pint (eeek) while watching the Olympic gymnastics. Those Romanians are HOT! Anyway, poured with a super-this tan head and smelled of roasted smores, malt and caramel. Smells delicious and it is a remarkably smooth stout with a tiny bitter after-taste. Mostly chocolatly, with roasted nuts, vanilla and a musky feel coming into the picture. I had two pints and it was well worth it!

Bottle. Deep brown with a tan head. Chocolate malty aroma, very pleasant. Flavors include oats, caramel, and chocolate malt, all blended together well. The other flavors fade away leaving a gentle smoky chocolate malt aftertaste. Rogue hit the nail right on the head with the term "earthy" printed on the bottle. One of the most mellow, well blended stouts I¬íve tried, none of the flavors are dominant yet they meld together very well.

UPDATED: DEC 7, 2008 [22 oz. bomber] Dark black color with some red highlights and a thick tan head. Rich and roasty chocolate, malt and coffee aroma with a hint of hops. Very roasty and toasty burnt malt and chocolate aroma with a mild smoky finish and a bitter hop aftertaste. Very nice. Great flavor.
UPDATED: APR 1, 2008 On tap.  Creamy head tops this beautiful black body.  Classic roasted coffee flavor that doesn¬ít overpower.  A great stout for sure.

UPDATED: AUG 26, 2006 bottle 22 oz. Dark brn/blk w slight ruby tint, no light through. Very large tan/brn head that held up fairly well, moderate lace. Lots of carbonation. Aroma is dark roasted malt & bitter chocolate w some floral hops. Flavor is rather dry & bitter dark roasted malt w a slightly burnt characteristic. A bit sharp & short on smoothness & richness. Lacking real depth & complexity. Large slug of sediment that came out in chunks ( a sign of "too old" for me). Bet it would be significantly better fresher or from a keg. Will have to try again and hopefully get a fresher bottle. 10/23/05: I¬ím raising this up .4 but want to leave the original rate. Bottle 22 oz. Ultra drk brn w huge lt brn head that held up well, lace forms in blobs like continents on the globe. Aroma is rich, creamy, drk roast malt & grain w bittersweet chocolate & a moderate floral hoppiness. Flavor is rather dry w dark rst malt & grain, bittersweet chocolate & balanced very well with the hops. A significant bitterness hits early on and carries well into the finish. Pushing the border of full bodied. No alcohol taste detected. There is a noticable trace of spiciness and complexity. This stout falls into the lower end of the sweetness scale which is just right for me. Looking foreward to enjoying this again. I¬íll bet its even smoother & yummier on tap & could well hit a 4. Had it on tap. Bumping it up to 3.9
On draft at the Flying Saucer in Memphis.  Surprisingly good.  Rich brew, not too roasted, a well rounded beer.
Poured one of the darkest heads around, on top of a midnight body.  Big and roasty, it has a well balanced bitter/malty flavor.  Very nice.
Pours an oily black with a dark brown head.  Aroma of coffee, chocolate.  Flavor is of a bitter chocolate maltiness with notes of roasted oats and more bitterness from hops.  Finishes dry and sweet.

Beautiful stout with a pitch black body under a creamy brown head! Roasted malt and plenty of coffeee in the aroma. Sweet milk chocolate also. Flavor is dominated by coffee with bitter hops and citrus. Dry finish. A delicious stout!

A damn black and hearty beer. Pours a pretty tan/brown head and has a slight smokey aroma to compliment the strong coffee and bittersweet taste. I can taste a hint of alcohol warmth. Earthy, the way a stout should be. Cheers to Rouge.
Poured a dark black with a huge (4 finger) brown head. Chocolate and coffee aroma and tastes and a little smokey with roasted malts. Light bitter finish. Tasty

Typical black colour and off-white head. Roasted malt and hoppy aromas are present, perhaps with a bit of soya-sauce in the mix as well. The flavor is much more "roasted" than I was expecting, but there¬ís chocolate there too along with a combination of earthy hops and faint citrus finish. The flavor profile seems more "imperial" than "sweet", but either way it¬ís all good.

660mL bottle. amazing aroma! roasted malt is quite evident as well as a good amount of hops. deep dark black colour with a brown chocolatey head. Lots of dark/bitter chocolate flavour, finishes with a nice bitterness. complex and flavourful. 

I wish I bought some more of this when it was available at the LCBO.

Great sweet stout. I¬íve been waiting to try this for a while and I wasn¬ít dissapointed. Pitch black dark appearance with a medium dark head. Good roasted coffee aroma. Flavor was a perfect blend of chocolate and light coffee. Some floral finish. Another great Rogue.

Hey NICE!!!! i¬ím the 500th rater of Shakespeare Stout. This stuff pour BLACK with a small tan head. Taste is coffee with a hint of chocolate. Good bitterness. I don¬ít know if I¬íve had a stout so bitter. I like this stuff. Smooth.
As good of a sweet stout that I have had. Chocolate taste and roasted dry espresso made this a joy to drink from beginning to end. I love Rogue.
Perfect beer!  Dark, earthy stout with strong chocolate/coffee taste.  Heavy aroma.

UPDATED: DEC 20, 2005 A fizzy stout, poured a black color with a big fluffy tan head.  Macintosh apple, smoked ham, and powdered chocolate comprise the aroma.  Chocolate and subdued grilled grapefruit in the start of the flavor, has a dry, roasted-bitter finish.  A nice dry stout with fruity highlights.
Pours black with a thick head...smells of chocolate...tastes malty and chocolatey...quite bitter and not in the friendly way...finished dry...not too refreshing...
Drank it out of the bottle like a hobo so it was all about the taste, but I remembered to spill a few drops to see the color.  An excellent beer with a wonderful smooth start and finish.

Black color, medium creamy head. Roasted malts, chocolate and cocoa flavor. Mouthfeel is smooth. Somewhat bitter. Full flavor. Smooth taste. Slightly malty. Finish is clean and smooth. Aftertaste is bitter.  Definitely better than some of their other offerings (Yellow Snow and Dead Guy Ale come to mind).

Another great stout from Rogue.  Poured an excellent ebony, with a thin brown head and thick lacing.  Aroma was a smooth malty, fruity scent, accompanied by some aromatic hops.  The flavor was full and sweet up front, with strong notes of coffee and roasted malt, and it finished with a great bittering hoppiness.  Mouthfeel was thick and full, with an appropriate dryness.  An excellent all-around stout that will find a regular home in my fridge.

Pours a dark black with a thick brown head. Aromas of roasted malts, toffee, mocha, coffee and some dark ripe fruits. The flavour was quite hoppy as well as chocolaty, fruity and a big pleasant coffee profile, nice dry finish. A great stout.
Black with a tan head.  Hoppy aroma.  Flovor is chocolate and bitter with lots of hops.  Medium to dark palate.
tasty roasted, chocolate aroma w/hints of nuts.  very dark hue, w/small head, medium-full body.  love the bittersweet mouthfeel, also feels a bit oily...but thats ok...another great stout by rogue.
This was really good, very dark almost black with a small tan head, a chocolate aroma, and chocolate flavors, very good stout.
Pretty good. Less bitter than Guiness, and with more of a chocolate/coffee aftertaste. Definitely drinkable, but given a choice between Rogue and Guiness I¬íll always pick Guiness.

Black with a nice tan head. Has chocolate oat aroma. Tastes roasted with a grassier taste. Similar to the Boulevard Bully Porter. Has good malt, and you can taste the hops. Finishes with a bitter taste.

Dissipating brown head on this mocha-colored stout.  Aromas of chocolate and orange.  It¬ís pretty bright on the tongue, with a lengthy finish.  Flavors of milk chocolate and oats.  A good sweet stout.

Wonderful sweet stout.  In a bottle.  Wish it poured with a bit more of a long-lasting head, but the taste and aroma are unflappable, if only a bit thin, but perhaps I'm too used to the imperial varieties running around now.
Wow is all I can say.  What a well balanced stout.  Dark, just sweet enough with the roasted chocolate delights, and just enough hoppiness in the finish to make it just about perfect.
Dark Black Coloring.  Tan Head Eternal.  Ideal Standard for A Stout.  Malts, Chocolate.. Little Bit of Roasts.  Bitter at The End.  Very Drinkable!!

On tap at the portland tap house. Very well done stout, very balance, and very enjoyable. Pours black with a tan creamy head that leaves some thick lacing. Great coffee aroma, very rich and sweet. Taste starts semi-sweet with a good bitter balance toward the end. Slight coffee note in the beginning and the chocolate shines in the aftertaste. Very smooth and well balanced brew.

Pitch black with a gorgeous long lasting rocky dark brown head.  Nice chocolately aroma over a touch of coffee.   Some spicy hop aroma behind the chocolate malts.  Full-bodied mouthfeel.  Flavour is sweet and chocolately on the front followed by a fairly assertive hop bitterness.  Finish leaves a nice roasty flavour mingling with tingly bitterness.

I am not a fan of stouts. This stout gave me a boner. Smells of bourbon, vanilla and a deep roastiness from the center of middle earth. Much drier than it smells. Sweet, chocolatey, slightly caramely and finally awesome great stout man
G-rat
Nice smoot stout with different reflections of sweetness, hops and finishes with right amount of roastiness.

very thick dark tan head. Pitch black body didnt let any light through when held up to it. Nice stout aroma, a little bitter but very nice stout. Not so much on the sweet side pleasant taste. coffe aftertaste. Very nice going down.

Bottle 54F Pours darn near black with a modest foamy dark tan head which rather coarse bubbles left after a minute.  No real lacing.  Aroma is distrinctly chocolate and molassas.  Bittersweet chocolate is the main player in the flavor.  A little more bitter/hopps than other Sweet Stouts recently. The feel is heavy and thick like I think it should be, the finish lingers a bit bitter.  Mo\derate/low carbonation.  Quite good.

Sampled at Empire Brewfest.  Sweet chocolate roasty aroma.  Very sweet and chocolately.  Willy wonka style.  Very tempting aroma.  Opaque black with a tan head.  Head could stand to be a bit darker.  Smooth, sweet chocolate taste with some bitter roastiness.  Could use a bit more body.  Still a very very good beer.
Damn Rogue makes some great beers and this is no exception. Dark, roasty, with tons of fruit and hops on the nose. Don¬ít pass it up if you see this one on your favorite brew sellers shelf.

UPDATED: NOV 5, 2010 Pour is black and oily with a thin tan head.  At cooler temps there is hardly any aroma, but as it warms the scents of chocolate and burnt malty come through.  Flavor is bitter chocolate with smooth oily mouthfeel. Damn fine stuff.

Haven¬ít had this in a long time.  22oz bomber from the grocery store. Pour is oily brown-black with a very minimal head of tan-cream lace.  Aroma is roasty, creamy, and chocolaty, with a hint of vanilla.  Flavors are a little dulled by the cold temperature, but I¬íll let it warm up.  The finish is obviously roasty. As it warms, I can taste the chocolate notes. 

The biggest crimes against beers this good are their availability.  No one craves a beer that they can have any where and at a reasonable price.

06.29.04  Bomber.  Rich black with glowing ruby highlights, fine head.  Thick aromas of chocolate, roasted malt.  Potent stuff, mean, complicated, and bitter.  Reminds of very sharp chocolate, finishes with burnt coffee notes.  Typical Rogue effervescent but smooth texture.  So available and so good, it¬ís another one of those beers that makes you wonder why you don¬ít drink it more often.
Sweet chocolate nose. Taste is roasted coffee and chocolate with some hop bite. Very full flavored brew. Everything blends well.
Mocca and chocolate in the aroma. Dry coffee flavour and loads of mocca. Bitter and dry coffee palate. The finish is a nice, smooth and round chocolate experience.

UPDATED: MAR 21, 2005 Beautiful black color with a nice tan head. More bitter than most stouts. Thick,
creamy and nicely dry with flavors of
oats, earth and chocolate. Was sampled
on tap but just as good bottled. A very good stout.

Pours out dark almost black with a medium sized dark tan head. It has a chocolate/malty aroma with a faint note of hops. It is rather thick texture. The taste to me is not a lot like guiness, this is much more of a complex, friendly flavor with noticible chocolate, roasted malt flavor that finishes very smooth. Drink this over Guinness any day, by far much better.

UPDATED: AUG 27, 2005 great! great !great! black color with nice chocolate head, awesome aroma of roasted chocolate and smoke.
a real nice easy drinking beer. strong enough to make you say wow! but not even close to overpowering,,I love it!!

This beer is awesome.  It¬ís a really flavorful, roasty stout, but its so drinkable at the same time.  I could drink a lot of this beer and never get tired of the flavor.  It tastes a lot like Guiness to me.  An excellent choice.
A beautiful looking beer.  Tremendous light brown, creamy, head....awesome lacing.  Hint of initial sweetness.  Moderate bitter roasted coffee finish.  I think I smell soy sauce floating in there!
2004 NABA Festival: Dark chocolate brown pour. Thin tan head. Smell of chocolate and roast. Tastes great. Chocolate with slight bitter roast.

The beer pours an abundant brown frothy head. The aroma is not too aggresive but reveals a sweet/malty/sugary concoction on the horizon. Just like I thought. The Flavour is intitially watery but then some complexity is introduced to the palate.
