40 weight color. Muddy looking irredescent head subsides forming a slick on top. Rich chocolate malt, anise, burnt toast crumbs, and coffee aromas with wafts of berries. Semi-sweet chocolate start attemps to mask a mildly astringent sensation on the tongue. Medium palate funnels down to a some what watery bitter finish with baker¬ís chocolate lingering.
Subdued chocolate aroma.  No sweetness.  Bitter, even burnt flavor.  Nasty acidic notes.  Poor stout.
A nice, somewhat hoppy stout with mellow chocolate and coffee overtones.

porter and stout tasting ¬í02:  jet black with a noisy light brown head.  roasty, burnt, cascade hop aroma.  big coffee and bitter chocolate flavours.  subtly sweet.  lingering hoppy finish.  very nice.
Dark, dark color, brown head.   Nose and taste of roasty chocolate and coffee.   Does have a hop presence at 69 IBU.
Good Stout. Just a solid rendition. Nothing exceptional but then again no real flaws.
Really nice stout.  Lots of chocolate and coffee flavors and aromas.  Nice yet not overpowering.  I would definitely try it again.
very solid and full - deep black colour, and deep chocolate and mocha notes. Long, hoppy finish. Complex and delicious.

UPDATED: MAY 20, 2003 Opaque deep black.  Thick dark tan head that hangs around throughout the whole glass.  Coffee/mocha aroma, roasted grain, slight floral accents.  Oh so smooth....Quiet first, medium to full bodied, chocolate and roasted grain, and awesome hopped out bitter finish.  This is an excellent sweet stout, one of the best ive ever had. WooHoo!

Had on nitro from stout faucet. Thick brown head. Oh man this is good. Gets better as it warms. Big coffee/chocolate taste. Finish is bitter chocolate. A damn fine stout. Guinness step aside, there¬ís a bad boy in town....

Bottle.  Black, of course, with a small brown head.  Strong roasted coffee flavors fuels this beer.  The aroma is semi-sweet with caramel.  Hoppy and bitter.  Re-Rate mid-October 2002.  Tap at Rogue Pub.  Chocolate aroma.  Full body, rich and very creamy.
Wonderful roasted coffee with just a hint of chocolate.(ya!)  Head stayed with you until the end.  Great little bite at the finish!
One of the hoppiest stouts i have had in a while. a chocolate and coffee undertone really makes u anticipate the next sip. Great brew. Good job rogue.

This is a really great beer! Heavy on the roasted malts but well balanced with a little hops. This beer smells like it is cooking on my stove with notes of chocolate and coffee. The flavor is again a lot of smokey roasted malts balanced with a touch of sweetness at first then the bitterness of the hops kick in for the finish.
very, very black.  Black body and dark, dark head.  Very flavorful and coffee-like.

UPDATED: DEC 16, 2003 This is my favorite beer...period. This is about as close to a perfect stout I think you can find. Beautiful brown frothy head and an excellent bouquet. The label description advertises an ebony color, but I couldn't really place it being so friggin dark. I held a flashlight up to it and could see nothing on the other side, except for some grains visibly floating around the dark liquid. The chocolate malts are very noticeable, and a winderful coffee-like finish - that nests right on your palate. Appropriately bitter (69 IBU) it's in the upper range for a dry stout, but they can be as high as 75. An all around fantastic beer. I think any comparison to Guiness (as I've been seeing here) is a weak one, this stands alone in my opinion.

Deep dark stout with a dark tan head.  Chocolate aroma, roasted coffee flavor, with hefty, long lasting hops.  Great stout that complimented my tuna sandwich quite nicely.  And to those that would disrepute such a brew, I can say only this:  "Fie, fie upon thee, strumpet!"

Darkest brown/black that pours beautifully in the glass--frothy pock-marked mocha head with clingy patch lace...Aroma is both sweet and roasty, a little toffee-like presence in there as well--very pleasant...Flavors are a smooth blend of chocolate, slightly sweet and roasted malts, very nicely balanced...Inclusion of oats gives it a distinctive mouthfeel and slight earthiness---also well-judged hops and carbonation provide gentle counter-bite...This is an excellent all-around stout--a little something for everybody here...

This is the only beer that can follow a Brutal Bitter. In fact the two enhance each other. A clean near black color and creamy slightly off white head are what you are looking at. The taste is full, sweet and root-like with a balance of hops and malt like looking at that picture of the two faces and the space between them is a vase. You can¬ít hold both thoughts in your head at the same time.  So you flip continuously between the two, then order another.

Black color, medium creamy head. Roasted malts, chocolate and cocoa flavor. Mouthfeel is smooth. Somewhat bitter. Full flavor. Smooth taste. Slightly malty. Finish is clean and smooth. Aftertaste is bitter.

Tastes like a good home-brewed stout to me.  In fact I have a recipe that gives 22L of this/batch (it¬ís real close).  Big on chocolate and roasted malts, chewey mouth feel - silky.  Commercial breweries tend to "clean" their products more than this, and it¬ís why i liked this one so much.

I am a big fan of the stouts, but not so much THIS stout.  This is the second stout where the aftertaste ruined it for me.  Both instances, i tasted a fishy flavor in the aftertaste, NOT my cup of tea. BTW, the other is a Hammerhead Stout at a local brewpub.  The color of this Rogue is very dark, basically  black.  Initial flavor is nice, but not special.  As the beer warmed, the aftertaste poked it¬ís head out.  This really is n¬ít a ¬íbad¬í beer, it just isn¬ít anything gret IMHO.

UPDATED: JAN 1, 2005 Re-rated from an aged bottle (approx. 3 years old). Deep black body with a creamy brown head. Inviting aroma of bittersweet cocoa and roasted coffee. Full mouthfeel. Luscious flavour of sweet malts, chocolate and smoky licorice. The hops had mellowed a bit with age, but were still there in the finish. Either this beer improved with age, or my tastes have changed - either way, I¬ím rating it higher this time.

Original rating (9/25/2002): Near perfect appearance, and a great aroma. The chocolate and coffee notes are balanced well, but the hoppiness can be a bit off-putting if you¬íre not expecting it. Not the best stout around, but it¬ís pretty damn good. 8/5/7/4/16
The hops takes away from the chocolatey sweetness.  Leaves a bit of a burnt tastebud effect due to the  cascade hops and very dry roasted barley.  Drinkable, but nothing to get excited about.
Nice but a little too hoppy for a stout. One of few Rogues I like. Bottled as Brown Bear beer here in Japan from Ezo Beer.
Not as good as I expected.  This was black in color with a dark tan head.  Tasted burnt and hoppy.  I will have to try this again and rerate.

Incredible stout--lots of body and a great hop presence.  The chocolate malts come through strong and are very pleasant.  A little coffee too.  I would love to drink more of this great, thick and rich stout.
Strong on the hops for a Stout, flavours of chocolate , bitter, and coffee .Prefer the Sam Smith, but this is a good choice too.
I have always thought this beer to be overrated. It¬ís a decent stout with a great aroma, it¬ís just not that easy to drink. A tad to hoppy of a stout for my tastes.
Nothing special here.  Simple, bitter stout with an aroma and flavor dominated by roasted barley.  Not very complex, not very flavorful, and not very memorable.
I¬ím going off memory here.  Not one of my favorite stouts.  Bitter and not as sweet when compared to my favorite, Sam Smiths Imperial Stout.

This beer rocks.
The aroma is of toasted malt, dark chocolate, espresso and alcohol. It¬ís pitch black with a small, creamy, light brown head with excellent lacing. The flavor is moderately bitter (dark chocolate) and a touch sour. Not sweet at all. The mouthfeel is medium dry... as is the finish. Very fizzy. Interesting and delicious stout. I want another right now.

Black and thick.  Darkest head I think I¬íve ever seen.  Nice roasted malts.  Coffee, Chocolate, roasted cereals.  Nice hoppiness in the finish.  Bitter.  Very nice.  Something I could drink pretty often.

The great aroma and dark color of this beer made me very excited to take a sip, but when I did, I was not as impressed as I thought I would be.  It is a great stout, but it¬ís a little on the bitter side.  However, the pack I bought may have been old (it was on the beer distributors shelf collecting dust), so that may be a factor in this review.  Not nearly as good as Victory Storm King Imperial Stout, or Samuel Smith Oatmeal Stout, but still very good.  Better than guinness anyway.
wow.  I haven¬ít had anything this dark in awhile.  Wonderful stout.  Great balance between many ingredients my palate is too amature to pick out.
UPDATED: MAY 3, 2003 This is the most intense sweet stout I've ever tried. The color was somehow darker than black! Nice chewy stout with a heavy hops kick. WOW!

Excellent stout, very sweet malty aroma, brownish tan lacy head, lots of different & vast flavors, seemed like a lot of chocolate especially in the lingering aftertaste, very well balanced, great stout

Ok, before I start rating, I¬íd just like to point out something odd about this bottle of beer.  It says on the side (and I¬ím still not too old, my vision is pretty good) 158 degrees Plato!  158!  You¬íd need a jackhammer!  Anyway, back to your regularly scheduled rating.  Aroma is almost on the magnitude of a typical West Coast Imperial Stout.  Super roasty malt, cocoa, espresso, even that dark fruitiness and hop are there.  Mostly opaque very dark brown-black color, with a light tan, thick and billowy head.  Lacing is also impressive.  Flavor is very full, even for a typical stout, and has a nice balance from the fruity, bitter Cascades.  Big bittersweet chocolate.  Great mingling of flavors for the finish and aftertaste.  Very roasty and rich, just a little more gravity and this would be an Imperial.

Just beautiful, another winner from Rogue. Pours black with a brown head, and has quite a hoppy aroma for a stout, but that¬ís a Rogue trademark. Malty/chocolate sweetness, but hops evident too.  Lovely, complex, wonderful.  YOU NEED TO TRY THIS.

Pours up with a body so dark it seems black topped by a substantial dark brown head.  The aroma screams roasted malt goodness with notes of chocolate.  The flavor is everything the aroma promises and more, with its thick roasted, almost burnt, malt flavors and dark chocolate highlights (though not as many as the Chocolate Stout).  It has a creamy feel as you drink it.  This is one of the best stouts going this side of an imperial.
Almost the perfect beer.  As far as I recon things.  A sweet stout, but a fine fine all around beer.

¬ímellow¬í chocolate aftertaste?  No way!  Tons of chocolate at the finish, and that¬ís what makes it stand out for me.  Would be great for desert, but I can¬ít imagine drinking it with anything else.  I prefer the Mackeson Triple, which is similar, with less chocolate.

For a stout it has an oddly hoppy aroma.  Dark with chocolate head that quickly disappears.  A great array of flavors.  The various malts and hops creates a delightful blend.  It might look like a stout but tastes more like an IPA.  A complex and challenging beer.

this is one of my favorite stouts pours black with a tan head that disipates after a little. the initial taste is a little sweet and chocolaty and the after taste is bitter and coffe like. the cascade hop comes through keeping it in balance. a great stout for those who like stouts.

Had this at Ashley¬ís in Ann Arbor, Michigan - wonderful beer selection!  This stout has a remarkable color, deep and shiny dark with interesting highlights if you hold it up to the light.  Beautiful head, too.  The taste, though, is too sharp and dry for me - less creamy balance than I like in my stouts and a touch more coffee taste than is good for this coffe phobic woman.
Served cold, tastes better warm. Very full in flavor and dark in taste. This is an awesome stout! Worth every penny, every time.
UPDATED: JUN 25, 2004 A good stout.  Nice chocolate/coffee bitterness. Large dark brown lasting head with moderate lacing. One to try again.

Smell sense of the aroma actually turns to the taste sense without even taking the first sip.  You can taste the chocolate bitterness without letting it hit your taste buds. Somewhat smokey with a clear sense of cocoa or coffee in the closing.  Excellent creamy head and best served with a nicely seared lamb chop!
Dark,rich,sweet,roasty, with strong notes of cofee.

Kind of a disappointment, but I had very high expectations.  Head similar to that of a root beer float, dark and frothy.  Sweet roasted nose, slightly acidic taste.  As it warmed, it took on sort of a roasted pale ale taste...hops made a nice appearance in the end.  Simon (girlfriends dog) REALLY liked this beer.  He went apeshit when I took it from him.
A decent stout. It had a nice flavor but the finish was a lil too overbearing of coffee.

RE-RATE 7:29:02 Just doesn¬ít blow me away. Its pretty good but not quite the world beater I once thought it was. A beautiful looking beer. Dark as night with a big head. Great aroma. Nice coffee/chocolate flavors. A great stout.

Just a great stout. Great coffee, carmel aroma. Good color. Great first sip almost a hint of vanilla mixed in with the coffee and carmel. Finishes not quite as good as it starts, but finish still has enough bitterness to satisfy. I buy it often and recommend it to anyone who has not tried it.
UPDATED: AUG 4, 2005 Black foam.  Smooth and cream. If you could only get one beer. One of my all time beers.  blank like....

Simply excellent.  A nice black color with a dark tan head and a thin lace.  Thick roasty aroma with a very nicely balanced roasted barley flavor and a light chocolate finish.  one of the best stout¬ís I¬íve had yet.
Rogue is an excellent stout but I certainly wouldn¬ít call it a sweet stout.

UPDATED: FEB 26, 2003 Delicious on tap and delicious in the bottle.  Aroma is roasty with a little vanilla.  Opaque, rich, and flavorful.  Roasted barley shines in the flavor with hints of dark chocolate and bitterness.  Excellent!

Carmel, toffee, hoppyness in the nose. Smells fresh like from the local brewpub. Big, brown, thick head. Coffee-like in apperance. Coco bitterness, some carmel flavors with a slight burnt flavor in the end. More carbonated than most stouts. This is a truly beautiful beer.
Very nice stout. A little bit of an alcohol aftertaste. Rich flavor.

UPDATED: OCT 27, 2004 2002 bottle Great amount of hops and balanced just right with the coffee taste. One of the better stouts produced in America and definitely worth a try.  Complex and dry. Good barley taste, not too sweet for a sweet stout.

2004 bomber.  Wow. that was one of the first beers I rated and without going in to too much lame detail, I was just about spot on for the rating I would give it now.  Dry coffee flavored palate, a bit of chalky like texture.  Quite roasty and complex with plenty of malts.  The cascades are apparent but not overly so.  A very dry chocolatey finish.  Good stuff tending much on the dry side.
Chocolate, coffee, liquorice aroma. Black as coal, thick cappuccino head. Strong coffee and bitter chocolate flavour. Oily, in keeping with the flavours, bitter, with a rich texture. Terrific.
Dark, smooth pour with a nice dark tan head.  Aroma a tad weak, but present.  Flavor includes a nice smoky/chocolate taste with a touch of bitterness. Very nice stout that is worth trying again.

UPDATED: JUL 23, 2014 From the bottle:
Shall I compare thee to a lovely winter¬ís night?
You are much more warming and suave...
Shall I compare thee to a pint o¬íGuiness?
God, your sappy hops and molasse bitterness overwhelm her...
Shall I compare thee to a St-Ambroise Oatmeal Stout?
Hmmm¬ÖMaybe so!!¬Ö Just bring me one more bottle of each!
4.1/5.

On tap (nitroed) at Rogue Ales Public House in San Francisco:
This was a huge disappointment, considering the quality of the bottled version. The nitrogen just took so much space in the flavor profile, it was pathetic. The oatmeal pretty much disappeared and the only thing left was coffee, caramel and roasted bitterness. 3.4/5
One of the best stouts I¬íve had in America.

This has become my favorite stout and the most opaque I¬íve had.  This is a beautiful stout and should be handled as such.  The chocolate is a little more than mellow which compliments the doughy/oaty aroma. Recommeded to everyone.  (and it¬ís not overly hopped)
Right up there with St. Ambroise Oatmeal Stout.  Really dark in colour with a chocolate and coffee aroma to it.  Absolutly worth a try.
A typically bitter beer from the Rogue clan.  I thought the hops somewhat overpowered the malt in this brew.
Nice balance of smoothness and slight chocolate malt  aftertaste.   Dark color, nice head and decent aroma
Opaque black with a brownish foamy head. If you like ¬íin your face¬í dry stouts then this will become one of your favorites. From first sip to last the flavor hits you right between the eyes.

UPDATED: MAR 17, 2003 Rerate - 3/16/03 - Must have had a bad bottle the 1st time. Exellent in all aspects this time - nice, caramel colored thick head - heavy lacing.  Strong coffee aroma.  Coffee and chocolate undertones - no chalkiness this time. Just the right amount of smokiness.  Original rating - 3.2 - Bit of a smoky, almost chalky aftertaste - expected better from Rogue - but overall not bad for an American stout.

This stout truly takes on a new character at different temperatures...
the more it warmed the better it got.
if ya like stouts and a little hops this is a good try nice and flavorful a bit bitter yet smooth
I love the color of this beer. It has a nice head and enjoy the taste of it. A slight bitter tinge to it, but I feel that it adds to the overall flavor. Slightly creamy, without being to heavy.

Dark black rich and creamy. Rich chocalate flavor.Sweet with a hop bite. I love this killer stout.After drinking the another 22oz I had stashed in the fridge,I do believe this stout is the finest I have ever tasted. I have to give it a perfect rating.
Over-the-top head.  Rich, chocolatey/coffee taste.  Mouthfeel is on the thicker side.  Very bitter finish.  A bold, distinctive stout.  The best domestic stout I¬íve had.

This stuff has the biggest head I¬íve ever seen on anything. I poured a little of it into a 16 oz. glass (held tilted over to minimize the head), and the thick tan foam filled up the entire glass! That was sort of ridiculous. Once that settled down a bit, though, I was able to appreciate the impenetrable blackness of its appearance, the rich, chocolatey/coffee-like taste, and the warm, glowing finish. This is a first-rate stout, and one that I plan to drink again.
Among the rich, indulgent stouts, this is the richest, most indulgent.

Beautiful looking beer - dark as the night. Dark head, not creamy but carbonated. A fine brew with notes of burnt chocolate and pine - flavors are abundant, which I like. However, I would categorize this as a dry stout and not exaclty my cup of tea - since I like a bit more malt. A bit hoppy for my taste buds, the hops are really accentuated. I¬ím sure the hop-heads would rate it higher.

Oh man this looks and smells terrific.  Crackling head, typical stout darkness.  Subtly-blended dark malt, slightly smoky, and I smell a touch of cinnamon?  Distinctly coffee-like, without trying to be.  Lovely earthy hop bite, not bitter to my palate by any means.  Impeccably smooth, what more could one ask for?

UPDATED: OCT 10, 2014 re-rated 10/10/2014; original rating 2.6



Eeegsh.  I guess I don¬ít understand why so many beer lovers like so many kinds of stout.  (Don¬ít get me wrong; I think I really like the Imperials....)  Well, what to say about this one . . .  I couldn¬ít detect much of any aroma, and what I could detect was pretty stale in character.  Lovely color, as usual, for a stout, but just really damn hard to shovel into my gut.  Decent dark head, but just really heavy and dull in the taste; I¬ím not sure what I¬ím supposed to be picking up here.  Yeah, something chocolate-like in the finish, I guess.  Maybe I¬ím just not a stout guy.  Rogue does good brews, too, so I guess it¬ís me.
Perhaps I need to try this one again... it has been a few years and my tastes have changed.  It¬ís bitter with coffee flavoring.  Felt good in the mouth.
This was really amazing!  Beautiful color & wonderfully creamy.  Great flavor.

UPDATED: JAN 30, 2003 Rerate 1/30/03: Still a great Stout, but I have to adjust this one down a tad. Blame Bell's. 5/22/02 (4.5): What a great beer. It was more bitter than I expected, but after the initial surprise I just sat back and enjoyed it. Strong chocolate aroma. Almost black color with a thin but beautifully dark brown head. This is definitely on my 'buy again' list.
A very good stout, strong coffee flavor well complemented by chocolate, more bitter than I like my stouts, but still very good, nice and silky texture.
Outstanding beer.  Deep color with thick brown head.  Extremely rich coffee, chocholate and some almost wine flavors.
Wonderful beer.  Sweet coffee aroma, roasted malt flavor, with hint of chocolate and coffee.
Great chocolate/coffee flavor. Wonderful aroma. A really nice stout.

This brew pours a dark enough black that no light particle will ever pass through it.  The stiff and fully lasting rocky/creamy head is the color of a chocolate milkshake, and has decent lacing.  The bold nose is more hoppy than I am used to for a stout with pine,  resin, and some malty caramel dominating with hints of dark chocolate, coffee, flowers, dates, and brown sugar.  The flavor is rich, robust and balanced with fair complexity.  The ultra-long finish is bittersweet chocolate and espresso.  The chewy creamy body has lively carbonation and a chalky feel.  Rogue is on top of it¬ís game.
Delicious, creamy stout.  Glorious brown head, and what a delicious coffee/chocolate flavor.  One of my new faves!

Long, moderately bitter finish. Light malty aroma - roasted/burnt overtones, and mild coffee and smoke. Small, frothy light-brown head. Dark black beer. A nice stout (still like Samuel Smith Oatmeal better).

My friend brought this beer over and tols me I had to try it.  Now I know why I like this guy!  Has a nice coffee-esque smell.  Dark as night with a nice brown head.  Flavor has a bit of a smoked coffee taste.  A very nice beer - easily one of my top 10.

I believe that stout should be the starter beer that all beer-drinkers cut their teeth on.  It is gentle, not biting, mild, but it has all the flavors in beer somehow represented.  You have the sweetness of malt, the small bite of hops, the almost imperceptible tang of yeast.  This stout is no exception.  It is welcoming, easy, and flavorful.  It¬ís color is black, it¬ís aroma gentle, and its flavor well balanced without any surprises (beyond how good it tastes).  This is a wonderful stout, and one worth sharing with those who think they aren¬ít beer fans.  They¬íll change their minds after a few sips.

Very dark- almost black.  Poured into a glass, expecting a large head, but the head was actually small, but lasting.  Excellent aroma of chocolaty malt/sweet and roasted aromas with some hop presence.  Awesome taste- by far the best stout I have ever had.  Sweet maltiness on the toungue at first with a nice balnce of hops, when it gets to the back of the tongue.  Will definately have again and again.
Nice, thick, dark head. Vaguely sweet aroma. A nice roud taste, with just a hint of burnt flavoring to it. A pretty good brew.
This is a first rate stout.  I have never had a better stout.  So many interesting flavors going on it is indescribable.  The maltiness is perfect for my taste-buds.
Roasty with perfect bitterness. Extremely quaffable for a big stout.
Top notch beer.  Excellent, complex flavor incorporating hints of chocolate, coffee, and bitterness.

This is as high as I think I¬íve ever rated a beer.  Wonderful, outstanding, refreshing, flavorful....I could go on and on.  This pours to a beautiful dark color with amber hints in the lace and foam.   A wonderful mouthfeel is followed by a near-perfect taste all the way through.  There is something magical that happens to stouts when oats are added.  It becomes a food, an event, a happening and not just a drink.  Yum.

(Re-rate)Almost black with hints of ruby.Thin but persistent brown head and lace. Nose of roasted barley,coffee and a touch of chocolate. Tons of body. Awesome roasty and coffee flavor,moderately hopped and balanced by an oaty sweetness. Incredible balance but to me, missing a bright spot. It leaves me wanting something more. But top notch all the same.

chocolate coffee taste, mellows a bit as it warms. the thick bitterness stays, but some of the sweetness is lost.  a nice thick stout - just the way i like ¬íem.  The color is soo dark, you could hide behind it. One of the best stouts I¬íve had.

This is a perfectly balanced beer with many flavors that dance with each other all the way to the bottom of the glass.  This is a dark beer with a dark, frothy head.  It goes down smoothly with a strong roasty flavor complemented by a great hop bitterness.  This beer should be at the top of any list of stouts.

UPDATED: NOV 19, 2003 I haven't had a bad Rogue beer yet but this is the best so far. I've been thinking about it every day since last Tuesday when I first drank it. Perfectly black with a dark creamy head that looks a little like a chocolate milkshake. The taste and mouthfeel are equally excellent and are much like drinking an espresso flavored glass of thin chocolate milk minus the lactic and sucrose sweetness (although a small bit of that is present) Nice roasty and hoppy bitterness. Comes across a bit thinner than Guinness, but it's also not nitrous dispensed. Give this beer a nitrous dispenser and it will rule the world. Wonderful, Wonderful beer.
as good as a stout gets..perfectly opaque, excellent coffee flavors that linger on and on!

Color of black coffee, none of the reddish notes in many other dark beers. Minimal head dissipates quickly. Aroma has coffee-chocolate, but flavor loses the chocolate in favor of the coffee (not a plus for me). Although I like a healthy dose of bitterness, this comes close to overdoing it. Sweet stout? See Kinmount Willie or Samuel Smith Oatmeal Stout. An okay dry stout, though, along the lines of a *bottled* Guinness.

Drank this beer on St-Patrick¬ís day but that did¬ínt make it any better.Decent head but the mouthfeel is a bit liquid with notes of coffee and black chocolate.Overall,this is a version of the commercial Guinness with more malt but without the great foamy head.Not a very bad stout but not a great one either.Way behind McAuslan stout.
Rogue couldn¬ít make a lousy beer if it tried. One of my favorite breweries ever. I catch them every year at an event called...Sippin by the river in Phila. PA  Great beer fdrom Oregon.

It¬ís a slightly better than average stout, a bit dry, but too chocolate coffee-ish for me (I¬ím not a big coffee drinker, and I don¬ít like chocolate notes in my beer).  If you like chocolate and coffee notes in your stout, then this is a brew for you.
Holy shizzel. This is some great beer. Dark as night, chocolaty, smooth with a great finish. The dude with shades on the label made it that much cooler to drink.

A pretty good stout, not one of my faves but I¬íd drink it again.  Let¬ís see...brown head that seems thick at first but then disappears when you¬íre not looking.  Nice smell with perhaps a bit of caramel in the nose.  Roasted coffee, chocolate tones.  Well done bitterness, it¬ís just right.  Not sure what the alcohol content is, but if you eat an entire 22 oz bottle on an empty stomach, you¬íll have a good start to a fun night when you¬íre through.
No head on this brew, especially out of the bottle.  Has a bit of bite, but a actually a bit too much coffee flavor for me.

Thin head, coffee flavors, kind of weak boquet for a stout.  More of a bitter stout rather than cream.  Wonderfull opaque color, almost black. Looks like Sheaf¬ís Stout, tastes much better. Not my favorite stout, but a good brew on the whole. I¬íve always like my stouts a good deal lower than room temperature, so that may make my opnions a bit less relevant than most stout drinkers. All in all tho, great label design, a drinkable beer.  Hard to calsssify this one, not a ¬íbeginner¬ís stout¬í but I can¬ít see hardcore stout drinkers not looking for more either.

Overrated. I usually agree with the stout-guzzlers here, but Rogue combines a good stouty flavour with a cheap acrid bite that basically ruines it. Reminds me of a horrid Quebecois microbrew mixed with Guinny.
A Stout that is actually good in the bottle?!  Nice beer.
Very black. Small brown head. Chocolate/coffee aroma. Roasted flavor. Long bitter finish.
I haven¬ít been impressed with much from Rogue.
A little disappointing as far as stouts go.  I expected a much fuller flavor with a better ending.  Worth buying, though.  Good beer for the stout virgin.
Not a big stout fan, but I could handle this one.  Reasonable bitterness, full bodied, thick head.  Hooray, i finished it.

Damn this is sweet.  This is one of THE best stouts Brandon (me) has ever tried.  Nice level of bitterness and not overwhelmingly coffe like.  A supreme masterpiece that should be any stout lovers daily choice.

I would say that there is more than just a hint of chocolate and coffee. Good, not great! Aftertaste gets more powerful as the bottle goes south. Thats the only draw back to an otherwise excellent stout.
It killed me.

wonderful beer, beautiful brown head, on a dark dark beer.  I loved the flavor with chocolate, malty, and the right hops to give it a nice bitter touch.  I tasted the coffee in the finish which was very enjoyable.  Wonderful beer.

UPDATED: MAY 17, 2003 Head is initially average sized, frothy, brown, mostly diminishing. Body is opaque black, bottle conditioned. Aroma is moderately malty (chocolate, roasted grain), lightly hoppy (grapefruit). Flavor is moderately sweet, moderately acidic, lightly bitter. Finish is lightly sweet, moderately acidic, moderately bitter. Medium body, watery texture, lively carbonation, moderately astringent. If there's one thing I can't abide, it's a citric/sour stout. And this is one of them. The grapefruit in the otherwise simple aroma puts me off as well. Undrinkable to me, loved by many...hell if I know why. So be it with Old Rasputin, so be it with this one. Third review in two years, that's it for this one.
I think most of Rogue beers are over-rated. Shakespear stout is not only the best from Rogue, ranks high on my favorites.

Nice one. The first time I had it I wasn¬ít too impressed but I think something I ate eariler messed up my taste. Tried again, was very good. Stay away from anything with sugars for at least an hour when drinking dry stouts!
Dark black powerful stout. Dry, almost harsh, with big bitterness.
Good strong (coffee )roastiness and a healthy hop bitterness that doesnt annoy, but this is not the rich, complex brew I expected it to be.

Found this bottle in the bargin bin at a local store for only one english pound with a best before date of 01 07 2000, so didnt realy expect much. What a shock, poured it out and was bombarded by aromas of licorice, chocolate and coffee. The head quickly dissapeared, but the flavours in the beer soon made me forget that. Excellent mouthfeel and finish, altogether a very pleasant drink. Cannot understand why the store hadnt been able to shift the bottle for two years.
STOUT and gooooood.  I like this beer even though I do not like most of the Rogue beers.  Quality flavor and very rich indeed.  It is a good winter time beer to drink.

UPDATED: AUG 22, 2008 like any real he-guy burly macho hombre, i use the word ‚Äôbeautiful‚Äô somewhat sparingly, you know: grand canyon at dawn, meg ryan... that‚Äôs about all that comes to mind. but this stout makes me glassy-eyed as i breathe with tremulous passion: beauuuuuutiful!  and it‚Äôs not especially the color: sure, it‚Äôs so black it would suck the light out of any lesser solar system than our own. it looks like a solvent for weather-proofing phone poles. the head is respectfully bronzed but drippy, not like a grand irish stout on tap that you can sculpt into little animals on the bar top.  it‚Äôs the aroma and flavor which will write you poetry and make your palate soar like an eagle.  you‚Äôve read about the awards and the chocolate and coffee and perfect cascade hop balancing bitterness and blah blah, but if i were stranded on an island in the aleutians and could have just one thing, it would be a reservoir of shakespear.  besides meg, that is...
Solid stout, but the aftertaste is horrendous.
Great looking bottle. I enjoyed this beer a lot and would certainly buy this one again. I have had a few Rogue beers and enjoyed them all.
user_location: Port Jefferson Station, New York, USA

text: dark black with a rocky blond head.  once again lacking the soy flavor i love from oatmeals, but making up for it with a subtle oatmeal tast backed up by a stellar hints of roasted oats and spice.  awsome
A good stout. Coffee and burnt chocolate flavor are there in full force, as well as some fruity malt notes. Pretty complex and assertive, and hoppier than most stouts.
Had this from a tap.  Excellent brew.  Would drink this everyday if I could.  Great mouthfeel and aftertaste.  Created my love of stouts.

UPDATED: JAN 21, 2004 Bottled, 2001.  The mouthfeel on this one is the best thing it has going, very rich and thick; flavors are your usual suspects, chocolate and coffee.  Not nearly as sweet as English versions of the style, but though I like sweet stouts I found it well-balanced.  A little weak on the nose and head.  Good beer, but I'm starting to feel that the brewer is a might overrated.
2004  sweetness really only apparent at the front, very bitter (esp. for a "sweet" stout) finishing.  Nice body, but the hops are just too overwhelming here.
This roasty stout would be fit for the great bard.

Drank it.  Loved it.  Drank another.  Loved it again.  Found out it is actually a sweet stout, (with lactose), and was surprised and felt guilty.  Wonderful brew.  Not at all sweet as the genre indicates.  Soild, good thickness, nice robust flavor, slightly smokey, is there molasses in this? More crisp than most other stouts I¬íve tried (higher carbonation). Despite what the manufacturer states, this is truly an American style stout due to the high carbonation and bitterness.  Not too bitter though.
Fruity aroma.  Toasty coffee chocolate flavor.  Creamy body well balanced by a nice hop bitterness.    Delicious beer.
Decent stout.  Pitch black with tall cascading head.  Pretty complex flavor. Slight medicinal aftertaste and thinnish palate.

an absolute wonderful brew. has everything you dream of in a stout. wonderful nose pleasing aroma, visual dark and forboding. the flavor is perfect, just enough carbonation, with a perfect balance of sweet and hops
Extremely good bottled stout.  This beer has as dark a head as I¬íve seen.  Dense carbonation (small bubbles) maintain mouthfeel throughout the glass.  A real winner.
Quite flavorul, malty with bitter burnt coffee, bitter chocolate, bitter oatmeal, bitter aftertaste that lingers long after the rest of the flavor has died.
Creamy head.  Very heavy and dark beer.  Makes for a nice breakfast in the morning.  Coffee aftertaste.

Originally rated 4/1/01 at 3.0. I said then it was sweet. I rated it again on 7/22 giving it a 3.6 saying it was good, but watery and not full flavored but went down nicely. I¬ím not sure what I was drinking then as this is a very good beer. Rich, thick and flavorful. It¬ís got that ¬íRogue¬í bitterness. I actually had a couple sips of this on cask (first time I¬íd ever tried a cask cond beer) and didn¬ít like it as much as from the tap, but I¬íll try a few more cask conditioned beers so i have an idea what they are all about. Nice creamy light brown head.

An nice stout.  I¬ím not sure if this isa impeial stout or a cream stout.  lot of complex, interesting tastes on the palate.
An enjoyable and exceptional stout, especially when cask-conditioned.

UPDATED: NOV 16, 2003 Draft and bottle average score: Draft is much creamier and far less acidic, with beautiful buttery mocha flavors over a Cascade backdrop. Numerous fresh bottle samples have yielded nothing but overbearing Cascades and acidity. Get this from the tap if you can.
user_location: Blue Ridge Mountains, North Carolina, USA

text: UPDATED: JAN 13, 2003 Lots of smoke, bacon, softened very deep, dark malt roast with deep coffee tones and some yeast in the nose, the bitter dark hues tend to dominate the overall experience without offering much complexity therein.
Nice brown head. Aroma: flowers and pollen, impressive and refreshing. The taste is dynamic and tart. Long aftertaste.
Roasted coffee & chocolatey. Bitter but smooth.
malty with bit of chocolate.

A lose interpretation of a cream stout. A little too bitter for a cream stout for my taste. Is it over-roasting the malt, not using the right hops?  I don¬ít know.  The finish is bitter and stays with you. Maybe they¬íre trying re-define the style.
Blatantly Northwestern in its use of hops, it¬ís nice and roasty-bitter, but not the most representative of the stout genre. It tastes amazing when consumed in conjunction with a Pirouline.

the bitterness did me in. gulp.

i managed to choke down a couple, but maaaan. 

i was under the misimpression that this was supposed to be a sweet stout. it is NOT. it is dryer/more bitter than most, in fact.

i seemed to recall having the same reaction to rogue¬ís mocha porter (overly bitter)

i¬ím still looking forward to trying rogue¬ís hazelnut brown. i hope my expectations aren¬ít too high....
A good stout and drinkable enough to not make it hard to get through the 22ounces. The palate to me is the weakest part of the beer with not much mouth ¬ípresence¬í.

UPDATED: JUL 2, 2006 Variable experiences with this one, I think this will be my last re-rate.  Despite some experiences that were of a dry bitter beer with low malt profile, my early and most recent samplings were more consistent: full malt palate, with roast, chocolate and just a little coffee.  Nicely smooth.  Piney and citrusy hop aromatics and hoppy finish.  One of the hoppier, esp. in terms of finishing hops, of the stouts out there.  Overall quite enjoyable.

There seems to be a sharp division of opinion on this beer; I¬ím with the naysayers unless I find the draft version and it blows me away. Too thin, roasty, and bitter for me. And 22 ounces is an awfully big bottle for any beer that I don¬ít absolutely adore. Give me the Old Rasputin.
A very good stout, much better than their Imperial stout in my opinion.  Bitterness much less apparent and the creamy malty flavors came through better.
This is one of my all-time favorites.  It is so good and creamy.  I wish all beer was as good as this
Fantastic stout.

This,my friends,is the king of stouts. The creamiest and thickest head. Nice bitter flavor throughout. I¬íve only found this in a 22oz. bottle, but this is not a problem. Quite filling, so be ready. Everyone should try this fantastic brew.

This is a great stout, don¬ít get me wrong, but I¬ím not sure this deserves quite the reputation it now has.  Rich and thick, an oil-like pour with a wonderful, thick head.  Roasty, warming, but overly hoppy in my opinion.  Very good, surely to buy again, but when given the choice -- SSOatmeal Stout is better. Cheers!
user_location: Palm Beach Gardens, FL, Florida, USA

text: right there with Old Rasputin
Not as good as Kalamazoo¬ís Stout, less flavorful but not bad. I may have drank this too cold this is good stuff.

Solidly above average; deeply roasted, toasty and complex. Bitterness runs wild, but managed to settle and mellow as the bottle progressed. Definitely a beer for very specialized tastes. I liked this a lot, but does it really deserve its legendary reputation? Try it and see. Your call.

Maybe my judgment was clouded after just having Westvleteren 12, but I wasn¬ít too impressed with this. Its dark head died quick, and there was nary a coffee or chocolate flavor. It looked great and had a nice level of bitterness, but the strong cascade hop aftertaste is what ruined this for me. Despite the fact I¬íve mostly noted negative points, I did enjoy it, just not nearly as much as I had hoped.  The fact that it came in a 22 oz bottle didn¬ít help much either.  Given the task of finishing the bottle came to feel like a job...it was as if I was being punished and didn¬ít know why.

UPDATED: JAN 30, 2004 Mmmmm . . . what a stout.  Rich, creamy, lush, full--aren't enough words to describe the great texture.  Great roasted maltiness, with just a hint of coffee (I hate coffee, so just a hint is nice).

This is a well balanced beer with ample hoppiness and coffee and roasted malt characteristics.  The hop aroma overpowers the malt aroma, althjough both are detectable.  It is opaque, the color of coffee and has a very light head.  The mouthfeel on this beer is top notch.  You definitely know you¬íre not drinking an ordinary brew when it hits you¬íre tongue.
UPDATED: APR 24, 2004 An excellent beer.  I can't wait to try more Rogue's!  I finished it 5 minutes ago and can still taste it.
One of the most overrated beers I have come across in 10 years.
What a hearty brew! This is the stout to drink when you are in the mood for a real stout, not watered down draft cans.  Delicious and filling. Great with Italian food.
A brew worthy of drinking in large quantities.  I loved it!

UPDATED: DEC 27, 2003 Very dark and impressively foamy. Burnt coffee-like aroma, but especially PNW style hoppy at the same time. Hops dominate, almost in an IPA-ish kind of way at first, while the sweet roasted barley and chocolate follow in the second half. Aftertaste is dry and incredibly bitter for the style almost like a Sierra Pale ale. It mellows in the aftertaste which should be savored as the burnt mocha like notes come through. Further tatsing reveals nice creaminess. One of USA's best and most original beers.

UPDATED: MAY 20, 2003 Rerate 5/2003 -- Scored 4 bottles of this recently and enjoyed each more than the last.--  
Actually, the beer I had was in a bottle titled 'Wild Irish Rogue".  
A bit of research revealed that this is the Shakespeare Stout in a different bottle for St. Patricks Day.  Please alert me if I"m wrong.
Anyway, this is by far the ugliest beer I"ve ever seen.  It looks like it leached out of the ground at a toxic waste dump.
It"s also one of the strangest.  The flavor is overpowering, at first.  After the first few sips, I was contemplating alternate uses for this stuff, such as cleaning the car engine or maybe sealing the driveway.
But then the beer cast it"s spell on me and, to my disbelief, I happily drank the whole thing (I think the oatmeal did the trick). 
It"s not something I"d want to drink every day, but I enjoyed it.  I"ll have to try some of the other Rogue offerings.
user_location: York, SC via NJ, South Carolina, USA

text:
Black as black can be.  So malty with a
great long aftertaste.  Oaty and creamy.
It¬ís the kind of beer, after drinking which,
you feel as if you should brush your teeth,
but that¬ís a good thing.
I dont really like stouts, but this one has a lot of character.
Ive only had it once since i am not from the west coast, but it is one the best beers i have had in a while

Beautiful combination of huge chocolate/mocha/coffee flavors along with the signature hop explosion of all Rogue beers.  This beer is very fragile, though, since it is unfilter and unpasteurized- I¬íve had bottles that made me think this was one of the ten best beers on earth, and bottles which made me think a Rogue employee had relieved himself in the brewing tank.  If you live on the West Coast, there is no reason why this beer shouldn¬ít be in your fridge at all times.

Still my favorite Stout.  This is a beer that you have to try to believe.  The dark, roasted flavor is wonderful.  I detected a hint of chocolate bitterness after each sip, which is a one of a kind.  Truly a fantastic stout.

UPDATED: SEP 22, 2012 re-rated 9/2012; [email¬†protected]/* */ black beer under a long lasting dark beige foam; solid aroma of coffee, hints of nuts and licorice; medium to full-bodied; fairly bitter and quite dry; long and very roasted aftertaste of coffee, tar and chocolate with a respectable hop presence

1/2001 - dark colour, fine long lasting head; aroma: roasty, truffle, strong and fresh; strong coffee flavor and very deep bitter aftertaste. (5/9/8/4/17)
I know that I am in the minority, but I feel that this style should be on the sweet side.  The Shakespeare stout over emphasizes the hops.

One of the best stouts bar none in the world. As full-bodied, rich and flavorful as any beer of any style could be. A mouthful of deep roasted malt, chocolate and coffee with a smooth, creamy texture. Balances well with an appropriate hop bitterness in the finish which is very long. If you are a stout fan, you¬íve got to try this!

UPDATED: FEB 4, 2003 The beer pours that deep rich jet black color that so typifies the stout style, the head elephantine in size, the consistency frothy, the color a deep chocolate brown with the resultant lace a thick and glutinous sheet to smother the glass. The aromas of rich roasted malt, coffee, brown sugar sweet, also a light hop floral scent to seal off the nose. Start is bitter chocolate sweet, malt and the top thick and chewy, with a finish that is hop bitter and purposeful in its bite. The carbonation moderate and the aftertaste dry and long lasting. Quite a good stout in my books and one I enjoy often when a big beer is called for.

UPDATED: JAN 8, 2008 "Close to perfect, the only way it could be better is if it had tits on it."

That quote is from my original review from a few years back. Too funny.

After trying a few more beers I brought this rating down a few notches.
This is more bitter than I can deal with - then again so is Rogue¬ís Mocha Porter.  It¬ís a strong stout and it¬ís well made, just not my type of beer.  Pass the Guinness :)

This is my favorite stout, hands down.  With a a wonderfully rich and smooth body and definite chocolate undertones as well as aroma, this is a
stout lovers dream.  This is not a dry stout, but IMO blows any dry stout away... and I LOVE Guinness.  Try this
beer when it hasn¬ít travelled
too far and you should love it.  I just had one about an hour ago.  Yum.
Can Rogue do anything wrong?
This is one of the better brews from Rogue.  It has a guinness quality to it, but it doesn¬ít have that bitter bite that some people don¬ít care for (not me!).  Impressive head retention.

UPDATED: SEP 27, 2005 10w-30 opaqueness; frothy tan/brown head; thick, smooth, creamy and sexy texture. Sharply roasted and toasted, with a slight burntness. Big dark chocolate notes throughout. Stylistically, it may be a little overhopped, but I loved every bit of it ... loved the nips of grassy bitterness. Incredible stout ... definitely best fresh.
